Description: NATIVE BEES PERFORM ESSENTIAL SERVICES THAT NATIVE ECOSYSTEMS RELY UPON. DESPITE INCREASING EVIDENCE THAT WILD, NATIVE BEES ARE DECLINING GLOBALLY AT UNPRECEDENTED RATES, THE CONSERVATION STATUS OF THE VAST MAJORITY OF THE  3600 NATIVE BEES IN THE U.S. HAS NOT YET BEEN DETERMINED. THIS KNOWLEDGE GAP, ALONG WITH A LACK OF INFORMATION ABOUT INDIVIDUAL BEE LIFE HISTORIES AND HABITAT NEEDS, GREATLY HINDERS BEE CONSERVATION BY STATE WILDLIFE AGENCIES AND OTHERS. THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THESE NATIVE BEE KNOWLEDGE GAPS AND FACILITATE THE INCLUSION OF NATIVE BEES AS CONSERVATION PRIORITIES WITHIN STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLANS (SWAPS), PROVIDING STATES WITH THE INFORMATION NEEDED TO PROTECT POPULATIONS OF SGCN NATIVE BEES, AND BOTH MANAGE AND RESTORE HABITAT FOR THEIR BENEFIT.

THIS PROJECT WILL MAKE MUCH-NEEDED IMPROVEMENTS TO THE ACCESSIBILITY AND ADAPTABILITY OF THE HAWAIISTATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (HI SWAP). THE HI SWAP WAS LAST UPDATED IN 2015 AND PREPARED AS AN 893-PAGE PDF THAT INCLUDES 122 ACCOMPANYING FACT SHEETS FOR OVER 6,000 HAWAII SPECIES OF GREATESTCONSERVATION NEED (SGCN), HOSTED ONLINE AS AN INVENTORY OF DOWNLOADABLE SPECIES FACT SHEETS. USINGWEBSITE ANALYTICS, THE STATE OF HAWAII DIVISION OF FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE (DOFAW) EVALUATED HOW VISITORSINTERACT WITH THE SWAP AND FOUND THAT VISITS WERE OFTEN GENERATED THROUGH SEARCHES FOR INDIVIDUALSPECIES. THIS MEANT PAGE VISITORS WOULD FIND THE FACT SHEET OF INTEREST AND REACH A DIGITAL DEAD END,HAVING NEVER SEEN THE SWAP NOR LEARNED ABOUT THAT SPECIES THROUGH A HOLISTIC ECOSYSTEM-LEVEL LENS.THE FACT SHEETS WILL BE ADAPTED INTO WEBPAGES FEATURING IMAGES, VIDEO, AND AUDIO WHERE AVAILABLE. THEWEBSITE CURRENTLY HOSTING THESE SGCN SPECIES PROFILES (HTTPS:  DLNR.HAWAII.GOV WILDLIFE HSWAP FACTSHEETS )WILL BE ADAPTED TO A STORY MAP AND ESRI DASHBOARD INTERFACE THAT IS EASIER TO SEARCH ANDNAVIGATE, AND WILL PRESENT ECOSYSTEM-BASED INFORMATION THAT ENCOURAGES SITE VISITORS TO INTERACT WITHINFORMATION LIKE RANGES AND HABITATS, OTHER OVERLAPPING SGCN, THEIR THREATS, AND CONSERVATION ACTIONS.CRITICALLY, THE SWAP PLAN ENHANCEMENT WILL INCLUDE DEVELOPING AN UNDERLYING DATABASE FOR PERFORMANCEMETRICS OF THE SWAP OBJECTIVES, STRATEGIES, AND ACTIONS. THIS METHOD OF TRACKING PROGRESS AND EVALUATINGTHE SWAP IS ESSENTIAL TO ADAPTING RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PRIORITIES SHARED BY GOVERNMENT AGENCIES,PARTNERS, AND COMMUNITIES STATEWIDE, AND WILL PROVE AN INVALUABLE TOOL FOR THE UPCOMING 2025 SWAPUPDATE. ULTIMATELY, THE TRANSITION OF THE STATES DENSE SWAP INTO AN ONLINE FORMAT WILL NOT ONLY SERVICETHE PUBLIC, BUT ALSO AID THE STATES MANY PARTNERS IN ACHIEVING THE HI SWAPS CONSERVATION OBJECTIVES

SEVERAL OF KAUA I S FOREST BIRD SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED, INCLUDING THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED ENDEMICSPECIES  AKIKIKI AND  AKEKE E, ARE CURRENTLY EXPERIENCING SHARP POPULATION DECLINES. RECENT RESEARCH FINDINGSINDICATE THAT POPULATIONS OF  AKIKIKI AND  AKEKE E IN PARTICULAR ARE IN CRITICAL DECLINE, ESTIMATED TO BE EXTINCTIN THE WILD IN 2023 AND 2030, RESPECTIVELY. A MAJOR THREAT TO THESE BIRD POPULATIONS IS THE PROLIFERATION OFAVIAN MALARIA, AS CLIMATE CHANGE FACILITATES THE INCURSION OF SOUTHERN HOUSE MOSQUITO (THE VECTOR FOR AVIANMALARIA) INTO FOREST BIRD HABITAT AT HIGHER ELEVATIONS. CURRENTLY NO MOSQUITO-FREE HABITAT REMAINS ON KAUAI.CONTROL OF VECTOR MOSQUITO POPULATIONS IS A CORE STRATEGY FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF BOTH  AKIKIKI AND  AKEKE E, ANDAS SUCH IS A PRIORITY ACTION IN HAWAI I S STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN FOR BOTH SPECIES. TO ASSESS THE EFFICACY OFVECTOR CONTROL IN SUPPORTING THEIR POPULATION RECOVERY, IT IS NECESSARY TO BETTER CHARACTERIZE THE CURRENTDISTRIBUTION AND POPULATION SIZES OF  AKIKIKI AND  AKEKE E.THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO 1) CHARACTERIZE THE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF THE  AKIKIKI AND AKEKE E, 2) DEVELOP A LABOR-SAVING MONITORING TOOL THAT EXPANDS MONITORING CAPACITY, AND 3) CONDUCT OUTREACH TOTHE PUBLIC REGARDING THE AVIAN MALARIA THREAT AND VECTOR CONTROL STRATEGIES. TO ACCOMPLISH THE FIRST AND SECONDOBJECTIVES, WE WILL SURVEY THE ALAKA I PLEATEAU FOR  AKIKIKI AND  AKEKE E, USING INTENSIVE AREA SEARCHES,TERRITORY MAPPING, OCCUPANCY SURVEYS AND ACOUSTIC RECORDING UNITS, FOCUSING ON REGIONS WHERE THESE SPECIES AREPREDICTED TO OCCUR, BUT HAVE NOT PREVIOUSLY BEEN SURVEYED. WE WILL USE ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE TO DEVELOPALGORITHMS TO RAPIDLY SCREEN THE RECORDINGS FOR THE SPECIES OF INTEREST. TO ACCOMPLISH THE THIRD OBJECTIVE, WEWILL HOST PUBLIC EVENTS, AND PRODUCE TRADITIONAL AND SOCIAL MEDIA PIECES TO ENGAGE DIVERSE AUDIENCES. THISPROJECT WILL RESULT IN A CLEARER PICTURE OF THE POPULATION DISTRIBUTION OF THE  AKIKIKI AND  AKEKE E, A HIGHERTHROUGHPUTTOOL FOR BIRD MONITORING TO SUPPORT CONSERVATION EFFORTS OF ALL MANAGED SPECIES, AND GREATER PUBLICUNDERSTANDING OF THREATS TO ENDEMIC BIRDS AND TOOLS FOR ADDRESSING THEM. COMBINED, THESE OBJECTIVES ENABLEMOSQUITO CONTROL REGIMES TO BE MONITORED FOR THEIR EFFICACY AND REACH THEIR MAXIMUM POTENTIAL FOR SUPPORTING THEPOPULATION RECOVERY OF THE  AKIKIKI AND  AKEKE E.

IMMORTALIZED BY LEGEND  YET PUSHED TO THE PRECIPICE BY THE RELENTLESSDEMANDS OF A PROGRESSING SOCIETY  ADULT BUMPHEAD PARROTFISH, OR ATUHUNG IN CHAMORU, AREHIGHLY GREGARIOUS CREATURES WHICH SPEND MUCH OF THE DAY ROAMING ABOUT IN SEARCH OF FOOD,DEVOURING CORALS AND MACROALGAE AS IF A HERD OF BISON HAD JUST DESCENDED UPON A CORAL REEF  ANDYET, LIKE CLOCKWORK, BUMPHEADS HABITUALLY RETURN TO SPECIFIC AREAS TO SLEEP AT NIGHT (ASWANI  HAMILTON, 2004). UNFORTUNATELY FOR THEM STUDIES REVEAL THAT FISH THAT BEHAVE SO PREDICTABLY, OFTENFALL VICTIM TO OVERFISHING, ESPECIALLY WHEN EXHIBITED BY ONE AS LARGE AND CONSPICUOUS ASBOLBOMETOPON MURICATUM, WHICH CONTINUES TO REST ATOP THE GUAM WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN LIST OFMARINE SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (C1  GDAWR 2019, P.180, AS PROVIDED INSUPPORTING DOCUMENTS). IN THIS PROPOSAL, THE GUAM DIVISION OF AQUATIC AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES(GDAWR) AND THE HAWAII INSTITUTE OF MARINE BIOLOGY (HIMB) SHARE AN EQUIVALENT DESIRE TOREVERSE THESE TRENDS BY DIRECTLY MANAGING THE RECOVERY OF GUAMS ATUHUNG POPULATION AND FURTHERPROTECTING THEM AS THEY SLEEP. YET WE CURRENTLY LACK A CLEAR UNDERSTANDING OF WHERE THEY GO WHENTHEY RETIRE FOR THE NIGHT, NOR DO WE POSSESS THE RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURE WITH WHICH TO UNCOVER THOSECLOSELY GUARDED SECRETS WITHOUT THE INDIGENOUS KNOWLEDGE OF ANGLERS WHO HAVE ALREADY GARNEREDTHAT KNOWLEDGE FROM OUR WATERS. THESE ARE THE REASONS THAT WE SHALL EMBARK UPON A FOUR-YEARJOURNEY FOCUSED UPON: I) BRINGING ATUHUNG TO GUAM AND II) USING CONTEMPORARY ACOUSTIC TELEMETRYTECHNOLOGY TO FILL DATA GAPS IDENTIFIED WITHIN OUR STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN AS CRITICAL FOR THEIMPLEMENTATION OF EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION STRATEGIES FOR THIS SPECIES. IRONICALLY, ALTHOUGH THISPOPULATION HAS HISTORICALLY BEEN IMPACTED BY GUAMS LOCAL FISHERIES, A GREAT DEAL OF THIS WORK ALSODEPENDS UPON THE EFFORTS AND INDIGENOUS KNOWLEDGE OF OUR LOCAL FISHERMEN, NOT ONLY TO DEPLOY THERECEIVER ARRAY, IMPLANT THE TRANSMITTER TAGS, AND RETRIEVE THE DATA, BUT ALSO TO DEVELOP SPATIALLYEXPLICIT MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES FOR MITIGATING FUTURE LOSSES ASSOCIATED WITH HABITAT DEGRADATIONAND CLIMATE VARIABILITY. FORTUNATELY, AFTER DECADES OF BEARING WITNESS TO A SCUBA-FISHING INDUSTRYTHAT MAY WELL HAVE DECIMATED OUR ATUHUNG POPULATION WHERE THEY SLEEP, GUAM HAS ENACTED ASCUBA-SPEAR BAN WHICH ATTESTS TO THEIR READINESS TO EXPLORE MORE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENTSTRATEGIES AND THUS, WE SHALL ALSO III) CREATE OPPORTUNITIES FOR GUAMS CITIZENRY TO BE TRAINED IN THERESEARCH TECHNIQUES TO ACHIEVE THESE LOFTY GOALS. TOGETHER, OUR NEWLY ESTABLISHED GUAMTELEMETRY NETWORK WILL CONDUCT THIS TWO-YEAR, ISLAND-WIDE STUDY OF THE MOVEMENTS OF ACOUSTICALLYTAGGEDAND SUBSEQUENTLY RELEASED FISH TO DETERMINE SPATIO-TEMPORAL MOVEMENT, IDENTIFY HOMERANGES, AND PATTERN THEIR USE OF HABITAT TO EVALUATE THE EFFICACY OF CURRENT POLICIES (E.G., SCUBAFISHINGBAN, MPAS) AND, AS SUGGESTED BY INFORMATION OBTAINED DURING THIS PROJECT, DEVELOPMEASURES SPATIALLY EXPLICIT TO THIS SGCN.

THE NORTHEAST ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (NEAFWA) STATES HAVE AN ENDURING, COLLABORATIVE CONSERVATION HISTORY AND,SINCE THEIR INCEPTION IN 2005, STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLANS (SWAPS) HAVE FURTHER ADVANCED REGIONAL LANDSCAPE CONSERVATION.IN SWAPS, THE CONGRESSIONALLY MANDATED REQUIRED ELEMENTS, PROVIDE A DATA FRAMEWORK TO SUPPORT MULTI-STATE PLANNING,RESEARCH, AND DECISION-MAKING. AFTER THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE 2005 SWAPS, REGIONAL COORDINATION MEETINGS REVEALED THAT THE FULL BENEFIT OF THE SWAPS COULD NOT BE REALIZED DUE TO LACK OF A COMPREHENSIVE REGIONAL DATA SOURCE AND ANALYTICALFUNCTIONALITY. THUS, THE NE STATES AS PART OF THE DEVELOPMENT PROCESS FOR THEIR 2015 COMPREHENSIVE REVIEW AND REVISION,COMPILED DATA INTO A MICROSOFT ACCESS DATABASE TO QUERY, SUMMARIZE, AND REPORT SWAP DATA. UNQUESTIONABLY, THIS SYSTEMWAS A HUGE ADVANCEMENT FROM COMPARING INDIVIDUAL STATE SWAP DATA PIECEMEAL, YET ACCESSIBILITY (I.E., REQUIRED DOWNLOADOF THE ENTIRE DATABASE AND SUBSCRIPTION TO MICROSOFT PRODUCTS) AND INABILITY TO INCLUDE REAL-TIME DATA UPDATES HAVECONSTRAINED USE AND FUNCTIONALITY OF THIS REGIONALLY IMPORTANT ANALYTICAL TOOL.ENVIRONMENTAL THREATS (E.G., CLIMATE CHANGE, LANDUSE CHANGES) AFFECTING NE REGIONAL SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATIONNEED (SGCN) AND THEIR HABITATS ARE EXPECTED TO INCREASE IN COMING YEARS. CONSEQUENTLY, THE NEED FOR CROSS-BOUNDARY,LANDSCAPE SCALE CONSERVATION TO ADDRESS RESOURCE NEEDS, AS WELL AS ROBUST ANALYTICAL TOOLS TO GUIDE CONSERVATION ACTIONS, IS EXPECTED TO GROW. BUILDING ON PRIOR ACHIEVEMENTS OF THE FIRST VERSION OF THE NORTHEAST SWAP DATABASE, THE NEAFWA STATES PROPOSE TO UPGRADE THIS IMPORTANT REGIONAL TOOL TO A WEB-BASED DATABASE TO INCREASE ACCESSIBILITY AND ANALYTICALFUNCTIONALITY TO PROACTIVELY ADDRESS GROWING RESOURCE CONCERNS AND FACILITATE LANDSCAPE SCALE CONSERVATION. WE PROPOSE TOBUILD THIS TOOL BY HIRING AN EXPERIENCED, HIGHLY QUALIFIED CONTRACTOR TO PERFORM THE DATABASE DEVELOPMENT, WITH COMPLETION BY JUNE 2026. THIS WORK WILL BE GUIDED BY A STEERING COMMITTEE COMPOSED OF STATE STAFF WHO WILL HELP ENSURE A FULLY FUNCTIONAL PRODUCT.

SALTMARSH SPARROWS NEST IN THE HIGHEST ELEVATION, LEAST FREQUENTLY FLOODED  HIGH MARSH  PORTIONOF TIDAL SALT MARSHES FROM MAINE TO VIRGINIA. THIS SPECIES HAS EXPERIENCED A DRAMATIC DECLINESINCE 1998 DUE TO LOW BREEDING PRODUCTIVITY THROUGHOUT ITS RANGE. RATES OF DECLINE VARYREGIONALLY, BUT AN AVERAGE ANNUAL POPULATION DECLINE RATE OF 9  (CORRELL ET AL. 2016) MEANS THATSALS MAY BECOME EXTINCT IN THE NEXT TWO DECADES. THE PRIMARY DRIVER OF THIS EXTINCTION RISK ISSEA LEVEL RISE. SALS NESTS ARE PARTICULARLY VULNERABLE TO LOSSES OF EGGS AND CHICKS FROM TIDALFLOODING. IN ADDITION, THE LOSS OF SALS BREEDING HABITAT IS INCREASING AS AREAS OF HIGH MARSH AREBEING REPLACED WITH LOW MARSH IN THE FACE OF RISING SEAS (GLICK ET AL., 2008  ZERVAS 2009). THEMID ATLANTIC REGION OF THE UNITED STATES EAST COAST IS EXPERIENCING SIGNIFICANTLY HIGHER RATES OFRELATIVE SEA LEVEL RISE THAN THE NORTHEAST AND SOUTHEAST REGIONS OF THE COUNTRY (BECKMAN ANDGARCIA 2019). SEA LEVELS IN VIRGINIA ARE CURRENTLY RISING AT AN ESTIMATED RATE OF ONE INCH EVERYFOUR YEARS AND THE SPEED IS EXACERBATED IN PART BY LAND SUBSIDENCE.THE GOAL OF THIS C SWG TIER 1 PROJECT IS TO DETERMINE THE BREEDING STATUS AND DISTRIBUTION OFSALTMARSH SPARROWS (AMMOSPIZA CAUDACUTA, SALS) IN VIRGINIA FOR THE PURPOSE OF DEVELOPINGAND EVALUATING STATE LEVEL MANAGEMENT ACTIONS FOR THIS TIER IIIA SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATIONNEED (SGCN) IN THE COMMONWEALTH. MOREOVER, THE SPECIES IS UNDER REVIEW FOR FEDERAL LISTING(CRITERION 2) AND SHOULD THE DECISION TO LIST MATERIALIZE, THE INFORMATION GAINED FROM THIS PROJECTWILL HELP INFORM THE DEVELOPMENT OF RECOVERY CRITERIA AND ACTIONS, ESPECIALLY FOR THESOUTHERNMOST EXTENT OF THE SPECIES  BREEDING RANGE.

THE STATES OF MINNESOTA, IOWA, MISSOURI, AND NEBRASKA ARE PARTNERING WITH THE XERCES SOCIETY FOR INVERTEBRATE CONSERVATION, IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY, THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA, AND TRAINED COMMUNITY SCIENTISTS TO DEVELOP THE FIRST MIDWEST BUMBLE BEE ATLAS TO TRACK AND CONSERVE BUMBLE BEE SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN).

THE SOUTHERN LINEAGE OF BOG TURTLES (GLYPTEMYS MUHLENBERGII) HAS SEEN PRECIPITOUS DECLINES OVER THE PAST SEVERAL DECADES. WHILE SUBJECT TO THE SAME DRIVERS OF DECLINE AS THE NORTHERN LINEAGE (MAINLY LOSS OF HABITAT AND POACHING), THE SOUTHERN LINEAGE WAS ONLY LISTED AS THREATENED DUE TO SIMILARITY OF APPEARANCE. HOWEVER, AT THE BEGINNING OF 2022, A NEW PETITION WAS FILED REQUESTING THE SOUTHERN LINEAGE BE LISTED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (C2). THE ORIGINAL LISTING WAS DUE TO A LACK OF STRONG DEMOGRAPHIC AND POPULATION INFORMATION ON SOUTHERN POPULATIONS. WITH OVER 2 DECADES OF FURTHER DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS, IT HAS BECOME CLEAR THAT, AT BEST, THE SOUTHERN POPULATION IS AS IMPERILED AS THE NORTHERN LINEAGE AND, AT WORST, IS IN A MORE PERILOUS STATE (PITTMAN ET AL. 2011  TUTTEROW ET AL. 2017  KNOERR 2018). THUS, THERE IS A CRITICAL NEED TO FILL DATA GAPS SURROUNDING THE SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION OF SOUTHERN LINEAGE OF BOG TURTLES, THEIR CURRENT AND POTENTIAL HABITAT, AND OVERALL HABITAT CONNECTIVITY THROUGHOUT THE SOUTHERN RANGE. IN FACT, ALL STATES WITHIN THE RANGE HAVE IDENTIFIED A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF MOUNTAIN BOG HABITAT OR BOG TURTLES AS A PRIORITY IN THEIR STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (NC SWAP, SECTION 4.31.6  P.315 317, HTTPS   WWW.NCWILDLIFE.ORG PORTALS 0 CONSERVING DOCUMENTS 2015WILDLIFEACTIONPLAN NC WAP 2015 ALL DOCUMENTS.PDF   VA SWAP, APPENDIX A  P.26 126, HTTP   BEWILDVIRGINIA.ORG WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN PDF 2015 VIRGINIA WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN.PDF) (C1). THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO FILL CRITICAL INFORMATION GAPS BY FOCUSING ON THE 3 R S (REDUNDANCY, RESILIENCY, AND REPRESENTATION) AND BEGIN ADDRESSING THE TWO MOST PRESSING THREATS FOR THE SOUTHERN LINEAGE (HABITAT LOSS AND ILLEGAL HARVEST). WE WILL ACHIEVE THIS BY CARRYING OUT A MULTI STATE AND MULTI PARTNER RESEARCH AND CONSERVATION PROGRAM THAT HAS 5 MAJOR COMPONENTS. THESE INCLUDE 1.) IMPROVING OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE CURRENT DISTRIBUTION OF THE SOUTHERN LINEAGE OF BOG TURTLES 2.) DETERMINE THE STATUS AND VIABILITY OF POPULATIONS WITHIN THE SOUTHERN LINEAGE OF BOG TURTLES 3.) A LARGE GENETIC STUDY TO IDENTIFY METAPOPULATIONS, MANAGEMENT UNITS, CORRIDORS, AND CURRENT POPULATION GENETIC PARAMETERS 4.) HABITAT MANAGEMENT AND NESTING HABITAT CREATION FOR A SUBSET OF POPULATIONS 5.) OUTREACH TO LANDOWNERS AND LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS.

THIS GRANT WILL ADVANCE THE CONSERVATION OF THE ROBUST REDHORSE THROUGH THREE MULTI-PART PROJECTS TO 1  IMPLEMENT A VARIETY OF STANDARDIZED SAMPLING TECHNIQUES TO AID IN DETERMINING THE STATUS OF EACH POPULATION  2  CONDUCT RESEARCH TO FILL LIFE HISTORY DATA GAPS  AND 3  CONTINUE TO SUPPORT MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION ACTIONS AS PRIORITIZED BY THE RRCC. THE GRANT ACTIVITIES WILL RESULT IN CONSERVATION ACTIONS THAT WILL DIRECTLY IMPACT THE PERSISTENCE OF ROBUST REDHORSE POPULATIONS AND CONTINUED COOPERATION OF STAKEHOLDERS ON A RANGE-WIDE SCALE. FOREMOST, THE RESULTING DATA ARE ESSENTIAL FOR DETERMINING IF LISTING IS WARRANTED UNDER THE ESA.

THIS GRANT WILL ADVANCE THE CONSERVATION OF THE ROBUST REDHORSE THROUGH THREE MULTI-PART PROJECTS TO 1  IMPLEMENT A VARIETY OF STANDARDIZED SAMPLING TECHNIQUES TO AID IN DETERMINING THE STATUS OF EACH POPULATION  2  CONDUCT RESEARCH TO FILL LIFE HISTORY DATA GAPS  AND 3  CONTINUE TO SUPPORT MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION ACTIONS AS PRIORITIZED BY THE RRCC. THE GRANT ACTIVITIES WILL RESULT IN CONSERVATION ACTIONS THAT WILL DIRECTLY IMPACT THE PERSISTENCE OF ROBUST REDHORSE POPULATIONS AND CONTINUED COOPERATION OF STAKEHOLDERS ON A RANGE-WIDE SCALE. FOREMOST, THE RESULTING DATA ARE ESSENTIAL FOR DETERMINING IF LISTING IS WARRANTED UNDER THE ESA.

DESPITE PROGRESS MADE BY THE ROBUST REDHORSE CONSERVATION COMMITTEE  RRCC  OVER THE LAST 20 YEARS, THE ROBUST REDHORSE REMAINS IMPERILED AND IN NEED OF ACTIVE MANAGEMENT. THIS PROPOSAL IS EXPECTED TO COMBINE DATA COLLECTED FROM STUDIES AND MONITORING TO BRIDGE DATA GAPS IN ROBUST REDHORSE POPULATION STATUSES AND LIFE HISTORY KNOWLEDGE ACROSS THREE STATES. CLOSING THESE GAPS WILL AID RESOURCE MANAGERS AND GUIDE CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES THROUGH ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT DURING CHANGING CLIMATIC CONDITIONS. ADDITIONALLY, FILLING THESE DATA GAPS WILL AID FWS DURING THE SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENT FOR THE UPCOMING LISTING DETERMINATION. SCDNR WILL ASSIST GADNR  LEAD AGENCY  IN ALL THREE OF THE GRANT PROJECTS. PROJECT 1 ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE CONDUCTING EDNA STUDIES FOR ROBUST REDHORSE IN MULTIPLE RIVER SYSTEMS, MONITORING OF THE SANTEE BASIN POPULATION THROUGH STANDARDIZED SAMPLING, AND PROVIDING GENETIC SUPPORT TO ALL GRANT PROJECT ACTIVITIES. PROJECT 2 ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE CREATION OF A LIFE HISTORY TABLE AND AN UPDATED AGE-LENGTH KEY FOR THE SANTEE BASIN POPULATION OF ROBUST REDHORSE TO PROVIDE CRITICAL DATA GAPS FOR THE SPECIES. PROJECT 3 ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE INVOLVEMENT IN ALL ASPECTS OF PRODUCTION OF ROBUST REDHORSE FOR STOCKING AND MONITORING ACTIVITIES IN THE PEE DEE RIVER AS WELL AS ANNUAL ENGAGEMENT IN THE ROBUST REDHORSE CONSERVATION COMMITTEE MEETINGS AND ACTIVITIES.
MN - MIDWEST BUMBLE BEE ATLAS  ENGAGING COMMUNITY SCIENTISTS TO CONSERVE SGCN BUMBLE BEES IN MINNESOTA, IOWA, MISSOURI, AND NEBRASKA  MN U-34-R-1

HUMAN PRESCRIPTION PHARMACEUTICALS WERE RECENTLY DETECTED BY THE PI AND CO-PI IN A POST-MORTEM COMMON BOTTLENOSE DOLPHIN(TURSIOPS TRUNCATUS) THAT DIED IN BAFFIN BAY, TEXAS. PHARMACEUTICALS IN COASTAL MARINE ENVIRONMENTS POSE THREATS TO HUMAN HEALTHTHROUGH CONSUMPTION OF EXPOSED SEAFOOD THAT SUBSEQUENTLY SUPPRESS ANTIBIOTIC RESISTANCE AND IMMUNE RESPONSE. PHARMACEUTICALEXPOSURE THREATENS THE RESILIENCY OF MARINE LIFE, PARTICULARLY IN ECOSYSTEMS ALREADY SUBJECTED TO EXTENSIVE OTHER STRESSORS AS OCCURSIN THE TEXAS COASTAL BEND. ALTHOUGH PRESCRIPTION DRUGS HAVE OCCASIONALLY BEEN REPORTED IN LOW TROPHIC LEVEL ORGANISMS IN OTHERMARINE ECOSYSTEMS, OUR FINDING IS THE FIRST EVIDENCE OF PHARMACEUTICAL CONTAMINANTS IN CETACEANS (WHALES, DOLPHINS, AND PORPOISES) IT IS UNCLEAR IF OTHER DOLPHINS IN THE SOUTH TEXAS REGION HAVE BEEN EXPOSED TO HIGH CONCENTRATIONS OF CONTAMINANTS THAT COMPROMISEIMMUNE RESPONSE. BECAUSE OF THEIR LIFE HISTORY ATTRIBUTES AND ANATOMY (E.G., LONG LIFESPAN, SITE FIDELITY, FEEDING AT A HIGH TROPHICLEVEL, LIPID-RICH BLUBBER THAT BIOACCUMULATE CONTAMINANTS), BOTTLENOSE DOLPHINS ARE IMPORTANT SENTINELS OF OVERALL ECOSYSTEM HEALTHAND SUSTAINABILITY. THE CORPUS CHRISTI BAY AND REDFISH BAY STOCKS OF DOLPHINS HAVE SPECIFICALLY BEEN IDENTIFIED AS IMPERILED BY THENATIONAL OCEANIC AND ATMOSPHERIC ADMINISTRATION DUE TO EXPOSURE TO POLLUTION FROM PESTICIDES, OILS, GASES, HEAVY METALS, ANDCHEMICALS, IN ADDITION TO THREATS FROM DREDGING, CONSTRUCTION, NOISE, RECREATIONAL FISHERIES, SHIPPING, AND ALGAL BLOOMS. LITTLE ISKNOWN ABOUT THE POPULATION BIOLOGY OR RESILIENCY OF DOLPHINS INHABITING LAGUNA MADRE, WHERE THE PHARMACEUTICAL-EXPOSED POSTMORTEMDOLPHIN WAS FOUND. WE PROPOSE TO CONDUCT A HABITAT ASSESSMENT OF CONTAMINANT LEVELS IN OUR MARINE ECOSYSTEMS USINGCOMMON BOTTLENOSE DOLPHINS AS A PROXY OF ECOSYSTEM HEALTH. WE WILL ASSESS THE POPULATION ABUNDANCE, SITE FIDELITY, ANDCONTAMINANT EXPOSURE TYPES AND CONCENTRATIONS IN BOTTLENOSE DOLPHINS INHABITING SOUTH TEXAS TO ENABLE RISK ASSESSMENTS OF ANDINFORMED MANAGEMENT FOR THE ECOSYSTEM AND ITS HUMAN AND ANIMAL INHABITANTS.

THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT THE COORDINATION ACTIVITIES RELATED TO THE STATE WILDLIFE GRANT PROGRAM (SWG) FOR TEXAS PARKS   WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT INLAND FISHERIES COASTAL FISHERIES THROUGH A SWG COORDINATOR.

WESTERN CHICKEN TURTLES HAVE ONLY BEGUN TO BE SERIOUSLY STUDIED IN THE LAST DECADE AND RECENT SURVEYS HAVE FAILED TO DETECT THEM AT THE SITES OF HISTORICAL RECORDS IN SEVERAL STATES. ALTHOUGH THERE CONTINUE TO BE OCCASIONAL SIGHTINGS OF WESTERN CHICKEN TURTLES IN ARKANSAS, RECENT TRAPPING SURVEYS HAVE GENERALLY NOT DETECTED THEM. THE CRITICAL FIRST STEPS IN ASSESSING CONSERVATION NEEDS AND IMPLEMENTING APPROPRIATE CONSERVATION ACTIONS FOR THIS IMPERILED SPECIES ARE 1) TO ASSESS THE CURRENT DISTRIBUTION OF WESTERN CHICKEN TURTLES IN ARKANSAS AND 2) TO ESTIMATE THE ABUNDANCE OF EXTANT POPULATIONS. FUNDS OBLIGATED TO THIS PROJECT WILL BE SUB-AWARDED TO THE UNIVERSITY OF ARKANSAS.

THIS PROJECT WILL GATHER INFORMATION TO INFORM, JUSTIFY, AND ENFORCE BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS) TO MINIMIZE SIGNIFICANT IMPACTS OF WIND TURBINE OPERATIONS ON VOLANT WILDLIFE IN THE ALTAMONT PASS WIND RESOURCE AREA (APWRA) OF CALIFORNIA (ALAMEDA AND CONTRA COSTA COUNTIES), WITH IMPLICATIONS AT LARGER SCALE. HERE, WE FOCUS ON TWO CALIFORNIA SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN), GOLDEN EAGLE (GOEA), BURROWING OWL (BUOW), AND INCLUDE A THIRD FOCAL SPECIES, HOARY BAT (HOBA), WHICH WAS NOT IMPERILED IN 2015 BUT WILL BE INCLUDED AS A SGCN IN THE 2025 SWAP DUE TO THE SIGNIFICANT POPULATION-LEVEL IMPACTS OF WIND ENERGY (PERS. COMM. SCOTT OSBORN, CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE  CDFW ). THESE SPECIES HAVE BEEN IMPACTED THROUGH COLLISION WITH WIND TURBINES SINCE BUILD OUT OF THE 30,000-ACRE APWRA BEGAN IN 1980. STUDIES PROPOSED INCLUDE PREDICTIVE MODELING OF GOEA FLIGHT RISK, GPS TELEMETRY DATA COLLECTION TO ANALYZE SPACE USE BY BUOW, AND COMPREHENSIVE DISTRIBUTION MAPPING OF HOBA FROM NEW AND EXISTING OCCURRENCE DATA. RESULTS OF THESE HIGH-PRIORITY STUDIES WILL SUPPORT CDFW CONSERVATION EFFORTS AND STREAMLINE REGULATORY RECOMMENDATIONS AT A TIME WHEN INVESTMENT IN RENEWABLE ENERGY DEVELOPMENT IS INCREASING EXPONENTIALLY.

THE TEXAS TORTOISE (GOPHERUS BERLANDIERI) IS THE ONLY TORTOISE SPECIES NATIVE TO TEXAS AND CAN BE FOUND IN THE THORNSCRUB SAVANNAS AND WOODLANDS OF SOUTH TEXAS. THE TEXAS TORTOISE IS LISTED AS THREATENED BY THE STATE OF TEXAS, AS PRESSURES FROM HABITAT LOSS AND DISEASE ARE HYPOTHESIZED TO BE DRIVING POPULATION DECLINES. HOWEVER, TAKE OF THESE ANIMALS FROM THE WILD, USUALLY BY INDIVIDUALS UNAWARE OF REGULATIONS, ALSO SERVES AS A THREAT TO THIS SPECIES, BOTH IN THE REDUCTION OF POPULATION SIZES AND THE POTENTIAL INTRODUCTION OF NOVEL PATHOGENS IF HOUSED WITH OTHER REPTILES AND RELEASED BACK INTO THE WILD. AN OUTREACH AND FORFEITURE PROGRAM ARE A NECESSITY TO SPREAD AWARENESS OF THE STATUS OF THE SPECIES AND LIMIT FURTHER TAKE FROM THE WILD, AS WELL AS RETURN TORTOISES IN CAPTIVITY BACK TO THE WILD TO INCREASE POPULATION SIZES. NEXT-GENERATION SEQUENCING TECHNOLOGIES NOW PERMIT THE RAPID ASSEMBLY OF A GENOME, AND WITH CURRENT DATA COLLECTION ON TEXAS TORTOISE POPULATION GENOMICS, A BASELINE STRUCTURE WILL BE AVAILABLE TO DETERMINE LIKELY AREAS OR REGIONS FORFEITED TORTOISES WERE COLLECTED. ADDITIONALLY, CURRENT DATA ON DISEASE INCIDENCE AND TRANSLOCATION PROTOCOLS PROVIDES A BASELINE UNDERSTANDING OF WHERE PATHOGENS ARE PRESENT TO PREVENT FOREIGN PATHOGEN MOVEMENT AND HOW TO RESPONSIBLY RELOCATE TORTOISES TO PREVENT THESE FORFEITED TORTOISES ATTEMPTING TO REHOME.

THE MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (DNR) RECEIVES FUNDS ADMINISTERED BY THE WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM (WSFR) OF THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) FOR A NUMBER OF PROGRAMS. ONE OF THESE PROGRAMS IS THE STATE WILDLIFE GRANT PROGRAM (SWG) WHICH ALLOWS DNR FINANCE AND OPERATIONS DIVISION STAFF TO EFFICIENTLY AND EFFECTIVELY COORDINATE FISCAL AND PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS FOR SWG. THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO ENSURE: SWG REIMBURSEMENT REQUESTS FOR EXPENSES MEET PROGRAM STANDARDS AND COMPLY WITH ALL FEDERAL LAWS AND REGULATIONS, TO PROVIDE INFORMATION TO THE USFWS RELATED TO MICHIGAN LAWS AND AUTHORITY TO THE STATE TO PARTICIPATE IN THE FEDERAL ASSISTANCE, TO INFORM AGENCY PERSONNEL INVOLVED WITH FEDERAL GRANTS OF FEDERAL REQUIREMENTS AND REGULATIONS, TO SUBMIT ACCURATE FINANCIAL REPORTS AND OBLIGATE AND MONITOR FEDERAL FUNDS, AND TO ENSURE THE FEDERAL AID COORDINATOR AND FEDERAL AID ANALYST REMAIN CURRENT ON SWG TOPICS THROUGH ATTENDANCE AT MEETINGS, CONFERENCES, AND TRAINING.

THERE HAS BEEN VERY LITTLE EFFORT IN RECENT MEMORY TO IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE STATUS OF SMALL MAMMALS IN SOUTH CAROLINA DESPITE 13 SPECIES BEING LISTED IN THE SWAP (2015). THIS IS LARGELY DUE TO THE DIFFICULTY IN MONITORING FOR THESE ANIMALS. THE ADAPTED-HUNT DRIFT FENCE TECHNIQUE (AHDRIFT) SYSTEM HAS BEEN SHOWN TO BE EFFECTIVE AT SAMPLING SMALL MAMMALS WITHOUT THE UPKEEP AND MORTALITY RISK OF TRADITIONAL DRIFT FENCES. THE APPALACHIAN OAK FOREST IS HOME TO 10 OF THE 13 SWAP LISTED SMALL MAMMAL SPECIES. BY SAMPLING EXCLUSIVELY IN HIGH ELEVATION FORESTED ENVIRONMENTS, WE FEEL CONFIDENT THAT WE CAN SURVEY FOR AND DETECT WITH THE AHDRIFT SYSTEM THE FOLLOWING SPECIES: CAROLINA RED-BACKED VOLE, WOODLAND JUMPING MOUSE, EASTERN WOODRAT, MASKED SHREW, PYGMY SHREW SOUTHERN), AND EASTERN SPOTTED SKUNK.

THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PYRAMID STATE RECREATION AREA GRASSLAND MANAGEMENT PLAN. ACTIVITIES UNDER THIS PROJECT WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT A SUBSET OF ILLINOIS SGCN THAT OCCUR AT THE PYRAMID SRA BY MAINTAINING AND ENHANCING THEIR HABITATS. FOCUSED NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ON PUBLIC LANDS WILL ENSURE THAT LONG-TERM IWAP AND IDNR GOALS CAN BE ACHIEVED, RESULTING IN PERMANENTLY IMPROVED HABITAT CONDITIONS AND INCREASED VIABILITY OF POPULATIONS OF SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED. THERE ARE NO EXPECTED SUBGRANTEES FOR THIS PROJECT.

SOUTHERN FLOUNDER (PARALICHTHYS LETHOSTIGMA) ARE ESTUARINE-DEPENDENT FLATFISH THAT SUPPORTECONOMICALLY IMPORTANT COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL FISHERIES IN TEXAS  HOWEVER, SPAWNING STOCKBIOMASS HAS DECREASED BY OVER 70  SINCE THE 1980S DESPITE INCREASINGLY STRINGENT REGULATORYMEASURES. CONSEQUENTLY, THE TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT (TPWD) HAS IDENTIFIED THE SOUTHERNFLOUNDER AS  S2-IMPERILED  TO  S3-VULNERABLE  AND A SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN)UNDER THE TEXAS CONSERVATION ACTION PLAN (TCAP). EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES FOR SOUTHERNFLOUNDER REQUIRE THE IDENTIFICATION AND CONSERVATION OF CRITICAL HABITATS WHICH SUPPORT THE FISHERYAND SHOULD ACCOUNT FOR POTENTIAL ADAPTIVE DIFFERENCES IN HABITAT USE AND MIGRATION STRATEGIES AMONGLOCAL POPULATIONS. THIS IS PARTICULARLY TRUE ALONG THE TEXAS COAST, WHERE THIS TEMPERATE SPECIES ISLOCATED AT THE SOUTHERN EDGE OF ITS DISTRIBUTION AND IS MOST SUSCEPTIBLE TO CHANGES IN TEMPERATUREAND FRESHWATER INFLOW THAT VARY ALONG A LATITUDINAL GRADIENT. FURTHER EVIDENCE SUGGESTS THATFRESHWATER INFLOW MAY BE CRITICAL TO DEFINING NURSERY HABITAT FOR SOUTHERN FLOUNDER IN TEXASESTUARIES. THUS, THE RESIDENCY OF SOUTHERN FLOUNDER IN OLIGOHALINE HABITATS ( 5) WARRANTS FURTHEREXAMINATION TO EVALUATE LOCAL ADAPTATION TO INTERANNUAL DROUGHT CYCLES AND VARIABLE FRESHWATERINPUTS. SOUTHERN FLOUNDER ARE ALSO HIGHLY MOBILE, UTILIZING BOTH THE ESTUARINE AND MARINEENVIRONMENTS OVER VARIOUS TIMESCALES  HOWEVER, THE TIMING OF MIGRATION AND SURVIVORSHIP FROMCENTRAL-SOUTHERN TEXAS ESTUARIES IS CURRENTLY UNKNOWN. ASSESSING THE DEGREE OF ESTUARINE DEPENDENCEAND SURVIVAL WILL DETERMINE THE NECESSARY SCALE FOR SPATIALLY EXPLICIT MANAGEMENT REGULATIONS TOFACILITATE FISHERY PRODUCTION THROUGHOUT THE GEOGRAPHIC RANGE OF THIS SPECIES, ESPECIALLY IFEXPOSED TO DISPROPORTIONATE LEVELS OF FISHING PRESSURE. THEREFORE, THIS PROJECT AIMS TO PROVIDE NEWINSIGHTS INTO THE ESTUARINE RESIDENCY, MIGRATION, AND SURVIVAL OF SOUTHERN FLOUNDER FOR A MOREROBUST EVALUATION OF CURRENT MANAGEMENT MEASURES AIMED AT REBUILDING THIS ECONOMICALLY IMPORTANTLIVING MARINE RESOURCE. THIS PROJECT WILL DIRECTLY ADDRESS A STATE WILDLIFE GRANT (SWG) PROGRAMPRIORITY FOR SOUTHERN FLOUNDER: RESEARCH THAT ADDRESSES MOVEMENT SURVIVAL IN ESTUARIES.SPECIFICALLY, THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO (1) EXAMINE THE TIMING OF SOUTHERN FLOUNDER SPAWNING MIGRATIONSAS A FUNCTION OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS  2) ESTIMATE SURVIVAL AND FISHING MORTALITY  AND 3)ASSESS THE FREQUENCY AND DURATION OF LIFETIME OLIGOHALINEHABITAT USE.

THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE INSIGHT INTO THE SHORE-BASED RECREATIONAL SHARK FISHERY IN TEXAS, INCLUDINGCHARACTERIZING SPECIES AND SIZE TRENDS OF SHARKS CAUGHT OVER TIME AS WELL AS EXPLORING FACTORS INFLUENCING THE ANGLER S DECISION TOHARVEST OR RELEASE SHARKS. THE VULNERABILITY OF SHARKS TO FISHING ACTIVITIES IS WELL KNOWN. SINCE THE 1960S, SHARK POPULATIONS HAVEDECLINED IN CONCERT WITH MANY OTHER GLOBAL FISHERIES (BAUM ET AL. 2003  BAUM AND MYERS 2004  BURGESS ET AL. 2005) AND CONTINUE TOBE OVEREXPLOITED IN MANY REGIONS (DULVY ET AL. 2021). REVERSAL OF THESE DECLINES FOR MANY SPECIES WILL REQUIRE A VARIETY OFAPPROACHES, INCLUDING PROTECTION OF ESSENTIAL HABITATS, LONG-TERM MONITORING PROGRAMS, AND REDUCTIONS IN FISHING MORTALITY (WARD-PAIGE ET AL. 2012). WHILE RECREATIONAL FISHERIES CAN ALSO INFLUENCE THE LONG-TERM POPULATION DYNAMICS OF THESE SPECIES (PAULY ET AL.2003), A RECENT SHIFT FROM HARVESTING THESE LARGE PREDATORS TO A CATCH-PHOTO-TAG-RELEASE APPROACH ALLOWS FOR NATIONAL TAGGINGPROGRAMS (E.G., NOAA FISHERIES APEX PREDATOR PROGRAM) AND LOCAL TAGGING INITIATIVES (E.G., CENTER FOR SPORTFISH SCIENCE ANDCONSERVATION  CSSC  SHARK TAGGING PROGRAM) TO ACCESS DATA ON A SCALE THAT OTHERWISE WOULD NOT BE MONETARILY OR PHYSICALLYFEASIBLE (GIBSON ET AL. 2019, KOHLER AND TURNER 2019). THIS TYPE OF FISHERY-DEPENDENT DATA IS CRUCIAL TO EVALUATING SHARKASSEMBLAGES, PARTICULARLY IN NEARSHORE AREAS WHERE EXISTING DATA IS LIMITED. TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT (TPWD) CURRENTLYHAS 33 OF 39 SHARK SPECIES ON THE SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) LIST UNRANKED DUE TO DATA DEFICIENCY OR LISTED AS ATLEAST  S3 - VULNERABLE . MUCH OF THE CURRENT DATA FROM WHICH SHARK POPULATION TRENDS ARE DERIVED ORIGINATE FROM FISHERY SURVEYS THAT,ALTHOUGH STANDARDIZED, MAY BE LIMITED AT SPATIAL OR TEMPORAL SCALES. SUCH DATA SETS ARE INADEQUATE IN EXPLAINING ABUNDANCE ANDCOMPOSITION TRENDS ALONG NEARSHORE HABITATS (E.G., SURF ZONE) DESPITE THE KNOWN USE OF THESE HABITATS BY A VARIETY OF SHARK SPECIES(REYIER ET AL. 2008  THORPE AND FRIERSON 2009  DRYMON ET AL. 2010  KNIP ET AL. 2010  BETHEA ET AL. 2014). CONSEQUENTLY, FEW LONGTERMDATA SETS DESCRIBE SHARKS IN SHALLOW NEARSHORE WATERS THROUGHOUT MUCH OF THE GULF OF MEXICO AND BEYOND, THEREBY IMPEDINGOUR UNDERSTANDING OF NEARSHORE SHARK ASSEMBLAGE DYNAMICS. TO ADDRESS THESE DATA GAPS, WE WILL USE COOPERATIVE RELATIONSHIPSPREVIOUSLY ESTABLISHED WITH TEXAS SHARK RODEO (TSR) AND RECREATIONAL ANGLERS PARTICIPATING IN THE CSSC SHARK TAGGING PROGRAM TOCHARACTERIZE SPECIES AND SIZE COMPOSITION OF SHARKS CAUGHT IN THE SHORE-BASED RECREATIONAL SHARK FISHERY AS WELL AS EVALUATE ANGLERBEHAVIOR INCLUDING THE DECISION TO HARVEST OR RELEASE SHARKS AND VALIDATE ENGAGEMENT EFFORTS TO INFORM ANGLERS ON BEST HANDLINGPRACTICES.

THIS PROJECT WILL ASSESS THE DIVERSITY AND DISTRIBUTION OF AQUATIC SNAIL SPECIES THROUGHOUT THE LOUISIANA SECTIONOF THE BAYOU BARTHOLOMEW DRAINAGE. MULTIPLE SAMPLING METHODS WILL BE USED TO DETERMINE THE OCCURRENCES ANDABUNDANCES OF THE ENTIRE AQUATIC SNAIL ASSEMBLAGE IN THIS SECTION OF THE RIVER. IN THIS THREE YEAR PROJECT WILL INVESTIGATE THE PERFORMANCE OF ARTIFICIAL REEF PYRAMID LOW PROFILE MODULES AND CONCRETE RAILROAD TIE PATCHES OF SEVERAL SIZES OVER SEVERAL SEDIMENT TYPES IN THE NEARSHORE GULF OF MEXICO ALONG THE TEXAS COAST IT IS IMPORTANT TO UNDERSTAND THE BENEFIT AND FUNCTION OF THESE NEARSHORE REEFS AND WHAT CONFIGURATIONS ARE MOST ROBUST IN TERMS OF PROVIDING ADEQUATE NURSERY HABITAT TO ADULT REEF HABITAT THERE ARE FOUR STUDY SITES OF THIS RESEARCH INCLUDING THE RIO GRANDE VALLEY REEF CORPUS CHRISTI REEF BIG MANS REEF AND KATES REEF THIS PROJECT WILL USE SIDESCAN SONAR ROV SURVEYS AND BOAT MOUNTED ADCP SURVEYS TO ASSESS THE EFFECTS OF THESE DEPLOYED CONFIGURATIONS AND THEIR PERFORMANCE PROVIDING FISH HABITAT SEVERAL YEARS AFTER DEPLOYMENT THE RESEARCH FOR THIS PROPOSAL FOCUSES ON HABITAT RESTORATION CREATION AND CULTIVATION IT WILL INFORM ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT FOR THE RESTORATION AND CREATION OF TEXAS NEARSHORE HABITATS USING ARTIFICIAL REEFS

RECENT RESEARCH HAS HELPED TO DOCUMENT THE PHENOLOGY OF MONARCH HABITAT USE, BREEDING ACTIVITY, AND PLANT ASSOCIATIONS IN BOTH MARITIME AND INLAND SWAMP HABITATS IN SC. THIS RESEARCH HAS RAISED SEVERAL QUESTIONS ABOUT THE POTENTIAL GENETIC RELATEDNESS OF MONARCHS USING COASTAL HABITATS IN SC. WHILE THE INITIAL PRESUMPTION WAS THAT SEASONALLY-SPECIFIC HABITAT USE (I.E. MARITIME HABITATS IN THE WINTER AND INLAND SWAMPS IN THE SUMMER) WAS AN INDICATION THAT MONARCHS WERE MOVING FROM ONE HABITAT TO ANOTHER, THERE IS LITTLE DATA TO SUPPORT THIS CONTENTION. OF THE   18,000 MONARCHS TAGGED AND 4,693 MONARCHS RECOVERED ACROSS THESE HABITATS, VERY FEW (  5) HAVE BEEN SHOWN TO MIGRATE FROM ONE HABITAT TO ANOTHER. UNDERSTANDING THE GENETIC RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN AND WITHIN MONARCHS USING MARITIME AND SWAMP HABITATS WILL PROVIDE GREATER RESOLUTION ON THE RELATEDNESS OF THESE MONARCHS. THIS PROJECT WILL COLLECT ADDITIONAL MONARCHS AND CONDUCT MICROSATELLITE-BASED GENETIC ANALYSES OF BOTH THE NEW CAPTURES AND THE SAMPLES IN THE LAB.

THIS GRANT SUPPORTS THE WORK OF WRC STAFF TO UPDATE THE NORTH CAROLINA WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN BY 2025. THIS IS A USFWS REQUIREMENT IN ORDER TO CONTINUE TO BE ELIGIBLE FOR STATE WILDLIFE GRANT FUNDING.

THIS GRANT WILL BE SUBAWARDED TO NORTHEASTERN STATE UNIVERSITY, TO SURVEY THE BAT COMMUNITIES OF PUBLIC LANDS THROUGHOUT EASTERN OKLAHOMA TO COMPARE CURRENT ABUNDANCE, DISTRIBUTION, AND SPECIES COMPOSITION TO A SIMILAR SURVEY CONDUCTED 25 YEARS AGO (CLARK AND CLARK 1997). NEW SURVEY SITES ARE ALSO PROPOSED TO GENERATE BASELINE POPULATION INFORMATION THAT MAY BE USED TO MONITOR FUTURE POPULATION CHANGES AND AID IN DEVELOPING EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION MEASURES. ADDITIONALLY, STUDIES WILL INVESTIGATE THE GEOGRAPHIC VARIABILITY IN MICROPLASTIC ACCUMULATION IN LOCAL FOOD CHAINS. THE OBJECTIVE IS TO ESTIMATE THE DISTRIBUTION, RELATIVE ABUNDANCE, AND SPECIES COMPOSITION OF BAT COMMUNITIES AT 18 SITES ACROSS 8 POTENTIAL COUNTIES IN EASTERN OKLAHOMA VIA A COMBINATION OF MIST-NET AND ACOUSTIC SURVEYS. ACOUSTIC DATA WILL BE ANALYZED WITH AUTOMATED BAT IDENTIFICATION SOFTWARE AND VETTED FOR CORRECT IDENTIFICATION AS NEEDED. RESULTS OF THE MIST-NET SURVEYS, ANALYSIS OF HOW CAPTURE DATA DIFFERS FROM CLARK AND CLARK (1997), AND ANALYSIS OF HOW ACOUSTIC DATA COMPARES WITH CAPTURE DATA WILL BE SUPPLIED TO ODWC IN ANNUAL-INTERIM REPORTS AND COMPILED INTO ONE FINAL COMPREHENSIVE REPORT. INSECTS WILL ALSO BE COLLECTED IN EMERGENT TRAPS AND SURBER SAMPLERS TO ASSESS PREY-BASE DIVERSITY AND ABUNDANCE, AS WELL AS ASSESSING MICROPLASTIC ACCUMULATION IN TROPHIC WEBS. ANY RESULTING THESES OR PUBLICATIONS WILL ACKNOWLEDGE ODWC FUNDING AND COPIES OF THE DOCUMENTS WILL BE PROVIDED TO ODWC AS DESIRED.

THIS GRANT WILL BE SUBAWARDED TO THE UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA, TO CONDUCT A 3-YEAR SURVEY OF THE PRESENCE, RELATIVE ABUNDANCE, AND HEALTH STATUS OF BAT COMMUNITIES IN SOUTHEASTERN OKLAHOMA, WITH AN EMPHASIS ON SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN). THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON RE-SURVEYING 11 SITES WHERE 5 SPECIES OF SCGN BATS WERE PREVIOUSLY DOCUMENTED AS PART OF AN ESA SECTION 6 PROGRAM NEARLY 30 YEARS AGO, AS WELL AS AN ADDITIONAL 2 SITES, BASED UPON CONSULTATION WITH ODWC. MIST-NETTING EFFORTS SIMILAR TO PREVIOUS SAMPLING STRATEGIES WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED WITH ACOUSTIC MONITORING, TO DEVELOP A ROBUST ESTIMATE FOR SITE OCCUPANCY AND DETECTABILITY OF BAT SPECIES, AS WELL AS ESTIMATES FOR COMMUNITY CHANGE DURING THE 30-YEAR INTERVAL. BATS WILL BE PROCESSED TO COLLECT MORPHOLOGICAL AND REPRODUCTIVE DATA, AS WELL AS A WING PUNCHES, GUANO, AND SAMPLES FOR IDENTIFICATION OF DISEASE AND HEALTH STATUS. MOST BATS WILL BE RELEASED AFTER PROCESSING, BUT UP TO TWO INDIVIDUALS PER SPECIES SITE WILL BE VOUCHERED FOR NON-FEDERALLY THREATENED OR ENDANGERED TO PROVIDE A HISTORICAL RECORD. LABORATORY ANALYSES WILL ASSESS THE PRESENCE AND PREVALENCE OF BLOOD PARASITES, CORONAVIRUSES, AND PSEUDOGYMNOASCUS DESTRUCTANS, THE FUNGUS THAT CAUSES WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME, AND UNDERLYING HEALTH INDICATORS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS STUDY IS TO CONTINUE A 4-YEAR MARK-RECAPTURE IN THE DEVILS RIVER FOCUSED ON UNDERSTANDING HOW FLOW AND WATER TEMPERATURE SHAPE POPENAIAS POPEII, TEXAS HORNSHELL, GROWTH AND SURVIVORSHIP. THIS INFORMATION IS IMPORTANT BECAUSE MUSSEL PERSISTENCE IS GENERALLY DEFINED BY EXTREMES IN FLOW, AND IN THE CASE OF P. POPEII, LOW FLOWS AND ELEVATED WATER TEMPERATURE HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS FACTORS IMPACTING ITS PERSISTENCE (RANDKLEV ET AL., 2018). BECAUSE OF THIS, IDENTIFYING HOW EXTREME FLOWS AFFECT POPULATION PERSISTENCE (I.E., GROWTH, SURVIVORSHIP, AND REPRODUCTION) WILL BE CRITICAL FOR ENSURING ITS LONG-TERM SURVIVAL.

CURRENTLY, 126 FRESHWATER SPECIES ARE CONSIDERED SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED IN NORTH CAROLINA (24 CRAYFISH, 85 FISHES, 39 MUSSELS AND 9 SNAILS). EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF THESE SPECIES NECESSITATES THAT THE RANGE, ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF THESE SPECIES NEED TO BE UPDATED REGULARLY. EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT ALSO REQUIRES THAT BASIC LIFE-HISTORY AND TAXONOMY BE DETERMINED. THEREFORE, THERE IS A NEED TO CONDUCT MONITORING, SURVEYS AND BASIC RESEARCH ON NCWAP PRIORITY SPECIES (NCWAP PAGES 89, 90, 100, 101, 111, 112, 153 AND 154).THERE ARE SEVERAL CONSERVATION ACTIONS THAT ARE ALSO NEEDED FOR THE PROTECTION OF THESE SPECIES, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO, THE FOLLOWING:MONITORING AND CONTROL OF EXOTIC SPECIES (NCWAP PAGE 90, 101 AND 112),PROVIDING TECHNICAL GUIDANCE   TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE (NCWAP PAGES 785-787),ESTABLISHING NEW POPULATIONS OR AUGMENTING EXISTING ONES (NCWAP PAGES 101, 112, AND 154), ANDIDENTIFYING AND REMEDIATING POOR HABITAT (NCWAP PAGES 101 AND 112).THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO PURSUE THESE CONSERVATION ACTIONS.

THIS GRANT WILL MEASURE IMPORTANT ASPECTS OF HIGH MARSH HABITAT AND BIRD USE OF THAT HABITAT, BY THE BLACK RAILAND YELLOW RAIL. THIS WILL INCLUDE CONDUCTING AN ASSESSMENT OF ELEVATION AND SOIL GRAIN SIZE COMPOSITION,QUANTIFYING THE RESPONSE OF BLACK RAILS TO THE 2020 HURRICANE SEASON, AND TRACKING THE MOVEMENTS OF YELLOW RAILSTO UNDERSTAND RESPONSES TO RAINFALL (AND MARSH INUNDATION) AS WELL AS THE TIMING OF SPRING MIGRATION.

THE VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES (DEPARTMENT) HAS UTILIZED STATE WILDLIFE GRANT (SWG) FUNDS TO IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION EFFORTS THAT BENEFIT VIRGINIAS SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN).  AS A CONDITION OF THE SWG PROGRAM THE DEPARTMENT CREATED A COMPREHENSIVE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION STRATEGY THAT ADDRESSED EIGHT ESSENTIAL ELEMENTS IDENTIFIED BY CONGRESS.  THESE WERE ALSO ADDRESSED IN THE 2015 WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN REVISION. THESE ELEMENTS INCLUDE:1) INFORMATION ON THE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF SPECIES OF WILDLIFE, INCLUDING LOW AND DECLINING POPULATIONS AS THE STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCY DEEMS APPROPRIATE, THAT ARE INDICATIVE OF THE DIVERSITY AND HEALTH OF THE STATES WILDLIFE  AND2)DESCRIPTIONS OF LOCATIONS AND RELATIVE CONDITION OF KEY HABITATS AND COMMUNITY TYPES ESSENTIAL TO CONSERVATION OF SPECIES IDENTIFIED IN (1)  AND3)DESCRIPTIONS OF PROBLEMS WHICH MAY ADVERSELY AFFECT SPECIES IDENTIFIED IN (1) OR THEIR HABITATS, AND PRIORITY RESEARCH AND SURVEY EFFORTS NEEDED TO IDENTIFY FACTORS WHICH MAY ASSIST IN RESTORATION AND IMPROVED CONSERVATION OF THESE SPECIES AND HABITATS  AND4)DESCRIPTIONS OF CONSERVATION ACTIONS DETERMINED TO BE NECESSARY TO CONSERVE THE IDENTIFIED SPECIES AND HABITATS AND PRIORITIES FOR IMPLEMENTING SUCH ACTIONS  AND5)PROPOSED PLANS FOR MONITORING SPECIES IDENTIFIED IN (1) AND THEIR HABITATS, FOR MONITORING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE CONSERVATION ACTIONS PROPOSED IN (4), AND FOR ADAPTING THESE CONSERVATION ACTIONS TO RESPOND APPROPRIATELY TO NEW INFORMATION OR CHANGING CONDITIONS  AND6)DESCRIPTIONS OF PROCEDURES TO REVIEW THE PLAN-STRATEGY AT INTERVALS NOT TO EXCEED TEN YEARS  AND7)PLANS FOR COORDINATING, TO THE EXTENT FEASIBLE, THE DEVELOPMENT, IMPLEMENTATION, REVIEW, AND REVISION OF THE PLAN-STRATEGY WITH FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL AGENCIES AND INDIAN TRIBES THAT MANAGE SIGNIFICANT LAND AND WATER AREAS WITHIN THE STATE OR ADMINISTER PROGRAMS THAT SIGNIFICANTLY AFFECT THE CONSERVATION OF IDENTIFIED SPECIES AND HABITATS.8)CONGRESS HAS AFFIRMED THROUGH WCRP AND SWG, THAT BROAD PUBLIC PARTICIPATION IS AN ESSENTIAL ELEMENT OF DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING THESE PLANS-STRATEGIES, THE PROJECTS THAT ARE CARRIED OUT WHILE THESE PLANS-STRATEGIES ARE DEVELOPED, AND THE SPECIES IN GREATEST NEED OF CONSERVATION THAT CONGRESS HAS INDICATED SUCH PROGRAMS AND PROJECTS ARE INTENDED TO EMPHASIZE.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS THE COORDINATION OF DELAWARE S STATE WILDLIFE GRANTS MANAGEMENT PROCESSES AND MAINTENANCE OF DELAWARE S ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE COORDINATION AND ADMINISTRATION OF PROGRAMMATIC AND FINANCIAL ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH STATE WILDLIFE GRANTS APPLICATIONS AND AGREEMENTS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE DELAWARE S ELIGIBILITY FOR PARTICIPATION IN THE STATE WILDLIFE GRANTS PROGRAM, TIMELY SUBMISSION OF GRANT APPLICATION PACKAGES AND PERFORMANCE REPORTS, EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATION AND COORDINATION OF ALL ASPECTS OF THE PROGRAM AND GRANT ACTIVITIES WITH WILDLIFE AND SPORT FISH RESTORATION PROGRAM, AND EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATION, COORDINATION AND TRAINING FOR DELAWARE LEADERSHIP, MANAGEMENT, PROJECT LEADERS AND STAFF. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE CONSERVATION MANAGERS AND SCIENTISTS IMPLEMENTING GRANT-FUNDED PROJECTS AIMED AT IMPROVING THE STATUS OF SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED IN SUPPORT OF THE DELAWARE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THIS PROJECT.

THE NEBRASKA STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP), ALSO KNOWN AS THE NEBRASKA NATURAL LEGACY PROJECT, IDENTIFIES ALLOF THE STATES AT-RISK SPECIES, NATURAL COMMUNITIES, AND BIOLOGICALLY UNIQUE LANDSCAPES AND CREATES A BLUEPRINT FOR CONSERVATION. NEBRASKAS SWAP HAD ITS LAST COMPREHENSIVE REVISION IN 2011 WITH A MINOR REVISION IN 2018. REVISION OF THE SWAP IS A COLLABORATIVE PROCESS AND THIS GRANT WOULD FUND STAFF ASSISTANCE, PUBLIC INPUT FORUMS, SPECIES EXPERT WORKING GROUPS, WRITING TEAMS, AND OTHER TASKS.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT WOULD FOCUS ON FOOTHILL YELLOW-LEGGED FROG (RANA BOYLII) POPULATION AND HABITAT MONITORING IN RESPONSE TO WILDFIRE AND DROUGHT CONDITIONS. MONITORING OF DROUGHT-SUSCEPTIBLE TERRESTRIAL SPECIES CONDUCTED BY CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) IN 2022 IDENTIFIED SEVERAL LOCATIONS WITH R. BOYLII PRESENT ALONG CAMP CREEK (ELDORADO NATIONAL FOREST), WHERE R. BOYLII POPULATIONS HAD NOT BEEN OBSERVED SINCE 2007. THE LAST KNOW SURVEYS WERE CONDUCTED BETWEEN 2016-2021 BY US FOREST SERVICE () BIOLOGISTS (JEFF MABE, PERSONAL COMMUNICATION) INDICATING THESE POPULATIONS MAY HAVE BEEN MISSED AND OR ARE REBOUNDING OR EXPANDING WHICH MAY ALSO BE TRUE FOR OTHER POPULATIONS. THIS WATERSHED LIES WITHIN THE CALDOR FIRE FOOTPRINT, INCLUDING AREAS OF LOW-, MODERATE-, AND HIGH-BURN SEVERITY AS REPORTED IN THE USFS 2021 CALDOR FIRE BURNED AREA EMERGENCY RESPONSE (BAER) ASSESSMENT REPORT. LITTLE IS KNOWN AS TO HOW THIS RECENT FIRE WILL AFFECT R. BOYLII POPULATIONS. OBSERVATIONS IN 2022 INCLUDED MULTIPLE LIFE STAGES, INCLUDING EGG MASSES, PROVIDING INITIAL EVIDENCE THAT SUCCESSFUL BREEDING IS STILL OCCURRING FOLLOWING THE CALDOR FIRE. THIS POPULATION PROVIDES AN OPPORTUNITY TO STUDY R. BOYLII RESPONSE TO POST-FIRE AND DROUGHT CONDITIONS. PROJECT FUNDS WOULD BE USED TO EXPAND UPON THIS INITIAL EFFORT TO ASSESS R. BOYLII OCCUPANCY, DISTRIBUTION, RELATIVE ABUNDANCE, AND HABITAT USE ELSEWHERE WITHIN THE CALDOR FIRE FOOTPRINT, WHILE ALSO MONITORING CHANGES TO R. BOYLII HABITAT IN THE YEARS FOLLOWING THE FIRE. THIS PROPOSED WORK WOULD CONTINUE IN CAMP CREEK AND ITS TRIBUTARIES AND WOULD ALSO EXPAND TO THE NORTH FORK COSUMNES RIVER AND MIDDLE FORK COSUMNES RIVER ON ELDORADO NATIONAL FOREST, TWO ADDITIONAL WATERSHEDS AFFECTED BY THE CALDOR FIRE, WHERE RECENT SURVEY EFFORTS FOR R. BOYLII ARE LACKING. ADDITIONAL WATERSHEDS AFFECTED BY DROUGHT AND WILDFIRE CONDITIONS, SUCH AS LOCATIONS WITHIN THE RECENT CAMP FIRE, MOSQUITO FIRE, AND DIXIE FIRE FOOTPRINTS, WILL ALSO BE CONSIDERED FOR INCLUSION IN THESE EFFORTS, DEPENDENT UPON PERSONNEL AVAILABILITY, OVERALL STUDY WORKLOAD, SITE ACCESS, AND INTERAGENCY COORDINATION.
FY24 STATE WILDLIFE GRANT FOR CONSERVATION OF WILDLIFE DIVERSITY IN OHIO

THE CONSERVATION STATUS OF THE LARGE MAJORITY OF TEXAS NATIVE ARTHROPOD SPECIES HAS NEVER BEEN ASSESSED FORMALLY. DETERMINING SPECIES THAT ARE MOST AT RISK IS VITAL TO MORE EFFECTIVELY CONSERVING ALL SPECIES OF WILDLIFE. MANY ARTHROPOD SPECIES ARE EXHIBITING SIGNIFICANT DECLINES WORLDWIDE, WITH ROUGHLY HALF OF THE CURRENT LIST OF SPECIES BEING REVIEWED FOR LISTING AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED IN THE US BEING INVERTEBRATES. CONSERVATION STATUS ASSESSMENTS ARE A VALUABLE TOOL FOR DETERMINING WHICH SPECIES ARE AT HIGHEST RISK BUT WE OFTEN LACK THE DATA TO BEST EVALUATE THE STATUS OF THIS DIVERSE GROUP OF ANIMALS. IN THE PROPOSED PROJECT WE WILL:1.CREATE A TEXAS INVERTEBRATE CONSERVATION WEB PORTAL TO REFINE AND MANAGE AGGREGATED ARTHROPOD DATA.2.CONDUCT INITIAL ANALYSES OF THE CONSERVATION STATUS OF ELIGIBLE SPECIES.3.CONDUCT SELECTED CASE STUDY ASSESSMENTS OF SEVERAL SPECIES TAGGED BY THE PROJECT.

FOR MORE THAN TWO DECADES NOW THE STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN SWAP HAS BEEN THE GUIDING DOCUMENT TO HELP DIRECT THE DEPARTMENTS NONGAME CONSERVATION EFFORTS ACROSS THE STATE. ARIZONA S NEWLY UPDATED COMPREHENSIVE WEB-BASED CONSERVATION STRATEGY AWCS IS GUIDED BY THE 2022 SWAP WHILE ALSO OFFERING ONLINE TOOLS DATA AND IMPORTANT INFORMATION FOR THE PUBLIC AND OUR CONSERVATION PARTNERS. THE AWCS INCREASES PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT WITH THE SWAP AND THE DEPARTMENTS NONGAME CONSERVATION EFFORTS AND OFFERS SEVERAL ONLINE TOOLS AND DATA PLATFORMS TO BE USED BY OUR PARTNERS AND PUBLIC ALIKE. THE GRANT ALSO FUNDS THE IMPLEMENTATION OF CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY PROJECTS FOR ARIZONA S NATIVE FISHES INVERTEBRATES AMPHIBIAN AND REPTILE SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED. ALL ACTIVITIES OUTLINED CAN BE TIED TO THREATS ACTIONS INFORMATION NEEDS AND CONSERVATION STRATEGIES IDENTIFIED IN THE SWAP.THE GRANT WILL SUPPORT THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES.MAINTENANCE AND CONTINUED UPGRADES TO THE AWCS-SWAP WEBSITE TO IMPROVE PUBLIC AND PARTNER ENGAGEMENT WITH ARIZONA S SWAP AND OTHER DEPARTMENT NONGAME CONSERVATION EFFORTS. DATA VISUALIZATION TOOLS ALLOW FOR BETTER INFORMATION SHARING BETWEEN THE DEPARTMENT AND OUR CONSERVATION PARTNERS BOTH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE. AS PART OF THE AWCS WEBSITE THE COA MAP VIEWER WILL BECOME AN IMPORTANT TOOL THAT WILL HELP FOCUS AND GUIDE CONSERVATION EFFORTS WHERE THEY ARE NEEDED MOST WHILE ALSO BUILDING COLLABORATION AND PARTNERSHIPS TO BETTER CONSERVE OUR SGCN AND THEIR HABITATS.COORDINATING WITH OUR NEIGHBOR STATES TO DEVELOP STRATEGIES THAT COORDINATE SWAPS ACROSS STATE BOUNDARIES WILL IMPROVE CONSERVATION EFFORTS FOR REGIONAL SGCN AND OTHER SPECIES OF CONCERN.DOCUMENTING THE CURRENT DISTRIBUTION AND POPULATION STATUS OF SGCN SPECIES BY GATHERING INFORMATION ON HISTORICAL AND PRESENT DISTRIBUTIONS HABITAT ASSOCIATIONS NATURAL HISTORY AND THREATS.ENHANCING EXISTING POPULATIONS AND REESTABLISH POPULATIONS INTO HISTORICAL HABITAT.CONDUCTING SURVEYS MONITORING POPULATIONS AND HABITATS AND IDENTIFYING MANAGEMENT POTENTIAL AT SPECIFIC SITES.COLLECTING A LIMITED NUMBER OF SPECIMENS FROM HISTORICAL AND NEWLY IDENTIFIED LOCATIONS FOR GENETIC ANALYSIS RESEARCH CAPTIVE PROPAGATION ETC.IDENTIFYING ESSENTIAL HABITATS RESEARCH NEEDS AND OTHER MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS.MAINTAINING BROODSTOCKS OF SELECT SGCN FISHES AND PROVIDE PROGENY TO MEET CONSERVATION NEEDS.INVESTIGATING THE USE OF DIFFERENT AQUACULTURE TECHNIQUES NEW TECHNOLOGY AND LIFE HISTORY RESEARCH ON NATIVE FISH TO IMPROVE SURVIVAL GROWTH PRODUCTION HEALTH AND CONDITION OF FISH IN REARING UNITS TRANSPORT STOCKING AND POST STOCKING PERFORMANCE INTO THE WILD.COLLABORATING WITH PARTNERS TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT MANAGEMENT PLANS CONSERVATION AGREEMENTS RECOVERY ACTIONS RESEARCH MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS AND TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT EFFORTS EXAMPLES INCLUDE WORKING WITH UNIVERSITIES AND SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTS TO CONDUCT GENETICS ANALYSES CONTRACTING ASSISTANCE IN PROTECTING AND IMPROVING HABITATS.

THE LARGE HOME RANGE SIZE AND DIVERSE HABITAT REQUIREMENTS OF THE GOLDEN EAGLE (AQUILA CHRYSAETOS, GOEA) MAKE IT PARTICULARLY SUSCEPTIBLE TO HUMAN DISTURBANCE, DEMOGRAPHIC DECLINE, AND SUBSEQUENT LOSS OF GENOMIC VARIATION. AS A RESULT, GOEA ARE A SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) IN THE STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP). PROPER MANAGEMENT REQUIRES DATA REGARDING INDIVIDUAL MOVEMENT, BREEDING POPULATION SIZE, AND GENOMIC HEALTH. TO ADDRESS THIS DATA GAP, THE CDFW WILDLIFE GENETICS RESEARCH UNIT HAS PARTNERED WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, LOS ANGELES AND THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY ON A STATE FUNDED CALIFORNIA CONSERVATION GENOMICS PROJECT (CCGP) GRANT TO EXAMINE THE LANDSCAPE GENOMICS OF GOEA. THE STATE FUNDED CCGP GRANT WAS AWARDED TO SEQUENCE THE GENOMES OF 150 INDIVIDUALS WITH PAIRED RADIO TELEMETRY OR NEST SITE DATA (FIG. 1). APPLYING INTEGRATED TELEMETRY AND LANDSCAPE GENOMIC DATA TO THE CONSERVATION OF GOEA WILL SERVE AS AN UNPRECEDENTED MODEL FOR GENOMICS-INFORMED MANAGEMENT OF OTHER BIRD SPECIES. FUNDS FROM THIS STATE WILDLIFE GRANT (SWG) WILL SUPPORT A CDFW RESEARCH SCIENTIST I FOR 12 MONTHS TO ANALYZE THE COMPLEX DATA AND PUBLISH RESULTS. THIS WORK WILL BE CONDUCTED AT THE CDFW GENETICS RESEARCH LAB IN SACRAMENTO AND OVERSEEN BY DR. MICHAEL BUCHALSKI (RESEARCH SCIENTIST III). THIS SWG WILL RESULT IN 1) COMPLETION OF AN INTEGRATED LANDSCAPE GENOMICS STUDY OF GOEA IN CALIFORNIA, AND 2) CREATION OF A PUBLIC DATABASE OF GENOME SEQUENCES TO FACILITATE FUTURE RESEARCH.

USING ENVIRONMENTAL DNA (EDNA) IN WATER SAMPLES IS AN INNOVATIVE MONITORING APPROACH THAT IS LESS EXPENSIVE, LESS INVASIVE, AND OFFERS SIMILAR OR HIGHER DETECTION PROBABILITIES THAN CONVENTIONAL APPROACHES USED TO MONITOR AQUATIC SPECIES (GOLDBERG ET AL. 2011  TABERLET ET AL. 2012  THOMSEN ET AL. 2012  GOLDBERG ET AL. 2013  SCHMELZLE AND KINZIGER 2016  EVANS ET AL. 2017). STUDIES HAVE SHOWN THAT EDNA METHODS CAN BE USED TO EFFECTIVELY DETERMINE SITE OCCUPANCY, AND THAT ESTIMATES OF EDNA CONCENTRATION MAY BE ABLE TO PROVIDE INFORMATION ON RELATIVE POPULATION DENSITIES UNDER SOME CIRCUMSTANCES (TAKAHARA ET AL. 2012  SCHMELZLE AND KINZIGER 2016  SALTER ET AL., 2019  STOEKLE ET AL. 2021  SHELTON ET AL. 2022). WHILE EDNA HAS THE POTENTIAL TO IMPROVE OUR ABILITY TO DETECT AQUATIC SPECIES AND TO CONDUCT MONITORING IN LARGE AREAS WITH HIGH EFFICIENCY, MINIMAL TAKE, AND LOWER COST (THOMSEN AND WILLERSLEV 2015), STANDARDIZED SURVEY PROTOCOLS ARE NEEDED FOR EDNA DATA TO BE SUFFICIENTLY CHARACTERIZED FOR REGULATORY DECISIONS. THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO PROVIDE  FIRST OF ITS KIND  GUIDANCE FOR THE STANDARDIZED APPLICATION OF EDNA APPROACHES FOR DETECTING AND MONITORING AN AQUATIC SPECIES LISTED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA. WE PROPOSE TO DEVELOP A STANDARDIZED EDNA SURVEY PROTOCOL FOR NORTHERN TIDEWATER GOBY (EUCYCLOGOBIUS NEWBERRYI). THE TIDEWATER GOBY IS A SMALL (30-60 MM TOTAL LENGTH), BENTHIC FISH ENDEMIC TO LAGOONS, BAYS, AND ESTUARIES ALONG THE ENTIRE COAST OF CALIFORNIA (SWENSON, 1999). THE NUMBER OF SITES OCCUPIED BY TIDEWATER GOBY HAS DECLINED DUE TO COASTAL DEVELOPMENTS, DROUGHTS, AND EXOTIC SPECIES INTRODUCTIONS (SWIFT ET AL. 1989). TIDEWATER GOBY WERE LISTED AS ENDANGERED UNDER THE U.S. ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT IN 1994 (USFWS, 2005). THE NORTHERN TIDEWATER GOBY (E. NEWBERRYI) IS KNOWN FROM MORE THAN 70 SITES BETWEEN THE PALOS VERDES PENINSULA AND THE CALIFORNIA-OREGON BORDER, AND IS THE FOCAL SPECIES FOR THIS STUDY (SWIFT ET AL., 2016). (THE RECENTLY DESCRIBED SOUTHERN TIDEWATER GOBY (E. KRISTINAE) IS KNOWN FROM ONLY NINE SITES SOUTH OF THE PALOS VERDES PENINSULA, LOS ANGELES COUNTY, TO SAN DIEGO COUNTY.) DETERMINING THE NUMBER OF SITES OCCUPIED BY NORTHERN TIDEWATER GOBY IS CRITICAL FOR MANAGEMENT (USFWS 2005). HOWEVER, DETERMINING SITE PRESENCE IS CHALLENGING AND THE SPECIES CAN BE EASILY OVERLOOKED USING CONVENTIONAL MONITORING APPROACHES WHEN ABUNDANCE IS LOW AND WHEN FIELD OBSERVATIONS ARE LIMITED BY WATER CLARITY, DEPTH, AND HABITAT SIZE AND COMPLEXITY. NORTHERN TIDEWATER GOBY ARE AN IDEAL CANDIDATE FOR DEVELOPMENT OF STANDARDIZED PROTOCOL BECAUSE EXTENSIVE PREVIOUS RESEARCH HAS ESTABLISHED EDNA METHODS AS EFFECTIVE MONITORING TOOL FOR THE SPECIES (SCHMELZLE AND KINZIGER 2016  SUTTER AND KINZIGER 2019  MARTEL ET AL. 2021). COMPARISON OF DETECTION PROBABILITIES BETWEEN EDNA METHODS AND STANDARDIZED SEINING APPROACHES REVEALED THAT EDNA METHODS HAVE NEARLY DOUBLE THE DETECTION RATE AS SEINING FOR NORTHERN TIDEWATER GOBY (SCHMELZLE AND KINZIGER 2016). FURTHER, EDNA MONITORING HAS BEEN EFFECTIVELY EMPLOYED TO GENERATE ACCURATE SINGLE-POINT-IN-TIME ESTIMATES OF THE ENTIRE GEOGRAPHIC DISTRIBUTION OF TIDEWATER GOBY (SUTTER AND KINZIGER 2019), AND RANGEWIDE CHARACTERIZATIONS OF SITE EXTINCTION AND COLONIZATION PATTERNS FROM YEAR TO YEAR (METAPOPULATION DYNAMICS  MARTEL ET AL. 2021).
