THIS GRANT IS A SUBAWARD TO OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY TO FUND A RESEARCH PROJECT DIRECTED AT THE LOGGERHEAD SHRIKE, A GRASSLAND BIRD WHOSE OVERALL POPULATION HAS DECLINED BY MORE THAN 50  DURING THE PAST FIFTY YEARS BASED ON THE BREEDING BIRD SURVEY PROGRAM. THE FIELD WORK FOR THIS PROJECT WILL BE FOCUSED ON FOUR REGIONS OF THE STATE THAT SHOW THE HIGHEST RELATIVE ABUNDANCE OF LOGGERHEAD SHRIKES. DURING THE BREEDING SEASON (ROUGHLY APRIL-JULY), THE HIGHEST DENSITIES OF SHRIKES APPEAR TO BE IN THE FLINT HILLS REGION. DURING THE NON-BREEDING SEASON (DECEMBER-MARCH), THE GREATEST CONCENTRATION OF SHRIKES OCCURS IN THE SOUTHWEST MIXED-GRASS PRAIRIE REGION. THE STUDY REGION ENCOMPASSES THOSE TWO AREAS (26 COUNTIES) AND INCLUDES PORTIONS OF THE FLINT HILLS (KAY, NOBLE, OSAGE, PAWNEE, AND PAYNE COUNTIES), NORTH-CENTRAL MIXED-GRASS PRAIRIE (ALFALFA, BLAINE, GARFIELD, GRANT, KINGFISHER, LOGAN, AND MAJOR COUNTIES), SOUTH-CENTRAL CROSS TIMBERS (CARTER, GARVIN, JEFFERSON, LOVE, MURRAY, AND STEPHENS COUNTIES), AND SOUTHWEST MIXED-GRASS PRAIRIE REGIONS (BECKHAM, COMANCHE, COTTON, GREER, HARMON, JACKSON, KIOWA, AND TILLMAN COUNTIES). BECAUSE OF THEIR LONG-TERM DECLINE, A PROTOCOL IS NEEDED FOR HOW TO BEST MONITOR LOGGERHEAD SHRIKE POPULATIONS WITH THE UNDERSTANDING THAT BREEDING (RESIDENT) AND NON-BREEDING (MIGRATORY) POPULATIONS MAY BE RESPONDING TO DIFFERENT PRESSURES. THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THAT NEED THROUGH RESEARCH TO BETTER DETERMINE THE DISTRIBUTION, ABUNDANCE, AND DENSITY OF LOGGERHEAD SHRIKES USING A COMBINATION OF SPATIAL MODELING, ROAD-BASED POINT-COUNT SURVEYS, AND COMMUNITY SCIENCE ENGAGEMENT TO ADDRESS LAND COVER AND LAND USE ASSOCIATIONS AT MULTIPLE SCALES IN BOTH WINTERING AND BREEDING SEASONS. THESE ANALYSES WILL HELP DEVELOP AND VALIDATE A SURVEY PROTOCOL FOR FUTURE MONITORING OF AND MANAGEMENT FOR LOGGERHEAD SHRIKES IN OKLAHOMA. A SPATIAL DATABASE OF SHRIKE OCCURRENCES WILL BE DEVELOPED BY COMPILING DATA FROM EXISTING SOURCES INCLUDING THE OKLAHOMA BREEDING BIRD ATLAS, BREEDING BIRD SURVEY ROUTES, BREEDING SEASON AND WINTERING SEASON RECORDS FROM EBIRD AND INATURALIST, AND THE OKLAHOMA WINTER BIRD ATLAS. THIS WILL RESULT IN A COMPILED, SPATIALLY EXPLICIT DATABASE OF SHRIKE USE LOCATIONS, ANALYZABLE BY REGION, SEASON, AND YEAR. FOR EACH SHRIKE-USE LOCATION, A SERIES OF RANDOM LOCATIONS WILL BE DRAWN AT 2, 5, AND 10KM AWAY AND ENTERED INTO A GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEM DATABASE. THE RESULTING SPATIAL DATABASE WILL MAP THE DISTRIBUTION OF LOGGERHEAD SHRIKES AND IDENTIFY CLUSTERS OF HIGHER AND LOWER OCCURRENCE ACROSS THE STATE. THE RANDOMLY-SELECTED NON-USE LOCATIONS WILL PERMIT ANALYSIS OF LAND USE AND LAND COVER AT MULTIPLE SCALES WHICH WILL PROVIDE INSIGHT INTO HABITAT ASSOCIATIONS FOR SHRIKES. A ROAD-BASED SURVEY PROTOCOL WILL BE DEVELOPED FOR BOTH THE WINTER AND SUMMER FIELD SEASONS THAT WILL BE USED TO FILL-IN DISTRIBUTIONAL DATA GAPS AND VALIDATE DISTRIBUTION, ABUNDANCE, AND HABITAT-USE MODELS. THIS SURVEY WILL CONSIST OF BRIEF ROADSIDE POINT-COUNTS ALONG ROUTES THAT WILL BE APPROXIMATELY 20 KM IN LENGTH AND PLACED ALONG EXISTING COUNTY ROADS. THE POINT-COUNT TECHNIQUE IS COMMONLY USED TO MONITOR BIRD COMMUNITIES AND THE DATA ARE COLLECTED BY AN OBSERVER PARKED ON A ROADSIDE AND RECORDING THE LOCATIONS OF BIRDS THAT ARE SEEN AND OR HEARD IN ALL DIRECTIONS AROUND THEIR STATIONARY POINT. FOR EACH SHRIKE SEEN OR HEARD, THE DISTANCE BETWEEN THE OBSERVER AND THE BIRD WILL BE ESTIMATED IN 50-METER DISTANCE BANDS AND THE TIME OF THE FIRST DETECTION OF EACH BIRD WILL BE RECORDED IN ONE-MINUTE TIME INTERVALS. IN ORDER TO MEASURE DETECTION VARIABILITY, EACH TRANSECT WILL BE SURVEYED TWICE PER SEASON TO ANALYZE THE RATE AT WHICH SHRIKES ARE DETECTED DURING SURVEYS. INDIVIDUAL SAMPLING POINTS AND DETECTION TIMES WILL BE ARCHIVED IN A GIS DATABASE AND USED TO ANALYZE DETECTION USING TIME REMOVAL AND OR DISTANCE SAMPLING, OCCUPANCY, AND THE INFLUENCE OF LAND USE, LAND COVER, AND DEGREE OF WOODY ENCROACHMENT ON SHRIKE OCCURRENCE.

THIS GRANT IS IMPLEMENTED BY THE MISSOURI DEPARTMENT OF CONSERVATION TO ACCOMPLISH CCS (STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP))OBJECTIVES AND INCLUDES TWO PROJECTS.PROJECT A PROVIDES ADMINISTRATION FOR THE INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL COORDINATION NEEDED TO ENSURE THE SUCCESS OF THE CCS (SWAP). THIS REQUIRES CONSIDERATION OF THE LONG-TERM CONSERVATION GOALS FOR MISSOURI, AND HOW THOSE ASSOCIATE WITH AND INTERRELATE TO REGIONAL, NATIONAL, AND GLOBAL CONSERVATION EFFORTS. COORDINATION DECISIONS ARE INFORMED BY BEST AVAILABLE SCIENCE AND PROFESSIONAL JUDGMENTS BASED ON THAT SCIENCE, SOME OF WHICH IS SUPPORTED BY THE EFFORTS DESCRIBED IN PROJECT B.PROJECT B PROVIDES THE INFORMATION NECESSARY TO DEVELOP, IMPLEMENT, AND EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE CCS(SWAP) BY CONDUCTING NECESSARY SURVEYS, MONITORING, AND TRACKING OF COMMUNITIES AND SPECIES OF CONSERVATION CONCERN (SOCC).

THE ARKANSAS WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN CONTINUES TO BE A GUIDING DOCUMENT FOR CONSERVATION ACTIONS IN THE STATE. BIOLOGISTS AND CONSERVATIONISTS STRIVE TO COMPLETE RESEARCH AND RESTORATION PROJECTS IN ORDER TO BENEFIT SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED THROUGH STATE WILDLIFE GRANTS AND OTHER PROJECTS. EVERY TWO YEARS THESE CONSERVATIONISTS GATHER AT THE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN SYMPOSIUM TO REVIEW PROGRESS AND REFINE PRIORITIES FOR ALL SPECIES AND HABITATS. THE WILDLIFE DIVERSITY PROGRAM COORDINATOR OVERSEES PLAN IMPLEMENTATION AND THE STATE WILDLIFE GRANTS PROCESS.

THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE FUNDING TO INVESTIGATE THE DISTRIBUTION OF THE SOUTHERN SNAKETAIL THROUGH EDNA SAMPLINGAS WELL AS PROVIDE INFORMATION ABOUT HABITAT REQUIREMENTS FOR THE NYMPH STAGE OF DEVELOPMENT, PHENOLOGY, AND FOODPREFERENCES. THIS STUDY WILL ALSO USE EDNA TO DETECT THE BLUENOSE SHINER, WHICH OCCUPIES THE SAME HABITATS AS THESOUTHERN SNAKETAIL. BOTH OF THESE SPECIES ARE LISTED AS SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED IN THE LOUISIANASTATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN AND THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS PRIORITY RESEARCH AND SURVEY NEEDS IDENTIFIED IN THE PLAN.

THE STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP) FOR NEW MEXICO IDENTIFIES ALL THE SPECIES OF CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) IN THE STATE AND THEIR ASSOCIATED HABITATS, THREATS, AND CONSERVATION ACTIONS. A COMPREHENSIVE REVISION OF THE SWAP WAS LAST APPROVED BY THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) IN 2017. THE NEXT SUCH COMPREHENSIVE REVISION MUST BE COMPLETED BY THE NEW MEXICO DEPARTMENT OF GAME AND FISH (DEPARTMENT) AND SUBMITTED TO THE USFWS BY OCTOBER 1, 2025. THIS PROJECT WILL ENTAIL A COMPREHENSIVE REVIEW AND REVISION OF THE 8 ELEMENTS OF THE SWAP INCLUDING: A) ELEMENT 1 (SGCN): REVIEWING AND REVISING THE SGCN SELECTION CRITERIA AND UPDATING THE LIST OF SGCN FOR NEW MEXICO, INCLUDING EXPLORATION OF ADDING POLLINATING INSECTS TO THE LIST  B) ELEMENT 2 (HABITATS): REVIEWING THE MACROGROUP DESCRIPTIONS AND REVISING TO ALIGN WITH THE UPDATED U.S. NATIONAL VEGETATION CLASSIFICATION SYSTEM, UPDATING MACROGROUP ASSOCIATIONS WITH SGCN, AND IDENTIFYING ASSOCIATIONS FOR NEW SGCN  C) ELEMENT 3 (THREATS STRESSORS): UPDATING THE THREATS AND CLIMATE CHANGE CHAPTERS AND THREATS-RELATED TABLES AND APPENDICES TO REFLECT NEW INFORMATION ON THREATS FACING SGCN IN NEW MEXICO, ESPECIALLY EMERGING THREATS OR THREATS THAT HAVE INTENSIFIED SINCE THE 2017 SWAP WAS WRITTEN, AND INCORPORATING INFORMATION ON POTENTIAL CLIMATE REFUGIA AND SGCN CLIMATE VULNERABILITY  D) ELEMENT 4 (ACTIONS): UPDATING CONSERVATION ACTIONS TO MATCH ANY NEW BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AND TO BETTER INCORPORATE CLIMATE ADAPTATION  E) ELEMENT 5 (MONITORING): UPDATING SGCN MONITORING TABLE AND OTHER MONITORING CHAPTER CONTENT AS NEEDED  F) ELEMENT 6 (REVIEW AND REVISION): UPDATING THE LANGUAGE REGARDING THE NEXT COMPREHENSIVE REVIEW AND REVISION OF THE SWAP  G) ELEMENT 7 (PARTNER INVOLVEMENT): CONVENING AND HOLDING FOUR MEETINGS WITH A CORE SWAP REVISION COMMITTEE COMPRISED OF STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES, NON-PROFITS, COMMERCIAL INTERESTS, AND EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTIONS WITH A NEXUS TO WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT AND CONDUCTING FORMAL CONSULTATION WITH ALL FEDERALLY-RECOGNIZED TRIBES IN NEW MEXICO  H) ELEMENT 8 (PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT): HOLDING PUBLIC MEETINGS AND PRESENTING INFORMATION ON THE 2025 COMPREHENSIVE SWAP REVISION DURING THREE PUBLICLY-ACCESSIBLE NEW MEXICO STATE GAME COMMISSION MEETINGS. THIS PROJECT WILL ENSURE THAT THIS IMPORTANT PLANNING DOCUMENT REMAINS UP TO DATE AND RELEVANT TO THE CONSERVATION OF WILDLIFE OF CONSERVATION CONCERN ACROSS NEW MEXICO. UPDATING THIS DOCUMENT WILL ENSURE THAT THE DEPARTMENT CAN CONTINUE TO PARTNER WITH USFWS ON USING STATE WILDLIFE GRANT FUNDS TO IMPLEMENT PROJECTS TO BENEFIT NEW MEXICOS SGCN AND ADDRESS THREATS AND IMPORTANT CONSERVATION ACTIONS FOR THESE SPECIES. THE DATA GATHERED AND CONSERVATION ACTIONS IMPLEMENTED THROUGH THESE FUTURE PROJECTS CAN BENEFIT DOZENS OF SGCN AND IMPORTANT, BIODIVERSE HABITATS IN NEW MEXICO FOR THENEXT 10 YEARS.

THE CALIFORNIA STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP) LISTS GRAY WOLVES (CANIS LUPUS) AS A SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED AND FOCAL SPECIES OF CONSERVATION STRATEGIES. GRAY WOLVES ARE LISTED AS ENDANGERED UNDER THE CALIFORNIA ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (CESA) AND FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. SINCE THE 2011 DISPERSAL OF OREGON WOLF OR-7, THE DISTRIBUTION OF GRAY WOLVES HAS EXPANDED IN CALIFORNIA. CURRENTLY, TWO BREEDING PACKS AND SEVERAL DISPERSED WOLVES ARE KNOWN IN THE STATE. IN 2016, THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) ESTABLISHED A GRAY WOLF CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, PARTLY WITH FEDERAL FUNDING, TO FULFILL ACTION ITEMS AND OBJECTIVES IN CDFW S CONSERVATION PLAN FOR GRAY WOLVES IN CALIFORNIA (WOLF PLAN). THERE ARE DIVERSE PUBLIC AND STAKEHOLDER OPINIONS ABOUT WOLF CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT. REGARDLESS OF POSITION, MOST INTERESTED PARTIES EXPECT CDFW TO BE PROACTIVE IN THEIR POLICIES AND ACTIONS REGARDING WOLVES, AND OTHER WILDLIFE, IN CALIFORNIA. THE CDFW HAS TRUSTEE AGENCY RESPONSIBILITY FOR CONSERVING BIODIVERSITY AND SUPPORTING ROBUST CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES FOR DIVERSE SPECIES THROUGHOUT CALIFORNIA (SWAP, 2015). THE PROVISION OF STABLE DEDICATED RESOURCES TO CONDUCT WOLF CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS WILL ALLOW STAFF TO MONITOR WOLF POPULATIONS IN CALIFORNIA, RESPOND TO CHANGES IN PACK SIZE OR DISTRIBUTION, AND EFFECTIVELY ENGAGE WITH STAKEHOLDER GROUPS AND THE PUBLIC. THIS THREE-YEAR STATE WILDLIFE GRANT (SWG) PROJECT IS NEW IN TERMS OF CURRENT SCOPE OF CONSERVATION, MANAGEMENT, AND RESEARCH OBJECTIVES, INCLUDING EXPANSION OF FOCUS AREAS FROM THE PREVIOUS GEOGRAPHIC EXTENT THROUGHOUT NORTHERN CALIFORNIA TO BETTER REPRESENT AREAS OF THE STATE ACTIVELY BEING RE-COLONIZED BY DISPERSING GRAY WOLVES. THE PROJECT WORK WILL OCCUR IN AREAS OF THE STATE WHERE CREDIBLE WOLF REPORTS OR SIGHTINGS MUST BE INVESTIGATED. PROJECT FUNDING IS CRITICAL FOR IMPLEMENTATION OF WOLF PLAN ACTION ITEMS AND TO ACHIEVE THE OVERARCHING GOALS FOR CONSERVING AND MANAGING CALIFORNIA S GRAY WOLF POPULATION.

GENOMIC RESEARCH TECHNIQUES HAVE REVOLUTIONIZED THE FIELD OF WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT, YET THE RELATIVELY ONEROUS REQUIREMENTS OF BOTH DNA QUANTITY AND QUALITY CONTINUE TO LIMIT THEIR APPLICATION TO SPECIES THAT ARE BOTH ELUSIVE AND HARD TO SAMPLE. NEW METHODS THAT CAN HARNESS THE POWER OF GENOMIC DATA FROM NONINVASIVE SAMPLE TYPES, SUCH AS SCAT, ARE GREATLY NEEDED. THIS STATE WILDLIFE GRANT (SWG) WILL ADDRESS THAT NEED BY SIMULTANEOUSLY 1) DEVELOPING A NEW METHOD FOR GENOTYPING NONINVASIVE SAMPLES AT 10,000S OF SINGLE NUCLEOTIDE POLYMORPHISM (SNP) MARKERS, AND AS PROOF OF CONCEPT 2) CONDUCTING A STATEWIDE GENOMIC STUDY OF BADGERS, AN ELUSIVE SPECIES THAT IS RARELY CAPTURED AND SAMPLED IN THE FIELD. BADGERS ARE A SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) IN THE STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP) AND A CALIFORNIA ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN (SSC), YET LITTLE DATA EXIST TO SUPPORT MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION PLANNING. THIS PROJECT WOULD PROVIDE THE FIRST GENETIC DATA REGARDING POPULATION STRUCTURE, CONNECTIVITY, AND GENETIC DIVERSITY FOR BADGERS IN CALIFORNIA. THE METHODS DEVELOPED DURING THIS STUDY WILL FACILITATE SIMILAR RESEARCH ON OTHER LOW-DENSITY, SECRETIVE WILDLIFE SPECIES. FUNDS FROM THIS SWG WILL SUPPORT A CDFW RESEARCH SCIENTIST 2 (RS2) FOR 24 MONTHS AND A SCIENTIFIC AID FOR 5 MONTHS. THIS WORK WILL BE CONDUCTED AT THE CDFW GENETICS RESEARCH LABORATORY IN SACRAMENTO AND OVERSEEN BY DR. MICHAEL BUCHALSKI (RS3). AT THE COMPLETION OF THE ANALYSES, A MANUSCRIPT WILL BE SUBMITTED FOR PEER-REVIEW AND A PUBLIC DATABASE OF BADGER DNA SEQUENCES WILL BE CREATED TO FACILITATE FUTURE RESEARCH. IN-KIND MATCHING FUNDS WILL COME FROM REGION 4, AN AREA OF CALIFORNIA WHERE BADGERS APPEAR ABUNDANT, AS WILDLIFE, LANDS, AND MITIGATION MONITORING FIELD STAFF OPPORTUNISTICALLY SAMPLE BADGER SCAT AND ROADKILL. THIS HIGH-DENSITY SAMPLING WITHIN REGION 4 WILL ALLOW FOR MORE SPATIALLY EXPLICIT LANDSCAPE GENETIC ANALYSES THAT IDENTIFY DISPERSAL BARRIERS AND CORRIDORS. THE RESULTS OF THAT PORTION OF THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE MANAGEMENT OF NUMEROUS WILDLIFE SPECIES IN THE REGION AS IT PERTAINS TO EXISTING PLANNED DEVELOPMENT AND RESULTING HABITAT FRAGMENTATION.

THIS GRANT PROPOSAL IS TO CONDUCT MUSSEL SURVEYS WITHIN THE OUACHITA AND TENSAS RIVERS AND BAYOUBARTHOLOMEW AT HISTORICALLY SURVEYED LOCATIONS. THESE SYSTEMS ARE CONSIDERED TO BE MUSSEL STRONGHOLDS FOR THESTATE AND THE RESULTS OF THE SURVEYS WILL BE USED TO UPDATE OCCURRENCE RECORDS AND ALLOW COMPARISONS BETWEENHISTORICAL AND MODERN MUSSEL ASSEMBLAGES.

THIS GRANT FUNDS OPERATIONS AT CPW S NATIVE FISH HATCHERY IN THE SAN LUIS VALLEY. THE HATCHERY REARS A VARIETY OF NATIVE THREATENED, ENDANGERED AND AT-RISK AQUATIC SPECIES, INCLUDING BOREAL TOAD. THE HATCHERY IS A PIONEER IN RESEARCHING AND IMPLEMENTING REARING AND BROODING TECHNIQUES FOR AQUATIC SPECIES THAT ARE OFTEN LITTLE UNDERSTOOD. FISH AND BOREAL TOADS FROM THE FACILITY ARE IMPORTANT COMPONENTS OF A NUMBER OF RECOVERY EFFORTS ACROSS THE STATE.

CONDUCTING STOCK ASSESSMENT PUGET SOUND PACIFIC HERRING (CLUPEA PALLASII) PROVIDES ESSENTIAL INFORMATION ABOUT THE ABUNDANCE OF THIS SPECIES. HERRING ARE IMPORTANT AS PREY FOR NUMEROUS SPECIES INCLUDING ESA LISTED CHINOOK SALMON (ONCORHYNCHUS TSHAWYTSCHA) AND SOUTHERN RESIDNET KILLER WHALES (ORCINUS ORCA) AND SUPPORT COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL FISHERIES. TJE CONTINUANCE OF HERRING STOCK ASSESSMENTS IN PUGET SOUND (SOUTHERN SALISH SEA) IS DEPENDENT ON THE FUNDING DESCRIBED IN THIS PROPOSAL. THIS PROJECT ALSO PROVIDES ANNUAL INFORMATION ABOUT HERRING SPAWNING DISTRIBUTIONAND TIMING ALLOWING US TO PROVIDE UPDATES TO MAPS OF CRITICAL HABITAT WHICH ARE USED IN ADMINISTRATION OF THE STATE S HYDRAULIC PROJECT APPROVAL AUTHORITY. ADDITIONALLY, THIS PROJECT HELPS TO SUPPORT MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT OF OTHER IMPORTAN FORAGE FISH SPECIES, INCLUDING SURF SMELF(HYPOMESUS PRETIOSUS AND NORTHERN ANCHOVY (ENGRAULIS MORDAX) WHICH ARE ALSO SUBJECT TO BOTH COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL HARVEST.

THIS GRANT REQUESTS FUNDING TO IMPLEMENT OBJECTIVES AND GOALS WITHIN THE NEVADA STATE WILDLIFEACTION PLAN (2022). SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED AS DESIGNATED WITHIN THE PLAN WILL BE THEFOCUS OF ACTIVITIES AS DESCRIBED BELOW. FOR THIS SWG GRANT NARRATIVE, ACTIVITIES ARE FOCUSED ONIMPLEMENTATION OF THE NEVADA STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN AS IT PERTAINS TO CONSERVATION OF NEVADA SWILDLIFE AND SUITABLE HABITAT. THE OVERALL GOALS ARE FOR HEALTHY, THRIVING POPULATIONS OF SPECIES OFGREATEST CONSERVATION NEEDS (SGCN) MANAGED IN STABLE TO INCREASING TREND AND TO PREVENT FURTHERDECLINES OF AT-RISK SPECIES WITHIN PRIORITY HABITAT TYPES. SOME PROJECTS FOCUS ON MONITORING MOREWELL-KNOWN SPECIES TO ASSESS TREND IN POPULATION STATUS AND EFFECTIVENESS OF CONSERVATION ACTIONSWHILE OTHER PROJECTS FOCUS ON INCREASING OUR UNDERSTANDING OF SPECIES WHERE LITTLE IS KNOWN.

ALASKA CONSTITUTION DIRECTS STATE GOVERNMENT TO MANAGE WILD ANADROMOUS AND RESIDENT FISH STOCKS UNDER THE SUSTAINED YIELD PRINCIPLE. SPAWNING, REARING AND MIGRATORY FISH HABITATS MUST FUNCTION FULLY TO ACHIEVE THIS GOAL. VARIOUS LAND USE ACTIVITIES CAN COMPROMISE THE ABILITY OF THESE HABITATS TO SUSTAIN FISH STOCKS AND THEREFORE FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS HAVE MULTIPLE ADMINISTRATIVE TOOLS TO MITIGATE IMPACTS. THE ANADROMOUS FISH ACT (AS 16.05.871) PROVIDES HABITAT PROTECTION TO WATERS LISTED IN THE CATALOG OF WATERS IMPORTANT FOR THE SPAWNING, REARING OR MIGRATION OF ANADROMOUS FISHES. EFFORTS OF THE ALASKA FRESHWATER FISH INVENTORY SAMPLE WATERS OF THE BERING LAND BRIDGE NATIONAL PRESERVE ON THE SEWARD PENINSULA AND SELECT SUBBASINS AROUND THE CONFLUENCE OF THE YUKON AND TANANA RIVERS.

THIS PROPOSAL SEEKS TO ASSIST ADF GS THREATENED, ENDANGERED, AND DIVERSITY PROGRAM BY CENTRALIZING AND SERVING CONSERVATION DATA FOR ALASKAS SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED. DATA INCLUDE CONSERVATION ASSESSMENTS, CONSERVATION RANKS, TAXONOMIC CHECKLISTS, AND OTHER PRODUCTS TO SUPPORT THE REVISION OF ALASKAS STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN.THE PURPOSE OF THIS 1-YEAR PROJECT IS TO ASSIST ADF GS TED PROGRAM BY CREATING, ANALYZING, AND SERVING DATA THAT ARE NECESSARY TO COMPLETE THEIR REVISION OF THE SWAP.  CONSERVATION PLANS LIKE THE STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLANS ARE MOST EFFECTIVE WHEN THE INFORMATION INCLUDED IN THEM IS ACCURATE AND UP TO DATE. EXPECTED RESULTS INCLUDE: UPDATED CONSERVATION RANKS OF SGCN-LISTED SPECIES  MAINTENANCE OF CORE DATA PRODUCTS AND DATABASES USED BY THE TED PROGRAM  CONTINUE TO UPDATE DATABASE INFRASTRUCTURE, PROVIDE A FINAL REPORT ON THE ASRS EFFORTS, AND CONDUCT TARGETED SURVEYS TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE ALASKA BEE ATLAS PROJECT. IN ADDITION, WE WILL WORK WITH THE TED PROGRAM TO HELPTHEM ADDRESS REVISIONS TO THE SWAP. BY THE END OF THIS GRANT, THE TED PROGRAM WILL BE WELL-POSITIONED TO REVISE THE SWAP ON TIME AND CONTINUE TO BE ELIGIBLE FOR STATE WILDLIFE GRANTS. THE INFORMATION THAT WE PROVIDE WILL ALLOW TED STAFF TO FOCUS ON THE MOST CRITICAL PIECES OF THE SWAP, WITHOUT NEEDING TO SPEND TIME VERIFYING DETAILS AND UPDATING TABLES AND APPENDICES. THE FINAL PRODUCT WILL BE A MORE ROBUST AND COMPREHENSIVE PLAN THAT REFLECTS CHANGES TO THE STATUS OF WILDLIFE SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS IN THE LAST 10 YEARS.

THE SOUTH DAKOTA WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SDGFP 2014  SDWAP) UNDERWENT ITS LAST MAJOR REVISION DURING 2012-2013.SOUTH DAKOTA GAME, FISH AND PARKS (SDGFP) HAS COMPLETED TWO MINOR REVISIONS SINCE THEN. DURING A MINOR REVISION COMPLETED IN 2018, THREE ANIMAL SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED WERE ADDED. A MORE RECENT REVISION WAS COMPLETED EARLIER THIS YEAR, RESULTING IN THE ADDITION OF 28 ANIMAL SPECIES AND 32 PLANT SPECIES. SOUTH DAKOTASCURRENT SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED LIST IS INCLUDED AS APPENDIX 1 AND IS AVAILABLE FOR PUBLIC VIEWING:HTTPS:  GFP.SD.GOV USERDOCS NAV SD SGCN LIST AS OF 1 MARCH 2023.PDF). A REVISED PLAN IS NEEDED FOR SDGFP TOCONTINUE TO BE ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE STATE WILDLIFE GRANT (SWG) ALLOCATIONS AND, IN THE FUTURE, TO BE ELIGIBLE FOR EXPANDED FUNDING OPPORTUNITIES, SUCH AS FUNDS TO BE PROVIDED THROUGH RECOVERING AMERICAS WILDLIFE ACT (RAWA).CERTAIN SPECIES OF SGCNS, INCLUDING REPTILES, AMPHIBIANS, INVERTEBRATES AND NON-SPORT FISH, HAVE NO OTHER FUNDINGSOURCE IN SOUTH DAKOTA, MAKING SWG FUNDS AN IMPORTANT TOOL IN IMPLEMENTING THE SDWAP FOR THOSE SPECIES GROUPS.

TO PROVIDE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT, COORDINATION, AND TECHNICAL SUPPORT FOR UTAH DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES(UDWR) STATE WILDLIFE GRANT (SWG) PROGRAM. THIS INCLUDES COMPLYING WITH ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS, AND ANY OTHERREGULATORY STANDARDS NECESSARY TO KEEP THE STATE OF UTAH ELIGIBLE TO CONTINUE TO RECEIVE AND IMPLEMENT SWG FUNDS.THE UDWR HAS ROUGHLY 3 GRANTS BEING IMPLEMENTED IN THE STATE WILDLIFE GRANT PROGRAM THAT NEEDS EFFECTIVECOORDINATION OF THIS PROGRAM THROUGH A LIAISON BETWEEN UDWR AND THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS).

THE UDWR WILDLIFE CONSERVATION PROGRAM WORKS TO ENSURE THE CONSERVATION OF THE DIVERSITY OF NATIVE MAMMALS ANDBIRDS IN UTAH. OUR GOALS ARE TO SAFEGUARD UTAHS NATURAL HERITAGE, PREVENT FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA)LISTINGS, AND WORK TOWARD RECOVERY OF ESA-LISTED SPECIES. SINCE THE CREATION OF THE PROGRAM, WE HAVE BEEN ABLE TOACCRUE A RECORD OF SUCCESS IN LISTING PREVENTION BASED PRIMARILY ON PROACTIVE DATA COLLECTION, ACTIVE MANAGEMENT,AND CONSERVATION PARTNERSHIPS. WE WILL CONTINUE TO BUILD ON THAT RECORD THROUGH STRATEGIC IMPLEMENTATION OF THE2015 WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN AS WELL AS SPECIES-BASED EFFORTS DESIGNED TO MEET CONSERVATION TARGETS.
THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE FUNDING FOR SURVEYS OF CRAYFISH LISTED AS SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED IN THELOUISIANA STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN.

AQUATIC SPECIES POPULATIONS IN UTAH FACE A WIDE VARIETY OF THREATS TO THEIR SHORT-AND-LONG-TERM CONSERVATION. THREATS AFFECTING MANY SPECIES IDENTIFIED IN THE 2015 UTAH WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (WAP) INCLUDE URBAN DEVELOPMENT, WATER USE, FIRE, AND INVASIVE SPECIES. OTHER THREATS MAY AFFECT ONLY A SINGLE SPECIES YET NEED REMEDIATION TO ENSURE THE SPECIES  PERSISTENCE. WE NEED BASIC INFORMATION ON THE ECOLOGY OF SPECIES AND STATUS OF POPULATIONS TO ADDRESS ANY THREATS. ADDITIONALLY, WE NEED DEDICATED BIOLOGISTS WITH KNOWLEDGE OF BOTH THE SPECIES AND THE HABITATS ON WHICH THEY DEPEND. REGIONAL NATIVE AQUATIC SPECIES BIOLOGISTS ARE CORE PERSONNEL IN THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE WAP. THEY ARE SPECIES EXPERTS, RESPECTED VOICES ON PLANNING TEAMS, AND HAVE INVALUABLE ON-THE-GROUND KNOWLEDGE OF THE LANDSCAPES AND AQUATIC HABITATS OF UTAH. THEY IDENTIFY THREATS AND FORMULATE ACTIONS. WITH THAT EXPERTISE, WE CAN SUCCESSFULLY IDENTIFY OPPORTUNITIES AND WORK WITH WILLING PARTNERS TO ACHIEVE OUR CONSERVATION GOALS. THIS PROJECT FUNDS THESE STAFF SO THEY CAN CONDUCT IMPORTANT WORK TO REDUCE THREATS TO AQUATIC SPECIES AT RISK IN UTAH. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENSURE THE FUTURE OF NATIVE FISH, AMPHIBIANS, REPTILES, AND MOLLUSKS IN UTAH BY REDUCING THREATS TO THE SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS, THEREBY PREVENTING THE NEED FOR FUTURE SPECIES LISTINGS UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE STATEWIDE SENSITIVE SPECIES INFORMATION AND FILL DATA GAPS IDENTIFIED IN THE UTAH WAP. THESE GOALS WILL BE ACHIEVED THROUGH THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES:1. IMPLEMENT PRIORITY ACTIONS IDENTIFIED IN THE WAP OR OTHER MANAGEMENT PLANS TO REDUCE THREATS TO SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS,2. INVENTORY, MONITOR, AND MANAGE SGCN SPECIES,3. IMPLEMENT AVAILABLE CONSERVATION PLANS AS THEY PERTAIN TO SGCN SPECIES,4. ENHANCE AND MAINTAIN POPULATIONS OF REGIONAL SGCN SPECIES.5. DEVELOP HABITAT MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES AS NEEDED FOR KEY SPECIES BASED ON EXISTING LITERATURE, ONGOING UDWR STUDIES AND PROJECT MONITORING RESULTS.6. MAINTAIN, ENHANCE, AND USE REGIONAL SENSITIVE SPECIES DATABASES

THIS PROJECT HAS THREE MAJOR COMPONENTS AND PURPOSES TO ENSURE EFFECTIVE, LONG RANGE, CONSISTENT GUIDANCE FOR MANAGEMENT OF THE ADF GS SPECIAL AREAS: MANAGEMENT PLANNING FOR SPECIAL AREAS, MANAGEMENT AND MONITORING OF LAND USE ACTIVITIES  AND PROGRAMMATIC CONSISTENCY.

THE UTAH WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (UWAP) IS A 10-YEAR PLAN FOR THE UTAH DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES (UDWR) AND CONSERVATION PARTNERS TO ALIGN AND COORDINATE PROGRAMMATIC- AND PROJECT-LEVEL ASPECTS OF THEIR PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION. THE UWAP S CORNERSTONE ARE THE SPECIES IN GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) IN UTAH. HAVING A COORDINATED LIST OF SPECIES IN NEED OF CONSERVATION ATTENTION ALLOWS ALL CONSERVATION PARTNERS IN UTAH TO FOCUS THEIR ATTENTION ON SPECIES TRULY NEEDING CONSERVATION ATTENTION. THE UWAP IDENTIFIES IMPORTANT HABITATS FOR THE SGCNS, SO THAT THESE HABITATS CAN BE MAINTAINED, PROTECTED, AND EVEN EXPANDED. THE PRIMARY THREATS TO THE SGCNS ARE ALSO IDENTIFIED SO THAT CONSERVATION PARTNERS WITH AUTHORITY TO ADDRESS THOSE THREATS CAN WORK TOWARD ALLEVIATING AND MINIMIZING THEM. WHILE SOME OF THE SGCNS IN THE UWAP ARE SPECIES THAT ARE ALREADY LISTED AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA), MOST ARE NOT AND THE GOAL OF THE UWAP IS TO MAINTAIN AND RESTORE HEALTHY SPECIES POPULATIONS, HABITATS, AND MINIMIZE THREATS TO PREVENT THE NEED FOR ADDITIONAL SPECIES LISTINGS UNDER THE ESA. OVER THE PAST 20 YEARS, UTAH HAS DEMONSTRATED A STRONG CONSERVATION ETHIC FOR ITS  NATIVE SPECIES THROUGH THE UWAP AND PROVIDED THE CONSERVATION TRACK RECORD TO KEEP SPECIES OFF THE ESA. IN FACT, THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE HAS FOUND THAT MORE THAN 90  OF THE UTAH SPECIES PETITIONED FOR LISTING UNDER THE ESA HAVE NOT WARRANTED PROTECTION, WHICH DEMONSTRATES EFFECTIVE STATE MANAGEMENT FOR THESE SPECIES. KEEPING SPECIES MANAGEMENT UNDER STATE AUTHORITY ALLOWS FOR EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR UTAH TO CONTINUE TO GROW ECONOMICALLY. THIS GRANT SUPPORTS THE COORDINATION OF IMPLEMENTATION AND REVISION OF THE UWAP.THIS GRANT SUPPORTS MUCH OF THE DATA HANDLING NEEDS CREATED BY THE UTAH WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN. THE UDWR S NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM (UNHP) MANAGES THE UDWR LOCALITY RECORDS FOR SGCNS. THE UNHP STAFF CONTINUALLY ADD NEW SPECIES LOCALITY RECORDS TO OUR CENTRAL DATABASE AS DATA ARE RECEIVED FROM THE UDWR BIOLOGISTS AND UWAP PARTNERS. MAINTAINING SGCN LOCALITY INFORMATION IS CRITICAL TO DETERMINING THE SUCCESS OF THE UWAP IN MAINTAINING HEALTHY POPULATIONS OF SGCNS IN UTAH.

WILD AND MANAGED INVERTEBRATE POLLINATORS ARE EXHIBITING PRONOUNCED DECLINES WORLDWIDE. GIVEN THE ECOLOGICAL AND ECONOMIC IMPORTANCE OF POLLINATORS IN FACILITATING WILD AND CULTIVATED PLANT REPRODUCTION, IT IS ESSENTIAL TO DEVELOP EFFECTIVE RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES THAT PROVIDE LONG-TERM SUPPORT FOR POLLINATOR COMMUNITIES. DESPITE THIS FACT, FEW EFFORTS HAVE BEEN MADE TO IDENTIFY AND IMPLEMENT THE CONSERVATION ACTIONS NECESSARY TO CONSERVE POLLINATORS IN TEXAS. TEXAS CURRENTLY HAS 29 POLLINATOR SPECIES IDENTIFIED AS SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) AND IN PARTICULAR 16 NATIVE BEES (APPENDIX B, TPWD 2012). LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT MANY OF THESE SPECIES BEYOND THE FEW SCANT RECORDS AND EVEN LESS IS KNOWN ABOUT HOW WE CAN PROPERLY DETERMINE THEIR TRUE DISTRIBUTION, CONSERVATION NEED AND POPULATION RECOVERY IF REQUIRED. IN THE PROPOSED PROJECT, WE WILL LEVERAGE THE KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERTISE OF NATIVE BEES AT UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS AT AUSTIN TO ANSWER MANY OF THESE CRITICAL QUESTIONS FOR OUR NATIVE BEES AND POLLINATORS. DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE: ASSIST EXPERTS WITH THE STATUS ASSESSMENTS OF ALL 1100 NATIVE SPECIES OF BEE AND DEVELOP A STRATEGY TO REASSESS AT LEAST EVERY FIVE YEARS AS MONITORING DATA BECOMES AVAILABLE. DEVELOP A COMPREHENSIVE TEXAS NATIVE BEE MONITORING STRATEGY. FACILITATE THE TEXAS NATIVE BEE RCN. SERVE AS THE TPWD REPRESENTATIVE TO THE U.S. NATIVE BEE RCN. INTEGRATE POLLINATOR HABITAT MANAGEMENT PROGRAM THROUGH THE POLLINATOR HABITAT MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES (TPWD 2016) AND PROVIDE TPWD DISTRICT BIOLOGIST SUPPORT FOR POLLINATOR WILDLIFE TAX VALUATIONS. COORDINATE NATIVE BEE CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES WITH SEAFWA STATES. SERVE AS THE TPWD MONARCH BUTTERFLY LIAISON BETWEEN THE MONARCH JOINT VENTURE AND SEAFWA. SERVE AS THE TPWD REPRESENTATIVE ON THE MAFWA MONARCH SOUTH CORE PLANNING TEAM. WORK WITH TEXAS INSECT COLLECTIONS TO ENSURE DATA AND CURATION STANDARDS ARE MAINTAINED FOR ALL NATIVE BEE SPECIMENS THAT ARE GATHERED USING STATE OR FEDERAL PASS-THROUGH DOLLARS. WORK WITH UT INSECT COLLECTION AND ENTOMOLOGY STAFF TO PROVIDE TAXONOMIC AND CURATORIAL SUPPORT.

THE NEW MEXICO RIPARIAN HABITAT MAP (NMRIPMAP) HAS BEEN IN DEVELOPMENT SINCE 2017 BY NATURAL HERITAGE NEW MEXICO (NHNM) AND THE NEW MEXICO DEPARTMENT OF GAME AND FISH (DEPARTMENT). THIS DATASET PROVIDES HIGH RESOLUTION INFORMATION ON THE QUALITY AND STRUCTURE OF RIPARIAN HABITATS IN NEW MEXICO. AS HIGH BIODIVERSITY HABITATS THAT PROVIDE IMPORTANT RESOURCES TO A HIGH PERCENTAGE OF ANIMALS, INCLUDING SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN), IN NEW MEXICO DURING AT LEAST A PORTION OF THEIR LIFE HISTORIES, RIPARIAN AREAS ARE ESPECIALLY IMPORTANT TO TARGET FOR RESTORATION PURPOSES. THIS PROJECT WILL ENTAIL THE FOLLOWING WORK BY NHNM: A) DEVELOPING A WORK FLOW TO IDENTIFY RIPARIAN CONSERVATION OPPORTUNITY AREAS (RCOAS) ACROSS NEW MEXICO, WHICH INCLUDE LARGER AREAS OF INTACT, NATIVE VEGETATION  ADJACENT AREAS SUITABLE FOR RESTORATION  AND  PINCHPOINTS  WHERE HABITAT CONSERVATION OR RESTORATION ARE ESPECIALLY IMPORTANT TO MAINTAIN NATIVE RIPARIAN VEGETATION CONNECTIVITY  AND ASSOCIATED CONNECTIVITY ZONES THAT ENHANCE LONGITUDINAL CONNECTIVITY ALONG RIVER AND STREAM CORRIDORS  B) DEVELOPING DRAFT RCOAS AND CONNECTIVITY ZONES BY MAJOR WATERSHED IN NEW MEXICO AND APPLYING QUALITY CONTROL PROCEDURES TO DETECT AND FIX ERRORS FROM AUTOMATED DATA ANALYSIS PROCESSES  C) DEVELOPING A PLAN FOR RCOA VALIDATION  D) RANKING RCOAS ACCORDING TO THEIR CONSERVATION VALUE AND RESTORATION POTENTIAL  E) UPDATING THE RCOA WEBSITE WITH FINAL DATA (HTTPS:  NHNM.UNM.EDU RCOAS)  F) DELIVERING PRESENTATIONS REGARDING PROJECT RESULTS AT LOCAL AND NATIONAL WILDLIFE CONFERENCES. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THE DEPARTMENT AND ITS PARTNERS IN WILDLIFE CONSERVATION A VALUABLE TOOL TO INFORM THE PLACEMENT OF FUTURE RIPARIAN RESTORATION EFFORTS AND ENSURE THAT EACH RIPARIAN RESTORATION PROJECT MAINTAINS AND IMPROVES THE CONNECTIVITY OF BIODIVERSE RIPARIAN HABITATS FOR SGCN AND OTHER WILDLIFE TO THE LARGEST EXTENT POSSIBLE. THE DATA FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO THE 2025 STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP) FOR NEW MEXICO, FURTHER UNDERSCORING THE IMPORTANCE OF RIPARIAN HABITATS FOR SGCN IN NEW MEXICO.

THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE FUNDING FOR A ONE-YEAR STUDY TO ASSESS THE DISTRIBUTION OF LONG-TAILED WEASEL AND OTHER SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED ON THE VERNON UNIT OF THE KISATCHIE NATIONAL FOREST. SURVEYS WILL CONSIST OF BAITED CAMERA-TRAPS THAT LOUISIANA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND FISHERIES WILL DEPLOY ON U.S. FOREST SERVICE PROPERTY.

THE STATE PARKS DIVISION OF TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT (TPWD) WILL IMPLEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION TREATMENTS ON TEXAS STATE PARKLANDS TO BENEFIT OCCUPIED AND POTENTIAL HABITAT FOR AVIAN SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) IDENTIFIED IN THE TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENTS TEXAS CONSERVATION ACTION PLAN, TPWD 2012. TREATMENTS WILL INCLUDE PRESCRIBED APPLICATIONS OF FIRE, HERBICIDE, AND PHYSICAL REMOVAL OF INVASIVE VEGETATION, PRIMARILY WOODY SPECIES THAT ARE ALTERING THE COMPOSITION AND ARRANGEMENT ON NATURAL COMMUNITIES CRUCIAL TO THE IDENTIFIED SGCN.THE RESTORATION PROJECT WILL ENCOMPASS IDENTIFIED PRIORITY HABITATS WITHIN STATE PARK AND STATE NATURAL AREA SITES ACROSS THE STATE MANAGED BY THE STATE PARKS DIVISION OF TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT.THE PROJECT WILL BE IMPLEMENTED FROM SEPTEMBER 1, 2023 (FY24) TO AUGUST 31, 2025 (FY25). SPECIFIC TIMING ON INDIVIDUAL TREATMENTS WILL BE BASED ON VEGETATION TYPE AND HISTORIC FIRE REGIME, OCCUPATION BY AND POTENTIAL IMPACT TO SGCN, AS WELL AS FUEL AND WEATHER CONDITIONS. ADDITIONAL TIMING CONSIDERATIONS WILL INCLUDE GROWTH STAGE OF TARGET VEGETATION FOR PROPER APPLICATION OF HERBICIDES AND PHYSICAL REMOVAL TO ACHIEVE THE MAXIMUM BENEFIT.THE STATE PARKS DIVISION WILL UTILIZE DEPARTMENT PERSONNEL AND CONTRACTORS TO COMPLETE IDENTIFIED TREATMENTS. SITES AND INDIVIDUAL TREATMENT AREAS WILL BE MONITORED THROUGHOUT THE PROJECT TIMEFRAME AND PROJECT CREWS WILL BE MOBILIZED ACROSS THE STATE FOR IMPLEMENTATION WHEN OPPORTUNITIES ARISE.

THE HOUSTON TOAD (ANAXYRUS HOUSTONESIS) IS A FEDERAL AND STATE PROTECTED ENDANGERED SPECIES, AS WELL AS A SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN G1 S1) IN THE TEXAS CONSERVATION ACTION PLAN (2012) THAT IS ENDEMIC 9 COUNTIES IN THE XERIC, SANDY LOST PINES AND POST OAK SAVANNAHH ECOREGIONS OF EASTERN CENTRAL TEXAS (FORSTNER AND DIXON, 2010). RANGE WIDE MONITORING SUGGESTS IT IS AT HISTORICALLY LOW OCCUPANCY AND ABUNDANCE LEVELS. THE MAIN THREAT FACING THIS SPECIES IS THE LOSS AND DEGRADATION OF FUNCTIONAL PINE-OAK SAVANNAH ECOSYSTEMS. MUCH OF THE POST OAK SAVANNAH HAS BEEN CONVERTED TO AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION. HOWEVER, WITHOUT ACTIVE PROCESSES SUCH AS FIRE, EVEN THE REMAINING PINE-OAK SAVANNAHS RAPIDLY TRANSITION (WITHIN 10-15 YEARS) FROM AN OPEN UNDERSTORY WITH A DIVERSE GROUND COVER LAYER OF WARM SEASON BUNCH GRASSES AND FORBS TO AN UNDERSTORY INFESTED WITH WOODY BRUSH. THESE DEGRADED SAVANNAHS ARE A HAZARD FOR BOTH HUMANS AND WILDLIFE DUE TO THE EXCESSIVE WOODY FUEL FOR WILDFIRES AND THEY ALSO REDUCE PRODUCTIVITY AND RESULT IN A STATE SHIFT TO A MORE MESIC UNDERSTORY WITH LITTLE LIGHT REACHING THE FOREST FLOOR (SPARKS ET AL., 2012). FORTUNATELY, WE HAVE THE TOOLS IN PLACE TO RESTORE THESE DEGRADED SAVANNAHS. SELECTIVELY REMOVING THE UNDERSTORY BRUSH LAYER USING A FORESTRY MULCHER, ALLOWING SUNLIGHT TO PENETRATE TO THE FLOOR AND FOLLOWING UP WITH HERBICIDE AND PRESCRIBED FIRE HAS BEEN DEMONSTRATED TO HAVE POSITIVE IMPACTS ON THE STRUCTURE AND COMPOSITION OF SAVANNAH ECOSYSTEMS (MITCHELL ET AL., 2005  MCINNERNEY ET AL., 2020).HERE WE PROPOSE TO ENHANCE OUR ABILITIES TO IMPLEMENT THESE RESTORATION TOOLS ON PRIVATE PROPERTY TO IMPROVE HABITAT FOR THE HOUSTON TOAD. WE PROPOSE TO HIRE A DEDICATED CONSERVATION DELIVERY SPECIALIST TO INCREASE OUR CAPACITY TO WORK WITH LANDOWNERS THROUGHOUT THE RANGE OF THE HOUSTON TOAD AND TO PROVIDE COST-SHARE FUNDS TO PRIVATE LANDOWNERS WILLING TO IMPLEMENT HABITAT MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. WHILE THE TARGET SPECIES OF THIS PROJECT IS THE HOUSTON TOAD, NUMEROUS OTHER SGCN SPECIES THAT RELY ON OPEN PINE-OAK SAVANNAH HABITATS WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS RESTORATION WORK, SUCH AS NORTHERN BOBWHITE QUAIL (COLINUS VIRGINIANUS).

CASCADES FROGS (RANA CASCADAE) ARE CURRENTLY UNDER REVIEW FOR LISTING UNDER BOTH THE CALIFORNIA AND FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACTS, IN PART DUE TO DRAMATIC DECLINES AT THE SOUTHERN END OF ITS RANGE (CALIFORNIA S LASSEN REGION). KEY THREATS IN THIS REGION INCLUDE DISEASE CAUSED BY THE FUNGAL PATHOGEN BATRACHOCHYTRIUM DENDROBATIDIS (BD) AND CLIMATE CHANGE. MAINTAINING LONG-TERM VIABILITY IN THIS REGION WILL REQUIRE MANAGING REMNANT POPULATIONS FOR DISEASE AND FOSTERING CLIMATE RESILIENCE. THIS PROJECT WILL: 1) USE ANTI-FUNGAL TREATMENT OF JUVENILE FROGS TO ENHANCE THE GROWTH RATE OF AT-RISK REMNANT POPULATIONS THREATENED BY BD, 2) CONTINUE ONGOING CAPTURE-MARK RECAPTURE AND DISEASE MONITORING SURVEYS IN REMNANT POPULATIONS, AND 3) ANALYZE LONG-TERM DATASETS FROM THESE SITES TO INVESTIGATE THE EFFECTS OF BD AND CLIMATE ON CASCADES FROG POPULATION DYNAMICS AT THESE LOCATIONS. THE PROJECT BUILDS ON EXISTING COLLABORATIONS BETWEEN CDFW AND UNIVERSITY RESEARCHERS, PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, AND US FOREST SERVICE BIOLOGISTS. THE PROJECT WILL ENHANCE COLLABORATION BETWEEN THESE GROUPS AND PROVIDE A STRONG FOUNDATION FOR EFFORTS TO CONSERVE AND MANAGE THE CASCADES FROG IN THE LASSEN REGION.

MOLLUSKS (E.G., SNAILS AND MUSSELS) ARE A GROUP OF ANIMALS THAT ARE DECLINING GLOBALLY (LYDEARD ET AL. 2004  FOONET AL. 2017). LAND SNAILS ARE A DIVERSE GROUP OF ANIMALS THAT HAVE A COILED SHELL AND ONE FOOT  HOWEVER, THESESMALL ANIMALS OFTEN GO UNNOTICED DESPITE THEIR CRITICAL ECOSYSTEM SERVICE OF BREAKING DOWN ORGANIC MATTER. ABOUT1200 SPECIES OF SNAILS ARE KNOWN FROM NORTH AMERICAN NORTH OF MEXICO (NEKOLA 2014) AND 36  OF SPECIES ARECONSIDERED IMPERILED OR CRITICALLY IMPERILED. IN FACT, NON-MARINE MOLLUSKS (E.G., TERRESTRIAL SNAILS, AND FRESHWATER SNAILS AND MUSSELS) HAVE THE HIGHEST NUMBER OF DOCUMENTED EXTINCTIONS OF ANY ANIMAL GROUP (LYDEARD ET AL. 2004  COWIE ET AL. 2017) AND LIKELY MANY UNDOCUMENTED EXTINCTIONS (TEDESCO ET AL. 2014  RGNIER ET AL. 2015). THEREFORE, TERRESTRIAL AND FRESHWATER MOLLUSKS ARE ONE OF THE MOST HIGHLY IMPERILED GROUPS OF ANIMALS IN THE UNITED STATES.LAND SNAILS ARE PARTICULARLY IMPERILED DUE TO THEIR LIFE HISTORY TRAITS. FOR EXAMPLE, SNAILS MOVE SMALL DISTANCES WHICH RESTRICTS DISPERSAL AND GENE FLOW (OVERTON ET AL. 2009) WHICH CAN CAUSE LOCAL ENDEMIC SPECIES TO ARISE. CLIMATE CHANGE MAY HAVE THE GREATEST EFFECT ON HIGH ELEVATION SPECIES, SUCH AS SNAILS IN THE GENUS OREOHELIX (MOUNTAIN SNAILS). SPECIES RANGES MAY SHIFT TO HIGHER ELEVATIONS AS CLIMATE WARMS  HOWEVER, SUCH SPECIES WILL LIKELY HAVE A LIMITED AREA TO MOVE TO (MULLER ET AL. 2009). RISING AIR TEMPERATURES, DRIER CONDITIONS AND ASSOCIATED CHANGES IN VEGETATION ARE PREDICTED TO MODIFY LAND SNAIL RESOURCES, ABUNDANCE AND DIVERSITY OVER TIME (BAKER ET AL. 2013  BELTRAMINO ET AL. 2015  WEHNER ET AL. 2019).LAND USE AND ABIOTIC CONDITIONS IN BOTH FORESTED AND GRASSLAND ECOSYSTEMS CAN ALTER THEIR DENSITY AND DIVERSITY(WEHNER ET AL. 2019). FOR EXAMPLE, LOGGING CAN DECREASE THE ABUNDANCE AND DIVERSITY OF LAND SNAILS, ESPECIALLYFOR RARER SPECIES (HYLANDER ET AL. 2004  PUIG-GIRONES ET AL. 2023), BUT USING VARIABLE-RETENTION TECHNIQUES CANHELP RETAIN SPECIES (OVASKA ET AL. 2016). INTERESTINGLY, LAND SNAILS WERE FOUND TO BE FAIRLY RESISTANT TO WILDFIRE AND THEIR RECOVERY MIRRORED THAT OF THE LANDSCAPE (KISS AND MAGNIN 2006).IN THE BLACK HILLS, 38 TO 39 SPECIES OF LAND SNAILS ARE REPORTED (FREST AND JOHANNES 2002  ANDERSON 2004) AND THE BLACK HILLS NATIONAL FOREST LISTS FIVE LAND SNAILS AS SPECIES OF CONCERN BECAUSE OF THEIR RARITY AND POTENTIAL DECLINES. OREOHELIX COOPERI (OR OREOHELIX STRIGOSA COOPERI) IS A FOREST SERVICE SENSITIVE SPECIES IN REGION 2. OREOHELIX IS A LARGE ( 20 MM DIAMETER), CONSPICUOUS SNAIL THAT ONLY LIVES IN THE BLACK HILLS AREA. FOUR OTHER SNAILS ARE SPECIES OF LOCAL CONCERN: DISCUS SHIMEKII, CATINELLA GELIDA, VERTIGO ARTHURI, AND VERTIGO PARADOXA. DISCUS SHIMEKII AND CATINELLA GELIDA ARE GENERALLY 5-7 MM IN DIAMETER AND HEIGHT, RESPECTIVELY. VERTIGO ARTHURIAND VERTIGO PARADOXA ARE VERY SMALL ( 2 MM IN HEIGHT) SNAILS. FREST AND JOHANNES (1993, 2002) SURVEYED FOR LAND SNAILS IN THE BLACK HILLS TWICE IN THE 1990S. DURING THEIR LATER SURVEY IN 1999 THEY VISITED 357 SITES IN THE BLACK HILLS REGION AND THEY FOUND AT LEAST ONE SPECIES OF INTEREST AT 164 SITES. TRONSTAD AND ANDERSEN (2011) REVISITED 45 SITES WITH SNAILS OF INTEREST IN 2010 TO RE-EVALUATE THESE SPECIES AND THEY ESTABLISHED A SAMPLING PLAN TO MONITOR THEM INTO THE FUTURE.

THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE AND BUILD UPON ONGOING WORK TO ADDRESS THE THREAT OF A DEADLY FUNGAL DISEASE IN BATS, WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME (WNS). IT WILL SUPPORT ONGOING RESPONSE EFFORTS IN CALIFORNIA THROUGH BAT POPULATION MONITORING AND SURVEILLANCE FOR THE FUNGUS, AND OTHER WNS RESPONSE ACTIVITIES. THE WORK WILL BE LED BY SENIOR CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) STAFF IN THE WILDLIFE BRANCH, WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF TWO TO THREE SCIENTIFIC AIDES FUNDED BY THE GRANT. RESULTS OF THE PROJECT WILL IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING OF THE DISEASE S IMPACTS TO CALIFORNIA S BAT POPULATIONS AND INFORM DECISIONS TO MINIMIZE THESE IMPACTS, AS WELL AS FOCUS TREATMENT OPTIONS AT LOCATIONS POPULATIONS MOST AT RISK. ADDITIONAL BENEFITS TO BAT CONSERVATION WILL BE DERIVED FROM OBJECTIVES RELATED TO PARTICIPATION IN THE NORTH AMERICAN BAT MONITORING PROGRAM (NABAT), DATABASE MANAGEMENT, AND PUBLIC OUTREACH AND EDUCATION.

THIS IS A PLANNING GRANT TO FUND THE 2025 COMPREHENSIVE REVISION OF THE OKLAHOMA COMPREHENSIVE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION STRATEGY (AKA OKLAHOMA WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN). EVERY SECTION OF THE OKLAHOMA COMPREHENSIVE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION STRATEGY (OCWCS) WILL BE REVIEWED AND UPDATED AS NEEDED TO INCORPORATE NEW INFORMATION THAT HAS BEEN COLLECTED SINCE THE PREVIOUS COMPREHENSIVE REVISION WAS COMPLETED IN 2015. THE SCOPE OF THIS GRANT IS STATEWIDE IN THE SENSE THAT OCWCS WILL INCLUDE CONSERVATION ISSUES, ACTIONS, MONITORING PROTOCOLS, AND HABITAT INFORMATION REGARDING SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF OKLAHOMA. ADDITIONALLY, INPUT WILL BE SOLICITED AND INCORPORATED INTO THE OCWCS FROM STAKEHOLDERS AND TECHNICAL EXPERTS ACROSS THE ENTIRE STATE. THE CURRENT VERSION OF THE OKLAHOMA COMPREHENSIVE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION STRATEGY WILL BE REVIEWED AND EDITED WITH ODWC BIOLOGISTS TAKING THE LEAD IN SOLICITING DATA AND COMMENTS FROM TECHNICAL EXPERTS, STAKEHOLDERS AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC, INCORPORATING THESE DATA INTO THE REVISED DOCUMENT, AND THEN RELEASING THE REVISED DRAFT FOR A SECOND ROUND OF REVIEW AND COMMENTS. DURING THE REVIEW AND EDITING PROCESS, MEETINGS (IN-PERSON AND VIRTUAL) WILL BE HELD WITH TECHNICAL EXPERTS IN THE AREAS OF ZOOLOGY AND LAND MANAGEMENT FROM UNIVERSITIES  CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS, AND STATE, TRIBAL, AND FEDERAL NATURAL RESOURCE AGENCIES (INCLUDING INTERNAL EXPERTS WITHIN ODWC). SPECIFIC ATTENTION WILL BE DIRECTED AT UPDATING THE CRITERIA USED TO IDENTIFY AND RANK OKLAHOMA S SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN)  INCORPORATING NEW INFORMATION REGARDING THE STATUSES AND DISTRIBUTIONS OF SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED AND THE HABITATS THAT ARE IMPORTANT TO THEM  EMERGING CONSERVATION ISSUES  POTENTIAL CONSERVATION ACTIONS TO ADDRESS THESE ISSUES, AND IMPROVEMENTS TO THE POTENTIAL MONITORING METRICS AND PROGRAMS FOR EVALUATING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF CONSERVATION MEASURES. EXISTING SHORT SECTIONS OF THE OCWCS THAT ADDRESS MONITORING PROGRAMS, AND IDENTIFY CONSERVATION EDUCATION, RECREATION, AND LAW ENFORCEMENT ACTIVITIES THAT MAY BENEFIT OKLAHOMA S SGCN WILL BE UPDATED AND EXPANDED. THE PROCESS THAT IS USED TO IDENTIFY AND RANK SGCN, WILL BE APPLIED TO OKLAHOMA S NATIVE PLANT TAXA TO DEVELOP A LIST OF PLANT SPECIES THAT ARE IN NEED OF GREATER CONSERVATION ATTENTION. MAPS WILL BE PREPARED TO DEPICT THE CURRENT DISTRIBUTION AND THE ESTIMATED ACREAGE OF KEY HABITAT TYPES THAT ARE IMPORTANT TO SGCN AND THAT ARE MAPPABLE ON A REGIONAL OR STATEWIDE SCALE. DISTRIBUTION MAPS WILL BE CREATED OR UPDATED FOR TIER I AND TIER II SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED BASED ON EXISTING SPATIAL DATA. THESE MAPS WILL BE EXAMINED IN CONJUNCTION WITH CURRENT VEGETATION MAPS TO IDENTIFY AND DELINEATE LANDSCAPES THAT ARE BIOLOGICALLY UNIQUE AND CAN SERVE AS OPPORTUNITY AREAS FOR THE CONSERVATION OF THE SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED. FOCUSED MEETINGS (IN-PERSON AND OR VIRTUAL) WILL BE ARRANGED TO IMPROVE THE DIALOG BETWEEN ODWC AND STAKEHOLDER GROUPS THAT ARE HIGHLY RELEVANT TO THE CONSERVATION OF OKLAHOMA S SGCN INCLUDING LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES, NONGOVERNMENTAL CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS, AND NATIVE AMERICAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS. THESE ENTITIES WILL BE CONTACTED TO OBTAIN THEIR FEEDBACK REGARDING HOW TO MAKE THE OCWCS MORE RELEVANT TO THEIR PROGRAMS AND HOW TO STRUCTURE THE OCWCS TO MAKE IT MORE READILY TRANSLATABLE TO THEIR PROGRAMS. TECHNICAL EXPERTS AND STAKEHOLDERS WILL BE CONTACTED FOR THEIR INPUT PRIOR TO THE EDITING PROCESS OF THE OCWCS, AND THESE SAME PEOPLE WILL BE ASKED TO REVIEW AND PROVIDE ADDITIONAL EDITS, COMMENTS, AND RELEVANT INFORMATION FOR EACH CHAPTER AND APPENDIX OF THE OCWCS AS EACH IS DEVELOPED.

THE NEBRASKA NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM MAINTAINS A COMPREHENSIVE DATABASE FOR ALL OF THE STATE S AT-RISK SPECIES, NATURAL COMMUNITIES, AND BIOLOGICALLY UNIQUE LANDSCAPES AS IDENTIFIED IN THE STATE S WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN, THE NEBRASKA NATURAL LEGACY PROJECT. THIS GRANT WILL FUND HERITAGE STAFF TO ACQUIRE AND ENTER DATA, CONDUCT ANALYSES, AND DEVELOP INFORMATION PRODUCTS TO STAFF AND CONSERVATION PARTNERS ACROSS THE STATE. THE HERITAGE DATABASE (BIOTICS) IS OPERATED BY NATURESERVE WITH AN ANNUAL FEE FOR THE HERITAGE PROGRAM TO USE IT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SEARCH FOR AND PROTECT LARGE NESTING COLONIES OF TRICOLORED BLACKBIRDS ON AGRICULTURAL GRAIN CROPS THAT ARE THREATENED WITH DESTRUCTION DUE TO HARVEST. WHERE POSSIBLE, REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS OF BREEDING COLONIES WILL BE ESTIMATED TO EVALUATE THE IMPACT OF COLONY PROTECTION PROGRAMS. THESE ACTIONS ARE HIGH PRIORITY GOALS OF THE TRICOLORED BLACKBIRD CONSERVATION PLAN (TBWG 2007). THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE PROVEN PROGRAMS THAT DETECT, MONITOR, AND PROTECT COLONIES THAT OCCUR ON AGRICULTURAL GRAIN FIELDS. OVER THREE BREEDING SEASONS, FIELD WORK WILL BE CONDUCTED TO LOCATE AND MONITOR ALL TRICOLORED BLACKBIRD BREEDING COLONIES ON GRAIN FIELDS IN THE SAN JOAQUIN VALLEY. LANDOWNERS WILL BE OFFERED PARTICIPATION IN COLONY PROTECTION PROGRAMS ADMINISTERED BY THE NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION SERVICE (NRCS). CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) STAFF WILL COLLABORATE WITH AGENCIES, NON-PROFITS, AND DAIRY TRADE ORGANIZATIONS TO COORDINATE FIELDWORK, OUTREACH EFFORTS, AND ENROLLMENT IN COLONY PROTECTION PROGRAMS.

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO CONTRIBUTE TO CONSERVATION OF THE TRICOLORED BLACKBIRD (AGELAIUS TRICOLOR) IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA (1) BY IDENTIFYING AND FILLING GAPS IN CURRENT SURVEYS IN THE REGION, ESPECIALLY OF NON-CONSERVED LANDS, (2) THROUGH FOCUSED STUDIES AT TWO KEY COLONIES, RANCHO JAMUL ECOLOGICAL RESERVE (RJER) AND SAN JACINTO WILDLIFE AREA (SJWA), AND (3) VIA PUBLIC OUTREACH. SURVEYS WILL REVEAL NEW COLONIES AND SITES WITH RESTORATION POTENTIAL. FOCUSED STUDY AT TWO OF THE FEW KNOWN REMAINING COLONIES WILL QUANTIFY LARGE-SCALE MOVEMENTS AND FORAGING REQUIREMENTS, AND IDENTIFY THREATS. RESULTS WILL INFORM THE TRICOLORED BLACKBIRD CONSERVATION STRATEGY SPECIFIC TO THIS REGION. OUTREACH TO THE PUBLIC AND TO SPECIFIC LANDOWNERS WILL AIM TO LOCATE ADDITIONAL COLONIES, IMPROVE AWARENESS, AND INCREASE PROTECTION ON BOTH CONSERVED AND NON-CONSERVED LANDS. SAN DIEGO NATURAL HISTORY MUSEUM (SDNHM) STAFF WILL LEAD THE SURVEYS AND FOCUSED STUDIES OVER TWO NESTING SEASONS, AS WELL AS THE OUTREACH. IDENTIFICATION OF ADDITIONAL SITES IS CRITICAL BECAUSE THE COLONIES CONFIRMED ACTIVE BY RECENT SURVEYS ARE SO FEW AS TO BE PROBABLY INSUFFICIENT TO SUSTAIN THE SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA BREEDING POPULATION OVER THE LONG TERM. CDFW STAFF WILL COORDINATE AND COLLABORATE WITH THE SDNHM TO WORK IN BOTH THE SOUTH COAST AND INLAND DESERT REGIONS AND WILL PROVIDE SUPPORT THROUGH PROJECT AND CONTRACT MANAGEMENT, ASSISTANCE IN FIELD SURVEYS, AND GIS SUPPORT. THE PROJECT TARGETS HIGH-PRIORITY GOALS OF THE TRICOLORED BLACKBIRD CONSERVATION PLAN (TBWG 2007) AND IS CONSISTENT WITH SOC PRIORITIES.

CALIFORNIA S SOUTH COAST REGION (SCR) ENCOMPASSES MORE THAN 8 MILLION ACRES, EXTENDING ALONG THE COAST FROM SANTA BARBARA COUNTY IN THE NORTH TO THE MEXICO BORDER IN THE SOUTH AND IS HOME TO NEARLY HALF OF THE STATE S POPULATION, WITH OVER 17 MILLION PEOPLE IN THE FIVE COASTAL COUNTIES. DESPITE THE EXTENSIVE DEVELOPMENT, THE SCR IS A BIOLOGICAL HOTSPOT WITH MORE THAN 150 VERTEBRATE ANIMAL SPECIES AND 200 SPECIES OF PLANTS EITHER LISTED AS PROTECTED OR CONSIDERED SENSITIVE BY WILDLIFE AGENCIES AND CONSERVATION GROUPS (HUNTER 1999). MANY OF THESE SPECIES ARE IDENTIFIED AS SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) IN CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE S (DEPARTMENT) 2015 CALIFORNIA STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP), WHICH IDENTIFIES CONSERVATION STRATEGIES FOR IMPROVING THE CONDITIONS OF SGCN AND THE HABITATS UPON WHICH THEY DEPEND. THE 2015 SWAP DEFINES SGCN AS 1) SPECIES LISTED AT THREATENED, ENDANGERED, OR CANDIDATE SPECIES IN CALIFORNIA UNDER THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA) OR THE CALIFORNIA ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (CESA)  2) SPECIES FOR WHICH THERE IS A CONSERVATION CONCERN (GENERALLY EQUIVALENT TO CALIFORNIA SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN)  OR 3) SPECIES IDENTIFIED BY THE DEPARTMENT AS BEING HIGHLY VULNERABLE TO CLIMATE CHANGE. CLIMATE CHANGE MODELING HAS SHOWN THAT THE SCR WILL UNDERGO BOTH HOTTER AND DRIER CONDITIONS (HE ET AL., 2018) AND A POTENTIAL SEA-LEVEL RISE OF 50 CM IN LOS ANGELES, ORANGE, AND SAN DIEGO COUNTIES (ERICKSON ET AL., 2018). THESE INCREASED CHALLENGES HAVE CREATED THE NEED FOR THE SCR TO FURTHER INVESTIGATE THE TREND OF CERTAIN SGCN IDENTIFIED IN THE SWAP. SPECIFICALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL SURVEY BAT TAXA, AND THE FOLLOWING SGCN - CALIFORNIA LEAST TERN  CLTE (STERNA ANTILLARUM BROWNI) , WESTERN SNOWY PLOVER  WSPL (CHARADRIUS ALEXANDRINUS NIVOSUS) , UNARMORED THREESPINE STICKLEBACK  UTS (GASTEROSTEUS ACULEATUS WILLIAMSONI) , MOUNTAIN YELLOW-LEGGED FROG  MYLF (RANA MUSCOSA) , BURROWING OWL  BUOW (ATHENE CUNICULARIA) , AND ARROYO TOAD (ANAXYRUS CALIFORNICUS). THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO DEPLOY UP TO 50 CAMERAS IN THE SCR TO FURTHER DOCUMENT BASELINE WILDLIFE INFORMATION. THE INFORMATION COLLECTED FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO DEPARTMENT DATABASE SYSTEMS SUCH AS THE CALIFORNIA NATURAL DIVERSITY DATABASE (CNDDB) AND SCR S REGIONAL DATABASE, THE FIELDWORK DATA MANAGEMENT APPLICATION (FDMA), AND OTHER RELATED COLLABORATIVE TOOLS. IN ADDITION, THIS INFORMATION AND DATA WILL BE USED FOR FURTHER RECOVERY ANALYSES BY THE DEPARTMENT, U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS), AND OTHER COLLABORATORS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS STUDY IS TO EVALUATE THE RELIABILITY OF THIN-SECTIONING MUSSELS TO ESTIMATE AGE AND GROWTH. THIS INFORMATION IS USEFUL FOR UNDERSTANDING WHY SOME MUSSEL POPULATIONS HAVE PERSISTED WHILE OTHERS HAVE BEEN EXTIRPATED. AGE, GROWTH, AND LONGEVITY DATA CAN ALSO HELP WITH PREDICTING HOW POPULATIONS WILL RESPOND TO FUTURE CHANGES IN HABITAT AND CLIMATE. UNDERSTANDING BOTH THINGS, CURRENT AND FUTURE CONDITION, IS CRITICAL TO DEVELOPING RECOVERY PLANS FOCUSED ON DELISTING DOWNLISTING.

THE REGIONAL CONSERVATION NEEDS (RCN) PROGRAM FORMALIZES A COOPERATIVE APPROACH TO ACTIONS THAT ADDRESS SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) ACROSS MULTIPLE STATES. THE PURPOSE OF THE RCN GRANTS IS TO DEVELOP, COORDINATE, AND IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION ACTIONS THAT ARE REGIONAL SUB-REGIONAL IN SCOPE, AND BUILD UPON THE MANY REGIONAL INITIATIVES THAT ALREADY EXIST. THE RCN PROGRAM UTILIZES A FUNDING MECHANISM THAT IS EQUITABLE TO ALL NORTHEAST STATES AND THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, CREATING A BASE OF FUNDING FOR REGIONAL PROJECTS. THE RCN 3 GRANTS SUPPORT THE OVERALL ADMINISTRATION OF THE RCN PROGRAM, PLUS 6 PROJECTS THAT ADDRESS HIGH PRIORITY SGCN AND REGIONAL ISSUES. THESE ARE: REGIONAL COORDINATION OF INVERTEBRATE CONSERVATION  TIGER BEETLE STATUS ASSESSMENT AND SURVEY METHODS  STONEFLY STATUS ASSESSMENT  NORTHERN DIAMONDBACK TERRAPIN SURVEY METHODS  RENEWABLE ENERGY WHITE PAPER AND IMPACT ANALYSIS  AND REGIONAL TECHNICAL SUPPORT SERVICES. THE EXPECTED RESULTS OF THIS GRANT WILL BE STANDARDIZED SURVEY PROTOCOLS THAT WILL BE IMPLEMENTED WITHIN THE NORTHEAST, AN ANALYSIS OF THE IMPACTS OF RENEWABLE ENERGY DEVELOPMENT ON SGCN, AND CONTINUED MAINTENANCE AND DEVELOPMENT OF REGIONAL ANALYSIS OF STATUS, THREATS, AND CONSERVATION ACTIONS FOR REGIONAL SGCN.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PUBLIC WHO USE AND APPRECIATE SGCN AND THEIR HABITATS. THERE ARE SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, AS IDENTIFIED IN THE PROJECT NARRATIVES.

RENEWABLE DIESEL IS DERIVED FROM NON-PETROLEUM FEEDSTOCKS SUCH AS ALGAE, PLANTS, ANIMAL FATS, VEGETABLE OIL OR WASTE OILS VIA THE PROCESS OF HYDRODEOXYGENATION. IT LACKS MEASURABLE PETROLEUM BIOMARKERS AND POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC HYDROCARBONS. WHEN COMPARED TO CONVENTIONAL DIESEL FUEL, THE AROMATIC CONTENT OF PURE RENEWABLE DIESEL IS REDUCED. THE AROMATIC FRACTION OF FUELS IS OF TOXICOLOGICAL INTEREST AND ITS REDUCTION IN RENEWABLE DIESEL MAKES IT LIKELY THAT ITS TOXICITY WILL ALSO BE REDUCED. HOWEVER, THE TOXICITY OF RENEWABLE DIESEL IS LARGELY UNTESTED. BLENDED RENEWABLE FUELS ARE COMPLEX MIXTURES AND LIKELY TO HAVE DIFFERENT TOXICITY PROFILES THAN THE PURE PRODUCT. IT IS THOUGHT THAT RENEWABLE FUELS MAY ELICIT SIMILAR ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS AS THEIR PETROLEUM COUNTERPARTS. HOWEVER, VERY LITTLE INFORMATION IS AVAILABLE TO CORROBORATE THAT CLAIM. TO REDUCE THE DATA GAP, WE WILL CONDUCT TOXICITY STUDIES USING STANDARD TESTING PROTOCOLS THAT WILL ASSESS IMPACTS TO MARINE, FRESHWATER, AND TERRESTRIAL ORGANISMS FROM RELEASE OF RENEWABLE FUELS. WHEN PETROLEUM-BASED FUELS ARE SPILLED INTO THE ENVIRONMENT, MANY FATE AND EFFECTS PROCESSES OCCUR LEADING TO PHYSICAL AND CHEMICAL CHANGES TO THE FUEL. THE ENVIRONMENTAL FATE OF RENEWABLE DIESEL IS ASSUMED TO BE SIMILAR TO THAT OF CONVENTIONAL DIESEL FUEL. WHEN RELEASED INTO AQUATIC ENVIRONMENTS, PETROLEUM FUELS, RENEWABLE DIESEL FEEDSTOCKS, AND BIODIESEL CAN IMPACT THE DISSOLVED OXYGEN IN THE WATER. THIS RESULTS IN HIGH BIOLOGICAL OXYGEN DEMAND (BOD), LEADING TO FISH KILLS AS LARGE AMOUNTS OF DISSOLVED OXYGEN ARE CONSUMED TO DEGRADE THE FUEL. IT HAS BEEN FOUND THAT BIODIESEL HAS A HIGHER BIOLOGICAL OXYGEN DEMAND WHEN DISCHARGED TO WATER. SINCE BIODIESEL AND RENEWABLE DIESEL USE SIMILAR FEEDSTOCKS, WE ANTICIPATE THE BOD OF RENEWABLE DIESEL AND ITS BLENDS TO BE LIKE THAT OF BIODIESEL. WE PROPOSE TO DETERMINE THE BOD OF RENEWABLE DIESEL USING STANDARD TESTING PROTOCOLS AS THIS INFORMATION IS NOT CURRENTLY AVAILABLE WITHIN THE LITERATURE. THE OUTLINED STUDIES AIM TO ANSWER THE FOLLOWING QUESTIONS: (1) WHAT EFFECTS DOES RENEWABLE DIESEL AND ITS BLENDS CAUSE TO MARINE FISH AND INVERTEBRATES, FRESHWATER FISH AND INVERTEBRATES AND TERRESTRIAL INVERTEBRATES   (2) HOW DOES RENEWABLE DIESEL AND ITS BLENDS IMPACT THE BIOLOGICAL OXYGEN DEMAND (BOD)   AND (3) WHAT ARE THE PHYSICAL EFFECTS OF RENEWABLE DIESEL ON SEABIRD FEATHERS AND OTTER FUR  THESE STUDIES WILL BENEFIT THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY BY CONTRIBUTING TO THE COLLECTION OF OIL SPILL DATA AND HELPING FILL THE DATA GAP FOR RENEWABLE FUEL TOXICITY.

THE REGIONAL CONSERVATION NEEDS (RCN) PROGRAM FORMALIZES A COOPERATIVE APPROACH TO ADDRESS SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) NEEDS ACROSS MULTIPLE STATES. THE PURPOSE OF THE RCN PROGRAM IS TO DEVELOP, COORDINATE, AND IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION ACTIONS THAT ARE REGIONAL SUB-REGIONAL IN SCOPE, AND BUILD UPON THE MANY REGIONAL INITIATIVES THAT ALREADY EXIST.

THE PURPOSE OF THE RCN GRANTS IS TO DEVELOP, COORDINATE, AND IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION ACTIONS THAT ARE REGIONAL SUB-REGIONAL IN SCOPE, AND BUILD UPON THE MANY REGIONAL INITIATIVES THAT ALREADY EXIST. THIS APPLICATION COMMITS THE FFY 23 APPROPRIATED SWG FUNDS THROUGH 7 NEW PROJECTS. THERE ARE OVER 800 MAMMALS, BIRDS, REPTILES, AMPHIBIANS, FISH, MOLLUSK AND CRUSTACEANS IN WYOMING, AS WELL AS HUNDREDS OF INSECTS AND OTHER INVERTEBRATES. OF THOSE 800, THERE ARE 278 SPECIES IDENTIFIED TO BE IN GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED IN WYOMING. OVER 80 SPECIES ARE CURRENTLY CONSIDERED TO BE AT SOME RISK OF LISTING UNDER THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. MANY OF THESE SPECIES ARE THOSE THAT HAVE THE LEAST AVAILABLE DATA CONCERNING THEIR STATUS, DISTRIBUTION AND HABITATS. NON-GAME SPECIES, NATIVE FISH SPECIES, REPTILES, AND AMPHIBIANS ARE ALL UNDER-FUNDED AND IN NEED OFSPECIAL CONSIDERATION.

THE NEVADA STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP) PROVIDES THE FRAMEWORK TO SET SPECIES-SPECIFIC PRIORITIES, FOCUSCONSERVATION EFFORTS, AND DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES FOR NEVADA S NATIVE AQUATIC SPECIES OFGREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN). EVEN WITH THE ARID CLIMATE AND LIMITED WATER RESOURCES, NEVADA S AQUATICHABITATS SUPPORT MORE AT-RISK, THREATENED, AND ENDANGERED SPECIES THAN ANY OTHER STATE AND IS HOME TO 173 ENDEMIC SPECIES THAT ARE FOUND NOWHERE ELSE ON THE PLANET. AMONG THE FIFTY STATES, NEVADA RANKS ELEVENTH IN OVERALL BIODIVERSITY IN TERMS OF PLANT AND ANIMAL SPECIES. FUNDAMENTAL TO ALL SPECIES PROTECTION, CONSERVATION, ANDMANAGEMENT EFFORTS IS THE NEED FOR DETAILED, COMPREHENSIVE, UP-TO-DATE KNOWLEDGE AND DATA ON ALL SPECIES ANDHABITATS. INFORMATION ON SPECIES  LIFE HISTORY, DISTRIBUTION, POPULATION STATUS AND TREND, HABITAT CONDITIONS,AND SPECIES INTERACTIONS IS NEEDED TO ASSESS RISK AND DEVELOP SOUND MANAGEMENT, CONSERVATION, AND RECOVERYSTRATEGIES FOR ALL NATIVE, AQUATIC NON-GAME SPECIES.THE NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE (NDOW), IN MANY CASES, FILLS THE PRIMARY ROLE OF DESIGNING AND IMPLEMENTINGSURVEY, MONITORING, MANAGEMENT, AND CONSERVATION STRATEGIES FOR SWAP PRIORITY AQUATIC SPECIES AND ASSOCIATEDHABITATS IN NEVADA. TO PROTECT AND PRESERVE OUR NATIVE SPECIES, ADEQUATE FUNDING MUST BE SECURED FOR EFFECTIVECONSERVATION PLANNING AND COORDINATION. THIS PROJECT WILL ENABLE NDOW TO CONTINUE TO IMPLEMENT THE SWAP ANDACCOMPLISH THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES: PREPARE PROPOSALS, WORK PLANS, BUDGETS AND REPORTS  COORDINATE AND IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES FOR NATIVE AQUATIC SPECIES THROUGH RESEARCH, SURVEY, MONITORING, DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS  IDENTIFY AND CARRY OUT SPECIES REINTRODUCTIONS AND REPATRIATION ACTIVITIES WHEN NECESSARY  DEVELOP NEW AND MAINTAIN EXISTING DATABASES AND LONG-TERM DATA SETS  DEVELOP AND PREPARE CONSERVATION PLANS, AGREEMENTS AND STRATEGIES, AND PARTICIPATE IN MULTI-PARTNER CONSERVATION PLANNING PROCESSES  IMPLEMENT DIRECT HABITAT AND SPECIES MANAGEMENT AND RESTORATION  COORDINATE WITH AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO OTHER AGENCIES, PARTNERS AND PRIVATE CITIZENS  AND ADDRESS THREATS TO NATIVE AQUATIC SPECIES, ESPECIALLY FROM INVASIVE NON-NATIVE SPECIES. JUST A FEW OF THE AT-RISK SPECIES THAT WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT FROM THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS SPECIFIC PROJECT INCLUDE: FLANNELMOUTH, WALL CANYON AND RAZORBACK SUCKERS  SPECKLED AND RELICT DACE  TUI CHUB  ASH MEADOWS AMARGOSA AND WARM SPRINGS PUPFISH  NORTHERN LEATHERSIDE CHUB  AMARGOSA AND RAILROAD VALLEY TOADS  NORTHERN AND RELICT LEOPARD FROGS, AND THE COLUMBIA SPOTTED FROG.THROUGH CONTINUALLY IMPROVING AND EXPANDING OUR KNOWLEDGE BASE, AND ENHANCED DATA MANAGEMENT AND ACCESSIBILITY, NDOW WILL BE BETTER ABLE TO PREDICT SPECIES RISK, PRIORITIZE SPECIES, AND DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION STRATEGIES FOR AQUATIC SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED. THE INFORMATION AND DATA GATHERED THROUGH THESE FUNDED PROJECTS WILL ENSURE THAT THE STATE S MOST SENSITIVE AQUATIC WILDLIFE SPECIES ARE CONSIDERED AND CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT PLANS ARE DEVELOPED AND IMPLEMENTED WHERE NEEDED. DEVELOPING EDUCATIONAL AND OUTREACH CONTENT WILL RAISE PUBLIC AND PARTNER AWARENESS OF AQUATIC WILDLIFE NEEDS AND CONCERNS. EXPECTED RESULTS INCLUDE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF SURVEY AND MONITORING ACTIVITIES AND UPDATED POPULATION STATUS INFORMATION  CONTINUATION OF HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS AND SPECIES REINTRODUCTIONS  CONTINUED COORDINATION IN THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF MULTI-PARTY CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT PLANS, AGREEMENTS AND STRATEGIES  A REDUCTION IN NON-NATIVE INVASIVE SPECIES THREATS  FEWER FUTURE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA) LISTED SPECIES, AND PROGRESS TOWARDS THE RECOVERY OF THOSE ALREADY LISTED.

INSTREAM FLOWS ARE THREATENED BY ONGOING AND PLANNED WATER DEVELOPMENT ACROSS THE STATE AND ESPECIALLY WITHIN CENTRAL TEXAS, ONE OF THE FASTEST GROWING AREAS IN TEXAS AND THE UNITED STATES. STREAMFLOW IN THE UPPER COLORADO RIVER BASIN SUPPORTS A DIVERSE AQUATIC ECOSYSTEM INCLUDING 15 SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) MUSSELS AND FISHES (MAGNELIA ET AL. 2019). EXTREME HEAT, DROUGHTS, AND CLIMATE WARMING INCREASE RISK EXPOSURE (SEVERITY, DURATION, AND FREQUENCY) FOR THESE SPECIES. TO THAT END, THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES STREAMFLOW SHORTAGES IN PRIORITY CONSERVATION STREAMS THROUGH THE TERM LEASE OF TARGETED WATER RIGHTS AND CORRESPONDING RETENTION OF INSTREAM FLOW BENEFITS.

OVER 10,000 TERRESTRIAL AND AQUATIC SPECIES ARE UNIQUE TO HAWAI I. HAWAII I S 2015 STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLANLISTS THE FOLLOWING TAXA AS SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED: TERRESTRIAL MAMMAL (1), BIRDS (78),TERRESTRIAL INVERTEBRATES ( 5,000), FRESHWATER FISHES (5), FRESHWATER INVERTEBRATES (12), ANCHIALINE PONDASSOCIATEDFAUNA (20), MARINE MAMMALS (26), MARINE REPTILES (6), MARINE FISHES (151), AND MARINE INVERTEBRATES(197), PLUS 756 PLANTS. THE MAJOR THREATS AND CHALLENGES FACING HAWAIIS NATIVE WILDLIFE ARE IDENTIFIED IN THE2015 SWAP AS: LOSS AND DEGRADATION OF HABITAT RESULTING FROM HUMAN DEVELOPMENT, ALTERATION OF HYDROLOGY,WILDFIRE, RECREATIONAL OVERUSE, AND NATURAL DISASTER INVASIVE SPECIES (E.G., HABITAT MODIFIERS, INCLUDING WEEDS,UNGULATES, ALGAE AND CORALS, PREDATORS, COMPETITORS, DISEASE CARRIERS, AND DISEASES)  THE ECOLOGICAL CONSEQUENCESOF CLIMATE CHANGE  LIMITED INFORMATION AND INSUFFICIENT INFORMATION MANAGEMENT  UNEVEN COMPLIANCE WITH EXISTINGCONSERVATION LAWS, RULES, AND REGULATIONS  OVERHARVESTING AND EXCESSIVE EXTRACTIVE USE  MANAGEMENT CONSTRAINTS AND INADEQUATE FUNDING.TO ADDRESS THESE THREATS, THE 2015 SWAP IDENTIFIES MULTIPLE STRATEGIES TO IMPLEMENT THE FOLLOWING SEVEN PRIORITYCONSERVATION OBJECTIVES IN HAWAI I:1. MAINTAIN, PROTECT, MANAGE, AND RESTORE NATIVE SPECIES AND HABITATS IN SUFFICIENT QUANTITY AND QUALITY TO ALLOWNATIVE SPECIES TO THRIVE 2. COMBAT INVASIVE SPECIES THROUGH A THREE-TIERED APPROACH COMBINING PREVENTION AND INTERDICTION, EARLY DETECTIONAND RAPID RESPONSE, AND ONGOING CONTROL OR ERADICATION 3. DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT PROGRAMS TO OBTAIN, MANAGE, AND DISSEMINATE INFORMATION NEEDED TO GUIDE CONSERVATIONMANAGEMENT AND RECOVERY PROGRAMS 4. STRENGTHEN EXISTING AND CREATE NEW PARTNERSHIPS AND COOPERATIVE EFFORTS 5. EXPAND AND STRENGTHEN OUTREACH AND EDUCATION TO IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING OF OUR NATIVE WILDLIFE RESOURCES AMONGTHE PEOPLE OF HAWAII 6. SUPPORT POLICY CHANGES AIMED AT IMPROVING AND PROTECTING NATIVE SPECIES AND HABITATS  AND7. ENHANCE FUNDING OPPORTUNITIES TO IMPLEMENT NEEDED CONSERVATION ACTIONS.HAWAII S ANNUAL STATE WILDLIFE GRANT FUNDS THE MOST URGENT OF THE ACTIONS IN HAWAII S 2015 STATE WILDLIFE ACTIONPLAN.

THE REGIONAL CONSERVATION NEEDS (RCN) PROGRAM FORMALIZES A COOPERATIVE APPROACH TO ACTIONS THAT ADDRESS SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) ACROSS MULTIPLE STATES. THE PURPOSE OF THE RCN GRANT IS TO DEVELOP, COORDINATE, AND IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION ACTIONS THAT ARE REGIONAL SUB-REGIONAL IN SCOPE, AND BUILD UPON THE MANY REGIONAL INITIATIVES THAT ALREADY EXIST. THE RCN PROGRAM UTILIZES A FUNDING MECHANISM THAT IS EQUITABLE TO ALL NORTHEAST STATES AND THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, CREATING A BASE OF FUNDING FOR REGIONAL PROJECTS. THE RCN 3 GRANT SUPPORT THE OVERALL ADMINISTRATION OF THE RCN PROGRAM, PLUS 6 PROJECTS THAT ADDRESS HIGH PRIORITY SGCN AND REGIONAL ISSUES. THESE ARE: REGIONAL COORDINATION OF INVERTEBRATE CONSERVATION, TIGER BEETLE STATUS ASSESSMENT AND SURVEY METHODS  STONEFLY STATUS ASSESSMENT  NORTHERN DIAMONDBACK TERRAPIN SURVEY METHODS  RENEWABLE ENERGY WHITE PAPER AND IMPACT ANALYSIS  AND REGIONAL TECHNICAL SUPPORT SERVICES. THE EXPECTED RESULTS OF THIS GRANT WILL BE STANDARDIZED SURVEY PROTOCOLS THAT WILL BE IMPLEMENTED WITHIN THE NORTHEAST, AN ANALYSIS OF THE IMPACTS OF RENEWABLE ENERGY DEVELOPMENT ON SGCN, AND CONTINUED MAINTENANCE AND DEVELOPMENT OF REGIONAL ANALYSIS OF STATUS, THREATS, AND CONSERVATION ACTIONS FOR REGIONAL SGCN. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PUBLIC WHO USE AND APPRECIATE SGCN AND THEIR HABITATS. THERE ARE SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, AS IDENTIFIED IN THE PROJECT NARRATIVES.

GEORGIA DNRS FRESHWATER BIODIVERSITY PROGRAM HAS A CRITICAL ROLE IN IMPLEMENTING GEORGIAS SWAP FOR HIGHPRIORITY AQUATIC SPECIES AND HABITATS. OUR PROGRAM FOCUSES ON SURVEYS AND MONITORING, ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW OFPROJECTS THAT MAY IMPACT OR BENEFIT PRIORITY SPECIES, AND THE COORDINATION OF AQUATIC CONSERVATION AND RESEARCHEFFORTS. THE SCOPE OF THE PROGRAM HAS CONTINUED TO EXPAND AS WE DEVELOP NEW AND DEEPEN EXISTING PARTNERSHIPS WITH STAKEHOLDERS. FOR EXAMPLE, UNDER OUR LAST SWG OUR COOSA BASIN BIOLOGIST COORDINATED AN ANNUAL CONSERVATIONPLANNING MEETING (THE COOSA SUMMIT) AND PARTICIPATED IN REGULAR MEETINGS WITH STAKEHOLDERS ENGAGED IN THEPARTNERSHIP FOR THE UPPER COOSA (PUC). AS FUNDING ALLOWS, WE PLAN TO REPLICATE THIS MODEL IN OTHER PRIORITYWATERSHEDS TO IMPROVE IMPLEMENTATION OF SWAP CONSERVATION ACTIONS. NEW OPPORTUNITIES FOR AQUATIC CONSERVATIONARE ON THE HORIZON AS WE UNDERTAKE A COMPREHENSIVE REVISION OF OUR SWAP AND PREPARE FOR POTENTIAL FUNDING UNDERRECOVERING AMERICAS WILDLIFE ACT. HOWEVER, SWG FUNDS ARE ESSENTIAL FOR CONTINUING OUR EXISTING CONSERVATIONEFFORTS UNTIL ADDITIONAL FUNDING CAN BE SECURED.

THESE ARE: REGIONAL COORDINATION OF INVERTEBRATE CONSERVATION  TIGER BEETLE STATUS ASSESSMENT AND SURVEY METHODS  STONEFLY STATUS ASSESSMENT  NORTHERN DIAMONDBACK TERRAPIN SURVEY METHODS  RENEWABLE ENERGY WHITE PAPER AND IMPACT ANALYSIS  AND REGIONAL TECHNICAL SUPPORT SERVICES.  THE EXPECTED RESULTS OF THIS GRANT WILL BE STANDARDIZED SURVEY PROTOCOLS THAT WILL BE IMPLEMENTED WITHIN THE NORTHEAST, AN ANALYSIS OF THE IMPACTS OF RENEWABLE ENERGY DEVELOPMENT ON SGCN, AND CONTINUED MAINTENANCE AND DEVELOPMENT OF REGIONAL ANALYSIS OF STATUS, THREATS, AND CONSERVATION ACTIONS FOR REGIONAL SGCN.  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PUBLIC WHO USE AND APPRECIATE SGCN AND THEIR HABITATS.  THERE ARE SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, AS IDENTIFIED IN THE PROJECT NARRATIVES.

A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF WHERE AND WHEN BATS ARE PRESENT THROUGHOUT NEBRASKA IS NEEDED TO FACILITATE THECONSERVATION OF BATS ACROSS THE ECOLOGICALLY DIVERSE STATE. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO COLLECT ANDANALYSIS DATA ON BAT SPECIES PRESENCE AND ABUNDANCE ACROSS NEBRASKA TO BETTER DOCUMENT CHANGES TO POPULATIONS AS A RESULT OF ALTERED HABITAT COMPOSITION, WIND ENERGY DEVELOPMENT, WNS, AND ONGOING TIMBER MANAGEMENT. INFORMATION FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE SHARED WITH OTHER ORGANIZATIONS TO GUIDE MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS AND PRACTICES TO BETTER FACILITATE CONSERVATION OF BATS IN NEBRASKA.

PROVIDE SURVEY AND INVENTORY DATA AND ANALYSES FOR SPECIES IN GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) AND COMMUNITY TYPES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (CTGCN) TO INFORM APPROACHES IN SPECIES CONSERVATION, IDENTIFY AREAS FOR POTENTIAL HABITAT RESTORATION, AND DEVELOP PLANNING FOR MANAGEMENT.

PROVIDE MANAGEMENT AND HABITAT RESTORATION FOR SPECIES IN GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) AND COMMUNITY TYPES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (CTGCN) TO CONTRIBUTE TO SPECIES CONSERVATION, INFORM AND IMPLEMENT HABITAT RESTORATION, AND GUIDE DECISIONS FOR MANAGEMENT.

THIS PROJECT WILL ENABLE THE LDWF WILDLIFE DIVERSITY PROGRAM (WDP) TO MAINTAIN THE BIOTICS DATABASE OF RARE, THREATENED, AND ENDANGERED SPECIES (I.E. SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED) AND NATURAL COMMUNITY OCCURRENCE RECORDS TO ENSURE THAT SUCH DATA ARE UP-TO-DATE TO MAXIMIZE CONSERVATION VALUE. DATA AND PROJECT REVIEWS WILL BE AVAILABLE TO RESOURCE MANAGERS, REGULATORY AGENCIES, ENVIRONMENTAL CONSULTANTS, INDUSTRY, AND OTHERS TO DETERMINE THE IMPACTS OF CONSTRUCTION, DEVELOPMENT, AND OTHER PROJECTS TO LOUISIANAS WILDLIFE AND FISH RESOURCES AND NATURAL COMMUNITIES AND TO INFORM DECISIONS ON AVOIDANCE, MINIMIZATION, AND MITIGATION OF SUCH IMPACTS. MAINTENANCE OF THIS CENTRALIZED DATABASE WILL FACILITATE THE CONSERVATION OF SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) AND ASSOCIATED HABITATS THROUGHOUT LOUISIANA, THEREBY HELPING TO ACHIEVE IMPLEMENTATION OF LOUISIANAS STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP), IN PART, AND TO PREVENT THE NEED FOR FUTURE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA) LISTINGS.

GARY CREEK IS A LOW DISCHARGE, GROUNDWATER DEPENDENT STREAM THAT ORIGINATES ALONG THE EASTERN EDGE OF THE COTEAUDES PRAIRIES IN DEUEL COUNTY, SOUTH DAKOTA. IT IS A UNIQUE STREAM FOR EASTERN SOUTH DAKOTA BECAUSE IT ISCHARACTERIZED BY COOL WATER HABITAT WITH SUMMER WATER TEMPERATURES THAT RARELY EXCEED 18C AND A NATIVE FISHCOMMUNITY INCLUDING NORTHERN REDBELLY DACE (CHROSOMUS EOS, STATE THREATENED), AND BLACKSIDE DARTER (PERCINAMACULATE, SGCN). IN 2015, A JOINT EFFORT AMONG SD GAME, FISH AND  PARKS, THE USGS SOUTH DAKOTA COOPERATIVE FISH AND  WILDLIFE RESEARCH UNIT, SOUTH DAKOTA TROUT UNLIMITED, THE SDSU STUDENT UNIT OF THE AMERICAN FISHERIES SOCIETY,AND BARR ENGINEERING CO. WAS UNDERTAKEN TO ASSESS FISH AND HABITAT CONDITIONS IN GARY CREEK. THE TASK FORCE ANDA RECONNAISSANCE SURVEY OF GARY CREEK AND THE SURROUNDING WATERSHED DETERMINED THE FOLLOWING HABITATCHARACTERISTICS SUCH AS (1) LACK OF DEEP-WATER POOLS, (2) SUBSTRATE EMBEDDEDNESS, (3) BANK EROSION, AND (4)PERCHED CULVERTS COULD BE CONTRIBUTING TO REDUCED HABITAT FOR FISHES IN GARY CREEK. AQUATIC HABITAT STAMP FUNDSWILL BE USED TO RESTORE CREATE CRITICAL IN-STREAM HABITAT THAT INCLUDES POOLS, RUNS, AND RIFFLES FOR THE TARGETSPECIES (I.E. BLACKSIDE DARTER AND NORTHERN REDBELLY DACE). IN ADDITION TO IN-STREAM HABITAT IMPROVEMENTS, THEDEVELOPMENT OF LIVESTOCK WATERING LANES AND RIPARIAN FENCING CAN BE BENEFICIAL FOR PROTECTING STREAM SHORELINESAND ASSOCIATED RIPARIAN VEGETATION. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT A PROGRAMMATIC MONITORING AND EVALUATIONSTUDY TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF HABITAT RESTORATION EFFORTS FOR TARGET SPECIES AND THEIR HABITAT AND FOODREQUIREMENTS. THE PROPOSED PROJECT MEETS WITH SOUTH DAKOTAS WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN IDENTIFIED CONSERVATION NEEDSAND ACTIONS TO TWO SGCN INCLUDING NORTHERN REDBELLY DACE AND BLACKSIDE DARTER TO MAINTAIN AND RESTORE STREAMCONNECTIVITY AND SECURE THE LONG-TERM PROTECTION OF UNIQUE AND HIGH-QUALITY HABITATS. IN ADDITION, THE PROPOSEDPROJECT COMPLEMENTS THE AQUATIC RESOURCES HABITAT MANAGEMENT GOALS WITHIN THE SDGFP FISHERIES ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT STATEWIDE STRATEGIC PLAN BY CONSERVING AND ENHANCING AQUATIC HABITATS TO BENEFIT FISHERIES AND NON-GAME AQUATIC COMMUNITIES IN SOUTH DAKOTA.

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO DETERMINE IF POPULATIONS OF THE NORTHERN LEOPARD FROG (LITHOBATES PIPIENS) STILL PERSIST INHISTORIC LOCALITIES AND IF THERE ARE POPULATIONS PRESENT IN PREVIOUSLY UNSURVEYED LOCATIONS. THE RESEARCHERS WILLVISIT AT LEAST 30 SITES TO CONDUCT DIURNAL AND NOCTURNAL SURVEYS FOR ADULT AND LARVAL FROGS AT STOCK TANK ANDSTREAM HABITATS BY WATCHING FOR JUMPING FROGS, LISTENING FOR CALLS, AND DIP NETTING UNDER STREAM BANKS AND INVEGETATION. DATA ON WATER QUALITY WILL BE MEASURED, INCLUDING WATER TEMPERATURE, PH, AND TOTAL DISSOLVED SOLIDS.THE RESEARCHERS WILL ALSO RECORD THE PRESENCE OF INVASIVE AND PROBLEMATIC SPECIES, INCLUDING BULLFROGS ANDCRAYFISH. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO GATHER DATA ON THE DISTRIBUTION OF BATRACHOCHYTRIUM DENDROBATIDIS (BD)INFECTIONS IN NORTHERN LEOPARD FROGS BY USING STERILE WOODEN COTTON SWABS TO COLLECT SKIN TISSUE SAMPLES FROM THEVENTRAL SKIN SURFACES AND THIGHS OF ALL CAPTURED NORTHERN LEOPARD FROGS. EACH SKIN TISSUE SAMPLE WILL BE PLACEDINTO A LABELED VIAL CONTAINING 70  ETHANOL AND SENT TO A MOLECULAR LABORATORY FOR ANALYSIS USING GENETIC PCRTECHNIQUES TO DETECT THE PRESENCE OF BD INFECTIONS. IN ADDITION TO NORTHERN LEOPARD FROGS, THE FOLLOWINGAMPHIBIANS, IF ENCOUNTERED, MAY BE CAPTURED AND SWABBED TO TEST FOR BD INFECTIONS  BOREAL TOAD, BOREAL CHORUSFROG, BULLFROG, PLAINS LEOPARD FROG, TIGER SALAMANDER, AND WOODHOUSES TOAD. THE RESEARCHERS WILL WEIGH, MEASURE,AND SEX EACH FROG FOR WHICH A SKIN SWAB IS COLLECTED AND WILL EMPLOY APPROPRIATE MEASURES AND DECONTAMINATIONPROCEDURES TO PREVENT THE TRANSFER OF DISEASE OR PARASITIC ORGANISMS BETWEEN INDIVIDUALS OR SURVEY SITES. FINALPRODUCTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE AN UPDATED EVALUATION OF THE DISTRIBUTION AND STATUS OF THE NORTHERNLEOPARD FROG, INCLUDING DISTRIBUTION MAPS OF EXISTING NORTHERN LEOPARD FROG POPULATIONS AND BD INFECTIONS ANDRECOMMENDATIONS FOR ANY FURTHER POPULATION SURVEYS.

THE INTENT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ADDRESS THE CONSERVATION NEEDS OF AMPHIBIAN AND REPTILE SGCN IDENTIFIED IN THE STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN FOR NEW MEXICO (SWAP). THROUGH THIS GRANT, WE PROPOSE TO CONDUCT SURVEYS FOR 7 AMPHIBIANS (JEMEZ MOUNTAINS SALAMANDER, SACRAMENTO MOUNTAIN SALAMANDER, EASTERN BARKING FROG, PLAINS LEOPARD FROG, NORTHERN LEOPARD FROG, SONORAN DESERT TOAD, ANDLOWLAND LEOPARD FROG) AND 3 REPTILES (BIG BEND SLIDER, GILA MONSTER, AND WESTERN MASSASAUGA) TO MONITOR THE STATUS AND DEMOGRAPHY OF THESE SPECIES. DURING SURVEYS FOR AMPHIBIANS, WE WILL REMOVE THE INVASIVE BULLFROG THAT PREY OPPORTUNISTICALLY ON NATIVE AMPHIBIANS. THE DEPARTMENT WILL COORDINATE WITH AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL GUIDANCE FOR OTHER FEDERAL, STATE, AND NGOS TO SHARE INFORMATION AND POLICIES, AND TO COORDINATE SURVEY AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES THAT WILL BENEFIT AMPHIBIANS AND REPTILES IN NEW MEXICO. THE DEPARTMENT WILL ALSO ASSIST WITH CONSERVATION PLANNING FOR AT LEAST 4 AMPHIBIANS AND 3 REPTILES, AND WILL PROVIDE TESTING OF AMPHIBIAN SKIN SAMPLES FOR THE PRESENCE OF THE INVASIVE CHYTRID FUNGUS. LASTLY, THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO REINTRODUCE BOREAL TOAD TADPOLES INTO RIO ARRIBA COUNTY TO IMPROVE POPULATIONS OF THIS TOAD IN THE STATE.

A MAJOR COMPONENT OF THIS GRANT FUNDS LONG TERM MONITORING AND ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT OF MINNESOTA S NATIVE PRAIRIE TO IDENTIFY TRENDS IN PLANTS, BIRDS, AND POLLINATORS.

TO INTENSIVELY SURVEY FOR AMERICAN TOADS IN EASTERN NORTH DAKOTA TO DETERMINE IF THEY ARE EXTIRPATED FROM THE STATE. TO DETERMINE KEY HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS FOR AMERICAN TOADS IF THEY ARE FOUND TO BE PRESENT AT SITES. TO DETERMINE IF HYBRIDIZATION WITH CANADIAN TOADS HAS OCCURRED IN NORTH DAKOTA AND COULD HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO THEIR DECLINE.
