THE APPROVED 2015 STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP) IDENTIFIES SIX HUNDRED FIFTY SIX (656) ANIMAL SPECIES (AND 486 PLANT SPECIES) AS SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN). THE PLAN ALSO CLASSIFIED 19 TERRESTRIAL 18 AQUATIC HABITAT TYPES WHICH ARE LINKED TO THE SGCN. THE SWAP EMPHASIZES CONSERVATION ACTION, COLLABORATION, AND ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT. ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT RELIES ON THE ABILITY TO DETECT CHANGES, EVALUATE OPTIONS, ESTABLISH PRIORITIES, AND RESPOND ACCORDINGLY. STATE WILDLIFE GRANTS SUPPORT THE WVDNR ACTIONS NEEDED TO ESTABLISH BASELINE INVENTORY, INVESTIGATE BIOLOGICAL CONDITIONS (E.G., STRESSES), DEVELOP PARTNERSHIPS, IMPLEMENT ACTIONS, MONITOR RESULTS, AND RESPOND TO CHANGES. THE WVDNR PROPOSES TO USE STATE WILDLIFE GRANT FUNDS TO IMPLEMENT THE SWAP THROUGH SIX BROAD PROJECT CATEGORIES  SURVEYS, MONITORING, RESEARCH, CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES, ADMINISTRATION, AND PUBLICATIONS OF EDUCATIONAL AND TECHNICAL MEDIA. ACTIVITIES IN EACH OF THESE CATEGORIES ARE INCLUDED IN THIS GRANT.

CONDUCTING STOCK ASSESSMENTS OF PUGET SOUND GROUNDFISH STOCKSPROVIDES ESSENTIAL INFORMATION ABOUT SPECIES ABUNDANCE,DISTRIBUTION, AND ECOSYSTEM HEALTH. IN PUGET SOUND, TWO SPECIESOF ROCKFISH, BOCACCIO AND YELLOWEYE ROCKFISH, WERE LISTED IN 2010AS ENDANGERED AND THREATENED, RESPECTIVELY, UNDER THEENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. A FEDERAL RECOVERY PLAN DEVELOPED FORTHESE SPECIES SPECIFICALLY CALLS OUT THE NEED FOR REGULAR SURVEYSAND MONITORING TO ACHIEVE SPECIFIC RECOVERY TRAJECTORIES AND TRACKPOPULATION DEMOGRAPHIC TRENDS. THESE SURVEYS REQUIRE COMPLEXEQUIPMENT AND STRATEGIC SURVEY DESIGNS TO EFFECTIVELY CAPTURE THEDATA REQUIRED TO INFORM POPULATION ASSESSMENT MODELS USED FOREVALUATING THE RECOVERY TRAJECTORIES OF THESE SPECIES. THE WDFWRELIES PRIMARILY ON REMOTELY OPERATED VEHICLE SURVEYS CONDUCTEDFROM AN AGENCY OWNED RESEARCH VESSEL TO SURVEY ROCKFISHES(INCLUDING LISTED SPECIES) FOR DEVELOPING STATISTICALLY ROBUSTPOPULATION ESTIMATES, AND TO DOCUMENT HABITAT CHARACTERISTICSTHAT CAN BE USED TO DEVELOP OBJECTIVE SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MODELSUSED TO REFINE FUTURE SURVEYS OF ROCKFISH AND OTHER SPECIESINHABITING SIMILAR HABITATS.

THIS GRANT IS CRUCIAL FOR THE NEW MEXICO GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT TO PREVENT DECLINES AND EXPAND THE DISTRIBUTION OF AQUATIC SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) AS IDENTIFIED BY THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE APPROVED STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLANFOR NEW MEXICO (2017).

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE ONGOING HABITAT WORK ACROSS THE STATE THROUGH FINANCIAL AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND TO CONDUCT SGCN INVENTORY MONITORING AND MAINTAIN AND ADD TO A DATABASE.

CLIMATE REFUGIA (AREAS THAT MAINTAIN SUITABLE ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS OVER LONG PERIODS OF TIME) PLAY A MAJOR ROLE IN HELPING SPECIES ADAPT TO CLIMATE CHANGE AND OTHER STRESSORS. MORE SPECIFICALLY, CLIMATE CHANGE REFUGIA ARE AREAS THAT EXPERIENCE RELATIVELY STABLE TEMPERATURE AND MOISTURE CONDITIONS THROUGH TIME. THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP MAPS OF REGIONAL AND LOCAL CLIMATE REFUGIA THAT ARE RELEVANT TO SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) BY A) CONDUCTING A LITERATURE REVIEW AND ENGAGING EXPERTS TO IDENTIFY APPROPRIATE INDICATORS OF THE BIOTIC AND ABIOTIC (E.G., TOPOGRAPHY) DETERMINANTS OF CLIMATE REFUGIA AND RELEVANT SGCN ATTRIBUTES (E.G., RANGE SIZES AND CLIMATIC TOLERANCES)  B) DEVELOPING DATA PRODUCTS THAT FORECAST CHANGES IN BOTH CLIMATIC AND CLIMATE RELATED CONDITIONS AND TAKE INTO ACCOUNT THE TOLERANCES OF DIFFERENT SPECIES FOR CLIMATIC VARIATION  C) IDENTIFYING CLIMATE AND NON CLIMATE SPATIAL DATA (E.G., TOPOGRAPHIC VARIATION) REPRESENTING AREAS OF STABLE THERMAL AND HYDROLOGIC CONDITIONS, ACCESSIBILITY FACTORS (E.G., CLIMATE CORRIDORS AND BARRIERS TO SPECIES MOVEMENT), AND SPECIES HABITAT QUALITY  D) CREATING MAPS RANKED ACCORDING TO CLIMATIC, NON CLIMATIC, AND ACCESSIBILITY FACTORS TO IDENTIFY REGIONAL AND LOCAL CLIMATE REFUGIA  AND E) CONDUCTING A SENSITIVITY ANALYSIS TO DETERMINE HOW IMPORTANT EACH VARIABLE IS TO THE FINAL REFUGIA SCORE. THIS PROJECT S LARGE SCALE APPROACH TO ESTIMATING WHERE CLIMATE REFUGIA CAN OCCUR WILL HELP IDENTIFY WHERE A DIVERSITY OF SGCN MAY BE BEST ABLE TO PERSIST IN NEW MEXICO AS THE ENVIRONMENT CHANGES. THIS PROJECT S PROPOSED DATA PRODUCTS ARE INTENDED TO ENHANCE CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION EFFORTS FOR SGCN BY IDENTIFYING AREAS OF POTENTIAL CONSERVATION IMPORTANCE FOR THESE SPECIES THAT SPECIFICALLY CONSIDER THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE. THESE AREAS MAY BE LOCATED WITHIN PREVIOUSLY IDENTIFIED CONSERVATION OPPORTUNITY AREAS (COAS), WHERE CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES ARE MOST LIKELY TO BENEFIT A HIGH DIVERSITY OF SGCN. REFUGIA MAY ALSO BE IDENTIFIED OUTSIDE OF EXISTING COAS AND COULD THUS REPRESENT NEW AREAS OF POTENTIAL HIGH CONSERVATION VALUE FOR SGCN AS THE CLIMATE CHANGES. THE RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE MANAGERS  CAPACITY TO PRIORITIZE REFUGIA FOR CONSERVATION AND WILL DIRECTLY CONTRIBUTE IMPORTANT INFORMATION TO THE NEXT REVISION OF THE STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN FOR NEW MEXICO.

THE SHARE WITH WILDLIFE PROGRAM SELECTS, COORDINATES, AND FUNDS AT LEAST 6 RESEARCH PROJECTS FOCUSED ON SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED  SGCN . THESE PROJECTS ARE SELECTED TO FILL KEY INFORMATION GAPS ON SGCN AS IDENTIFIED BY THE NEW MEXICO DEPARTMENT OF GAME AND FISH  DEPARTMENT  STAFF. THESE PROJECTS ARE ULTIMATELY INTENDED TO ENHANCE THE DEPARTMENT S UNDERSTANDING, AND INFORM THE FUTURE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT, OF SGCN.

A MAJOR FOCUS OF OUR FISH HATCHERY SYSTEM IS TO OPTIMIZE HATCHERY PRODUCTION OF GILA TROUT IN SUPPORT OF GILA TROUT RECOVERY EFFORTS  71 FR 40657 . GILA TROUT ARE ALSO IDENTIFIED AS A SPECIES OF GREATEST CONCERN UNDER THE NEW MEXICO STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN. TO INITIATE REARING GILA TROUT, WE NEED TO BUY AQUACULTURE TANKS FOR GLENWOOD FISH HATCHERY.

THIS PROJECT WILL GATHER DEMOGRAPHIC DATA ON THREE ROSY-FINCH SPECIES, BLACK  LEUCOSTICTE ATRATA , BROWN-CAPPED  L. AUSTRALIS , AND GRAY-CROWNED  L. TEPHROCOTIS  HEREAFTER ROSY-FINCHES , THAT ARE AMONG THE MOST CLIMATE-THREATENED SPECIES IN THE UNITED STATES. THE BROWN-CAPPED ROSY-FINCH  BCRF  IS LISTED AS A BIRD OF CONSERVATION CONCERN ACROSS MULTIPLE STATES  IN NEW MEXICO, IT IS LISTED AS A SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED  SGCN  FOR WHICH MORE DATA ARE NEEDED. THIS STUDY ALSO SEEKS TO IDENTIFY BCRF BREEDING SITE ORIGINS BY CONDUCTING HYDROGEN ISOTOPE ANALYSIS ON FEATHER SAMPLES. A TOTAL OF THREE RADIOFREQUENCY IDENTIFICATION  RFID -EQUIPPED BIRD FEEDERS WILL BE INSTALLED AND MAINTAINED IN THE SANDIA MOUNTAINS ON CIBOLA NATIONAL FOREST LANDS AND IN THE TAOS SKI VALLEY ON PRIVATE PROPERTY. ROSY-FINCHES WILL BE CAPTURED NEAR FEEDERS USING MIST NETS AND TRAPS IN JANUARY-MARCH AND NOVEMBER THROUGH DECEMBER, THEN MARKED WITH ALUMINUM AND PLASTIC LEG BANDS AND A FEATHER SAMPLE WILL BE COLLECTED. ESPECIALLY FOR BCRFS, ONE BAND WILL CONTAIN A UNIQUELY CODED, PASSIVE INTEGRATED TRANSPONDER  PIT  TAG. THE FOLLOWING VARIABLES WILL BE RECORDED FOR EACH CAPTURED INDIVIDUAL  DATE, TIME, METHOD OF CAPTURE, SPECIES, AGE, SEX, WING AND TAIL LENGTH, FAT SCORE, MOLT STATUS, AND WEIGHT. WHEN PIT TAGGED BIRDS SUBSEQUENTLY VISIT THE RFID-EQUIPPED FEEDERS, THE UNIQUE IDENTIFIER DATA WILL BE COLLECTED AND ADDED TO A LONG-TERM  19 YEAR  ROSY-FINCH MARK-RECAPTURE DATASET. THIS DATASET WILL BE ANALYZED TO ASSESS WINTER SURVIVAL, TOTAL POPULATION SIZE, AND RESIDENCE TIME IN THE SAMPLING AREA. A TOTAL OF 460 FEATHER SAMPLES WILL BE SUBMITTED FOR HYDROGEN STABLE ISOTOPE ANALYSIS. THE ISOTOPE DATA WILL BE USED TO CHARACTERIZE HYDROGEN ISOTOPE ISOSCAPE DISTRIBUTIONS FOR BREEDING ROSY-FINCHES AND CREATE SPECIES-SPECIFIC PROBABILITY OF BREEDING ORIGIN MAPS. THESE DATA WILL INFORM FUTURE MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION ACTIONS FOR THE BCRF AND CONGENERS.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ESTABLISH TX-FISH-DNA, A REGIONALLY-FOCUSED DNA-DATABASE FOR ALL SPECIES OF FISHES INHABITING FRESHWATER, ESTUARINE AND MARINE HABITATS IN TEXAS. TX-FISH-DNA WILL BE POPULATED BY REFERENCE DNA-SEQUENCES OBTAINED FROM EXPERT VERIFIED AND MUSEUM VOUCHERED SPECIMENS COLLECTED FROM TEXAS WATERS AND WILL OFFER DIVERSE END USERS RAPID ACCESS TO HIGH QUALITY MITOCHONDRIAL DNA SEQUENCES THAT CAN BE APPLIED TO SOLVE MYRIAD SCIENTIFIC AND SOCIETAL PROBLEMS. ONCE ESTABLISHED, TX-FISH-DNA COULD FOR EXAMPLE BE EMPLOYED BY RESEARCHERS TO ACCURATELY IDENTIFY EGGS OR EARLY LARVAL STAGES OF COASTAL FISHES  WHICH ARE CHALLENGING TO IDENTIFY USING TRADITIONAL METHODS , INVESTIGATE THE DIET OF PISCIVOROUS FISHES, BIRDS, OR MAMMALS  FROM FRAGMENTS IN STOMACH CONTENT OR SCAT , OR DESIGN TAXON-SPECIFIC PRIMERS FOR METABARCODE STUDIES OR ENVIRONMENTAL DNA  EDNA  STUDIES TARGETING RARE AND OR ENDANGERED SPECIES. THE TX SEAFOOD INDUSTRY MAY ALSO BENEFIT FROM TX-FISH-DNA, WHICH WILL HAVE APPLICATION SPECIFICALLY IN THE AREA OF SEAFOOD TRACEABILITY AND FORENSICS. TX-FISH-DNA WILL BE HOSTED ON THE BARCODE OF LIFE DATA SYSTEMS  BOLD  WEB PLATFORM WITH SEQUENCES LINKED TO MUSEUM VOUCHERED SPECIMENS, HOUSED WITHIN THE COLLECTION OF FISHES AT THE TEXAS AAND M UNIVERSITY  TAMU  BIODIVERSITY RESEARCH AND TEACHING COLLECTIONS  BRTC . TX-FISH-DNA IS A COLLABORATIVE PROJECT THAT INVOLVES TAMU, TAMUCC AND BOTH THE COASTAL AND INLAND FISHERIES DIVISIONS AT TPWD, BUT THE FOCUS OF THIS PROPOSAL IS FISHES FOUND IN ESTUARINE AND MARINE HABITATS.
THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO   1  DEVELOP AN EDNA ASSAY FOR SOUTHERN FLOUNDER AND  2  APPLY THE ASSAY TO DEMONSTRATE ITS EFFECTIVENESS IN FIELD SAMPLES AS COMPARED TO STANDARD SAMPLING METHODS.

THE LARGEST FRESHWATER TURTLE SPECIES IN NORTH AMERICA, THE ALLIGATOR SNAPPING TURTLE  MACROCHELYS TEMMINCKII , IS LISTED AS A SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION CONCERN IN TEXAS  TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE 2012 . THE SPECIES POSSESSES SEVERAL TRAITS INCLUDING A TYPE III SURVIVORSHIP CURVE AND DELAYED SEXUAL MATURITY THAT MAKE IT PARTICULARLY SUSCEPTIBLE TO POPULATION DECLINES. INTENSIVE HARVEST OF ALLIGATOR SNAPPING TURTLE IS LIKELY NOT SUSTAINABLE IN THIS SLOW GROWING SPECIES AND HAS BEEN LINKED TO DECLINE IN SOME AREAS  LOVICH ET AL. 2018 . INCIDENTAL MORTALITY CAUSED BY TROTLINES IS LIKELY ANOTHER CONTRIBUTING FACTOR TO THE DECLINE OF POPULATIONS, YET THIS THREAT IS LIKELY UNDERREPORTED  STEEN AND ROBINSON 2017 . BECAUSE THIS SPECIES IS THREATENED BY PASSIVE FISHING PRESSURE AND CRYPTIC IN MANY FACETS OF ITS ECOLOGY, WE PROPOSE TO QUANTIFY DEMOGRAPHIC PARAMETERS IN ALLIGATOR SNAPPING TURTLES  MACROCHELYS TEMMINCKII  IN TEXAS IN SITES SUBJECTED TO DIFFERENT INTENSITIES OF RECREATIONAL FISHING PRESSURE AS WELL AS EXAMINE THEIR TROPHIC ECOLOGY IN THESE SITES.

THE SUCCESS OF A STOCK ENHANCEMENT PROGRAM DEPENDS ON THE SURVIVAL OF THE STOCKED FISH AFTER RELEASE. HATCHERY-PRODUCED SOUTHERN FLOUNDER  PARALICHTHYS LETHOSTIGMA  HAVE A HIGH INCIDENCE OF MALPIGMENTATION WHICH MAKES THEM HIGHLY VULNERABLE TO PREDATORS. MALPIGMENTATION IS THOUGHT TO RESULT FROM THE INTERACTION OF GENETIC AND ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS, SUCH AS LARVAL NUTRITION AND REARING CONDITIONS. NEW PRELIMINARY DATA SUGGEST THAT BROODSTOCK DIET MAY PLAY A ROLE IN DETERMINING ADULT PIGMENTATION IN SOUTHERN FLOUNDER, A PROCESS KNOWN AS NUTRITIONAL PROGRAMMING. THIS PROJECT WILL TEST THE RELATIONSHIP SUGGESTED BY THE PRELIMINARY DATA BY DETERMINING WHETHER THE INCIDENCE OF MALPIGMENTATION IN JUVENILES DIFFERS BETWEEN TWO VERY DIFFERENT BROODSTOCK DIETS. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO MEASURE THE EXPRESSION OF FIVE KEY GENES INVOLVED IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF PIGMENT CELLS AND TEST WHETHER GENE EXPRESSION IS SUBJECT TO NUTRITIONAL PROGRAMMING. THESE ANALYSES WILL BE CONDUCTED AT THREE DEVELOPMENTAL STAGES AROUND METAMORPHOSIS IN ORDER TO IDENTIFY THE PATHWAY THAT IS DISRUPTED TO PRODUCE MALPIGMENTATION AND THE DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE WHEN THAT OCCURS. THE GOAL OF THE RESEARCH IS TO IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING OF MALPIGMENTATION IN SOUTHERN FLOUNDER, LEADING TO CORRECTIVE ACTIONS THAT CAN BE APPLIED IN HATCHERIES TO REDUCE ITS INCIDENCE AND THEREBY IMPROVE STOCK ENHANCEMENT SUCCESS.

IDENTIFY DIOXIN RELATED TISSUE ACCUMULATION AND LARVAL MORTALITY, AS WELL AS ASSESS EFFECTIVENESS OF CARBON FILTERS AT REMOVING DIOXINS AT TPWD COASTAL HATCHERIES AND IDENTIFY APPROPRIATE CHANGES IN WATER MANAGEMENT AND FILTRATION TO IMPROVE LARVAL FLOUNDER PRODUCTION. EVALUATE THE EFFICACY OF OVAPLANT-L TO IMPROVE AND SYNCHRONIZE FLOUNDER SPAWNING AND INCREASE EGG AND LARVAL OUTPUT OF TPWD COASTAL HATCHERIES. THESE OUTCOMES WILL ULTIMATELY IMPROVE THE TPWD STOCK ENHANCEMENT PROGRAM TO OPTIMIZE THE LONG-TERM UTILIZATION AND SUSTAIN FLOUNDER POPULATIONS AT LEVELS THAT ARE NECESSARY TO ENSURE REPLENISHABLE STOCKS OF THIS COMMERCIALLY AND RECREATIONALLY IMPORTANT SPECIES.

BASED UPON THE TCAP STATED NEED TO IMPROVE THE STABILITY AND RECOVERY OF A SPECIES IN DECLINE, THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE DIRECT DATA ON THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE DEVELOPMENTAL MORPHOLOGY AND PHYSIOLOGY OF LARVAL SOUTHERN FLOUNDER, AND THEIR GROWTH RATE AND SURVIVAL. THIS 2-YEAR PROJECT WILL QUANTIFY VARIOUS MORPHOLOGICAL AND PHYSIOLOGICAL CHARACTERISTICS OF DEVELOPING LARVAL FISH FROM 24 HOURS POST FERTILIZATION  HPF  TO 50 DAYS POST HATCH  DPH   ENCOMPASSING METAMORPHOSIS . THESE CHARACTERISTICS WILL BE MEASURED AND COMPARED BETWEEN TWO TPWD STATE HATCHERIES THAT ARE INVOLVED WITH SOUTHERN FLOUNDER LARVICULTURE. THE TWO SITES INCLUDE TPWD SEA CENTER TEXAS  LAKE JACKSON  AND TPWD CCA MARINE DEVELOPMENT CENTER IN CORPUS CHRISTI. THE RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY THE MORPHOLOGICAL AND PHYSIOLOGICAL CHARACTERISTICS OF DEVELOPING SOUTHERN FLOUNDER LARVAE THAT CAN IDENTIFY EARLY-WARNING INDICATORS OF MORTALITY OR POOR GROWTH RATE. THEREFORE, THE KNOWLEDGE GAINED WILL PROVIDE TPWD HATCHERY MANAGERS WITH VALUABLE INFORMATION REGARDING DEVELOPMENTALLY CRITICAL EARLY LIFE-STAGES OF SOUTHERN FLOUNDERS. IN TURN, OUR RESULTS CAN POSITIVELY INFLUENCE HATCHERY OPERATIONS BY DETERMINING THE IMPLEMENTATION OF MARICULTURE STRATEGIES TO ALLEVIATE THE LOW SURVIVAL BOTTLENECK TO HATCHERY OPERATIONS. FOR EXAMPLE, SPECIFIC SOLUTIONS MAY ENCOMPASS THE MODIFICATION OF LARVICULTURE CONDITIONS  I.E., EXTENT OF AERATION , ENVIRONMENTAL ENRICHMENT  TO LOWER STRESS , OR DIETARY MODULATION.

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO EXAMINE THE SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL PATTERNS IN DENSITY AND DISTRIBUTION OFPLANKTONIC OYSTER LARVAE IN TERMS OF RESTORATION OF OYSTER REEFS. THE RELEVANT INFORMATION ISCURRENTLY MISSING, BUT IS HIGHLY NEEDED TO IDENTIFY THE  SOURCES AND SINKS  OF LARVAL OYSTER TOQUANTIFY THE RECRUITMENT SUCCESS OF OYSTER POPULATIONS. WE PLAN TO CONDUCT SAMPLING OF BIVALVELARVAE DURING THE SPAWNING SEASON  MAY TO OCTOBER 2023 , AND WILL TEASE OUT EASTERN OYSTER FROMOTHER SPECIES THROUGH GENETIC  BARCODE  AND GENOMIC  METABARCODE  ANALYSES AND QUANTIFY THEDENSITY AND DISTRIBUTION OF PELAGIC OYSTER LARVAE IN GALVESTON BAY FOR MANAGEMENT PURPOSES. THISPROJECT WILL GENERATE BENCHMARK DATA OF PELAGIC OYSTER LARVAE FOR RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT OFOYSTER HABITATS IN THE BAY. EXPECTED RESULTS AND BENEFITS OF THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE GUIDANCE TO THESTATE AGENCY AND STAKEHOLDERS IN SELECTION OF SITES TO MAXIMIZE RECRUITMENT SUCCESS, AND SELECTINGLOCATIONS FOR POTENTIAL OYSTER SANCTUARIES THAT COULD SERVE AS SOURCES OF A RELIABLE AND CONSISTENTSUPPLY OF PELAGIC OYSTER LARVAE.

AS PRAIRIE HABITAT QUANTITY, QUALITY, AND CONNECTIVITY HAS BEEN DEGRADED, DECLINES HAVE BEEN DOCUMENTED NEARLY ALL GRASSLAND-DEPENDENT SPECIES. THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO ACCELERATE CONSERVATION ACTION FOR PRAIRIE ON DNR-MANAGED LANDS WITHIN LANDSCAPES THAT HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS PRIORITIES FOR CONSERVATION OF AMPHIBIANS, REPTILES, AND BIRDS. THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON PROVIDING ADDITIONAL HABITAT FOR PRAIRIE-ASSOCIATED SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED  SGCN . WE PROPOSE TO RESTORE NATIVE PRAIRIE AS WELL AS MANAGE EXISTING PRAIRIE, TO INCREASE THE AVAILABILITY OF HIGH QUALITY, DIVERSE PRAIRIE HABITAT. BY THE COMPLETION OF THE PROJECT, WE EXPECT IMPROVED HABITAT CONDITIONS FOR PRAIRIE-DEPENDENT SGCN ON AT LEAST 1,000 ACRES OF PRAIRIE HABITAT.

THE SPOTTED TURTLE  CLEMMYS GUTTA  IS VERMONT S RAREST TURTLE AND IS BOTH ENDANGERED AND A HIGH PRIORITY SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED  SGCN  IN THE STATE  CRITERION 2   VULNERABLE ACROSS MUCH OF ITS RANGE, THE SPOTTED TURTLE IS INCLUDED IN THE CURRENT NATIONAL DOMESTIC LISTING WORKPLAN AND IS UNDER REVIEW FOR FEDERAL LISTING UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  CRITERION 2   SPOTTED TURTLES ALSO HAVE SGCN STATUS IN ALL 21 US STATES IN WHICH THEY OCCUR  CRITERION 2 , ARE A SPECIES OF REGIONAL RESPONSIBILITY BY THE NORTHEAST PARTNERS FOR AMPHIBIAN AND REPTILE CONSERVATION, ARE A VERY HIGH PRIORITY REGIONAL SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED IN THE NORTHEAST, AND ARE CONSIDERED ENDANGERED IN CANADA AND BY THE INTERNATIONAL UNION FOR CONSERVATION OF NATURE VERMONT S SPOTTED TURTLE POPULATIONS ARE LOCATED ALONG THE NORTHERN FRINGE OF THE SPECIES  RANGE  PERIPHERAL POPULATIONS SUCH AS THESE ARE OFTEN SMALLER AND MORE ISOLATED THAN CORE INTERIOR POPULATIONS, AND INDIVIDUALS MAY HAVE DIFFERENT ECOLOGICAL REQUIREMENTS THAN CONSPECIFICS IN OTHER REGIONS  CONSEQUENTLY, REGION SPECIFIC INFORMATION IS NEEDED TO INFORM AND GUIDE CONSERVATION ACTIONS AND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS ONLY THREE SPOTTED TURTLE POPULATIONS ARE KNOWN IN VERMONT, BUT ADDITIONAL UNKNOWN POPULATIONS LIKELY EXIST  THESE POPULATIONS APPEAR TO BE GEOGRAPHICALLY ISOLATED, BEING SEPARATED BY 38 101 MILES, BUT UNSURVEYED AND APPARENTLY SUITABLE HABITAT ACROSS THE STATE MAY ALSO SUPPORT SPOTTED TURTLES  OUR INCOMPLETE KNOWLEDGE OF THE SPECIES  DISTRIBUTION IN THE STATE IS LIKELY OWING TO ITS LOW DETECTABILITY, THE COMPLEX HABITATS IT USES, AND A LACK OF CONCERTED SURVEY EFFORT THIS PROJECT WILL COMPLEMENT ONGOING REGIONAL SPOTTED TURTLE POPULATION ASSESSMENTS SUPPORTED BY A 2018 C SWG RCN PROJECT BY PROVIDING VERMONT SPECIFIC INFORMATION, WHICH IS CURRENTLY LACKING  IF FUNDED, THIS PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY SUITABLE SPOTTED TURTLE HABITATS, AND WILL DETERMINE IF THOSE HABITATS ARE OCCUPIED  IT WILL SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT OF EDNA SAMPLING PROTOCOLS IN LENTIC SYSTEMS, WHICH WILL BE TRANSFERRABLE TO OTHER STATES WITH SPOTTED TURTLE INFORMATION GAPS AND TO OTHER SGCN FRESHWATER TURTLE SPECIES  CRITERION 7 BONUS   IT WILL USE STANDARDIZED METHODS AND PROTOCOLS DEVELOPED FOR THE ONGOING C SWG RCN SPOTTED TURTLE PROJECT TO EVALUATE THE SPECIES  PRESENCE AT 25 SITES AND IMPROVE PRIORITY NESTING HABITAT

INDIAN MONGOOSE, DOMESTIC CATS, AND SEVERAL SPECIES OF RODENTS THESE SPECIES DRASTICALLY DECLINED  ON HAWAII ISLAND, ALL THREE KNOWN SPECIES OF ENDANGERED SEABIRD  'AKE'AKE  OCEANADROMA CASTRO CRYPTOLEUCURA, BAND RUMPED STORM PETREL , 'A'O  PUFFINUS NEWELLI, NEWELL S SHEARWATER, AND 'UA'U  PTERODROMA SANDWICHENSIS, HAWAIIAN PETREL   WERE THOUGHT EXTINCT, BUT STARTING IN 1954 AND CONTINUING INTO 2021 REMNANT BREEDING POPULATIONS HAVE BEEN REDISCOVERED  THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE THREAT OF MAMMALIAN PREDATION FOR THESE POPULATIONS OF ENDANGERED SEABIRDS  TO DATE, ONLY LIMITED LANDSCAPE LEVEL TRAPPING EFFORTS HAVE BEEN UNDERTAKEN TO REMOVE PREDATORS FROM WET FOREST SEABIRD HABITATS ON HAWAI'I ISLAND AND THERE HAS BEEN A LITTLE EFFORT ON STATE LAND IN SUBALPINE MAUNA LOA AND MAUNAKEA  THIS PROJECT WILL HELP RESTORE THE SUITABILITY OF HUNDREDS OF ACRES OF NESTING HABITAT FOR ENDANGERED SEABIRDS AND PROTECT ALL KNOWN REMNANT POPULATIONS ON STATE LANDS ON HAWAI'I ISLAND  OUTCOMES OF THIS STUDY WILL PROVIDE INSIGHTS INTO THE SUCCESS OF DIFFERENT TYPES OF PREDATOR CONTROL TRAPS AND DIFFERENT TRAPPING TECHNIQUES FOR ELIMINATING PREDATORS FROM THE LANDSCAPE  IT WILL ALSO PROVIDE INSIGHT INTO IMPROVED METHODS FOR NEST SEARCHING AND POPULATION MONITORING FOR THESE THREE CRYPTIC AND ELUSIVE SEABIRD SPECIES  FINALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL HELP EVALUATE THE SUCCESS OF NOVEL PREDATOR EXCLUSION FENCING BEING DEVELOPED AND INSTALLED BY THE STATE DEPARTMENT OF HAWAIIAN HOMELANDS IN SPRING SUMMER OF 2022  IMPLEMENTATION OF THE WORK PROPOSED HEREIN WILL GREATLY AID IN PLANS FOR ESTABLISHING ADDITIONAL PREDATOR PROOF BARRIERS ON MAUNA LOA, MAUNAKEA, AND KOHALA  ALL TOGETHER LEADING TO THE ESTABLISHMENT OF THE NEEDED FRAMEWORKS FOR MANAGERS TO CONTINUE TO PROTECT AND MANAGE THE SEABIRD POPULATIONS IN PERPETUITY

THE COOK INLET BELUGA WHALE (CIB) POPULATION, LISTED AS ENDANGERED UNDER THE U.S. ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA), IS AN ALASKA SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) THAT WAS HIGHLIGHTED IN THE ALASKA'S STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP) AND IS A NATIONAL MARINE FISHERIES SERVICE (NMFS) "SPECIES IN THE SPOTLIGHT." WHILE OVERHARVEST LED TO THE DECLINE AND LISTING OF CIB UNDER THE ESA (NMFS 2016), THE CURTAILMENT OF HARVEST FOR TWO DECADES HAS FAILED TO RECOVER THE POPULATION. RECENT ANALYSES INDICATE THAT THE CIB POPULATION IS CURRENTLY IN A DOWNWARD TREND (SHELDEN AND WADE 2019). MORE THAN HALF THE HUMAN POPULATION OF ALASKA LIVES AND WORKS IN THE COOK INLET REGION, LEADING TO NUMEROUS POTENTIAL THREATS TO THE RECOVERY OF THE CIB. MAJOR OBSTACLES TO CIB RECOVERY IDENTIFIED IN THE CIB RECOVERY PLAN (NMFS 2016) INCLUDE THE UNCERTAINTY AROUND WHY THE POPULATION HAS FAILED TO RECOVER AND THE NEED FOR LEADERSHIP AND COORDINATION TO ADDRESS CIB CONSERVATION IN AN AREA WITH DIVERSE INDUSTRIES AND REGULATORY JURISDICTIONS. THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THESE OBSTACLES BY 1) A RESEARCH INVESTIGATION TO LINK PREY SPECIES TO CIB DIET THROUGH STABLE ISOTOPES; 2) PROMOTING RAPID IDENTIFICATION OF STRANDED CIB TO SUPPORT RECOVERY AND IDENTIFY POTENTIAL POPULATION DRIVERS; 3) WORKING WITH NATIONAL MARINE FISHERIES SERVICE TO BRING DIVERSE GOVERNMENT AGENCIES (LOCAL, STATE, FEDERAL, AND TRIBAL), INDUSTRIES (E.G., OIL AND GAS, SHIPPING, AND FISHING), AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS TOGETHER TO IDENTIFY THREATS AND ESTABLISH MITIGATION MEASURES FOR CIB; AND 4) SUPPORTING PERMIT APPLICATION REVIEWS TO ADD CONSERVATION MEASURES TO MINIMIZE AND MITIGATE IMPACT ON CIB AND THEIR HABITAT.

THE VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES (VDWR) IS AN ACTIVE PARTNER IN THE COMPETITIVE STATE WILDLIFE GRANTS PROJECT WORKING TO CREATE AND RESTORE BLACK RAIL HABITAT. THE VDWR HAS REQUESTED $258,375 OF FEDERAL FUNDS AND VDWR AND SUBRECIPIENTS WILL PROVIDE $94,006 WORTH OF NONFEDERAL MATCH.AS A PARTNER IN THIS EFFORT, VDWR WILL USE FUNDS FROM THIS AWARD TO:- TREAT 125-ACRES OF MARSH HABITAT ON THE SAXIS WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA WITH HERBICIDES TO CONTROL INVASIVE PHRAGMITES AND IMPROVE HABITAT FOR BLACK RAILS;- MONITOR CHANGES TO MARSH HABITATS TREATED WITH HERBICIDES;- TREAT 125-ACRES OF MARSH HABITAT ON THE SAXIS WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA WITH PRESCRIBED FIRE TO CONTROL INVASIVE PHRAGMITES AND IMPROVE HABITAT FOR BLACK RAILS;- MONITOR CHANGES TO MARSH HABITATS TREATED WITH PRESCRIBED FIRE;- MODIFY A 103 ACRES OF WATERFOWL IMPOUNDMENTS ON THE DOE CREEK WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA TO CREATE ARTIFICIAL MARSH SUITABLE FOR BLACK RAILS;- MONITOR THE SUCCESS OF EFFORTS TO ESTABLISH ARTIFICIAL MARSH HABITATS WITHIN IMPOUNDMENTS; AND- ESTABLISH A SUBAWARD WITH THE CENTER FOR CONSERVATION BIOLOGY TO:O MONITOR CHANGES IN BIRD POPULATIONS AT SAXIS TO DETERMINE IF EITHER HERBICIDES OR FIRE ARE BETTER FOR RESTORING BLACK RAIL HABITATS;O MONITOR CHANGES IN BIRD POPULATIONS IN THE MODIFIED IMPOUNDMENT TO DETERMINE IF VDWR CAN SUCCESSFULLY CREATE ARTIFICIAL BLACK RAIL HABITAT.THIS WORK WILL HELP VDWR AND OTHER CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS IDENTIFY THE BEST MEANS OF MANAGING HABITATS TO SUPPORT THE RECOVERY OF VIRGINIA'S BLACK RAIL POPULATIONS.

SINCE 2009, WISCONSIN AND MINNESOTA HAVE IMPROVED OVER 14,500 ACRES OF PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS FOR THE BENEFIT OF SGCN. WE HAVE DEMONSTRATED THROUGH SURVEYS AND MONITORING THAT TARGET AND OTHER SGCN PRESENCE HAS INCREASED ON MANY SITES. THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO CONTINUE OUR EFFORTS TO IMPROVE PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LAND TO BENEFIT SGCN POLLINATORS, HERPS, BIRDS AND OTHER SPECIES ASSOCIATED WITH THE PRAIRIE-SAVANNA OAKWOODLAND CONTINUUM OF THE DRIFTLESS AREA (DA).

SINCE 2009, WISCONSIN AND MINNESOTA HAVE IMPROVED OVER 14,500 ACRES OF PUBLIC AND PRIVATELANDS FOR THE BENEFIT OF SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN). WE HAVE DEMONSTRATED THROUGH SURVEYS AND MONITORING THAT TARGET AND OTHER SGCN PRESENCE HAS INCREASED ON MANY SITES. THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE OUR EFFORTS TO IMPROVE PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LAND TO BENEFIT SGCN POLLINATORS, HERPS, BIRDS AND OTHER SPECIES ASSOCIATED WITH THE PRAIRIE-SAVANNA-OAK WOODLAND CONTINUUM OF THE DRIFTLESS AREA (DA). THE NEED, INTEREST, AND ABILITY FOR STATE PROGRAMS TO FACILITATE MANAGEMENT FOR SGCN ON PRIVATE LANDS ARE ALL THERE; THIS PROJECT GAINS THE FINANCIAL MEANS TO ACHIEVE IT. PROJECT LOCATIONS INCLUDE ROOT RIVER AND WHITEWATER CONSERVATION FOCUS AREAS (CFAS) OF MN AND WESTERN COULEE AND RIDGES AND SOUTHWEST SAVANNA ECOLOGICAL LANDSCAPES (EL) OF WI. BOTH LOCATIONS ARE FOUND WITHIN OUR RESPECTIVE STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLANS (SWAP).WISCONSIN WILL DIRECTLY RESTORE, ENHANCE, REMOVE, CREATE OR MANAGE 300 PRIVATE LAND ACRES OF GRASSLAND, PRAIRIE, SAVANNA, AND/OR WOODLAND HABITATS TO BENEFIT RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE, MONARCHS, POLLINATORS, BIRDS AND OTHER SGCN THROUGH PRESCRIBED FIRE, INVASIVES CONTROL, PLANTING AND SEEDING, AND VEGETATION MANAGEMENT (BRUSH REMOVAL). WISCONSIN WILL CONDUCT SURVEYS OF SGCN LISTED IN OUR SWAP: RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE (BOMBUS AFFINIS), YELLOW BUMBLE BEE (B. FERVIDUS), YELLOW-BANDED BUMBLE BEE (B. TERRICOLA), MONARCH, OTHER LEPIDOPTERA, TIMBER RATTLESNAKE, CERULEAN WARBLER (SETOPHAGA CERULEAN), ACADIAN FLYCATCHER (EMPIDONAX VIRESCENS) AND BREEDING BIRD SURVEYS (BBS) TARGETING SGCN GRASSLAND BIRDS. WISCONSIN WILL ALSO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO APPROXIMATELY 25 INDIVIDUAL PRIVATE LANDOWNERS.

THE TRAFFICKING OF U.S. NATIVE TURTLES HAS REACHED A TIPPING POINT-STATE AND FEDERAL LAWENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS AND CONSERVATION BIOLOGISTS CONSIDER THE ILLEGAL COLLECTION AND TRADE OFTURTLES TO BE A NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL CONSERVATION CRISIS. FROM MAY 2018 TO DECEMBER 2020,THERE WERE AT LEAST 11 MAJOR U.S. CASES INVOLVING THE CONFISCATION OF 11,892 TURTLES (FIGURE 1).MANY OF THE SPECIES BEING TARGETED ARE SGCN, STATE LISTED SPECIES, OR SPECIES BEING PETITIONED FORLISTING UNDER THE U.S. ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (WOOD, BLANDING'S, AND SPOTTED). SGCN TURTLESFACING EXTREMELY HIGH DEMAND IN THE ILLEGAL TRADE INCLUDE EASTERN BOX TURTLE, SPOTTED TURTLE,DIAMONDBACK TERRAPIN, WOOD TURTLE, BOG TURTLE, AND BLANDING'S TURTLE. OVER A THREE YEAR PERIOD(2017-2020), SERVICE INSPECTORS HAVE INTERDICTED (I.E., DETECTING, DETAINING, OR SEIZING WILDLIFETHAT HAS ENTERED THE STREAM OF COMMERCE) SHIPMENTS CONTAINING MORE THAN 7,000 INDIVIDUALTURTLES REPRESENTING 13 DIFFERENT NATIVE SPECIES AT THE INTERNATIONAL MAIL FACILITY AT JFK AIRPORT.THE SOUTHEAST REGION IS EXPERIENCING SIMILAR NUMBERS ON AN ANNUAL BASIS (PERS. COMM. SERVICEOLE CHIEF, R1). TURTLE POPULATIONS, INCLUDING POPULATIONS FOUND IN THE EASTERN HALF OF THE UNITEDSTATES, ARE DECLINING RAPIDLY DUE TO HABITAT LOSS AND DEGRADATION, ROAD MORTALITY, AND NESTPREDATION FROM HUMAN SUBSIDIZED PREDATORS. THE ADDITIONAL LOSS OF ADULT TURTLES FROM ILLEGALCOLLECTION FOR DOMESTIC AND INTERNATIONAL TRADE HAS AN ENORMOUS IMPACT ON THE PERSISTENCE OFTHESE SPECIES. MANY OF THESE TAXA COULD BECOME EXTINCT THIS CENTURY IF THE AFOREMENTIONED THREATSARE NOT ADDRESSED (STANFORD ET AL. 2020). THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP LONG TERM APPROACHES TOGETTING CONFISCATED TURTLES BACK INTO THE WILD (REPATRIATION) BY FUNDING DISEASE SCREENING ANDGENETIC ANALYSIS, THE TWO MAJOR FACTORS IN STATES' DECISION-MAKING RELATED TO THE LONG TERMOUTCOME OF THESE TURTLES (COLLABORATIVE TO COMBAT ILLEGAL TRADE IN TURTLES (CCITT) REPATRIATIONAND CONFISCATIONS WORKING GROUP, 2020).THE GOALS OF THE PROJECT ARE TO: 1) TEST RECENTLY DEVELOPED HEALTH AND DISEASE TESTING PROTOCOLS;2) DETERMINE THE BEST METHOD AND USE OF GENETIC INFORMATION TO DETERMINE PLACE OF ORIGIN OFCONFISCATED ANIMALS. THESE TWO ACTIONS SHOULD DECREASE THE DECLINE IN EASTERN, NATIVE SGCNTURTLE POPULATIONS DUE TO WILDLIFE TRAFFICKING BY PROVIDING STATES WITH THE INFORMATION NEEDED TOMAKE AN INFORMED DECISION REGARDING REPATRIATION.

THE VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES (VDWR) IS AN ACTIVE PARTNER IN THE COMPETITIVE STATE WILDLIFE GRANTS PROJECT: ADVANCING CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION OF BROOK FLOATER AND ASSOCIATED FRESHWATER MUSSELS. VDWR HAS REQUESTED $164,214 OF FEDERAL FUNDS AND VDWR AND SUBRECIPIENTS WILL PROVIDE $64,322.86 WORTH OF NONFEDERAL MATCH.AS A PARTNER IN THIS EFFORT, VDWR WILL USE FUNDS FROM THIS AWARD TO:- ESTABLISH A SUBAWARD WITH VIRGINIA TECH'S CONSERVATION MANAGEMENT INSTITUTE TO PERFORM MUSSEL AND HABITAT SURVEYS TO IDENTIFY SPECIFIC SITES TO STOCK PROPAGATED BROOK FLOATERS (JOB 3.1);- ESTABLISH A SUBAWARD WITH THE VIRGINIA FISHERIES AND AQUATIC WILDLIFE CENTER TO:O CONDUCT PRE-STOCKING MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT (JOB 2.1)O PROPAGATE BROOK FLOATERS AND RELEASE JUVENILES IN AN ATTEMPT TO RESTORE POPULATIONS IN VIRGINIA RIVERS (JOB 2.2); ANDO MONITOR BROOK FLOATERS STOCKED INTO VIRGINIA RIVERS (JOB 2.3); AND- ESTABLISH A SUBAWARD WITH AUBURN UNIVERSITY TO ANALYZE GENETIC SAMPLES THAT WILL BE PROVIDED BY PARTICIPATING STATES (JOB 3.2).THESE EFFORTS WILL HELP TO RESTORE BROOK FLOATERS TO THEIR HISTORIC HABITATS AND, HOPEFULLY, PREVENT THE NEED FOR THIS SPECIES TO BECOME LISTED UNDER THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT.

GEORGIA S STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN REVISION IS DUE IN OCTOBER 2025  WE COMPLETED OUR LAST COMPREHENSIVE REVISION IN 2015 AND HAVE UTILIZED THE SWAP TO GUIDE VIRTUALLY ALL OF OUR CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING SURVEYS AND MONITORING, RESEARCH, ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW, HABITAT MANAGEMENT, AND LAND ACQUISITION  WHILE THE REVISION IS A REQUIREMENT TO MAINTAIN ELIGIBILITY FOR STATE WILDLIFE GRANT FUNDING, REVISING THE SWAP PLAN IS TIMELY AND CRITICAL TO OUR COLLABORATIVE CONSERVATION WORK  WE WILL UTILIZE TECHNICAL COMMITTEES AND AN ADVISORY COMMITTEE TO COMPLETE THE SWAP REVISION AS DETAILED IN THE PROPOSED SCHEDULE  TECHNICAL TEAMS WILL BE LED BY SPECIES AND HABITAT EXPERTS IN GEORGIA DNR BUT WILL ALSO INCLUDE OUTSIDE EXPERTISE FROM OTHER AGENCIES, ACADEMIA, AND CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS  TECHNICAL TEAM LEADERS WILL ENGAGE THEIR TEAMS THROUGH IN PERSON AND VIRTUALMEETINGS THROUGHOUT THE REVISION PROCESS  TECHNICAL TEAMS WILL FOLLOW RECENTLY DEVELOPED RECOMMENDATIONS TOIDENTIFY, ASSESS, AND PRIORITIZE SGCN

THE PENNSYLVANIA AMPHIBIAN AND REPTILE SURVEY  PARS  PROJECT IS A HIGHLY SUCCESSFUL CITIZEN SCIENCE FOCUSED EFFORT TO GATHER COMPREHENSIVE INFORMATION ON THESE TAXA  INITIATED IN 2013, THE PROJECT NOW HAS OVER 2,500 REGISTERED VOLUNTEERS WHO PROVIDE INFORMATION WHICH, AFTER RIGOROUS VERIFICATION PROCESSES, IS ENTERED INTO A CENTRAL DATABASE  THE MOST COMPLETE, UP TO DATE PENNSYLVANIA AMPHIBIAN AND REPTILE INFORMATION WILL BE AVAILABLE IN THE RESULTING ATLAS  UNDER PFBC JURISDICTION, AMPHIBIANS AND REPTILES PROVIDE VITAL ECOLOGICAL FUNCTIONS, SERVING AS BOTH PREY AND PREDATOR ACROSS AQUATIC AND TERRESTRIAL HABITATS  INFORMATION GARNERED BY THIS PROJECT IS CRUCIAL TO DEVELOPING SCIENCE BASED CONSERVATION ACTION PLANS AND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS  THIS PROJECT WILL HELP MAINTAIN THE PARS DATABASE AND WEBSITE, CREATE NEW FOCAL SPECIES TEAMS, ESTABLISH A LONG TERM AMPHIBIAN AND REPTILE MONITORING PROGRAM, AND SUPPORT THE PA WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN COMPREHENSIVE REVIEW AND REVISION BY ASSESSING AMPHIBIANS AND REPTILES AND ENTERING INTO, OR UPDATING INFORMATION IN, THE PA WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN DATABASE  ADDITIONALLY, TASKS WILL ALSO ASSESS THE FEASIBILITY OF REINTRODUCING SPECIES BY DEVELOPING A SUITABILITY MATRIX AND STOCKING TWO AMPHIBIAN SPECIES  THE AMPHIBIANS AND REPTILES, EXTENSIVE VOLUNTEER COMMUNITY    2,400 REGISTERED    6,000 UNREGISTERED , AS WELL AS ALL PENNSYLVANIANS CONCERNED AND INTERESTED ABOUT THESE ANIMALS WILL BENEFIT FROM THE INCREASED KNOWLEDGE AND ANTICIPATED SECUREMENT OF THESE ANIMALS  THIS PROJECT WILL BE LED BY THE PENNSYLVANIA FISH AND BOAT COMMISSION, WITH THE MID ATLANTIC CENTER FOR HERPETOLOGY AND CONSERVATION SERVING AS A SUBRECIPIENT

RECENT RESEARCH DESCRIBING THE RELATIVE ABUNDANCE AND TROPHIC ECOLOGY OF SCALLOPED AND CAROLINAHAMMERHEADS SHOWED THAT SOUTH CAROLINA NURSERY AREAS HAVE THE HIGHEST ABUNDANCE OF NEWBORNCAROLINA HAMMERHEADS IN THE SOUTHEAST US  AND LIKELY THE WORLD   HOWEVER, LITTLE TO NO INFORMATION ISKNOWN ABOUT JUVENILE AND ADULT CAROLINA HAMMERHEADS  THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE THE FIRSTMOVEMENT ECOLOGY DATA FOR CAROLINA HAMMERHEADS, ALLOWING UNDERSTANDING OF HABITAT USE, DISTRIBUTION,AND CONSERVATION RISK  SPECIFIC PROJECTS ARE  1  GENERATE LONG TERM HORIZONTAL MOVEMENTS OF 3 CAROLINAHAMMERHEADS IN THE WESTERN NORTH ATLANTIC 2  COMPARE THEIR DISTRIBUTION TO SCALLOPED HAMMERHEADS 3 DEVELOP PREDICTIVE SEASONAL HABITAT MODELS USING ENVIRONMENTAL DATA TO DETERMINE AVAILABLE HABITAT,ALLOWING INSIGHT INTO CAROLINA HAMMERHEAD S LIMITED DISTRIBUTION, AND 4  DEVELOP OUTREACH MATERIALS TOINCORPORATE PROJECT RESULTS INTO CURRENT SCDNR EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS AND SC SWAP

HORSESHOE CRABS  LIMULUS POLYPHEMUS  PROVIDE AN INFLUX OF MARINE DERIVED NUTRIENTS TO TERRESTRIAL ECOSYSTEMS WHEN THEY LAY THEIR EGGS IN INTERTIDAL SEDIMENTS  THESE EGGS ARE CONSUMED BY MANY ORGANISMS, INCLUDING MANY MIGRATORY SHOREBIRDS, SUCH AS THE FEDERALLY LISTED RUFA RED KNOT  CALIDRIS CANUTUS RUFA   THE LINK BETWEEN HORSESHOE CRAB EGGS AND RED KNOTS IS ESPECIALLY WELL DESCRIBED IN THE DELAWARE BAY, WHERE RED KNOTS DEPEND ON HORSESHOE CRAB EGGS TO FUEL THEIR MIGRATION TO ARCTIC SPAWNING GROUNDS  THIS LINK HAS LED TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN ADAPTIVE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT  ARM  MODEL BY THE ATLANTIC STATES MARINE FISHERIES COMMISSION THAT IS USED TO SET HARVEST LIMITS ON HORSESHOE CRABS IN THE DELAWARE BAY REGION  IN SOUTH CAROLINA  SC , HORSESHOE CRABS SPAWN FROM APRIL TO JUNE WHEN RED KNOTS AND OTHER MIGRATORY SHOREBIRDS ARE PRESENT  HOWEVER, IT REMAINS UNKNOWN WHETHER THESE BIRDS ARE AS DEPENDENT ON HORSESHOE CRAB EGGS IN SC AS THEY ARE IN THE DELAWARE BAY REGION  THIS PROJECT AIMS TO TACKLE THAT QUESTION BY INVESTIGATING  1  CHANGES IN HORSESHOE CRAB EGG AVAILABILITY TO SHOREBIRDS OVER THE SPAWNING SEASON  2  CHANGES IN THE DIET COMPOSITION OF SHOREBIRDS AS HORSESHOE CRAB EGGS BECOME AVAILABLE FOR CONSUMPTION  AND 3  THE NUTRITIONAL VALUE OF HORSESHOE CRAB EGGS COMPARED TO OTHER PREY ITEMS CONSUMED BY MIGRATORY SHOREBIRDS  THE RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED IN EFFORTS TO IDENTIFY WHETHER AN ARM FRAMEWORK IS APPROPRIATE FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF HORSESHOE CRABS IN SC  ADDITIONALLY, THE FINDINGS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO EDUCATIONAL EVENTS AND OUTREACH MATERIALS USED TO EDUCATE THE PUBLIC ON THE HORSESHOE CRAB SHOREBIRD CONNECTION IN SC

AS THE LONGEST FREE FLOWING BLACKWATER RIVER IN THE UNITED STATES THE EDISTO RIVER SUPPORTS AN IMMENSE DIVERSITY OF AQUATIC SPECIES, INCLUDING 87 FRESHWATER FISH SPECIES AND 120 MARINE FISH SPECIES  FIFTEEN FRESHWATER FISH SPECIES, FOUR DIADROMOUS FISH SPECIES, AND THIRTEEN FRESHWATER MUSSEL SPECIES INHABITING THE EDISTO RIVER BASIN WERE LISTED AS SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED IN THE SOUTH CAROLINA 2015 STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN  SWAP   THESE SPECIES FACE A SEVERE THREAT FROM INCREASING HUMAN APPROPRIATION OF WATER RESOURCES FOR PUBLIC, AGRICULTURAL, OR OTHER USES  THE EDISTO RIVER HAS THE HIGHEST NUMBER OF WATER WITHDRAWAL REGISTRATIONS AND THE HIGHEST MAXIMUM MONTHLY WITHDRAWALS OF ANY RIVER BASIN IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA  REDUCED FLOWS MAY NEGATIVELY IMPACT SWAP LISTED FISH SPECIES THROUGH A VARIETY OF MECHANISMS, BUT ELEVATED SUMMERTIME WATER TEMPERATURES DURING LOW FLOW EVENTS COULD BE ESPECIALLY DETRIMENTAL TO SWAP SPECIES SUCH AS STRIPED BASS  MORONE SAXATILIS  THAT REQUIRE COOLWATER HABITATS  KEY KNOWLEDGE GAPS LIMIT OUR ABILITY TO UNDERSTAND HOW INCREASES IN SUMMERTIME FLOW DEPENDENT TEMPERATURE MAY NEGATIVELY IMPACT SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED IN THE EDISTO RIVER BASIN  THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO QUANTIFY THE EFFECT OF MEAN DAILY FLOW ON SUMMERTIME WATER TEMPERATURES IN THE EDISTO RIVER, MODEL SUMMERTIME WATER TEMPERATURE UNDER CURRENT AND FUTURE CLIMATE AND WATER WITHDRAWAL SCENARIOS, AND DETERMINE IF THERMAL TOLERANCES OF SELECTED SWAP FISHES ARE EXCEEDED

GUAM DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE S DIVISION OF AQUATIC AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES  DAWR  HAS BEEN DOCUMENTING SEA TURTLE NESTING ON GUAM SINCE THE 1970 S  DURING THE 2010 S DAWR ESTABLISHED A MORE CONSISTENT AND RELIABLE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM TO MONITOR SEA TURTLE NESTING, SPECIFICALLY AT COCOS ISLAND AND JINAPSAN BEACH  THESE TWO LOCATIONS ARE A PRIORITY FOR MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT BECAUSE ANNUALLY, COCOS ISLAND IS ONE OF THE MOST ACTIVE SEA TURTLE NESTING BEACHES ON GUAM, WHILE JINAPSAN BEACH IS ONE PART OF THE NORTHERN COAST  THE ENTIRE NORTHERN COAST IS ALSO A VERY ACTIVE SEA TURTLE NESTING SITE  THIS GRANT ALLOWS DAWR TO CONTINUE WITH MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT OF SEA TURTLE NESTING IN THESE AREAS  A PREVIOUS SWG PROJECT  ISLAND WIDE NESTING HABITAT ASSESSMENT  ALSO IDENTIFIED OTHER NESTING BEACHES THAT ARE NOT AS ACTIVE AS COCOS ISLAND AND JINAPSAN, BUT HAVE SEEN MORE NESTING ACTIVITY IN RECENT YEARS  IT WILL ALSO ALLOW FOR OUTREACH AND EDUCATION OF SEA TURTLE INFORMATION TO THE PUBLIC VIA A VOLUNTEER PROGRAM  HAGGAN WATCH , AND QUARTERLY AGENCY PARTNER MEETINGS  HAGGAN HUDDLE   MONITORING SEA TURTLE NESTING AT THROUGHOUT GUAM WILL HELP ASSESS POPULATION STRUCTURE OF GUAM S NESTING POPULATION, WHILE THE EDUCATION AND OUTREACH COMPONENT WILL KEEP THE PUBLIC AND PARTNER AGENCIES INFORMED ABOUT GUAM S SEA TURTLES, THUS MEETING PRIORITY ACTIONS FOR THESE TWO SPECIES IN GUAM S WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN

THIS GRANT IS PRIMARILY A SUBAWARD TO MISSOURI STATE UNIVERSITY  ODWC WILL PROVIDE MINIMAL FIELD ASSISTANCE AS NEEDED  THIS PROJECT IS A SURVEY FOR ALLIGATOR SNAPPING TURTLES  MACROCHELYS TEMMINCKII  IN RIVERS AND LARGE STREAMS IN THE EASTERN THIRD OF OKLAHOMA  THE SITES WHERE SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED ARE WATERS WHERE HISTORIC RECORDS EXISTS TO DOCUMENT THE SPECIES  PAST OCCURRENCE, BUT WHERE FEW OR NO ALLIGATOR SNAPPING TURTLES HAVE BEEN SEEN OR CAPTURED IN THE PAST THIRTY YEARS TO ASSESS ITS CURRENT STATUS  ALLIGATOR SNAPPING TURTLES ARE WIDESPREAD WITHIN THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES, BUT THIS SPECIES IS SECRETIVE AND DIFFICULT TO DOCUMENT, AND AS A RESULT THERE REMAIN SUBSTANTIAL GAPS IN WHAT IS KNOWN OF THEIR DISTRIBUTION  SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED USING BAITED HOOP TRAPS AT LOCATIONS THAT THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION HAS IDENTIFIED AS THE MOST PRESSING DISTRIBUTIONAL DATA GAPS FOR THIS SPECIES  NATIVE FISH WILL BE USED AS BAIT IN THE HOOP TRAPS AND SURVEY EFFORT WILL OCCUR IN THE EARLY AND MID SUMMER, AND AGAIN IN THE EARLY FALL MONTHS WHEN WATER TEMPERATURES ARE MODERATE AND MOST OPTIMAL FOR ALLIGATOR SNAPPING TURTLE ACTIVITY  A MINIMUM OF 80 NET NIGHTS OF EFFORT WILL TAKE PLACE AT EACH SITE THAT IS SURVEYED AND THIS MAY BE INCREASED IN ORDER TO CAPTURE AT LEAST THREE INDIVIDUALS TO ESTIMATE POPULATION SIZE AND STRUCTURE UPON CAPTURE, EACH ALLIGATOR SNAPPING TURTLE WILL BE SEXED USING EXTERNAL MORPHOLOGICAL CHARACTERS, MEASURED, AND WEIGHED  A HOLE WILL BE DRILLED IN A COMMON MARGINAL SCUTE TO IDENTIFY THE ANIMALS AS CAPTURED, AND A PIT TAG WITH A UNIQUE ALPHA NUMERIC CODE WILL BE INJECTED SUBCUTANEOUSLY IN THE RIGHT REAR THIGH  THE LOCATION OVER EVERY INDIVIDUAL WILL ALSO BE GEOREFERENCED  ALL CO OCCURRING TURTLES AND FISH THAT ARE CAPTURED IN THE HOOP TRAPS WILL BE COUNTED AND IDENTIFIED TO SPECIES  ALL TURTLES ALSO WILL BE WEIGHED, MEASURED AND GIVEN A DISCRETE TEMPORARY PAINT MARK TO IDENTIFY IT AS PREVIOUSLY CAPTURED FOR THE DURATION OF THE SURVEY  THESE DATA WILL BE USED TO GENERATE AN ESTIMATE OF RELATIVE ABUNDANCE OF EACH TURTLE SPECIES WITHIN IN WATERSHED

DUE TO ALABAMA S WIDE VARIETY OF PHYSIOGRAPHIC REGIONS AND AQUATIC HABITAT, IT HOSTS THE MOST DIVERSE ASSEMBLAGE OF FRESHWATERWILDLIFE IN NORTH AMERICA  HISTORICALLY, ALABAMA WATERS WERE HOME TO OVER 204 SPECIES OF FRESHWATER SNAILS, OVER 184 SPECIES OFFRESHWATER MUSSELS, AND OVER 300 SPECIES OF NATIVE FRESHWATER FISHES  THE HIGH DEGREE OF IMPERILMENT IN ALABAMA IS DUE TOHISTORICAL POLLUTION AND MODIFICATION OF RIVERINE HABITATS ACROSS MULTIPLE DRAINAGE BASINS IN THE STATE  MANY SPECIES OF MOLLUSKS,FISHES, AND CRAYFISHES ARE NOW ENDANGERED, THREATENED, OR IMPERILED  AT VARIOUS LOCATIONS AROUND THE COUNTRY, CAPTIVE PROPAGATIONEFFORTS INVOLVING FRESHWATER FISH, MUSSELS, AND SNAILS ARE UNDERWAY TO CONSERVE AND REINTRODUCE THEM INTO AREAS OF THEIR FORMERRANGES  IN ALABAMA WATERS, INITIAL EFFORTS TO REINTRODUCE EXTIRPATED AQUATIC AND OR FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES INTO PORTIONS OF THEIRFORMER RANGES WERE INITIATED THROUGH THE COOPERATIVE EFFORTS OF GOVERNMENT AND PRIVATE CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS  ONGOING EFFORTSTO IMPROVE RIVERINE HABITATS VIA MODIFIED FLOW REGIMES, LAND ACQUISITION, AND STREAM RESTORATION PROJECTS WILL INCREASE OPPORTUNITIESTO RESTORE POPULATIONS OF AQUATIC SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED  SGCN  THROUGH REINTRODUCTION AND AUGMENTATION  ASPROPAGATION AND CULTURE TECHNIQUES FOR SGCN AQUATIC SPECIES HAVE BEEN ONGOING FOR MORE THAN 20 YEARS, THE PRIMARY LIMITING FACTORIN THE EXPANSION OF THESE EFFORTS IN ALABAMA HAS BEEN THE AVAILABILITY OF ADEQUATE FACILITIES AND PERSONNEL DEDICATED TO THIS EFFORT  IN2004, WITH FUNDING PROVIDED IN PART THROUGH THE STATE WILDLIFE GRANT, AL T  2 1, THE ALABAMA DIVISION OF WILDLIFE AND FRESHWATERFISHERIES INITIATED THE DEVELOPMENT OF A NEW FACILITY DEDICATED TO THE PROPAGATION AND CONSERVATION OF ALABAMA S SGCN AQUATICSPECIES  THIS FACILITY, THE ALABAMA AQUATIC BIODIVERSITY CENTER  AABC  BASED NEAR MARION, HAS BEEN IN FULL OPERATION SINCE 2010 PROJECT ACTIVITIES INVOLVE 1  AABC ADMINISTRATION AND OVERHEAD  2  AQUATIC SGCN PROPAGATION, CAPTIVE CARE, AND FIELD ACTIVITIES  3 INVESTIGATION OF AQUATIC SGCNS FIELD MORTALITIES AND RESCUES  4  AQUATIC SGCN PARASITE, DISEASE, AND TOXICOLOGY STUDIES, AND 5 SCIENTIFIC ASSESSMENT OF AQUATIC SGCNS

WE PROPOSE TO EXAMINE 8 AQUATIC INSECT SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED FROM THE ORDERS EPHEMEROPTERA PLECOPTERA AND TRICHOPTERA EPT LARVAL EPT TAXA ARE IMPORTANT WATER QUALITY INDICATORS AND OFTEN USED IN BIOASSESSMENT THESE 8 SPECIES ARE SGCN SPECIES BECAUSE THEY ARE EITHER RARE LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT THEM OR BOTH WE WILL REVIEW THE LITERATURE AND MUSEUM RECORDS TO DETERMINE KNOWN DISTRIBUTIONS AND CONDUCT FIELD SURVEYS AT HISTORICAL AND POTENTIAL NEW SAMPLING LOCALITIES WE WILL EXTRACT DNA AND DEVELOP SPECIES SPECIFIC PRIMERS AND A DATABASE OF DNA SEQUENCES WE WILL PERFORM EDNA SAMPLING AT APPROXIMATELY 32 ADDITIONAL SITES IN YEAR 2 WITHIN AND AROUND THE HISTORICAL WATERSHEDS NECHES SABINE SAN JACINTO AND BRAZOS USING OUR SPECIESSPECIFIC PRIMERS WE WILL DETECT THE PRESENCE OR ABSENCE OF EACH OF THE 8 EPT TAXA AS WELL AS MEASURE THEIR ABUNDANCE USING GEL ELECTROPHORESIS

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO FILL SIGNIFICANT DATA GAPS REGARDING ROAD RELATED STREAM BARRIERS AND UNPAVED ROADS IN A HIGH PRIORITY WATERSHED  WE WILL USE OUR WORK TO CREATE COMMUNICATION MATERIALS THAT CAN BE USED BY EXISTING PARTNERSHIPS TO COMMUNICATE THE IMPORTANCE OF UNPAVED ROAD AND STREAM BARRIER REMEDIATION WORK AND HELP TO LEVERAGE ADDITIONAL RESOURCES  TO DO THIS, THE PROJECT HAS THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES 1  USE ESTABLISHED PROTOCOLS TO ASSESS, INVENTORY, AND PRIORITIZE ROAD RELATED STREAM BARRIERS IN THE UPPER SALINE RIVER WATERSHED 2  USE ESTABLISHED PROTOCOLS TO ASSESS, INVENTORY, AND PRIORITIZE UNPAVED ROADS IN THE UPPER SALINE RIVER WATERSHED 3  USE THIS PROJECT TO DEMONSTRATE THE VALUE AND MISSION OF THE ARKANSAS STREAM HERITAGE PARTNERSHIP AND COMMUNICATE THE IMPORTANCE OF STREAM BARRIER REMOVAL AND UNPAVED ROAD BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FUNDS OBLIGATED TO THIS PROJECT WILL BE SUB AWARDED TO THE NATURE CONSERVANCY

THE PURPOSE OF THIS STUDY IS TO IDENTIFY POTENTIAL THREATS TO E  CLINTON BY UNDERSTANDING THE DRIVERS OF OCCUPANCY AND THE SPATIAL GENETIC STRUCTURE OF THE SPECIES, AS WELL AS FILL INFORMATION GAPS REGARDING THE REPRODUCTIVE LIFE HISTORY OF E  CLINTON  OUR SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES INCLUDE TO 1  IDENTIFY DRIVERS OF OCCUPANCY OF E  CLINTON  DRIVERS OF OCCUPANCY THAT WILL BE CONSIDERED INCLUDE LOCAL SCALE INSTREAM HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS AND WATERSHED SCALE FACTORS SUCH AS LAND USE, FRAGMENTATION, AND STREAM NETWORK CHARACTERISTICS 2  DESCRIBE THE GENETIC DIVERSITY AND STRUCTURE OF E  CLINTON WITHIN AND BETWEEN THE UPPER OUACHITA AND CADDO RIVERS  FIN CLIPS WILL BE COLLECTED FROM TRIBUTARY AND MAINSTEM SITES IDENTIFIED FROM OCCUPANCY ANALYSIS 3  DESCRIBE THE SPAWNING SEASON AND BASIC REPRODUCTIVE LIFE HISTORY TRAITS OF E  CLINTON FUNDS OBLIGATED TO THIS PROJECT WILL BE SUB AWARDED TO THE UNIVERSITY OF ARKANSAS AND OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY

THE OVERALL PURPOSE OF THIS STUDY IS TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE S  OF WOOD FROG MASS MORTALITY EVENTS IN ARKANSAS AND TO IDENTIFY WHETHER WOOD FROGS HAVE EXPERIENCED A BOTTLENECK  THE FINAL PRODUCTS OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE QUANTITATIVE DATA ON VIRAL, FUNGAL, AND PARASITIC PATHOGENS, AS WELL AS A CONTEMPORARY GENETIC ANALYSIS, BY COMPLETING THREE MAIN OBJECTIVES 1  SURVEY WETLANDS FOR MASS MORTALITY EVENTS AND ENVIRONMENTAL DNA OF SUSPECTEDPATHOGENS 2  DETERMINE THE PRESENCE OF RANAVIRUSES, CHYTRID FUNGI, AND PARASITES USING MOLECULAR METHODS, MICRO DISSECTIONS, AND DIGITAL MICROSCOPY IN THE LABORATORY 3  USE NEXT GENERATION SEQUENCING METHODS TO DETERMINE WOOD FROG GENETIC DIVERSITY AND TEST FOR POPULATION BOTTLENECKS

THE PURPOSE OF THIS STUDY IS TO CONDUCT A PHYLOGENOMIC RE EVALUATION OF THE NOTROPIS RUBELLUS SPECIES GROUP, IN ORDER TO PROVIDE AN UPDATED TAXONOMIC STATUS AND CONSERVATION GENETIC ASSESSMENT FOR THE OUACHITA RIVER  CLADE F  POPULATION  FUNDS OBLIGATED TO THIS PROJECT WILL BE SUB AWARDED TO ARKANSAS STATE UNIVERSITY

THE MAIN OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO OBTAIN BASELINE INFORMATION ON POPULATION DISTRIBUTION AND STATUS, HABITAT REQUIREMENTS, HOST PLANT ASSOCIATIONS, AND SEASONAL OCCURRENCE OF NATIVE BEES IN ARKANSAS  IN PARTICULAR, WE WILL CONDUCT STATEWIDE SURVEYS  OVER A PERIOD OF TWO YEARS  TO DOCUMENT THE POPULATION STATUS AND DIVERSITY OF NATIVE BEES AND THEIR ASSOCIATION WITH NATIVE FLOWERING PLANTS AND HABITATS  WE WILL CONDUCT VARIOUS STATISTICAL ANALYSES AND IDENTIFY RARE OR ENDANGERED SPECIES OF NATIVE BEES  INCLUDING SPECIES THAT ARE NOT IN THE SGCN LIST  IN ARKANSAS  BASED ON THE FINDINGS OF THE PROPOSED STUDY, WE WILL DEVELOP ONLINE RESOURCES DOCUMENTING NATIVE BEES OF ARKANSAS AND THEIR HABITAT  THESE RESOURCES WILL BE HELPFUL IN MAKING PUBLIC AWARE OF OUR NATIVE BEES AND THEIR HABITATS, AND SUCH INITIATIVES WILL LEAD TO THE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF NATIVE BEES IN ARKANSAS  FUNDS OBLIGATED TO THIS PROJECT WILL BE SUB AWARDED TO THE UNIVERSITY OF ARKANSAS

THIS GRANT WILL FUND A STUDY TO USE MORPHOLOGICAL AND GENETIC ANALYSES TO REFINE THE TAXONOMY OF PRIORITY PROCAMBARUS SPECIES AND TO PROVIDE A ROBUST FOUNDATION FROM WHICH TO GUIDE FUTURE CONSERVATION STRATEGIES FOR THIS GROUP THIS RESEARCH PROJECT WILL BUILD ON OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE TAXONOMY OF PROCAMBARUS CRAYFISHES IN SC,INCLUDING DELIMITATIONS OF SPECIES LISTED IN THE SOUTH CAROLINA S STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN

MANY SEABIRDS AND SHOREBIRDS ARE AT MUCH LOWER POPULATION LEVELS THAN IN THE 1800S, AND RECENT DATA SUGGESTS THEIR POPULATION LEVELS HAVE DECLINED BY 70  IN THE LAST 40 YEARS  ALTHOUGH WE MAY NOT BE ABLE TO RESTORE POPULATIONS TO HISTORICAL NUMBERS OR TO ALLEVIATE ALL THREATS TO THESE SPECIES  CONSERVATION OF IMPORTANT HABITAT, MONITORING OF SPECIES ABUNDANCE, AND EDUCATION CAN PREVENT FURTHER DECLINES  THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROMOTE THE CONSERVATION OF WATERBIRDS BY PROTECTING NESTING AND FORAGING AREAS, MONITORING PRODUCTIVITY AND POPULATION STATUSES, AND PROVIDING GUIDANCE TO LAND MANAGERS AND THE PUBLIC  OBJECTIVES WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY  POSTING NESTING CLOSURES AND EDUCATIONAL SIGNS MONITORING FOR VIOLATIONS, PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  BMPS  TO VISITORS AND PROPERTY MANAGERS, CONDUCTING NEST COUNTS  BY GROUND AND THROUGH AERIAL PHOTOGRAPHY , DOCUMENTING AND ANALYZING REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS, CONDUCTING WORKSHOPS AND GIVING PRESENTATION TO KEY AUDIENCES, PARTICIPATING IN SCIENTIFIC MEETINGS AND RESEARCH BY SHARING DATA, AND BY PRODUCING PRESS RELEASES  RESULTS EXPECTED ARE MANY  POSTING OF SEABIRD NESTING AREAS WILL REDUCE DISTURBANCE DURING THE NESTING SEASON  DATA FROM NEST COUNTS AND OTHER SURVEYS WILL HELP IN DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS TO REVERSE OR SLOW DECLINES IN NUMEROUS WATERBIRD SPECIES THAT NEST IN SOUTH CAROLINA  SUCCESSFUL MANAGEMENT OF HABITATS WILL ALSO POSITIVELY AFFECT WINTERING AND MIGRATION SURVIVAL OF HIGHEST, HIGH, AND MODERATE CONSERVATION CONCERN SPECIES  COLLABORATION AND COORDINATION WITH LOCAL AND REGIONAL PARTNERS WILL IMPROVE OUTCOMES FOR AT RISK WATERBIRDS WITHIN SOUTH CAROLINA AND AT LARGER GEOGRAPHIC SCALES

THIS GRANT WILL ENHANCE, RESTORE, OR CREATE SUITABLE HABITAT FOR REPTILE AND AMPHIBIAN SPECIES WITH A FOCUS ON SGCN THIS GRANT WILL ALSO AUGMENT EXISTING POPULATIONS OF OF REPTILES AND AMPHIBIANS THROUGH BREEDING, REARING IN CAPTIVITY, AND HEAD STARTING SPECIES TO RESTORE POPULATIONS WHERE HABITAT HAS BEEN RESTORED, AND IN THE CASE OF HELLBENDERS, TO PROVIDE A NON WILD SOURCE OF ANIMALS FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES

GUADALUPE BASS MICROPTERUS TRECULII HEREAFTER GB IS A SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED SGCN DUE TO HYBRIDIZATION WITH NONNATIVE SMALLMOUTH BASS INSTREAM HABITAT LOSS AND FLOW REGIME ALTERATION PRACTITIONERS TASKED WITH MANAGING GB RELY ON TOOLS THAT SHED LIGHT ON HABITAT QUALITY AND CONSEQUENT HEALTH OF INDIVIDUALS AND POPULATIONS BIOENERGETICS MODELING BEM IS ONE SUCH TOOL USED FREQUENTLY BY FISHERIES MANAGERS TO PREDICT SURVIVAL AND GROWTH GIVEN ENVIRONMENTAL TEMPERATURE AND PREY AVAILABILITY SPECIESSPECIFIC PHYSIOLOGICAL PARAMETERS ARE REQUIRED TO DEVELOP BEMS BUT THESE PARAMETERS HAVE NOT BEEN MEASURED FOR GB THE FIRST OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO MEASURE IN THE LAB THE FOUR ESSENTIAL PHYSIOLOGICAL PARAMETERS FOR GB WHICH INCLUDE THE TEMPERATURE AND MASSDEPENDENCE OF CONSUMPTION AND RESPIRATION NEXT FIELDBASED AND LABBASED MEASUREMENTS OF GB GROWTH WILL BE USED TO VALIDATE THE BEM LASTLY THE VALIDATED BEM WILL BE USED TO PROJECT AND COMPARE PREY DEMAND AND GROWTH POTENTIAL ACROSS 8119 PERENNIAL INTERCONFLUENCE STREAM REACHES HEREAFTER REACHES SPANNING THE ENTIRE GEOGRAPHIC RANGE OF GB THESE PROJECTIONS WILL EXPLORE ALTERNATIVE SCENARIOS OF TEMPERATURE EG UNDER CLIMATE CHANGE ANDOR SPRINGFLOW DECLINES AND PREY AVAILABILITY EG ALTERED BY COMPETITION WITH OTHER MICROPTERIDS

CHICKEN TURTLES  DEIROCHELYS RETICULARIA  ARE SEMI AQUATIC MEMBERS OF THE EMYDIDAE FAMILY THAT INHABIT SHALLOW, EPHEMERAL WETLANDS AND ADJACENT TERRESTRIAL HABITATS IN THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES  ALTHOUGH LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT THE WESTERN CHICKEN TURTLE  WCT  DEIROCHELYS RETICULARIA MIARIA , IT IS PERCEIVED AS RARE AND UNCERTAINTY REGARDING ITS BIOLOGY, DISTRIBUTION, AND ABUNDANCE PROMPTED THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS  TO ISSUE A 90 DAY FINDING THAT STATES LISTING MAY BE WARRANTED  USFWS 2011   RECENT RESEARCH IN TEXAS SUGGESTS THAT THE SPECIES CAN BE DIFFICULT TO DETECT AND POTENTIALLY MORE COMMON THAN PREVIOUSLY THOUGHT, BUT INFORMATION ON POPULATION STRUCTURE AND DYNAMICS IS STILL LACKING  HERE WE PROPOSE RESEARCH THAT BUILDS ON OUR CURRENT RESEARCH PROGRAM BY 1  CHARACTERIZING STATE WIDE POPULATION GENETIC STRUCTURE, AND 2  CONTINUING MARK RECAPTURE STUDIES TO DETERMINE DETECTION PROBABILITIES, ESTIMATE SURVIVAL RATES, AND CHARACTERIZE THE POPULATION DYNAMICS OF WCTS IN TWO TEXAS ECOREGIONS  THESE DATA WILL HELP DETERMINE IF FEDERAL LISTING OR STATE PROTECTION IS WARRANTED, AND GUIDE REGIONAL CONSERVATION PLANNING ALONG WITH THE TEXAS CONSERVATION ACTION PLAN  TCAP 2012, PG  61

THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO SUPPORT ECOLOGICALLY SOUND, SCIENCE BASED WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE DATA COLLECTION RESEARCH AND MONITORING ON THE HEALTH, ABUNDANCE, AND DISTRIBUTION OF SMALL AND MESO MAMMALS AND INVERTEBRATES IN THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA  INVASIVE PLANT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE EARLY DETECTION AND RAPID RESPONSE REMOVAL, RESTORATION OF NATIVE SPECIES, AND CONTINUED LEADERSHIP OF THE NATIONAL CAPITAL PARTNERSHIP FOR REGIONAL INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT TO IMPROVE HABITAT FOR NATIVE PLANTS AND ANIMALS  EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE MAINTAINING HEALTHY AND SUSTAINABLE POPULATIONS OF WILDLIFE WITHIN BIOLOGICAL AND CULTURAL LIMITS, WHICH SUPPORTS THE DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT S MISSION OF CONSERVATION  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE PLANTS AND ANIMALS THAT RESIDE IN THE TERRESTRIAL AND AQUATIC HABITATS AND PUBLIC WHO USE AND APPRECIATE THESE NATURAL RESOURCES  THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENSURE DATA DRIVEN MANAGEMENT AND DECISION MAKING THAT WOULD IMPACT NATURAL RESOURCES ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE INVENTORY AND MONITORING AVIFAUNA, BREEDING BIRD SURVEYS, AND RESEARCHING THE DISTRIBUTION OF SPECIES IN THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA  EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE SUPPORTING OUR NATIVE BIRD SPECIES AND THE HABITATS THEY REQUIRE WHILE OCCUPYING AN URBAN SUBURBAN LOCATION, AND SUPPORTING THE DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENT S CONSERVATION AND SUSTAINABILITY GOALS  INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PUBLIC AND FUTURE GENERATIONS WHO WOULD USE THE DISTRICT S NATURAL SPACES  THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENTS ACTIVITIES

THE PURPOSE OF THIS STUDY IS TO EVALUATE THE FEASIBILITY OF USING A STRUCTURED DECISION MAKING SDM FRAMEWORK WITH THE NATURESERVE CALCULATOR TO IDENTIFY OUTCOMES THAT FACILITATE RECOVERY OF THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SDM HAS BEEN USED SUCCESSFULLY TO PRIORITIZE RESEARCH ACTIVITIES IN THE GUADALUPE BASIN WITH LIMITED INFORMATION RANDKLEV ET AL 2021 WHICH MAKES THIS APPROACH ATTRACTIVE FOR DEVELOPING A SIMILAR TOOL BASED ON THE NATURESERVE CALCULATOR UTILIZING IMPERILED MUSSEL SPECIES AS TEST SPECIES TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE TPWD AND US FISH WILDLIFE SERVICE USFWS CAN USE THE RESULTING INFORMATION TO HELP GUIDE CURRENT AND FUTURE CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES

THE SOUTHERN FLYING SQUIRREL  GLAUCOMYS VOLANS  HEREAFTER SFS  IS LISTED AS A SPECIES IN NEED OF CONSERVATION IN KANSAS AND LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT THE SPECIES ECOLOGY IN THE STATE  THIS PROJECT OUTLINES A PLAN TO SURVEY SFSS USING BAITED TRAIL CAMERAS, LIVE TRAPS, AND GENETIC DATA  TRAIL CAMERAS WILL BE USED TO SURVEY 300 SITES IN COUNTIES WITH KNOWN OCCURRENCES  THE DATA PROVIDED WILL INFORM OCCUPANCY MODELS AND DETERMINE HOW FOREST COMPOSITION, MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES, FRAGMENTATION, AND HUMAN INFLUENCE EFFECT SITE OCCUPANCY  LOCAL AND LANDSCAPE HABITAT VARIABLES COLLECTED AT THE SURVEY SITES AND REMOTELY WILL BE USED TO DEVELOP A HABITAT SUITABILITY MAP AND DEFINE THE GEOGRAPHIC DISTRIBUTION IN KANSAS  A SUBSET OF THE OCCUPIED SITES WILL BE RANDOMLY SELECTED TO BE SURVEYED USING LIVE TRAPS  CAPTURED INDIVIDUALS WILL BE UNIQUELY MARKED WITH A PIT TAG AND THE SITES WILL BE REVISITED ONCE EACH SUMMER FOR 3 YEARS  THE MARK RECAPTURE DATA WILL BE USED TO ESTIMATE POPULATION DENSITIES, CALCULATE AGE AND SEX RATIOS, AND ANNUAL SURVIVAL RATE  THE POPULATION DENSITY AND HABITAT VARIABLES COLLECTED WILL GIVE INSIGHT INTO HOW DENSITIES VARY WITH FOREST MANAGEMENT, STRUCTURE, AND COMPOSITION  TISSUE SAMPLES COLLECTED FROM LIVE TRAPPED INDIVIDUALS WILL BE USED FOR A COMPARATIVE ANALYSIS OF KANSAS SPECIMENS AND ELSEWHERE THROUGHOUT THEIR RANGE  GENETIC DATA WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION ON POPULATION HEALTH AND CONNECTIVITY OF KANSAS POPULATIONS  THE INFORMATION PROVIDED BY THE STUDY WILL INFORM EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION EFFORTS FOR THE SPECIES AS WELL AS ADDRESS CONSERVATION ISSUES LISTED IN STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN

THE FORT WORTH ZOO  FWZ  HAS WORKED WITH THE TEXAS HORNED LIZARD, PHRYNOSOMA CORNUTUM, FOR TWO DECADES AND IS A LEADER IN THE SPECIES CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT  IN 2007, FWZ BEGAN COLLABORATIONS WITH TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT  TPWD  AND TEXAS CHRISTIAN UNIVERSITY  TCU  TO GENETICALLY IDENTIFY TEXAS HORNED LIZARDS ACROSS THE STATE AND ESTABLISH REPEATABLE METHODOLOGIES FOR REINTRODUCTION  IN 2011, WE BEGAN A REINTRODUCTION PILOT STUDY USING CAPTIVE HATCHED LIZARDS ON A PRIVATE RANCH, WHICH WAS CONCLUDED AFTER SIX YEARS DUE TO HIGH HATCHLING MORTALITY FROM INVASIVE RED IMPORTED FIRE ANTS  SOLENOPSIS INVICTA, RIFA  AND OUR INABILITY TO MITIGATE ITS ABUNDANCE ON THE PROPERTY  PRIMARY FOCUS FOR THE REINTRODUCTION PROJECT THEN MOVED TO A MORE MANAGEABLE HABITAT ON MASON MOUNTAIN WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA  MMWMA  IN MASON, TX  SINCE THIS PROJECT BEGAN IN 2017, PROMISING MILESTONES HAVE BEEN REACHED TOWARDS THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A NEW TEXAS HORNED LIZARD POPULATION  I E , SURVIVORSHIP OF HATCHLINGS TO ADULT, REPRODUCTION, EGG LAYING, HATCHING OF F1S, ETC    DESPITE THESE SUCCESSES, CONSIDERABLE DISPARITY OF HATCHLING SURVIVORSHIP HAS OCCURRED FOR THE PAST TWO YEARS BETWEEN TWO RELEASE LOCATIONS ON THE MMWMA  BOTH LOCATIONS ARE VERY CLOSE AND HABITAT SIMILAR, SO IT IS THEORIZED SURVIVORSHIP IS CORRELATED TO PRESENCE OR ABSENCE OF RIFA AND THEIR IMPACTS TO HATCHLINGS FOOD SOURCE  THE FWZ IS REQUESTING FUNDING TO OFFSET A POSTDOCTORAL FELLOWS SALARY TO CONTINUE POST RELEASE MONITORING AND INVESTIGATE THE UTILITY OF A HIGHLY TARGETED PESTICIDE TREATMENT FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF RIFA  IMMEDIATE RESULTS ARE EXPECTED TO INCREASE HATCHLING GROWTH AND SURVIVORSHIP  LONG TERM BENEFITS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE THE COMPLETION OF AT TARGETED RIFA TREATMENT PLAN FOR TEXAS HORNED LIZARD CONSERVATION PROGRAMMING

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO IDENTIFY AND DIGITIZE THE BEE SPECIMENS DEPOSITED AT THE INVERTEBRATE ZOOLOGY COLLECTION OF THE MUSEUM OF TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY  IZC MOTTU  AND THE BEE COLLECTION AT THE LONGING ENTOMOLOGY LAB, WHICH NEEDS TO BE CURATED AND DIGITIZED FOR ACCESSION INTO THE IZC MOTTU, BECAUSE PORTIONS OF THESE MATERIALS ARE BULK PRESERVED IN ETHANOL SINCE THEIR COLLECTION  2018 2021   INFORMATION  INCLUDING LOCALITIES, HABITAT, COLLECTING DATE, COLLECTORS  WILL BE ENTERED INTO AND MADE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE THROUGH THE COLLECTIONS EXISTING SCAN, WHICH ALLOWS UPLOADING IMAGES  ALL SPECIMENS WILL BE IDENTIFIED TO SPECIES, WHEN POSSIBLE, WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF EXPERT BEE TAXONOMISTS  DNA BARCODE DATA WILL BE GENERATED FOR BEE SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED  SGCN   TABLE 1  AND NATIVE BEE SPECIALISTS ASSOCIATED WITH NAMA SP  STUDENT WORKERS WILL BE TRAINED IN CURATION AND DIGITIZATION OF INSECT SPECIMENS, AND BEE IDENTIFICATION

ACCORDING TO THE 2015 SWAP, BURROWING CRAYFISH WERE THE ONLY BEHAVIORAL CRAYFISH GROUP THAT WAS NOT THOROUGHLY SURVEYED DURING THE COMPREHENSIVE 2013 CRAYFISH ATLAS  LOUGHMAN AND WELSH 2013   AS SUCH, THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO FORMALLY DESCRIBE AND DETERMINE THE CONSERVATION STATUS FOR CAMBARUS SP  3 BEFORE CONSERVATION MANAGEMENT ACTIONS CAN BE TAKEN  IN ORDER TO DO SO, SURVEYS WILL NEED TO FOCUS ON DETERMINING THEIR DISTRIBUTIONS BY SUFFICIENT COLLECTION OF VOUCHER MATERIALS WITHIN THE C  DUBIUS COMPLEX  SWAP 2015  THERE IS EMPHASIZE ON RESEARCH NEEDS FOR CRAYFISH IN GENERAL BEFORE CONSERVATION ISSUES ARE ADDRESSED SUCH AS LAND USE ISSUES AND HABITAT LOSS  SWAP 2015  COMPLETION OF THIS WORK WILL RESULT IN WEST VIRGINIA BEING THE FIRST SOUTHEASTERN STATE TO HAVE ALL CRAYFISH FAUNA TAXONOMICALLY UNDERSTOOD  RECORDS OF OCCURRENCE WILL ALLOW US TO DETERMINE DISTRIBUTION FOR CAMBARUS SP  3  LIFE HISTORY AND ECOLOGY WILL BE ELUCIDATED FROM FIELD SURVEYS  SAMPLES COLLECTED DURING FIELD SURVEYS WILL LEADTO FORMAL TAXONOMIC DESCRIPTION OF CAMBARUS SP  3  THIS WORK COLLECTIVELY WILL ALLOW FOR CONSERVATION STATUS ASSESSMENT IMPORTANT TO STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN  SWAP  PLANNING  THE 2015 SWAP EMPHASIZED RESEARCH NEEDS FOR BURROWING CRAYFISH AS THEY WERE A BEHAVIORAL GROUP LEAST TARGETED DURING 2013 CRAYFISH ATLAS EFFORTS  LOUGHMAN AND WELSH 2013   CONSERVATION STATUS ASSESSMENT WILL ALLOW FOR CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ON THE GROUND FOR SPECIES DEALING WITH CURRENT THREATS AND STRESSES KNOWN TO CRAYFISH POPULATIONS SUCH AS LANDUSE CONVERSION ANDHABITAT LOSS  SWAP 2015

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IDENTIFY AND CHARACTERIZE MATERNITY ROOSTS OF CORA, LAIN, MYLU, MYSE, AND PESU  COLLECT MORPHOLOGICAL INFORMATION ON EPFU, LABO, LACI, LASE, AND MYAU  AND CONDUCT EARLY SPRING NWHC SURVEILLANCE TESTING FOR PD IN THE COASTAL PLAIN  WE WILL CONDUCT COASTAL PLAIN BAT SURVEYS IN AT LEAST SIX SITES  THREE PER YEAR  FROM THE FOLLOWING LIST  SEE ALSO FIGURE 1   BONNEAU FERRY WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA  WMA , BOTANY BAY PLANTATION HERITAGE PRESERVE  HP  WMA, DONNELLEY WMA, HAMILTON RIDGE WMA, MARSH WMA, TILLMAN SAND RIDGE HP WMA, WACCAMAW RIVER HP WMA, WEBB WILDLIFE CENTER, OR WOODBURY WMA  THE OBJECTIVES AT THESE SITES ARE TO 1  CONDUCT ACOUSTIC SURVEYS ON THE COASTAL PLAIN TO DETERMINE SPECIES RICHNESS AND IDENTIFY NETTING HOTSPOTS  2  CONDUCT BAT NETTING SURVEYS ON THE COASTAL PLAIN TO CONFIRM SPECIES PRESENCE AND COLLECT MORPHOLOGICAL INFORMATION FOR 10 OF THE HIGHEST PRIORITY SWAP BAT SPECIES  3  RADIO TAG, TRACK, AND CONDUCT EMERGENCE COUNTS ON A  PREGNANT OR LACTATING CORA, LAIN, MYLU, MYSE, AND PESU TO LOCATE AND CHARACTERIZE COASTAL MATERNITY COLONY ROOST HABITAT  AND B  ANY NON PREGNANT OR LACTATING LAIN, MYLU, OR MYSE TO LOCATE AND CHARACTERIZE COASTAL SUMMER ROOST HABITAT FOR THESE DATA DEFICIENT SPECIES  AND 4  CONDUCT EARLY SPRING PD SURVEILLANCE TESTING IN APR MAY IN NWHC COASTAL PLAIN PRIORITY AREAS  THE RESULTS WILL PROVIDE MUCH NEEDED SUMMER ROOST LOCATION AND HABITAT INFORMATION, WNS STATUS, AND SITE SPECIFIC BAT SPECIES RICHNESS INFORMATION OF COASTAL BAT SPECIES OF HIGHEST CONSERVATION CONCERN IN SOUTH CAROLINA  THIS INFORMATION WILL ASSIST DNR AND PARTNER AGENCIES IN HABITAT MANAGEMENT, BAT POPULATION MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION, REGULATORY DECISIONS, AND DISEASE SURVEILLANCE IN THE COASTAL PLAIN FOR THESE HIGH PRIORITY BAT SPECIES

THE EDWARDS AQUIFER RESEARCH AND DATA CENTER AT TEXAS STATE UNIVERSITY  EARDC  HOUSES THE WORLDS LARGEST COLLECTION OF TEXAS GROUNDWATER OBLIGATE AND GROUNDWATER DEPENDENT ORGANISMS, WITH PARTICULAR STRENGTH IN NON INSECT CRUSTACEANS  THE RAPIDLY EXPANDING COLLECTION ARCHIVES GROUNDWATER FAUNA FROM THE CENTRAL TEXAS KARST REGION AND BEYOND  E G , WEST TEXAS SPRINGS, STATEWIDE HYPORHEIC SAMPLES   MUCH OF THE COLLECTION CONSISTS OF SPECIMENS COLLECTED FROM THE 1970S THROUGH THE 1980S AND MORE RECENT COLLECTIONS FROM THE 2010S 2020S  THESE SPECIMENS ARE IN GOOD PHYSICAL CONDITION  PRESERVED IN POLY SEAL GLASS VIALS IN ETOH WITH INTERNAL LABELS  BUT ASSOCIATED DIGITAL DATA FOR OLDER SPECIMENS IS ENTIRELY LACKING  MANY SPECIMENS ARE ALSO NOT IDENTIFIED TO THE LOWEST POSSIBLE TAXONOMIC LEVEL  THE MORE RECENT LOTS CONSIST LARGELY OF SAMPLES COLLECTED BY CO PIS HUTCHINS AND SCHWARTZ DURING THE 2010S THROUGH 2020S, AND WHILE STORED AND LABELED IN A SIMILAR FASHION, ONGOING DATABASING EFFORTS BARELY KEEP UP WITH THE RAPID INTAKE OF NEW SAMPLES RESULTING FROM ONGOING MUNICIPAL   E G  CITY OF AUSTIN , STATE   E G  SWG  AND FEDERALLY   E G  U S  ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS  FUNDED PROJECTS THE ROUGHLY 200,000 SPECIMENS AND ASSOCIATED DATA IN THE EARDC AQUIFER BIODIVERSITY COLLECTION  ABC  ARE UNDERUTILIZED BY RESOURCE MANAGERS AND RESEARCHERS BECAUSE THE SPECIMENS ALMOST ENTIRELY LACK PROPER DIGITAL CURATION  EARDC HAS RECENTLY DEVELOPED AN ACCESSION PROTOCOL THAT MEETS DARWIN CORE STANDARDS AND HAS REGISTERED THE ABC AS AN OFFICIAL COLLECTION WITH THE GLOBAL REGISTRY OF SCIENTIFIC COLLECTIONS  TO DATE, OVER 3000 LOTS HAVE BEEN DIGITIZED AND TWO STAFF MEMBERS ALLOCATE PART TIME EFFORT  APPROXIMATELY 16 HOURS PER WEEK, COLLECTIVELY  TO DIGITIZING LOTS  THE ABC COLLECTION IS NOW THE PRIMARY REPOSITORY FOR ALL SPECIMENS OF GROUNDWATER ORGANISMS IN THE REGION, AND AS THE COLLECTION GROWS, BOTH THE AMOUNT OF DATA AND THE NEED FOR THESE DATA INCREASES  TRANSFORMING AND UPDATING THE ABC INTO A PROPERLY CURATED AND DIGITALLY ACCESSIBLE COLLECTION IS A HIGH PRIORITY FOR MANAGERS AND RESEARCHERS ALIKE DUE TO THE PREVALENCE OF SGCN TAXA IN GROUNDWATER HABITATS, AND IT IS CRITICAL FOR SUPPORTING ALL FUTURE WORK ON GROUNDWATER TAXA IN TEXAS WITH SWG SUPPORT, WE PROPOSE TO EXPAND DIGITIZING EFFORTS INTERNALLY OVER THE NEXT TWO YEARS, BUT ALSO TO UPLOAD THE FIRST BATCH OF SPECIMEN RECORDS ONLINE VIA IDIGBIO  ANTICIPATED 7000 LOTS  WHERE THEY CAN BE PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE TO RESEARCHERS AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS  WE WILL ALSO CONTINUE TO COLLABORATE WITH TAXONOMIC EXPERTS TO IDENTIFY LOTS REPRESENTING POTENTIAL SGCN TAXA, EVALUATE THE CONSERVATION STATUS OF RECENTLY DESCRIBED AND POORLY KNOWN TAXA THAT WERE NOT EVALUATED IN THE MOST RECENT STATE WIDE EVALUATION OF GROUNDWATER INVERTEBRATES  HUTCHINS, 2018 , AND USE THE RESULTING DATASET TO DEVELOP A YOUTH FOCUSED EDUCATION MODULE FOR OUR LONG RUNNING AQUATIC SCIENCE ADVENTURE CAMP THAT ILLUSTRATES THE IMPORTANCE OF NATURAL HISTORY COLLECTIONS IN NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT

THE CONSERVATION STATUS OF THE LARGE MAJORITY OF TEXAS NATIVE BEES HAS NOT BEEN ASSESSED IN OVER TWO DECADES, AND MANY SPECIES HAVE NEVER BEEN FORMALLY ASSESSED  DETERMINING SPECIES THAT ARE MOST AT RISK IS VITAL TO MORE EFFECTIVELY CONSERVE NATIVE BEES, AND THE CRITICAL POLLINATION SERVICES THESE BEES PROVIDE TO BOTH WILD AND CULTIVATED PLANTS  NATIVE BEES ARE EXHIBITING SIGNIFICANT DECLINES WORLDWIDE, WITH EIGHT SPECIES LISTED AS ENDANGERED IN THE US AND HUNDREDS OF OTHER SPECIES THREATENED  CONSERVATION STATUS ASSESSMENT IS A VALUABLE TOOL FOR DETERMINING WHICH SPECIES ARE AT HIGHEST RISK  THE LAST 20 YEARS HAVE SEEN A DRAMATIC INCREASE IN THREATS TO NATIVE BEES, INCLUDING URBANIZATION AND CLIMATE CHANGE, AND SIGNIFICANT BEE DECLINES NATIONWIDE  THUS, DETERMINING THE CONSERVATION STATUS OF TEXAS NATIVE BEES IS PARTICULARLY URGENT  THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE HIGH PRIORITY AREA OF CONSERVATION STATUS ASSESSMENT OF PRIORITY INSECT SGCN GROUPS  TX SWG 2023 RFP , FOCUSING ON NATIVE BEES

THE OREGON CONSERVATION STRATEGY  OCS  WAS PART OF A NATIONAL EFFORT GUIDED BY CONGRESS AND THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE  USFWS  TO ENCOURAGE STATES TO DEVELOP COMPREHENSIVE WILDLIFE PLANS  THE FIRST OCS WAS APPROVED BY THE USFWS IN 2006 AND UPDATED IN 2016  HTTP   OREGONCONSERVATIONSTRATEGY ORG   OREGON S APPROACH WAS TO ESTABLISH A LONG TERM VISION AND SET SPECIFIC GOALS NOT ONLY FOR CONSERVATION ACTIONS TO BE IMPLEMENTED BY THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE  ODFW , BUT ALSO AS A CONSERVATION BLUEPRINT FOR ALL OREGONIANS  THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THE OCS IS TO  MAINTAIN HEALTHY FISH AND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS BY MAINTAINING AND RESTORING FUNCTIONING HABITATS, PREVENT DECLINES OF AT RISK SPECIES, AND REVERSE DECLINES IN THESE RESOURCES WHERE POSSIBLE  THE STATEWIDE OCS EMPHASIZES THE PROACTIVE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF 11 STRATEGY HABITATS ACROSS 9 ECOREGIONS  IT ADDRESSED SPECIES CONSERVATION THROUGH A FINE FILTER APPROACH AND IDENTIFIED 294 STRATEGY SPECIES  SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED  DEFINED AS HAVING SMALL OR DECLINING POPULATIONS, ARE AT RISK, AND OR ARE OF MANAGEMENT CONCERN THIS GRANT PROPOSAL IS A REQUEST FOR FUNDING OCS IMPLEMENTATION EFFORTS FOR JULY 1, 2021   JUNE 30,2022  BASED ON EXPERIENCE SINCE 2006, ODFW IDENTIFIED FIVE PRIORITIES FOR THE NEXT PHASE OF OCS IMPLEMENTATION, INCLUDING A  CONSERVING STRATEGY SPECIESB  CONSERVING STRATEGY HABITATSC  ADDRESSING KEY CONSERVATION ISSUESD  IMPROVING DATA MANAGEMENTE  EXPANDING INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL UTILIZATION OF THE OCSTHE OBJECTIVES DESCRIBED IN THIS PROPOSAL ARE DIRECTLY RELATED TO THE PRIORITIES LISTED ABOVE AND FALL UNDER THE STRATEGIES OF TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW, OUTREACH COMMUNICATION, RESEARCH, SURVEY, DATA COLLECTION, AND ANALYSIS, AND DIRECT HABITAT AND SPECIES MANAGEMENT

TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT  TPWD  AND OUR PARTNERS IMPLEMENT A VERY BROAD SPECTRUM OF CONSERVATION ACTIONS TO BENEFIT SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED  SGCN  AS DEFINED BY THE CURRENT REVISED  2013  TEXAS CONSERVATION ACTION PLAN  TCAP, FORMERLY, THE TEXAS COMPREHENSIVE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION STRATEGY OR WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN   THE STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN  SWAP  COORDINATOR WOULD BE A POSITION WITHIN TPWD FUNDED THROUGH THIS GRANT AND WOULD BE RESPONSIBLE FOR IMPLEMENTING THE CURRENT SWAP WHILE SIMULTANEOUSLY SERVING AS LEAD AUTHOR AND EDITOR OF A COMPREHENSIVE REVISION OF THE SWAP TO GUIDE SGCN CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT FOR THE NEXT 10 YEARS, COMMUNICATING IMPLEMENTATION PRIORITIES WITHIN TPWD AND EXTERNALLY TO OUR PARTNERS AND STAKEHOLDERS, AND THE STATE WILDLIFE GRANT  SWG  PROPOSAL EVALUATION PROCESS  WITH THE FEDERAL AID COORDINATORS AND OTHER REVIEW TEAMS
