THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENHANCE ARCTIC GRAYLING YOUNG OF THE YEAR (YOY) SURVIVAL BY ELIMINATING MORTALITY FROM ENTRAINMENT INTO AN IRRIGATION SYSTEM AND PROVIDING FISH PASSAGE INTO A REARING SIDE CHANNEL OF THE BIG HOLE RIVER. SPECIFICALLY, THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A SAFE RETURN CHANNEL FOR ENTRAINED ARCTIC GRAYLING YOY ONCE IRRIGATION SHUTS OFF AND A SCREEN WILL PREVENT GRAYLING FROM ENTERING THE LOWER DITCH WHERE MORTALITY OCCURS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT TWO POPULATIONS OF GENETICALLY DISTINCT WESTSLOPE CUTTHROAT TROUT FROM COMPETITION AND HYBRIDIZATION WITH NONNATIVE TROUT BY THE INSTALLATION OF A CAST-IN-PLACE CONCRETE FISH BARRIER.

AQUATIC SPECIES POPULATIONS IN UTAH FACE A WIDE VARIETY OF THREATS TO THEIR SHORT-AND-LONG-TERM CONSERVATION. THREATS AFFECTING MANY SPECIES IDENTIFIED IN THE 2015 UTAH WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (WAP) INCLUDE URBAN DEVELOPMENT, WATER USE, FIRE, AND INVASIVE SPECIES. OTHER THREATS MAY AFFECT ONLY A SINGLE SPECIES YET NEED REMEDIATION TO ENSURE THE SPECIES' PERSISTENCE. WE NEED BASIC INFORMATION ON THE ECOLOGY OF SPECIES AND STATUS OF POPULATIONS TO ADDRESS ANY THREATS. ADDITIONALLY, WE NEED DEDICATED BIOLOGISTS WITH KNOWLEDGE OF BOTH THE SPECIES AND THE HABITATS ON WHICH THEY DEPEND. REGIONAL NATIVE AQUATIC SPECIES BIOLOGISTS ARE CORE PERSONNEL IN THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE WAP. THEY ARE SPECIES EXPERTS, RESPECTED VOICES ON PLANNING TEAMS, AND HAVE INVALUABLE ON-THE-GROUND KNOWLEDGE OF THE LANDSCAPES AND AQUATIC HABITATS OF UTAH. THEY IDENTIFY THREATS AND FORMULATE ACTIONS. WITH THAT EXPERTISE, WE CAN SUCCESSFULLY IDENTIFY OPPORTUNITIES AND WORK WITH WILLING PARTNERS TO ACHIEVE OUR CONSERVATION GOALS. THIS PROJECT FUNDS THESE STAFF SO THEY CAN CONDUCT IMPORTANT WORK TO REDUCE THREATS TO AQUATIC SPECIES AT RISK IN UTAH. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENSURE THE FUTURE OF NATIVE FISH, AMPHIBIANS, REPTILES, AND MOLLUSKS IN UTAH BY REDUCING THREATS TO THE SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS, THEREBY PREVENTING THE NEED FOR FUTURE SPECIES LISTINGS UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE STATEWIDE SENSITIVE SPECIES INFORMATION AND FILL DATA GAPS IDENTIFIED IN THE UTAH WAP. THESE GOALS WILL BE ACHIEVED THROUGH THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES:1. IMPLEMENT PRIORITY ACTIONS IDENTIFIED IN THE WAP OR OTHER MANAGEMENT PLANS TO REDUCE THREATS TO SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS,2. INVENTORY, MONITOR, AND MANAGE SGCN SPECIES,3. IMPLEMENT AVAILABLE CONSERVATION PLANS AS THEY PERTAIN TO SGCN SPECIES,4. ENHANCE AND MAINTAIN POPULATIONS OF REGIONAL SGCN SPECIES.5. DEVELOP HABITAT MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES AS NEEDED FOR KEY SPECIES BASED ON EXISTING LITERATURE, ONGOING UDWR STUDIES AND PROJECT MONITORING RESULTS.6. MAINTAIN, ENHANCE, AND USE REGIONAL SENSITIVE SPECIES DATABASES

THIS GRANT IS BEING COMPLETED BY ODWC PERSONNEL. THIS PROJECT WILL POTENTIALLY INCLUDE ALL 77 COUNTIES OF OKLAHOMA. THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE ODWC A QUANTITATIVE ASSESSMENT OF LAND SNAIL DIVERSITY AND ABUNDANCE ACROSS THE STATE'S PUBLIC LANDS, WHICH WILL ALLOW FOR A DATA-DRIVEN REVISION OF THE LAND SNAIL SPECIES ON THE STATE'S SGCN LIST AND PROVIDE THE GROUNDWORK DATA NEEDED FOR FUTURE RESEARCH AND FOR ANY SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENT.

THIS GRANT IS A SUB-AWARD TO THE UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA; ODWC WILL PROVIDE A SMALL AMOUNT OF FIELD ASSISTANCE AS NEEDED. THIS PROJECT WILL POTENTIALLY INCLUDE ALL 77 COUNTIES OF OKLAHOMA. THIS PROJECT WILL GENERATE THE MOST COMPREHENSIVE DATASET OF CONTEMPORARY BUMBLE BEE SPECIES DISTRIBUTION IN OKLAHOMA, AS WELL AS HABITAT RANKINGS FOR SURVEYED SITES, TO BE USED IN FUTURE STATUS ASSESSMENTS AND CONSERVATION PLANS.

THIS GRANT IS A SUB-AWARD TO OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY. THIS PROJECT WILL BE BASED AT THE OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY CAMPUS IN STILLWATER, OKLAHOMA (PAYNE COUNTY). THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO GENERATE GENETIC DATA THAT WILL COMPLEMENT AND CONFIRM MORPHOLOGICAL ASSESSMENT OF SPECIES IDENTITY OF OKLAHOMA BUFFALOFISH. COMPLEMENTARY ANALYSES USING THESE SAME DATA WILL PROVIDE INSIGHT INTO THE DISTRIBUTION OF EACH SPECIES, EXTENT OF HYBRIDIZATION, AND POPULATION AND DEMOGRAPHIC DYNAMICS FOR THE THREE SPECIES OF BUFFALOFISH. THE PROJECT DOES NOT HAVE A FIELD COMPONENT AND NO ANIMAL OR TISSUE SAMPLING WILL BE INCLUDED IN THE GRANT AS TISSUE SAMPLES ARE BEING PROVIDED BY ODWC FROM PREVIOUS WORK.

THIS GRANT IS PRIMARILY A SUB-AWARD TO OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY; ODWC WILL PROVIDE A SMALL AMOUNT OF FIELD ASSISTANCE AS NEEDED. THIS PROJECT WILL POTENTIALLY INCLUDE ALL 77 COUNTIES OF OKLAHOMA. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ASSESS THE STATUS OF THE BUMBLE BEE COMMUNITY IN OKLAHOMA WITH A FOCUS ON SPECIES THAT HAVE BEEN PETITIONED (OR ARE EXPECTED TO BE PETITIONED SOON) FOR FEDERAL LISTING UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. WE WILL ASSESS THE STATUS OF THE BUMBLE BEE COMMUNITY IN OKLAHOMA THROUGH A COMBINATION OF COMPLEMENTARY APPROACHES. OUR FIRST OBJECTIVE IS TO COMPILE HISTORICAL AND RECENT OBSERVATIONS OF THE THREE TARGET SPECIES (B. FRATERNUS, B. PENSYLVANICUS, B. VARIABILIS) AND OTHER BUMBLE BEE SPECIES THAT REGULARLY OCCUR IN OKLAHOMA THROUGH AVAILABLE SOURCES, INCLUDING RECORDS OF FLORAL HOSTS. AS PART OF THIS OBJECTIVE, WE WILL ENCOURAGE PARTICIPATION IN COMMUNITY SCIENCE PROJECTS, INCLUDING INATURALIST AND BUMBLE BEE WATCH, AND WE WILL CONTRIBUTE IDENTIFICATIONS OF SUBMITTED IMAGES TO THESE PROJECTS. OUR SECOND OBJECTIVE IS TO CONDUCT A STATEWIDE SURVEY OF THE BUMBLE BEE COMMUNITY. WE WILL CONDUCT A STATEWIDE ROADSIDE SURVEY (DATA TO SUPPORT THE VALUE OF USING ROADSIDES FOR SURVEYS ARE PROVIDED IN THE APPROACH SECTION), INCLUDING RECORDING HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS AT EACH SURVEY LOCATION. WE WILL ALSO CONDUCT SURVEYS AT SITES WITH SEMI-NATURAL TO NATURAL PLANT COMMUNITIES THAT WOULD BE CONSIDERED HIGH QUALITY HABITAT FOR BUMBLE BEES, INCLUDING LOCATIONS WHERE B. FRATERNUS AND B. VARIABILIS HAVE PREVIOUSLY BEEN RECORDED AND COUNTIES WHERE B. PENSYLVANICUS HAS NOT BEEN RECORDED RECENTLY. BODY SIZE, FLORAL CONSTANCY, AND POLLEN LOAD COMPOSITION WILL ALSO BE COLLECTED DURING FIELD SURVEYS.

OUR PROPOSAL FOCUSES ON TWO KEY CHALLENGES IN LONGLEAF PINE ECOSYSTEMS. FIRST, USING THE EXPERTISE OF THE UL ECOLOGY CENTER, WE WILL DEVELOP NATIVE SEED MIXES TO RESTORE THE UNDERSTORY OF LONGLEAF PINE ECOSYSTEMS AFTER PRESCRIBED FIRE. WE WILL ASSESS RESTORED AREAS IN TERMS OF THE ECOSYSTEM FUNCTIONS THEY SUPPORT, SPECIFICALLY: PLANT SPECIES RICHNESS, AND SPECIES OF GREATEST CONCERN: WILD BEE SPECIES RICHNESS AND ABUNDANCE. SECOND, IN THESE SAME HABITATS WE WILL USE EMERGENCE TRAPS TO SAMPLE FOR BOMBUS VARIABILIS, A VERY RARE BEE SPECIES BEING CONSIDERED FOR LISTING UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA). B. VARIABILIS IS A SOCIAL PARASITE OF BOMBUS PENSYLVANICUS, WHICH IS AMONG THE MOST COMMON BEE SPECIES IN LOUISIANA GRASSLANDS DESPITE DECLINING IN THE NORTHERN PARTS OF ITS RANGE.

THIS GRANT SUPPORTS THE OVERALL COORDINATION AND ADMINISTRATION OF STATE WILDLIFE GRANT (SWG) PROGRAM GRANTS BY THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION (ODWC). ODWC ADMINISTERS APPROXIMATELY 30 SWG GRANTS PER YEAR, AND THIS COORDINATION GRANT ALLOWS ODWC TO COMPLY WITH FEDERAL REGULATIONS, MAINTAINING ELIGIBILITY TO RECEIVE FUTURE GRANT FUNDING. SWG COORDINATION GRANT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE MAINTENANCE OF GRANT RECORDS, PLANNING PROJECTS (INCLUDING COORDINATION OF A REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS RELATIVE TO SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED PRIORITIES), PREPARATION OF GRANT PACKAGES (SCOPE OF WORK, BUDGET, COMPLIANCE, ETC.), SUBMISSION OF GRANT PACKAGES USING USFWS ONLINE PLATFORMS, ADMINISTRATION OF SUBAWARDS (THE MAJORITY OF ODWC'S SWG GRANTS ARE SUBAWARDS), MONITORING OF GRANT PERFORMANCE, DOCUMENTATION OF GRANT EXPENDITURES, MONTHLY DRAWDOWN OF REIMBURSEMENT, PROCESSING OF AMENDMENTS AS NECESSARY, REVIEW AND SUBMISSION OF PERFORMANCE REPORTS, PREPARATION AND SUBMISSION OF FINANCIAL REPORTS, COORDINATION OF GRANT-RELATED TRAINING FOR ODWC STAFF, SUPPORT FOR AUDITS AS NEEDED, SUPPORT FOR STATE-FEDERAL LAND RECORDS RECONCILIATION, ETC.

USING ENVIRONMENTAL DNA TO SURVEY FOR AMPHIBIANS AND REPTILE OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED IN TWO ESTABLISHED PRIORITY AMPHIBIAN AND REPTILE CONSERVATION AREAS. THIS GRANT WILL A FUND A PROJECT TO USE ENVIRONMENTAL DNA TO SURVEY FOR 15 TARGET SPECIES IN 2 PRIORITY AMPHIBIAN AND REPTILE CONSERVATION AREAS.

MAINTAINING THE NECESSARY HABITATS AND CONDITIONS FOR SENSITIVE SPECIES WHILE BALANCING THE ECONOMIC NEEDS OF THE STATE IS AKEY CHALLENGE FOR THE WYOMING GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT ANDOTHER MANAGEMENT AGENCIES. ENERGY DEVELOPMENT CONTINUES TOEXPAND IN WYOMING'S SAGEBRUSH STEPPE HABITATS, AND THE EFFECTS OF ASSOCIATED HABITAT CHANGES ON MANY OF WYOMING'S SGCN REMAIN ENTIRELY UNKNOWN.THESE POPULATION STUDIES WILL ADDRESS HUGE INFORMATIONAL GAPS FOR WYOMING'S SGCNS, AND THE EXTENT TO WHICH THERE MAY BE CLEAR AND PERVASIVE LIMITING FACTORS FOR THE CONTINUED PERSISTENCE OF THESE UNIQUE SPECIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO CONSERVE UNCOMMON AND DECLINING WILDLIFE SPECIES, DESIGNATED AS SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED IN THE OKLAHOMA COMPREHENSIVE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION STRATEGY, WITH THE GOAL OF MAINTAINING SELF-SUSTAINING POPULATIONS THAT PRECLUDE THE NEED TO LIST THESE SPECIES AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. THIS GRANT SUPPORTS THE ADMINISTRATIVE ACTIVITIES AND BIOLOGICAL SURVEYS NEEDED FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED IN OKLAHOMA. ADMINISTRATIVE ACTIVITIES INCLUDE COORDINATION, DATA-SHARING, AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF CONSERVATION ASSESSMENTS AND STRATEGIES WITH OTHER STATES WILDLIFE AGENCIES, THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, ACADEMIC AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS THAT SHARE AN INTEREST IN THE CONSERVATION OF SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED. FIELD ACTIVITIES INCLUDE PLANNING, COORDINATION AND CONDUCTING BIOLOGICAL SURVEYS TO COLLECT INFORMATION REGARDING THE DISTRIBUTION, STATUS, AND ECOLOGICAL NEEDS OF SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED USING TECHNIQUES SUCH AS AURAL AND VISUAL SURVEYS THAT HAVE A LOW IMPACT ON THE TARGET SPECIES, CO-OCCURRING SPECIES, AND THE HABITAT CONDITIONS AT THE SITES THAT ARE SURVEYED. WE WILL CONDUCT VISUAL SURVEYS FOR SWIFT FOX TRACKS, BUMBLE BEES, RICH MOUNTAIN SALAMANDERS, AND BLACK-TAILED PRAIRIE DOGS. WE WILL CONDUCT AURAL SURVEYS FOR A RANGE OF MIGRATORY BIRDS INCLUDING THE BELL'S VIREO AND THE BACHMAN'S SPARROW, AS WELL AS BATS INCLUDING THE TRICOLORED BAT. THE RESULTS OF THESE BIOLOGICAL SURVEYS WILL BE MAINTAINED IN A SPATIAL DATABASE. WE WILL PRODUCE OUTREACH MATERIALS, IN THE FORM OF WRITTEN ARTICLES AND SOCIAL MEDIA CONTENT, TO INCREASE AWARENESS OF TARGETED SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED AND THE CONSERVATION ACTIONS THAT ARE BEING TAKEN TO IMPROVE EACH ONE'S STATUS.

THE OBJECTIVE IS TO MAINTAIN AND ENHANCE POPULATIONS OF WILDLIFE SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED BY IMPLEMENTING CONSERVATION ACTIONS TO ADDRESS THREATS TO SPECIES AND HABITATS  AS IDENTIFIED IN THE 2015 2025 MARYLAND STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN, CHAPTER 7 , MONITORING POPULATIONS, AND GATHERING INFORMATION NECESSARY FOR THE SOUND CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF MARYLAND S WILDLIFE DIVERSITY AND KEY HABITATS

THIS GRANT IS A SUB-AWARD TO OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT A STUDY TO ASSESS THE CURRENT STATUS OF CRAWFISH FROGS IN OKLAHOMA, WITH THE AIM TO VERIFY THE STATUS OF KNOWN OR SUSPECTED BREEDING POPULATIONS AND TO IDENTIFY ADDITIONAL LOCATIONS WHERE THIS SPECIES BREEDS, ALONG WITH COLLECTING HABITAT DATA AND DEVELOPING A MODELING STUDY TO DETERMINE HABITAT PREFERENCES FOR THIS SPECIES. WE WILL ACCOMPANY IN-PERSON SAMPLING WITH PASSIVE ACOUSTIC RECORDING TO GAIN INFORMATION ON BOTH POPULATION PRESENCE AND POPULATION SIZE IN SELECT LOCATIONS.

SOUTHERN FLOUNDER POPULATIONS HAVE SHOWN SIGNS OF DECLINE THROUGHOUT THE UNITED STATES, INCLUDING IN TEXAS. TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT TPWD SOUGHT TO PREVENT LARGE-SCALE DECLINES WITH NEW RESTRICTIONS THAT WERE ENACTED IN 2020 HOWEVER THE DEPARTMENT RECEIVED MANY PUBLIC COMMENTS DURING THIS TIME CONCERNED OVER THE NIGHTTIME RECREATIONAL FLOUNDER HARVEST, WHICH IS NOT CURRENTLY CAPTURED IN THE AGENCYS DAYTIME BOAT RAMP HARVEST SURVEYS. NIGHTTIME ANGLERS AND GUIDE COMMONLY GO GIGGING FOR FLOUNDER BETWEEN SUNRISE AND SUNSET. THIS PROPOSAL SEEKS TO CHARACTERIZE THE NIGHTTIME RECREATIONAL FLOUNDER HARVEST IN CENTRAL TEXAS BAYS USING COMMUNITY SCIENCE TPWD STAFF SURVEYS AND NOVEL FORMS OF HARVEST DATA COLLECTION. SELF REPORTED CATCH DATA FROM GUIDES AND RECREATIONAL ANGLERS WILL BE COLLECTED THROUGH AN APP OR GUIDE LOGS THEN USED ALONGSIDE BOAT RAMP SURVEY AND ROVE DATA COLLECTED BY TPWD DURING NIGHTTIME HOURS. ADDITIONALLY THE STUDY WILL UTILIZE TRAFFIC COUNTERS AT BOAT RAMPS TO QUANTIFY USE AND TEST VIABILITY OF THIS NEW TOOL. THE PROPOSAL ALSO INCLUDES IN-PERSON AND VIRTUAL STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENTS AND TRAININGS AND DIGITAL ADVERTISING TO INCREASE ANGLER PARTICIPATION. THESE DATA WILL PROVIDE MANAGERS INFORMATION ON THE EXTENT AND CHARACTERISTICS OF THE NIGHTTIME FLOUNDER FISHERY ON THE CENTRAL TEXAS COAST AND PROVIDE LOGISTICAL INSIGHT INTO HOW TPWD OR OTHER AGENCIES COULD EXPAND SUCH MONITORING USING THE TOOLS PILOTED HERE. THIS WORK ALSO INCREASES INVOLVEMENT OF ANGLERS AND COMMERCIAL GUIDES IN FISHERY MONITORING AND SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT.

SACRAMENTO PERCH - ARCHOPLITES INTERRUPTUS, IS CALIFORNIA'S ONLY NATIVE CENTRARCHID, A CALIFORNIA SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN, SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED, AND IS IDENTIFIED AS ENDANGERED ON THE IUCN RED LIST OF THREATENED SPECIES.  (CDFW 2015; MOYLE ET. AL 2015).IT WAS HISTORICALLY DISTRIBUTED THROUGHOUT THE SACRAMENTO-SAN JOAQUIN DELTA, PAJARO RIVER, SALINAS RIVER DRAINAGES, CLEAR LAKE, AND COYOTE CREEK, BUT ALTERATION AND REDUCTION OF NATIVE HABITAT AND COMPETITION WITH INTRODUCED FISHES HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO ITS RAPID DECLINE DURING THE END OF THE 19TH CENTURY AND THROUGHOUT THE 20TH CENTURY (MOYLE 2002). IN RECENT YEARS, THE MANAGEMENT OF KNOWN SACRAMENTO PERCH POPULATIONS HAS BEEN HIGHLIGHTED AS AN IMPORTANT PRIORITY THROUGHOUT THE STATE. CURRENT STRATEGIES FOR MANAGING AND MAINTAINING ITS REMAINING POPULATION INCLUDES REINTRODUCING AND REESTABLISHING SACRAMENTO PERCH THROUGHOUT THEIR NATIVE SACRAMENTO - SAN JOAQUIN VALLEY AND COASTAL RANGE HABITATS WHILE MINIMIZING FURTHER GENETIC BOTTLENECKING THAT HAS AFFECTED THE SPECIES IN MANY AREAS (SCHWARTZ AND MAY 2008; COEN AND SCHREIER 2018; CRAIN AND MOYLE 2011). SUCH EFFORTS RELY ON A SOLID UNDERSTANDING OF THE GENETIC HEALTH OF KNOWN POPULATIONS (TOWARD WHICH PREVIOUS SWG-FUNDED WORK WAS CONTRIBUTED BY MEMBERS OF THIS PROPOSALS TEAM) AND DEVELOPING STRATEGIES FOR DIRECTED MANAGEMENT THAT SUPPORTS THE PERSISTENCE AND RESILIENCY OF THIS SPECIES.  TO UNDERSTAND THE GENETIC FOUNDATION NEEDED TO INFORM FUTURE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES, A 2015 SWG NAPPLIED GENETICS FOR SACRAMENTO PERCH MANAGEMENT" (F15AF00659/GL598102) REVEALED TWO GENETICALLY DISTINCT LINEAGES - THE NORTH AND SOUTH MANAGEMENT UNITS (MUS) - WITH POPULATION SUBSTRUCTURE WITHIN THOSE LINEAGES (COEN AND SCHREIER 2018; COEN ET AL 2021; FIGURE 1). IN THE RESULTING SACRAMENTO PERCH GENETIC MANAGEMENT PLAN (APPENDIX A), RODZEN (2018) IDENTIFIED THAT THE NORTH MU HAS MORE GENETICALLY DIVERSE POPULATIONS THAN THE SOUTH MU, AND THAT THE PRIMARY CONSERVATION PRIORITY SHOULD BE MAINTAINING THE GENETIC DIVERSITY OF THE SOUTH MU. THIS COULD BE ACCOMPLISHED BY INCREASING DIVERSITY WITHIN INDIVIDUAL POPULATIONS (BISCAR RESERVOIR, BRIDGEPORT RESERVOIR, AND CROWLEY LAKE) BY TRANSLOCATING AND MIXING FISH BETWEEN THESE WATERS. THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO CONDUCT TRANSLOCATIONS BETWEEN BISCAR AND BRIDGEPORT RESERVOIRS.VARIOUS CONSIDERATIONS AND COMPONENTS SUPPORTING THE CONSERVATION OF SACRAMENTO PERCH HAVE BEEN PREVIOUSLY SUGGESTED IN THE LITERATURE (CRAIN AND MOYLE, 2011) AND ATTEMPTED PIECEMEAL BY PROGRAMS WITHIN THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) AND OTHER ENTITIES SUCH AS RESOURCE CONSERVATION DISTRICTS AND THE CONTRA COSTA MOSQUITO AND VECTOR CONTROL DISTRICT. HOWEVER, THE STATE HAS NOT YET DEVELOPED AND ADOPTED A COMPREHENSIVE STATEWIDE CDFW SACRAMENTO PERCH MANAGEMENT PLAN (CDFW MANAGEMENT PLAN) THAT WOULD ESTABLISH CDFW'S LEADERSHIP ROLE IN SUPPORTING THE PERSISTENCE AND RESILIENCY OF SACRAMENTO PERCH. THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DEVELOP SUCH A PLAN.ESTABLISHING NEW, GENETICALLY ROBUST POPULATIONS RELIES ON EASILY ACQUIRING ENOUGH GENETICALLY DIVERSE SACRAMENTO PERCH FROM EXISTING SOURCES. HOWEVER, INCREASINGLY FREQUENT CLIMATE THREATS AND CHALLENGING LOGISTICAL ACCESS TO REFUGE WATERS, AS WELL AS A SPECIES THAT HAS PROVEN ELUSIVE TO EFFICIENT CAPTURE SUGGESTS THAT EFFORT BE INVESTED IN IDENTIFYING SUITABLY ACCESSIBLE, ADDITIONAL REFUGE WATERS FOR DONOR POPULATIONS NEEDED FOR VARIOUS MANAGEMENT ACTIONS. THIS PROJECT PROPOSES THE DEVELOPMENT OF ACTIONABLE PLANS FOR CREATING A MINIMUM OF ONE NEW REFUGE WATER PER MU THAT IS LOGISTICALLY ACCESSIBLE AND WHOSE POPULATION IS GENETICALLY ROBUST.

SINCE 2002, CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) HAS BEEN MONITORING WILDLIFE SPECIES WITHIN FORESTED HABITATS ACROSS MUCH OF ITS NORTHERN REGION VIA ITS ECOREGIONAL BIODIVERSITY MONITORING (EBM) PROGRAM. NOTABLE RESULTS INCLUDE BASELINE STATUSES OF FOREST BIRDS AT THE ECOREGION-LEVEL (FURNAS AND CALLAS 2015), IDENTIFICATION OF CLIMATE CHANGE VULNERABILITIES OF MIGRATORY BIRDS (MCGRANN AND FURNAS 2016), ESTIMATION OF TOTAL POPULATION SIZE OF THE FISHER (PEKANIA PENNANTI) IN NORTHWESTERN CALIFORNIA (FURNAS ET AL. 2017), DOCUMENTATION OF SONGBIRD RESPONSE TO CLIMATE CHANGE (FURNAS 2020) AND EVALUATING THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN CARNIVORE DIVERSITY AND FIRE HISTORY (FURNAS ET AL. 2021). CDFW PROPOSES TO CONTINUE THIS MONITORING EFFORT IN THE NORTHERN REGION IN 2023 AND 2024. WE WILL SURVEY FOR BIRDS, BATS, AND OTHER MAMMALS FOR TWO YEARS, WHICH SUPPORT CONTINUED LANDSCAPE-SCALE ASSESSMENT OF BIODIVERSITY. DATA COLLECTED WILL ALSO BE AVAILABLE FOR USE IN ANALYSES AND COLLABORATIONS WITH OTHER LANDSCAPE-SCALE CDFW MONITORING EFFORTS, INCLUDING THE CALIFORNIA ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT PROGRAM. THIS PROJECT IS CONSISTENT WITH MULTIPLE CDFW AND CALIFORNIA GOVERNOR'S PRIORITIES FOR BIOLOGICAL CONSERVATION INCLUDING LONG-TERM MONITORING, MULTI-SPECIES LANDSCAPE-SCALE MONITORING, WILDFIRE RESPONSE, PROJECTS INTENDED TO INFORM CDFW'S LANDSCAPE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, PROCESSING AND ANALYSIS OF EXISTING DATASETS, AND SPECIES RESPONSE AND RESILIENCY PLANNING FOR DROUGHT AND CLIMATE CHANGE.

THE NARROW-FACED KANGAROO RAT (DIPODOMYS VENUSTUS) IS ENDEMIC TO THE COAST RANGE OF CALIFORNIA. TAXONOMICALLY,THE THREE SUBSPECIES CURRENTLY RECOGNIZED ARE: D. V. VENUSTUS (SANTA CRUZ KANGAROO RAT), D. V. ELEPHANTINUS (BIGEAREDKANGAROO RAT) AND D. V. SANCTILUCIAE (SANTA LUCIA KANGAROO RAT). ALL THREE SUBSPECIES ARE ON THE CALIFORNIADEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) "SPECIAL ANIMALS LIST;" D. V. ELEPHANTINUS IS LISTED AS A SPECIES OFSPECIAL CONCERN, D. V. SANCTILUCIAE IS LISTED AS VULNERABLE, AND D. V. VENUSTUS IS STATE LISTED AS CRITICALLYIMPERILED. A LACK OF INFORMATION ABOUT CURRENT DISTRIBUTION, POPULATION TRENDS AND GENETIC DIFFERENTIATION OF THESUBSPECIES PREVENTS FURTHER MANAGEMENT ACTION. A CLEARER UNDERSTANDING OF SUBSPECIES' TAXONOMY IS NECESSARY TOMAKE INFORMED DECISIONS ABOUT ENDANGERMENT STATUS. WE PROPOSE TWO COMPLEMENTARY RESEARCH QUESTIONS: WHAT IS THEOCCUPANCY STATUS OF THE SPECIES ACROSS ITS RANGE? AND WHAT IS THE TAXONOMIC STATUS OF THE POPULATIONS? WE WILLPROVIDE A HABITAT SUITABILITY MODEL FOR EACH OF THE SUBSPECIES AND GUIDANCE ON A LONG-TERM MONITORING PLAN; ANDWE WILL RESOLVE LONG-STANDING QUESTIONS ABOUT THE SPECIES' TAXONOMY, PROVIDING GUIDANCE TOWARDS LISTING.ADDITIONALLY, BOTH THE CDFW REGION 3 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTIST, TERRIS KASTEEN AND THE CDFW GENETICS LAB LEAD, DR.MIKE BULCHALSKI, WERE CONSULTED DURING THE DEVELOPMENT OF THIS PROPOSAL AND ARE BOTH IN ACCORD WITH THE RESEARCHOBJECTIVES AND TECHNIQUES DESCRIBED IN THIS PROPOSAL.

THIS WORK WILL REMOVE THE NEWTON-PEDRAZZI DIVERSION DAM AND SPILLWAY FROM MUSSELSHELL RIVER AND ITS FLOODPLAIN TO IMPROVE FLOODPLAIN AND HABITAT CONNECTIVITY FOR A SUITE OF NATIVE FISHES.
