THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT TWO GENETICALLY UNALTERED WESTSLOPE CUTTHROAT TROUT POPULATIONS FROM NON-NATIVE FISH IN RESERVOIR CREEK IN THE BEAVERHEAD SUB-BASIN AND DUTCHMAN CREEK IN THE UPPER MISSOURI SUB-BASIN. BASED ON THE TOPOGRAPHY OF THE DRAINAGES, EACH POPULATION CAN BE PROTECTED WITH A CONSTRUCTED FISH BARRIER. ON RESERVOIR CREEK, A WOODEN BARRIER WILL BE BUILT ON PRIVATE LAND THAT WILL PROTECT HABITAT. ON DUTCHMAN CREEK, IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT A WOODEN BARRIER CAN BE CONSTRUCTED ON PRIVATE LAND AND PROTECT HABITAT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE 3 YEARS OF FUNDING FOR THE IOWA STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (IWAP) MANAGER TO COORDINATE THE IMPLEMENTATION, REVIEW, AND REVISION OF THE IWAP. THE PRIMARY ACTIVITIES OF THE IWAP MANAGER INCLUDE PROJECT MANAGEMENT OF GRANTS THAT CONTRIBUTE TO THE GOALS OF THE IWAP, COORDINATION WITH CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS AND INDIVIDUALS, AND PARTICIPATION ON TECHNICAL COMMITTEES. ANOTHER ASPECT OF THE PROJECT IS COORDINATING THE COMPREHENSIVE REVIEW AND REVISION OF THE IWAP. STATES ARE REQUIRED BY CONGRESS TO UNDERTAKE A COMPREHENSIVE REVIEW OF THEIR STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN EVERY TEN YEARS, WITH THE NEXT REVIEW AND REVISION OF IOWA'S PLAN BEING DUE IN 2025. THE IWAP MANAGER WILL COORDINATE THE REVISION PROCESS AND COLLECT INPUT FROM WILDLIFE CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS AND INTERESTED INDIVIDUALS TO HELP MAKE THE REVISED IWAP A USEFUL RESOURCE AND A CATALYST FOR CONSERVATION.

ODWC WILL SUBAWARD THIS GRANT TO SOUTHEASTERN OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY. WE SEEK TO STUDY POPULATIONS OF AMERICAN ALLIGATORS IN SOUTHEASTERN OKLAHOMA WITH THE OVERALL AIM OF DETERMINING KEY ELEMENTS OF POPULATION DYNAMICS AND INFORMING FUTURE MANAGEMENT PLANS. THE OBJECTIVES AND APPROACHES OUTLINED IN THE FOLLOWING PROPOSAL AIM TO DETERMINE PRESENCE-ABSENCE OF ALLIGATORS IN VARIOUS AQUATIC HABITATS OF SOUTHEASTERN OKLAHOMA, QUANTIFY MOVEMENT PATTERNS OF DISPERSING JUVENILE ALLIGATORS AT RED SLOUGH WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA (RSWMA), AND TO EXAMINE HABITAT REQUIREMENTS OF DIFFERENT SIZE CLASSES OF ALLIGATORS AT RSWMA. THE RESEARCH PROPOSED HERE IS AIMED TOWARD PROVIDING THE OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND CONSERVATION (ODWC) WITH INFORMATION REGARDING THE POPULATION STATUS OF AMERICAN ALLIGATORS IN SOUTHEASTERN OKLAHOMA. ONE OF THE PRIORITIES OUTLINED IN A RECENT REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS FROM THE ODWC WAS TO ASSESS ALLIGATOR POPULATIONS IN THE STATE TO INFORM POTENTIAL FUTURE HARVESTING REGULATIONS. WHILE ALLIGATOR POPULATIONS IN NEIGHBORING STATES HAVE REACHED SUFFICIENT NUMBERS TO SUSTAIN ANNUAL HARVESTS, THE STATUS OF ALLIGATOR POPULATIONS IN OKLAHOMA ARE LARGELY UNKNOWN. THE PURPOSE OF OUR PROJECT IS TO DETERMINE THE OVERALL POPULATION STATUS OF AMERICAN ALLIGATORS IN SOUTHEASTERN OKLAHOMA. DATA GENERATED FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE SUPPLIED TO ODWC IN THE FORM OF A FINAL REPORT AND MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS.

THE PURPOSE IS TO REVISE THE 2015 STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN BY OCTOBER 2025. THIS WILL BE A THREE- YEAR PROJECT, AND THIS GRANT COVERS YEAR 1.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE DATA COMPILATION AND DOCUMENTATION; DATA ANALYSIS, INCLUDING ASSESSMENT OF CONSERVATION STATUS; REVIEW OF NEEDS, THREATS, AND OPTIONS TO ADDRESS THEM, INCLUDING CLIMATE CHANGE; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT; REVISION AND PRIORITIZATION OF CONSERVATION STRATEGIES; COORDINATION WITH REGIONAL PARTNERS AND INCORPORATION OF PROJECT OUTCOMES; PREPARATION OF THE REVISED PLAN; AND DISSEMINATION OF THE REVISED PLAN. COORDINATION WITH OTHER STATES IN THE REGION THROUGH PARTICIPATION IN MEETINGS AND TRAININGS WILL ASSIST WITH DEFINING EFFECTIVE STRATEGIES TO MEET THE REQUIRED ELEMENTS OF THE PLAN AS WELL AS SET THE STAGE FOR MORE EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION ACTIONS AND COMMUNICATION ABOUT STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLANS.A REVISION OF THE STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN WILL BE PRODUCED, ADDRESSING ALL THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE U.S. FISH & WILDLIFE SERVICE FOR SUCH A REVISED PLAN. THE PLAN WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE TO THE DNR STAFF, THE U.S. FISH & WILDLIFE SERVICE, CONSERVATION PARTNERS, AND THE PUBLIC.

ODWC WILL SUBAWARD FUNDS TO SOUTHWESTERN ADVENTIST UNIVERSITY FOR THIS PROJECT. THE AMERICAN ALLIGATOR (ALLIGATOR MISSISSIPPIENSIS) REACHES ITS NORTHWESTERN-MOST DISTRIBUTION IN THE GULF COASTAL PLAIN REGION OF SOUTHEASTERN OKLAHOMA. IT OCCURS IN THE RED RIVER AND LITTLE RIVER BASINS OF MCCURTAIN COUNTY, ALTHOUGH OCCASIONAL RECORDS EXIST FOR SPECIMENS SEEN ELSEWHERE IN THE SOUTHEASTERN REGION OF THE STATE (ARBOUR AND BASTARACHE 2006; HECK 2006). WITH THE NATIONWIDE RECOVERY OF ALLIGATORS HAS COME A REEMERGING, INCREASING INTEREST IN THE SPECIES AS A HARVESTABLE ANIMAL (E.G., GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES 2010; NORTH CAROLINA WILDLIFE RESOURCES COMMISSION 2017) AND EVEN WIDER INTEREST AS WATCHABLE WILDLIFE FOR NON-GAME ENTHUSIASTS. VERY LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT THE POPULATION STATUS OF ALLIGATORS IN SOUTHEASTERN OKLAHOMA, DESPITE THEIR PRESENCE AND SIGNIFICANCE IN THE AREA WETLANDS. LITTLE IS UNDERSTOOD OF THE FACTORS AFFECTING REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS, AND ESPECIALLY RECRUITMENT BOTTLENECKS, TO THE SUBADULT AND ADULT POPULATION. IN ADDITION, A MULTI-DISCIPLINARY, SCIENCE-SUPPORTED PLAN IN OKLAHOMA IS NEEDED BECAUSE OF THE PAST AND PRESENT WAYS IN WHICH ALLIGATOR MANAGEMENT AND HARVEST MONITORING HAS DEVELOPED AND BEEN COORDINATED NATIONALLY. TO ADDRESS THESE SHORTCOMINGS, WE PROPOSE TO ASSESS THE POPULATION STATUS AND REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS OF THE ALLIGATOR POPULATION AT RED SLOUGH WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA (RSWMA). POPULATION STATUS WILL BE EVALUATED USING CAPTURE AND VISUAL SURVEYS. REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS WILL BE EXAMINED BY MONITORING NESTS WITH CAMERAS AND VISUAL SURVEYS, AS WELL AS MARKING HATCHLINGS COMBINED, THESE APPROACHES SHOULD FACILITATE THE DETERMINATION OF POPULATION SIZE, DENSITY, SEX RATIOS, SIZE STRUCTURE, BODY CONDITION, AND NEST SUCCESS. LONG-TERM SURVIVAL OF HATCHLINGS AND RECRUITMENT RATES OF HATCHLINGS AND NEW ENTRANTS INTO THE POPULATION WILL BE DIFFICULT TO ASSESS WITH ONLY TWO YEARS OF DATA COLLECTION, BUT OUR SAMPLING AND TAGGING EFFORTS WILL PROVIDE THE GROUNDWORK FOR FUTURE STUDIES TO ACCURATELY ESTIMATE THESE PARAMETERS.

THE UDWR WILDLIFE CONSERVATION PROGRAM WORKS TO ENSURE THE CONSERVATION OF THE DIVERSITY OF NATIVE MAMMALS ANDBIRDS IN UTAH. OUR GOALS ARE TO SAFEGUARD UTAH'S NATURAL HERITAGE, PREVENT FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA)LISTINGS, AND WORK TOWARD RECOVERY OF ESA-LISTED SPECIES. SINCE THE CREATION OF THE PROGRAM, WE HAVE BEEN ABLE TOACCRUE A RECORD OF SUCCESS IN LISTING PREVENTION BASED PRIMARILY ON PROACTIVE DATA COLLECTION, ACTIVE MANAGEMENT,AND CONSERVATION PARTNERSHIPS. WE WILL CONTINUE TO BUILD ON THAT RECORD THROUGH STRATEGIC IMPLEMENTATION OF THE2015 WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN AS WELL AS SPECIES-BASED EFFORTS DESIGNED TO MEET CONSERVATION TARGETS.
DETECTION OF SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED USING CAMERA TRAPS, WITH AN EMPHASIS ON EASTERN DIAMOND-BACKED RATTLESNAKES, HARLEQUIN CORALSNAKES, AND BLACK PINESNAKES

THE FLORIDA FISH AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION COMMISSION (COMMISSION) IS THE STATE WILDLIFE AGENCY THAT RECEIVES AND MANAGES FEDERAL STATE WILDLIFE GRANTS (SWG) FUNDING AND LEADS THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THE STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (ACTION PLAN). STAFF WILL CONTINUE TO FOCUS ON, 1) FLORIDA'S STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN AND COMPLEMENTARY MANAGEMENT PLANS, 2) PARTNERSHIP DEVELOPMENT, AND 3) FLORIDA'S STATE WILDLIFE GRANTS PROGRAM, WHICH WORK TOGETHER IN AN ADAPTIVE FRAMEWORK. THE PLANS IDENTIFY AND PRIORITIZE ACTIONS NECESSARY TO CONSERVE FISH AND WILDLIFE; STAFF AND PARTNERS FOCUS IMPLEMENTATION ON A SUBSET OF THE ACTIONS CALLED IMPLEMENTATION GOALS OR OBJECTIVES (DEPENDING ON THE PLAN); GRANTS PROVIDE FUNDING TO IMPLEMENT ACTIONS THAT ACHIEVE THOSE GOALS; PARTNERSHIPS ARE BUILT AND MAINTAINED TO IMPROVE IMPLEMENTATION. AS THE ACTION PLAN IS REVISED AND UPDATED, GOALS AND FUNDING PRIORITIES OF THE SWG PROGRAM CHANGE ACCORDINGLY. THE ACTION PLAN AND SWG FUNDS ENHANCE THE COMMISSION'S ABILITY TO CONSERVE WILDLIFE SPECIES IN TERRESTRIAL, MARINE AND FRESHWATER SYSTEMS, WITH A FOCUS ON STRATEGIC HABITAT CONSERVATION AND SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN). IN PARTICULAR, STAFF WILL WORK TO ACHIEVE THE FOLLOWING GOALS: 1) AUGMENT AND IMPROVE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES; 2) INCREASE COORDINATION WITH OTHER STATE AND LOCAL AGENCIES TO BETTER IDENTIFY WILDLIFE CONSERVATION NEEDS ON PUBLIC LANDS THEY MANAGE, AND TO IMPLEMENT STRATEGIES TO MEET THOSE NEEDS; AND 3) INCREASE COORDINATION WITH PARTNERS AND STAKEHOLDERS, INCLUDING PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, TO IMPROVE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION THROUGHOUT FLORIDA. THIS GRANT/PROJECT WILL CONTINUE TO SUPPORT STAFF WHO COMPLETE WORK RELATED TO THE ACTION PLAN, INCLUDING ACTION IMPLEMENTATION, PARTNERSHIP DEVELOPMENT, ACTION PLAN REVISIONS, AND MANAGEMENT OF CURRENT AND FUTURE SWG AWARDS.

FOR MORE THAN TWO DECADES NOW THE STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP) HAS BEEN THE GUIDING DOCUMENT TO HELP DIRECT THE DEPARTMENT'S NONGAME CONSERVATION EFFORTS ACROSS THE STATE. UNTIL RECENTLY, THE SWAP WAS LARGELY AN EXHAUSTIVE POLICY DOCUMENT, EXISTING AS A LARGE PDF DOCUMENT AND UTILIZED BY A LIMITED NUMBER OF PARTNERS OUTSIDE THE DEPARTMENT. HOWEVER, WITH THIS LATEST REVISION (ANTICIPATED TO BE FINALIZED FALL 2022), THE ARIZONA GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT WILL MODERNIZE THEIR SWAP BY LAUNCHING THE ARIZONA WILDLIFE CONSERVATION STRATEGY (AWCS). THIS COMPREHENSIVE, WEB-BASED CONSERVATION STRATEGY WILL BE GUIDED BY THE 2022 SWAP WHILE ALSO OFFERING ON-LINE TOOLS, DATA, AND IMPORTANT INFORMATION FOR THE PUBLIC AND OUR CONSERVATION PARTNERS. THROUGH THE AWCS, THE SWAP WILL BE AVAILABLE IN AN EASY-TO-USE WEB PLATFORM. THE AWCS WILL NOT ONLY GREATLY INCREASE PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT WITH THE SWAP AND THE DEPARTMENT'S NONGAME CONSERVATION EFFORTS, BUT WILL ALSO OFFER SEVERAL ON-LINE TOOLS AND DATA PLATFORMS TO BE USED BY OUR PARTNERS AND PUBLIC ALIKE. THE GRANT ALSO FUNDS THE IMPLEMENTATION OF CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY PROJECTS FOR ARIZONA'S NATIVE FISHES, INVERTEBRATES, AMPHIBIANS AND REPTILES AND NONGAME BIRDS AND MAMMAL SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED. ALL ACTIVITIES OUTLINED CAN BE TIED TO THREATS, ACTIONS, INFORMATION NEEDS AND CONSERVATION STRATEGIES IDENTIFIED IN THE ARIZONA STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN. THE GRANT WILL SUPPORT THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES: ROLLOUT OF THE AWCS WEBSITE TO IMPROVE PUBLIC AND PARTNER ENGAGEMENT WITH ARIZONA'S SWAP AND OTHER DEPARTMENT NON-GAME CONSERVATION EFFORTS. ASSOCIATED DATA VISUALIZATION TOOLS WILL ALLOW FOR BETTER INFORMATION SHARING BETWEEN THE DEPARTMENT AND OUR CONSERVATION PARTNERS, BOTH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE. AS PART OF THE AWCS WEBSITE, THE COA MAP VIEWER WILL BECOME AN IMPORTANT TOOL THAT WILL HELP FOCUS AND GUIDE CONSERVATION EFFORTS WHERE THEY ARE NEEDED MOST WHILE ALSO BUILDING COLLABORATION AND PARTNERSHIPS TO BETTER CONSERVE OUR SGCN AND THEIR HABITATS. COORDINATING WITH OUR NEIGHBOR STATES TO DEVELOP STRATEGIES THAT COORDINATE SWAPS ACROSS STATE BOUNDARIES WILL IMPROVE CONSERVATION EFFORTS FOR REGIONAL SGCN AND OTHER SPECIES OF CONCERN. DOCUMENTING THE CURRENT DISTRIBUTION AND POPULATION STATUS OF SGCN SPECIES BY GATHERING INFORMATION ON HISTORICAL AND PRESENT DISTRIBUTIONS, HABITAT ASSOCIATIONS, NATURAL HISTORY, AND THREATS. ENHANCING EXISTING POPULATIONS AND REESTABLISH POPULATIONS INTO HISTORICAL HABITAT. CONDUCTING SURVEYS, MONITORING POPULATIONS AND HABITATS, AND IDENTIFYING MANAGEMENT POTENTIAL AT SPECIFIC SITES. COLLECTING A LIMITED NUMBER OF SPECIMENS FROM HISTORICAL AND NEWLY IDENTIFIED LOCATIONS FOR GENETIC ANALYSIS, RESEARCH, CAPTIVE PROPAGATION, ETC. IDENTIFYING ESSENTIAL HABITATS, RESEARCH NEEDS, AND OTHER MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS. MAINTAINING BROODSTOCKS OF SELECT SGCN FISHES AND PROVIDE PROGENY TO MEET CONSERVATION NEEDS. INVESTIGATING THE USE OF DIFFERENT AQUACULTURE TECHNIQUES, NEW TECHNOLOGY, AND/OR LIFE HISTORY RESEARCH ON NATIVE FISH TO IMPROVE: SURVIVAL, GROWTH, PRODUCTION, HEALTH, AND CONDITION OF FISH IN REARING UNITS, TRANSPORT, STOCKING AND POST-STOCKING PERFORMANCE INTO THE WILD. COLLABORATING WITH PARTNERS TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT MANAGEMENT PLANS, CONSERVATION AGREEMENTS, RECOVERY ACTIONS, RESEARCH, MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS, AND TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT EFFORTS. EXAMPLES INCLUDE WORKING WITH UNIVERSITIES TO CONDUCT GENETICS ANALYSES, CONTRACTING ASSISTANCE IN PROTECTING AND IMPROVING HABITATS, AND PARTNERING WITH THE PHOENIX ZOO TO ENHANCE HUSBANDRY AND CAPTIVE PROPAGATION FOR NATIVE AQUATIC SPECIES.

THE SIERRA NEVADA RED FOX (VULPES VULPES NECATOR; SNRF) IS A MONTANE SUBSPECIES NATIVE TO CALIFORNIA AND OREGON. IN CALIFORNIA, THE SNRF PERSISTS ONLY WITHIN TWO GEOGRAPHICALLY AND GENETICALLY ISOLATED REGIONS: THE LASSEN PEAK AREA IN THE SOUTHERN CASCADES, AND THE SIERRA NEVADA BETWEEN CARSON PASS AND BISHOP PASS. MORE THAN TWO DECADES OF MONITORING HAVE DEMONSTRATED THAT THE LASSEN POPULATION IS SMALL, GREATLY REDUCED IN DISTRIBUTION FROM ITS HISTORICAL EXTENT, EXTREMELY ISOLATED, HIGHLY INBRED, AND VULNERABLE TO EXTIRPATION WITHIN A SMALL NUMBER OF GENERATIONS. THE SIERRA NEVADA POPULATION WAS LISTED AS FEDERALLY ENDANGERED IN 2021 AS A DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENT (DPS) .A CONSERVATION STRATEGY FOR THE SIERRA NEVADA RED FOX (HEREAFTER, THE STRATEGY) RECOMMENDS A SUITE OF RESEARCH, MANAGEMENT, AND PLANNING ACTIVITIES THAT WILL INFORM AND ENABLE RECOVERY EFFORTS FOR THE SNRF. THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO IMPLEMENT THE STRATEGY IN CALIFORNIA, ADDRESSING IMMEDIATE CONSERVATION PRIORITIES FOR BOTH REMNANT SNRF POPULATIONS IN THE STATE. TO PREVENT THE IMMINENT EXTIRPATION OF THE LASSEN POPULATION, THIS PROPOSAL WILL FUND THE DEVELOPMENT OF A TRANSLOCATION FEASIBILITY ASSESSMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION PLAN FOR RECOVERING THE LASSEN POPULATION THROUGH GENETIC RESCUE. BECAUSE THE SPECIFIC ACTIONS NEEDED TO RECOVER THE SIERRA NEVADA POPULATION ARE LESS WELL UNDERSTOOD THAN FOR THE LASSEN POPULATION, THE STRATEGY RECOMMENDS EXTENSIVE RESEARCH AND MONITORING TO SUPPORT RECOVERY OF THIS POPULATION. THIS PROPOSAL WILL FUND ANALYSIS OF SURVEY AND MONITORING DATA TO ESTIMATE THE DENSITY, OCCUPANCY, DETECTION RATES, HABITAT ASSOCIATIONS, AND PREY RELATIONSHIPS OF SNRF AND SYMPATRIC MESOCARNIVORES IN THE MONO CREEK STUDY AREA OF THE SIERRA NEVADA POPULATION. IN ADDITION TO ONGOING DISTRIBUTION SURVEYS AND GENETIC ANALYSIS, THIS STUDY WILL PROVIDE IMPORTANT INSIGHT INTO MANAGEMENT APPROACHES TO RECOVER THE SIERRA NEVADA POPULATION.FINALLY, THIS PROPOSAL WILL FUND ESSENTIAL COORDINATION TO ENSURE THE STRATEGY REMAINS RELEVANT AND FUNCTIONAL DURING THE IMPLEMENTATION PHASE. SNRF DISTRIBUTION DATA ARE THE MOST FUNDAMENTAL BUILDING BLOCK FOR MANAGEMENT OF THE SUBSPECIES, AS THESE DATA DETERMINE WHERE SUBSPECIES MANAGEMENT SHOULD OCCUR, AND AID IN DETERMINING THE SUBSPECIES' RANGE AND DISTRIBUTION. AS PART OF THIS PROJECT, NEW DISTRIBUTION DATA AT THE LEVEL OF THE 10.4-KM2 SAMPLING CELL WILL BE COMPILED AND SHARED ANNUALLY WITH ALL PARTICIPANTS. NEW RESULTS AND ANALYSES WILL BE INCORPORATED AS ANNUAL UPDATES OR ADDENDA TO THE STRATEGY, PROVIDING MANAGERS WITH THE MOST UP-TO-DATE INFORMATION ON WHICH TO BASE CONSERVATION DECISIONS FOR THE SNRF.THIS PROJECT IS CONSISTENT WITH THE GOVERNOR'S PRIORITIES (CLIMATE CHANGE, BIODIVERSITY, AND RESILIENCY) AS WELL AS WITH NUMEROUS SWG OVERSIGHT COMMITTEE PRIORITIES, INCLUDING LONG-TERM SPECIES MONITORING, DISCRETE, CRITICAL NONGAME MANAGEMENT PROJECTS, PROCESSING AND ANALYSIS OF EXISTING DATASETS TO INFORM CDFW MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, AND SPECIES RESPONSE AND RESILIENCY PLANNING FOR DROUGHT AND CLIMATE CHANGE.

THE NEVADA STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP) PROVIDES A FRAMEWORK AND GUIDANCE ON WHICH CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES AND MANAGEMENT PRIORITIES ARE BUILT AND IMPLEMENTED FOR NEVADA'S IDENTIFIED AQUATIC SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED. EVEN WITH ITS ARID CLIMATE AND LIMITED WATER RESOURCES, NEVADA'S AQUATIC HABITATS SUPPORT MORE AT-RISK, THREATENED, AND ENDANGERED FISH THAN ANY OTHER STATE, AND RANKS ELEVENTH IN OVERALL BIODIVERSITY IN TERMS OF UNIQUE SPECIES OF FISH, AMPHIBIANS, GASTROPODS, AND AQUATIC INSECTS. FUNDAMENTAL TO ALL PROTECTION, CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT EFFORTS IS THE NEED FOR DETAILED UP-TO-DATE KNOWLEDGE AND DATA ON ALL SPECIES AND HABITATS. AN UNDERSTANDING OF SPECIES LIFE HISTORY, DISTRIBUTION, POPULATION STATUS AND TREND, HABITAT CONDITION, AND SPECIES INTERACTIONS ARE NEEDED IN ORDER TO ASSESS RISK AND DEVELOP SOUND MANAGEMENT, CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY STRATEGIES FOR ALL NATIVE, AQUATIC, NON-GAME SPECIES.THE NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE (NDOW), IN MANY CASES, FILLS THE PRIMARY ROLE FOR DESIGNING AND IMPLEMENTING SURVEY, MONITORING, MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION STRATEGIES FOR SWAP PRIORITY AQUATIC SPECIES AND ASSOCIATED HABITATS IN NEVADA. TO PROTECT AND PRESERVE OUR NATIVE SPECIES, SECURE FUNDING MUST BE ACQUIRED FOR EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION PLANNING AND COORDINATION IN ORDER TO FOCUS ACTIVITIES AND BUDGETS WHERE THEY ARE MOST NEEDED. THIS PROJECT WILL ENABLE NDOW TO CONTINUE TO IMPLEMENT THE SWAP AND ACCOMPLISH THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES: PREPARE PROPOSALS, WORK PLANS, BUDGETS AND REPORTS; COORDINATE AND IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES FOR NATIVE AQUATIC SPECIES THROUGH RESEARCH, SURVEY, MONITORING, DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS; IDENTIFY AND CARRY OUT SPECIES REINTRODUCTIONS AND REPATRIATION ACTIVITIES WHEN NECESSARY; DEVELOP NEW AND MAINTAIN EXISTING DATABASES AND LONG-TERM DATA SETS; DEVELOP AND PREPARE CONSERVATION PLANS, AGREEMENTS AND STRATEGIES, AND PARTICIPATE IN MULTI-PARTNER CONSERVATION PLANNING PROCESSES; IMPLEMENT DIRECT HABITAT AND SPECIES MANAGEMENT AND RESTORATION; COORDINATE WITH AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO OTHER AGENCIES, PARTNERS AND PRIVATE CITIZENS; AND ADDRESS THREATS TO NATIVE AQUATIC SPECIES DUE TO COMPETITION FROM INVASIVE NON-NATIVE SPECIES. THE FLANNELMOUTH, WALL CANYON AND RAZORBACK SUCKERS, SPECKLED AND RELICT DACE, TUI CHUB, ASH MEADOWS AMARGOSA AND WARM SPRINGS PUPFISH, NORTHERN LEATHERSIDE CHUB, LAHONTAN CUTTHROAT TROUT, AMARGOSA AND DIXIE VALLEY TOADS, AND THE NORTHERN AND RELICT LEOPARD, AND COLUMBIA SPOTTED FROGS, ARE JUST A FEW OF THE AT-RISK SPECIES THAT WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT FROM THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS SPECIFIC PROJECT.THROUGH CONTINUALLY IMPROVING AND EXPANDING OUR KNOWLEDGE BASE, AND ENHANCED DATA MANAGEMENT AND ACCESSIBILITY, NDOW WILL BE BETTER ABLE TO PREDICT SPECIES RISK, PRIORITIZE SPECIES, AND DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION STRATEGIES FOR AQUATIC SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED. THE INFORMATION AND DATA GATHERED THROUGH THESE FUNDED PROJECTS, WILL ENSURE THAT THE STATE'S MOST SENSITIVE AQUATIC WILDLIFE SPECIES ARE EVALUATED, AND CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT PLANS ARE DEVELOPED AND IMPLEMENTED WHERE NEEDED. DEVELOPING EDUCATIONAL AND OUTREACH CONTENT WILL RAISE PUBLIC AND PARTNER AWARENESS OF AQUATIC WILDLIFE NEEDS AND CONCERNS. EXPECTED RESULTS INCLUDE IMPLEMENTING SURVEY AND MONITORING ACTIVITIES AND UPDATED POPULATION STATUS INFORMATION; CONTINUED IMPLEMENTATION OF HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS AND SPECIES REINTRODUCTIONS; CONTINUED COORDINATION IN THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF MULTI-PARTY CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT PLANS, AGREEMENTS AND STRATEGIES; AND REDUCTION IN NON-NATIVE INVASIVE SPECIES THREATS.

CALIFORNIA'S SOUTH COAST REGION (SCR) ENCOMPASSES MORE THAN EIGHT MILLION ACRES, EXTENDING ALONG THE COAST FROM SANTA BARBARA COUNTY IN THE NORTH TO THE MEXICO BORDER IN THE SOUTH AND IS HOME TO NEARLY HALF OF THE STATE'S POPULATION, WITH OVER 17 MILLION PEOPLE IN THE FIVE COASTAL COUNTIES. DESPITE THE EXTENSIVE DEVELOPMENT, THE SCR IS A BIOLOGICAL HOTSPOT WITH WITH MORE THAN 150 VERTEBRATE ANIMAL SPECIES AND 200 SPECIES OF PLANTS EITHER LISTED AS PROTECTED OR CONSIDERED SENSITIVE BY WILDLIFE AGENCIES AND CONSERVATION GROUPS (HUNTER 1999). MANY OF THESE SPECIES ARE IDENTIFIED AS SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) IN CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE'S (DEPARTMENT) 2015 CALIFORNIA STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP), WHICH IDENTIFIES CONSERVATION STRATEGIES FOR IMPROVING THE CONDITIONS OF SGCN AND THE HABITATS UPON WHICH THEY DEPEND. THE 2015 SWAP DEFINES SGCN AS 1) SPECIES LISTED AT THREATENED, ENDANGERED, OR CANDIDATE SPECIES IN CALIFORNIA UNDER THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA) OR THE CALIFORNIA ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (CESA); 2) SPECIES FOR WHICH THERE IS A CONSERVATION CONCERN (GENERALLY EQUIVALENT TO CALIFORNIA SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN); OR 3) SPECIES IDENTIFIED BY THE DEPARTMENT AS BEING HIGHLY VULNERABLE TO CLIMATE CHANGE. SEE TABLE 1 (ATTACHMENT) FOR A LIST OF SGCN IN THE SCR.CLIMATE CHANGE MODELING HAS SHOWN THAT THE SCR WILL UNDERGO BOTH HOTTER AND DRIER CONDITIONS (HE ET AL., 2018) AND A POTENTIAL SEA-LEVEL RISE OF 50 CM IN LOS ANGELES, ORANGE, AND SAN DIEGO COUNTIES (ERICKSON ET AL., 2018). GIVEN THIS DAUNTING SCENARIO, IT HAS BECOME EVEN MORE IMPORTANT TO ESTABLISH BASELINE AND LONG-TERM TREND DATA FOR SGCN TO EXAMINE POTENTIAL CORRELATIONS WITH ABIOTIC FACTORS (E.G., TEMPERATURE, RAINFALL, ETC.). THIS PROJECT WILL COLLECT BASELINE AND START LONG-TERM TREND DATA COLLECTION ON THREE TO SIX DEPARTMENT LANDS THAT HAVE EXISTING WEATHER STATIONS. SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL SURVEY AT A MINIMUM UPPER NEWPORT BAY ECOLOGICAL RESERVE(UNBER), THE VULCAN MOUNTAIN SECTION OF SAN FELIPE VALLEY WILDLIFE AREA (SFVWA), AND BURTON MESA ECOLOGICAL RESERVE (BMER) USING STANDARDIZED SURVEY METHODS BASED ON THE CALIFORNIA ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT FRAMEWORK ([CEMAF] CDFW 2021) AND OTHER RELEVANT STANDARDIZED SURVEYS. THESE LANDS REPRESENT A VARIETY OF UNIQUE HABITATS INCLUDING COASTAL LAGOON HABITATS IN UNBER, MONTANE CONIFER FOREST AT SFVWA, AND MARITIME CHAPARRAL COMMUNITY IN BMER. SURVEYS WILL INCLUDE ASSESSMENTS OF BIRD, MAMMAL, AND HERPETOFAUNA TAXA AND THEIR HABITATS. POTENTIAL ADDITIONAL SITES COULD INCLUDE BUT NOT LIMITED TO SFVWA (VALLEY FLOOR) AND RANCHO JAMUL ECOLOGICAL RESERVE DEPENDENT ON TIME LIMITATIONS.IN ADDITION TO THE SURVEYS DESCRIBED ABOVE, THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO CONDUCT METADATA ANALYSES OF DECLINING SGCN IN THE SCR, FOCUSING ON HERMES COPPER BUTTERFLY (LYCAENA HEREMES; HERMES), TRICOLORED BLACKBIRD (AGELAIUS TRICOLOR) AND COASTAL CACTUS WREN (CAMPYLORHYNCHUS BRUNNEICAPILLUS SANDIEGENSIS). THESE ANALYSES WILL UTILIZE ALL CURRENTLY AVAILABLE DATA AND WILL HELP THE DEPARTMENT IN POLICY DECISIONS AND LANDSCAPE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. GAP SURVEYS COULD POSSIBLY OCCUR IF DEEMED CRITICAL IN FURTHER ASSESSING THE SPECIES. THE RESULTS WILL ALSO ASSIST IN RESILIENCY PLANNING FOR DROUGHT CONDITIONS AND CLIMATE CHANGE FOR THE REGION OVER TIME.

AKSF FY23 T-10-15 AQUATIC RESOURCE IMPLEMENTATION. THE ALASKA WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN IDENTIFIES REMOVAL OF INVASIVE SPECIES AS A PRIORITY CONSERVATION ACTION.THE DIVISION OF SPORT FISH STRATEGIC PLAN ADDRESSES THE NEED TO MINIMIZE THE IMPACTS OF INVASIVE SPECIES ON HABITATS AND FISH STOCKS. PROPER APPLICATION OF ADMINISTRATIVE HABITAT PROTECTION TOOLS DEPENDS ON KNOWLEDGE OF THE DISTRIBUTION OF FISH IN SPECIFIC WATERS AND FISH HABITAT PROTECTION AUTHORITIES AND PLANNING PROCESSES ARE CONSTRAINED BY THE EXTENT OF CURRENT KNOWLEDGE OF FISH DISTRIBUTION AND THEIR HABITATS, AND READYACCESS TO THAT KNOWLEDGE

A CRITICAL STEP TO HABITAT MANAGEMENT AND PROTECTION IS MAKING SURE THAT STATUS AND DISTRIBUTION INFORMATION ON SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) ARE AVAILABLE TO MANAGERS AND REGULATORS FOR INFORMED DECISION MAKING. THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON THREE MAIN NEEDS OF A COMPREHENSIVE SGCN PROGRAM. THESE NEEDS INCLUDE DATA COLLECTION, DATA MANAGEMENT AND DATA SCREENING (E.G. THE PRESENTATION AND REVIEW OF DATA TO ASSIST IN DECISION MAKING). THIS WORK WILL ENABLE THE DEPARTMENT TO MAINTAIN ACCURATE DATA ON THE STATUS AND LOCATION OF SGCN, WITH A FOCUS ON HIGH PRIORITY SGCN AND STATE ENDANGERED AND THREATENED SPECIES AS IDENTIFIED IN THE NEW YORK STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN. WORK WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH AN MOU WITH THE NEW YORK NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM(NYNHP). NYNYHP WILL ENTER ALL NEW DATA ON STATE LISTED SPECIES AND HIGH PRIORITY SGCN INTO THEIR BIOTICS DATABASE. THIS DATA WILL THEN BE MADE AVAILABLE TO STATE AGENCIES AND THE PUBLIC THROUGH PROJECT REVIEWS AND THROUGH THE PROVISIONING OF DATA TOOLS, INCLUDING GEOGRAPHICALLY EXPLICIT DATA COVERAGES COMPATIBLE WITH STATE GIS SYSTEMS AND PUBLIC, WEB-ACCESSIBLE PLATFORMS.

TO PROVIDE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT, COORDINATION, AND TECHNICAL SUPPORT FOR UTAH DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES(UDWR) STATE WILDLIFE GRANT (SWG) PROGRAM. THIS INCLUDES COMPLYING WITH ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS, AND ANY OTHERREGULATORY STANDARDS NECESSARY TO KEEP THE STATE OF UTAH ELIGIBLE TO CONTINUE TO RECEIVE AND IMPLEMENT SWG FUNDS.THE UDWR HAS ROUGHLY 3 GRANTS BEING IMPLEMENTED IN THE STATE WILDLIFE GRANT PROGRAM THAT NEEDS EFFECTIVECOORDINATION OF THIS PROGRAM THROUGH A LIAISON BETWEEN UDWR AND THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS).

DETAILED SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE OF SPECIES DISTRIBUTION, STATUS, AND TREND IS FUNDAMENTAL TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF SOUND CONSERVATION STRATEGY. CRITICAL ELEMENTS INCLUDE SPECIES DISTRIBUTION, POPULATION STATUS AND TREND, HABITAT CONDITION AND TREND, AND SPECIES/HABITAT RELATIONSHIPS. THERE REMAIN LARGE GAPS IN OUR KNOWLEDGE OF THE BASIC NATURAL HISTORY PARAMETERS FOR MANY OF NEVADA'S SPECIES OF CONSERVATION PRIORITY (SOCP). BASIC SURVEY, INVENTORY AND MONITORING DATA ARE NECESSARY TO UNDERSTAND AND EFFECTIVELY MANAGE THESE POPULATIONS IN STABLE TO INCREASING TRENDS AS DELINEATED IN THE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN. THIS STATE WILDLIFE GRANT PROPOSAL IS DESIGNED TO FUND OUR EFFORTS TO OBTAIN SPECIES AND HABITAT INFORMATION ACROSS TAXONOMIC GROUPS (E.G., BIRDS, BATS, SMALL MAMMALS, REPTILES) IN ORDER TO HELP NDOW CONSERVE TERRESTRIAL NONGAME SPECIES IDENTIFIED IN OUR STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN, ENABLING US TO KEEP COMMON SPECIES COMMON AND ADDRESS THREATS AND CONSERVATION STRATEGIES RELATING TO MANY OF OUR RARE AND SENSITIVE SPECIES. THE OVERALL GOALS ARE FOR HEALTHY, THRIVING POPULATIONS OF SOCP MANAGED FOR STABLE TO INCREASING TREND AND TO PREVENT FURTHER DECLINES OF AT-RISK SPECIES WITHIN PRIORITY HABITAT TYPES. SOME PROJECTS FOCUS ON MONITORING MORE WELL-KNOWN SPECIES TO ASSESS TREND IN POPULATION STATUS AND EFFECTIVENESS OF CONSERVATION ACTIONS WHILE OTHER PROJECTS FOCUS ON INCREASING OUR UNDERSTANDING OF SPECIES WHERE LITTLE IS KNOWN

THE MAJORITY OF SOUTH DAKOTA'S SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SDGFP 2014) ARE ALSO ANIMAL SPECIES MONITORED BY THE SOUTH DAKOTA NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM. THE SOUTH DAKOTA NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM IS A MEMBER OF NATURESERVE, AN INTERNATIONAL NETWORK OF BIOLOGICAL INVENTORIES KNOWN AS NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAMS OR CONSERVATION DATA CENTERS THAT OPERATE IN ALL FIFTY U.S. STATES, CANADA, LATIN AMERICA AND THE CARIBBEAN. AN IMPORTANT TOOL IS THE SOUTH DAKOTA NATURAL HERITAGE DATABASE, A SYSTEM THAT ALLOWS LOCATIONS AND RELATED INFORMATION ON RARE SPECIES TO BE ENTERED AND SHARED FOR ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW AND CONSERVATION PURPOSES. LISTS OF RARE, UNIQUE OR VULNERABLE PLANTS, ANIMALS AND BIOLOGICAL COMMUNITIES ARE MAINTAINED BY EACH HERITAGE PROGRAM. NATURESERVE HAS DEVELOPED AN ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW TOOL (ERT) THAT CAN BE CUSTOMIZED TO MEET SPECIFIC HOSTING HERITAGE PROGRAM NEEDS (HTTP://WWW.NATURESERVE.ORG/CONSERVATION-TOOLS/ENVIRONMENTAL-REVIEW-TOOL). THE ERT USES THE DRUPAL CONTENT MANAGEMENT SYSTEM AND ESRI'S ARCGIS FOR SERVER TO ALLOW ACCESS TO DATA AND SPECIFIC MAP DATA LAYERS THROUGH A SECURE WEB MAP VIEWER. USERS CAN EXPLORE AND QUERY MAP LAYERS TO LEARN MORE ABOUT RARE SPECIES AND UNIQUE NATURAL HABITATS, FULFILL ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW NEEDS, AND VIEW AND INTEGRATE DATA ON RARE SPECIES AND HABITATS FOR CONSERVATION PLANNING. THE ERT CAN UPDATE CONTENT ON A DAILY BASIS WITHOUT INVOLVING THE HOSTING PROVIDER. ARCGIS TOOLS ALLOW DEVELOPMENT AND PUBLISHING CUSTOMIZED AND AUTOMATED PROJECT REVIEWS TO STREAMLINE THE ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW PROCESS, REDUCE STATE AGENCY WORKLOAD, AND PROVIDE EFFICIENT OUTPUT TO THE PUBLIC AND SPECIFIC USERS, SUCH AS ENVIRONMENTAL CONSULTING FIRMS AND LAND USE PLANNERS AT MANY ADMINISTRATIVE LEVELS.

T-17-12 P 01 - PLANNING AND MANAGEMENT OF ALASKA'S LEGISLATIVELY DESIGNATED SPECIAL AREAS FY2023 (ALL SWG FED FUNDS) TO BE RSAD TO DIVISION OF HABITAT.THIS PROJECT HAS THREE MAJOR COMPONENTS ANDPURPOSES TO ENSURE EFFECTIVE, LONG RANGE, CONSISTENT GUIDANCE FOR MANAGEMENT OF THE ADF&G'S SPECIALAREAS: MANAGEMENT PLANNING FOR SPECIAL AREAS, MANAGEMENT AND MONITORING OF LAND USE ACTIVITIES; AND PROGRAMMATIC CONSISTENCY.
IN T-2-P-5 SWAP 2025 REVISION

LOUISIANA'S WILDLIFE DIVERSITY PROGRAM IS RESPONSIBLE FOR CONSERVING LOUISIANA'S RARE, THREATENED, AND ENDANGERED PLANT AND ANIMAL SPECIES, NONGAME BIRDS, AND NATURAL COMMUNITIES. PROGRAM STAFF CONDUCT, GUIDE, FUND, AND FACILITATE RESEARCH, MONITORING, AND INVENTORY OF SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED AND THEIR ASSOCIATED HABITATS AS IDENTIFIED IN THE LOUISIANA WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN. THIS GRANT WILL CONTINUE TO SUPPORT STAFF UNDER THE WILDLIFE DIVERSITY SECTION WHO COMPLETE WORK RELATED TO THE ACTION PLAN, INCLUDING ACTION IMPLEMENTATION, PARTNERSHIP DEVELOPMENT, ACTION PLAN REVISIONS, AND MANAGEMENT OF CURRENT AND FUTURE STATE WILDLIFE GRANT AWARDS.

AS THE DESIGNATED TRUSTEE OF THE STATE'S WILDLIFE RESOURCES, ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH & GAME (ADF&G) HOLDS ALL WILDLIFE, INCLUDING AMPHIBIANS, BIRDS, AND MAMMALS (GAME AND NONGAME), IN TRUST FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE PEOPLE OF ALASKA. IN KEEPING WITH THE AGENCY'S MISSION, ADF&G USES FEDERAL FUNDS PROVIDED TO ALL STATES VIA THE STATE WILDLIFE GRANT (SWG) PROGRAM TO MANAGE AND CONSERVE WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS, INCLUDING SPECIES THAT ARE NOT HUNTED OR FISHED. SWG FUNDS ALLOW ALASKA TO PROACTIVELY ADDRESS RESEARCH, MANAGEMENT, AND CONSERVATION NEEDS THAT ULTIMATELY PREVENT SPECIES FROM BECOMING LISTED AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA) AND ADDRESS FEDERAL ACTIONS AND RECOVERY EFFORTS OF EXISTING ESA-LISTED SPECIES. ADF&G'S THREATENED, ENDANGERED, AND DIVERSITY PROGRAM (TED) IMPLEMENTS THE STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP) AND THEREBY REFLECTS THE BROAD RANGE OF BENEFITS AND VALUES THAT ALASKAN'S DESIRE FROM ALL OF THE STATE'S WILDLIFE RESOURCES. THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THE TED PROGRAM IS TO SUPPORT RESEARCH AND UNDERSTANDING OF SPECIES THAT HAVE A REAL OR PERCEIVED CONSERVATION CONCERN AND TO TAKE ACTIONS TO PREVENT SPECIES FROM BEING LISTED AS FEDERALLY THREATENED OR ENDANGERED. RESULTS OF OUR APPLIED RESEARCH ARE USED BY MANAGERS AND POLICY MAKERS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE SEVERITY OF A SPECIES' DECLINE, IDENTIFY THE CAUSE(S) OF A DECLINE, AND IDENTIFY CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS TO REVERSE A DECLINE. THE 14 PROJECTS PROACTIVELY ADDRESS A SPECIFIC, HIGH PRIORITY RESEARCH OR MONITORING TOPIC ON SPECIES IN STEEP DECLINE OR CURRENTLY LISTED UNDER THE ESA, INCLUDING 7 RESEARCH PROJECTS FOCUSED ON SINGLE SGCNS, INCLUDING 5 BIRD SPECIES, 5 MULTI-SPECIES, LONG-TERM SGCN MONITORING PROJECTS, AND 1 COORDINATION AND PLANNING PROJECT THAT PROVIDES FUNDING FOR OPERATIONAL, ADMINISTRATIVE, AND COORDINATION EXPENSES OF THE PROGRAM NOT CLEARLY ASSOCIATED WITH INDIVIDUAL RESEARCH AND MONITORING PROJECTS.
IMPLEMENTATION OF HAWAII STATE WILDLIFE PROGRAM FY23

THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL EXAMINE HABITAT ASSOCIATIONS OF TWO POORLY-KNOWN BIRD SPECIES, CHUCK-WILL'S-WIDOW ANDGREATER ROADRUNNER, IN UPLAND PINE WOODLAND MANAGED FOR OPEN PINE HABITAT CONDITIONS, IN PART TO BENEFIT WILDLIFE, AND IN PINE PLANTATION MANAGED TO MAXIMIZE TIMBER YIELD. AUDIO SURVEYS CONDUCTED USING AUTONOMOUSRECORDING UNITS WILL MAXIMIZE DETECTION PROBABILITY FOR EACH SPECIES, WHICH IS UNDERREPRESENTED BY TRADITIONAL BIRD SURVEY METHODS. BY CONDUCTING SURVEYS WITHIN FOREST STANDS OF MULTIPLE AGE STRUCTURE CATEGORIES, WITHIN BOTHOPEN-PINE AND HIGH-YIELD FORESTRY MANAGEMENT APPROACHES, THE PROJECT WILL ALLOW EVALUATION OF RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN FOREST CONDITIONS AND/OR MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AND THE ABUNDANCE OF EACH SPECIES. DUE TO INFORMATION GAPS,CONCERNS ABOUT LOW POPULATION DENSITIES, AND/OR EVIDENCE OF DECLINING POPULATIONS, CHUCK-WILL'S-WIDOW AND GREATERROADRUNNER ARE CLASSIFIED AS SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED, ASSIGNED STATE ELEMENT RANKS S4B AND S3,RESPECTIVELY.

THE ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES (AFWA) DIRECTS EACH STATE TO REVIEW AND UPDATE ITS STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP) AT LEAST EVERY 10 YEARS. THUS, FOR CALIFORNIA'S SWAP, A REVIEW IS DUE BY 2025. THIS PRESENTS AN OPPORTUNITY TO REVISE THE 2015 VERSION BY CONDUCTING A PROGRESS EVALUATION AND A SCOPING PROCESS FOR INCORPORATING NEW INFORMATION AND LESSONS LEARNED SINCE 2015. IT ALSO PROVIDES THE CHANCE TO FOLLOW ADVANCED STEPS OF THE OPEN CONSERVATION STANDARDS FRAMEWORK, WHICH PROVIDES THE STRUCTURE FOR THE 2015 SWAP. THIS WILL INCREASE THE FOCUS ON CRITICAL CONSERVATION NEEDS AND IDENTIFY SPECIFIC ACTIONS TO HELP REACH DESIRED CONSERVATION OUTCOMES, AS WELL AS ENHANCE THE USABILITY AND RELEVANCY FOR PARTNERS BY FOLLOWING A CONSISTENT PROCESS AND FORMAT. THE PROPOSED REVIEW PROCESS WILL CONSIST OF THE FOLLOWING TASKS, OVER A TWO-YEAR PERIOD: DURING FISCAL YEAR (FY) 22/23, WE WILL CARRY OUT AND FINALIZE A SWAP 2015 PROGRESS EVALUATION AND CONDUCT INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL SWAP 2025 SCOPING. DURING FY 23/24, WE WILL INCORPORATE INFORMATION RESULTING FROM THE SCOPING PROCESS INTO THE SWAP 2025 DRAFT AND CONTINUE THE SWAP STRATEGY EVALUATION, USING THE OPEN CONSERVATION STANDARDS FRAMEWORK. THIS WILL INCLUDE THE USE OF THEORY-OF-CHANGE (TOC) LOGIC MODELS TO SUPPORT FOCUSED ACTION PLANNING AND PRIORITIZATION. WE WILL ALSO CONDUCT THREE PUBLIC INPUT SESSIONS. WE WILL THEN UPDATE THE SWAP WITH THE RESULTING INFORMATION. DURING FY 24/25, WE WILL FINALIZE THE DRAFT, CONDUCT INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL REVIEWS, AND FINALIZE SWAP 2025, WHICH WILL BE PART OF A SEPARATE SWG PROPOSAL TO BE SUBMITTED IN FY 23/24. SWAP PROGRAM STAFF, WITH SUPPORT FROM OTHER SCIENCE INSTITUTE (SI) STAFF, WILL LEAD AND COORDINATE ALL TASKS AND PROCESSES OUTLINED HERE. MOST PLANNING WORK WILL OCCUR THROUGH A SERIES OF WORKING SESSIONS PER SWAP PROVINCE, WITH CDFW SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTS (SMES), PARTNER SMES, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS, EITHER VIRTUALLY OR IN PERSON.

THIS PROJECT WILL USE GENOMICS TO DETERMINE APPROPRIATE RECOVERY STRATEGIES FOR WESTERN MIGRATORY MONARCH BUTTERFLIES (DANAUS PLEXIPPUS) GIVEN THE RECENT CRASH IN THE OVERWINTERING POPULATION AND APPARENT INCREASE IN THE YEAR-ROUND RESIDENT BREEDING POPULATION. SPECIALLY, THE PROJECT WILL EVALUATE A) WHETHER THERE IS CONNECTIVITY BETWEEN RESIDENT MONARCHS THAT BREED ON NON-NATIVE TROPICAL MILKWEED PLANTED IN HOME GARDENS AND THE REMNANT MIGRATORY POPULATION, AND B) MIGRATORY CONNECTIVITY (THE DEGREE TO WHICH BUTTERFLIES FROM SPECIFIC BREEDING SITES MIGRATE TO SPECIFIC OVERWINTERING GROVES). THIS INFORMATION WILL HELP GUIDE THE DELINEATION OF US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) CONSERVATION UNITS, AS WELL AS REGIONAL RECOVERY ACTIONS (USING THE BEST AVAILABLE SCIENCE TO ADVANCE MONARCH RECOVERY FGC - 1021). TO CONDUCT THE GENETIC ANALYSES, STAFF FROM STATE, FEDERAL AGENCIES AND COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY ALONG WITH VOLUNTEERS COVERED BY A CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) SCIENTIFIC COLLECTING PERMIT WILL SALVAGE MONARCH SPECIMENS FROM DIFFERENT PORTIONS OF ITS RANGE IN CALIFORNIA. ALL SAMPLES WILL BE SENT TO DR. CHRIS FUNK OF COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY, WHOSE LAB WILL CONDUCT THE GENOMIC ANALYSIS. THIS PROJECT IS CONDUCTED IN PARTNERSHIP WITH USFWS, WHO CONSIDERS THE DATA GENERATED BY THIS PROPOSAL KEY TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF A SUCCESSFUL RECOVERY PROGRAM.

THIS GRANT IS TO SUPPORT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OUTLINED IN THE LOUISANA STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN. THE GRANT WILL PROVIDE FUNDING FOR A ONE-YEAR STUDY TO ASSESS THE STATUS OF EASTERN SPOTTED SKUNK (ESS; SPILOGALE PUTORIOUS) AND OTHER SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) ON COASTAL PRAIRIES IN SOUTHWEST, LA. SURVEYS WILL CONSIST OF BAITED CAMERA-TRAP-ARRAYS THAT LOUISIANA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND FISHERIES WILL DEPLOY NEAR HISTORIC LOCALITIES FOR EASTERN SPOTTED SKUNK IN SOUTHWEST LOUISIANA AND SITES THAT SPECIES ARE SUSPECTED TO OCCUR.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS GRANT IS TO IMPLEMENT FLORIDA'S STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN WITH SELECT TERRESTRIAL AND AQUATIC PROJECTS AIMED AT BENEFITING SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED. THIS STATE WILDLIFE GRANT INCLUDES SIX PROJECTS FOR THE PERIOD COVERED. 1. RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT IN A PINE ROCKLAND HABITAT AT PINE FOREST PARK 2. QUANTITY AND QUALITY PRESCRIBED BURNS AT KISSIMMEE PRAIRIE PRESERVE STATE PARK 3. EGLIN AIRFORCE BASE CULVERT REPLACEMENT 4. PEACE RIVER STREAMBANK RESTORATION PROJECT - FORT MEADE 5. GRAHAM SPRING STREAM BANK RE-CONTOUR AND RE-VEGETATION 6. GATEWAY TO MYAKKA RIVER STATE PARK - MARSH RESTORATION PARTNERS INCLUDE: ELGIN AIRFORCE BASE, FORT MEADE AND THE POLK COUNTY PARKS AND NATURAL RESOURCES, PINE FOREST PARK, FAIRCHILD TROPICAL BOTANIC GARDEN, NATURE CONSERVANCY, AUDUBON OF FLORIDA, VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY, ALACHUA CONSERVATION TRUST, SUWANNEE RIVER WATER MANAGEMENT DISTRICT, MYAKKA RIVER STATE PARK

THIS STUDY WILL DETERMINE ANNUAL LIFE HISTORY CHARACTERISTICS FOR THE PONTCHARTRAIN PAINTED CRAYFISH FAXONIUS HOBBSI, A SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) IN LOUISIANA. TWO STREAMS IN THE TCHEFUNCTE AND TANGIPAHOA RIVER BASINS WILL BE SAMPLED MONTHLY FOR 24 MONTHS TO DOCUMENT F. HOBBSI LIFE HISTORY DATA. ALL F. HOBBSI COLLECTED WILL BE SEXED, REPRODUCTIVE FORM DETERMINED, AND MEASURED (CARAPACE LENGTH, ORBITAL LENGTH, ABDOMEN LENGTH, PALM LENGTH, PALM WIDTH, PROPODUS LENGTH, AND WET WEIGHT). DATA COLLECTED WILL BE USED TO DETERMINE CRITICAL F. HOBBSI LIFE HISTORY CHARACTERISTICS INCLUDING MORPHOMETRICS, SIZE-CLASS STRUCTURE, AGE STRUCTURE, REPRODUCTIVE SEASON, AND GROWTH RATES. THE RESULTS FROM THIS STUDY WILL PROVIDE THE FIRST COMPREHENSIVE LIFE HISTORY INFORMATION FOR F. HOBBSI. THIS INFORMATION CAN AID RESOURCE MANAGERS WITH SPECIES MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION EFFORTS AND BE INCORPORATED INTO FUTURE ECOSYSTEM/WATERSHED/STREAM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS IN LOUISIANA.

THIS PROJECT WILL ASSESS AMPHIBIAN AND REPTILE HABITAT USE, TIMING/RATE OF MOVEMENT, INJURY AND SURVIVAL, AS WELL AS PRE- AND POST-EVENT HABITAT CONDITIONS IN AREAS OF FIRE MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES (I.E., PRESCRIBED FIRE). THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH QUALITATIVE AND QUANTITATIVE SURVEYS TARGETING SPECIES ESPECIALLY BOX TURTLE (TERRAPENE CAROLINA) AND TIMBER RATTLESNAKE (CROTALUS HORRIDUS), AND AS OPPORTUNITIES ALLOW, SELECT VERNAL POOL ASSOCIATED SPECIES (E.G., MARBLED SALAMANDER AMBYSTOMA OPACUM, JEFFERSON SALAMANDER AMBYSTOMA JEFFERSONIANUM), WOOD TURTLE GLYPTEMYS INSCULPTA, AND SPOTTED TURTLE CLEMMYS GUTTATA, AND THEIR HABITATS. BY ASSESSING SURVIVAL AND DISTRIBUTION IN RESPONSE TO FIRE MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES, THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES WILL BE BEST PRACTICES FOR MINIMIZING NEGATIVE IMPACTS TO AMPHIBIANS AND REPTILES WHILE SUPPORTING THE MANY BENEFICIAL HABITAT GOALS ACHIEVED THROUGH FIRE MANAGEMENT CONDUCTED BY RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AGENCIES AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS. THIS PROJECT IS LED BY THE PENNSYLVANIA FISH AND BOAT COMMISSION (PFBC) IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE PENNSYLVANIA GAME COMMISSION (PGC) AND A SUB-RECIPIENT, EAST STROUDSBURG UNIVERSITY.

MANY CALIFORNIA NATIVE INLAND DESERT FISH SPECIES ARE AT RISK FROM THE IMMEDIATE THREAT OF DROUGHT AND THE LONGER-TERM IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE. THESE FISH LIVE IN ISOLATED, POTENTIALLY EPHEMERAL HABITATS (SPRINGS AND CIENEGAS) AND ARE SUSCEPTIBLE TO STOCHASTIC EVENTS THAT CAN RESULT IN LOCAL EXTIRPATION OR EXTINCTION, SUCH AS EXTREME WATER TEMPERATURE AND SALINITY CHANGES DUE TO VARIABILITY IN WATER SUPPLY, DESICCATION OF HABITAT, AND HUMAN ACTIVITIES SUCH AS HABITAT MODIFICATION AND INVASIVE SPECIES INTRODUCTIONS. AS SUCH, ALL CALIFORNIA SPECIES OF CYPRINODON PUPFISH ARE EITHER A CALIFORNIA SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN OR THREATENED OR LISTED AS AN ENDANGERED SPECIES AT STATE AND/OR FEDERAL LEVELS. FACILITATED INTRODUCTIONS TO NEW HABITATS HAVE RESULTED IN SUCCESSFUL ESTABLISHMENT OF NEW OR REINTRODUCED POPULATIONS FOR THESE SPECIES, BUT THESE ACTIONS CAN RESULT IN STRONG GENETIC 'FOUNDER EFFECTS' AND/OR GENETIC DRIFT OVER TIME IN SMALL, ISOLATED POPULATIONS (ALLENDORF, 1986; FRANKHAM, BALLOU, & BRISCOE, 2002; NEI, MARUYAMA, & CHAKRABORTY, 1975). GENETIC EVALUATION OF THESE POPULATIONS IS CRITICAL FOR A LANDSCAPE-SCALE MONITORING PROGRAM THAT SEEKS TO ADDRESS THE LONG-TERM GENETIC CHALLENGES OF THESE ISOLATED POPULATIONS WITHIN THE MULTI-SPECIES PUPFISH COMPLEX.OWENS PUPFISH (C. RADIOSUS) HAVE BEEN LISTED UNDER THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT SINCE 1967. ALL EXTANT MEMBERS OF THIS SPECIES ARE DESCENDED FROM NEARLY 400 FISH THAT WERE RELOCATED FROM A DRYING POND (THE LAST KNOWN POPULATION OF OWENS PUPFISH) TO BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT (BLM) SPRING IN 1969 (MILLER & PISTER, 1971; PISTER, 1993), AS ALL OTHER HISTORICAL POPULATIONS HAD BEEN EXTIRPATED FROM THEIR NATIVE HABITATS. THESE BLM SPRING FISH SERVED AS A SOURCE POPULATION FOR A COMPLEX HISTORY OF POPULATION FOUNDING, EXTIRPATION, RE-FOUNDING, AND RELOCATION ACROSS MULTIPLE LOCATIONS IN OWENS VALLEY. THE FIVE CURRENTLY EXTANT POPULATIONS OF OWENS PUPFISH (BLM SPRING, MULE SPRING, LETTER PONDS, MARVIN'S MARSH, AND WELL 368) ARE BEING USED AS SOURCE POPULATIONS FOR THE CURRENT SPECIES MANAGEMENT ACTION TO SET UP A LARGER REFUGE POPULATION AT RIVER SPRING LAKES ECOLOGICAL RESERVE.IN THIS PROPOSAL, WE WILL SEQUENCE, ASSEMBLE, AND ANNOTATE REFERENCE GENOMES FOR ALL SEVEN CALIFORNIA PUPFISH SPECIES, WHICH WILL THEN BE USED TO EVALUATE CURRENT AND FUTURE CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES FOR THIS NATIVE AND THREATENED FISH COMPLEX. ONCE ALL SPECIES REFERENCE GENOMES ARE CREATED, WE WILL DESIGN A PAN-SPECIES GENETIC ASSAY THAT CAN BE USED ACROSS ALL CALIFORNIA PUPFISH SPECIES. THIS ASSAY WILL CONSIST OF SPECIFIC AND TARGETED DNA SEQUENCING THE GENOME AT HUNDREDS OF SEQUENCE VARIANTS TO ASSESS OVERALL GENETIC DIVERSITY BOTH WITHIN AND BETWEEN PUPFISH SPECIES. AFTER ASSAY VALIDATION, WE WILL EMPLOY THE ASSAY TO EXAMINE DIVERSITY OF THE OWENS PUPFISH POPULATIONS ACROSS ALL FIVE CURRENT SOURCE POPULATIONS, AS WELL AS WITHIN THE RECENTLY ESTABLISHED REFUGE POPULATION AT RIVER SPRING LAKES ECOLOGICAL RESERVE. USING THE ASSAY, WE WILL ATTEMPT TO IDENTIFY THE PROPORTION OF EACH DONOR POPULATION OF ORIGIN WITHIN SAMPLES AT THE RESERVE, AIDING SPECIES MANAGEMENT IN ENSURING APPROPRIATE CONSERVATION OF SOURCE POPULATIONS WHICH ARE PROVEN SUCCESSFUL IN THE ESTABLISHMENT OF THIS RESERVE POPULATION.

THE UTAH WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (UWAP) IS A 10-YEAR PLAN FOR THE UTAH DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES (UDWR) AND CONSERVATION PARTNERS TO ALIGN AND COORDINATE PROGRAMMATIC- AND PROJECT-LEVEL ASPECTS OF THEIR PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION. THE UWAP'S CORNERSTONE ARE THE SPECIES IN GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) IN UTAH. HAVING A COORDINATED LIST OF SPECIES IN NEED OF CONSERVATION ATTENTION ALLOWS ALL CONSERVATION PARTNERS IN UTAH TO FOCUS THEIR ATTENTION ON SPECIES TRULY NEEDING CONSERVATION ATTENTION. THE UWAP IDENTIFIES IMPORTANT HABITATS FOR THE SGCNS, SO THAT THESE HABITATS CAN BE MAINTAINED, PROTECTED, AND EVEN EXPANDED. THE PRIMARY THREATS TO THE SGCNS ARE ALSO IDENTIFIED SO THAT CONSERVATION PARTNERS WITH AUTHORITY TO ADDRESS THOSE THREATS CAN WORK TOWARD ALLEVIATING AND MINIMIZING THEM. WHILE SOME OF THE SGCNS IN THE UWAP ARE SPECIES THAT ARE ALREADY LISTED AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA), MOST ARE NOT AND THE GOAL OF THE UWAP IS TO MAINTAIN AND RESTORE HEALTHY SPECIES POPULATIONS, HABITATS, AND MINIMIZE THREATS TO PREVENT THE NEED FOR ADDITIONAL SPECIES LISTINGS UNDER THE ESA. OVER THE PAST 20 YEARS, UTAH HAS DEMONSTRATED A STRONG CONSERVATION ETHIC FOR ITS' NATIVE SPECIES THROUGH THE UWAP AND PROVIDED THE CONSERVATION TRACK RECORD TO KEEP SPECIES OFF THE ESA. IN FACT, THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE HAS FOUND THAT MORE THAN 90% OF THE UTAH SPECIES PETITIONED FOR LISTING UNDER THE ESA HAVE NOT WARRANTED PROTECTION, WHICH DEMONSTRATES EFFECTIVE STATE MANAGEMENT FOR THESE SPECIES. KEEPING SPECIES MANAGEMENT UNDER STATE AUTHORITY ALLOWS FOR EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR UTAH TO CONTINUE TO GROW ECONOMICALLY. THIS GRANT SUPPORTS THE COORDINATION OF IMPLEMENTATION AND REVISION OF THE UWAP.THIS GRANT SUPPORTS MUCH OF THE DATA HANDLING NEEDS CREATED BY THE UTAH WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN. THE UDWR'S NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM (UNHP) MANAGES MORE THAN 75,000 LOCALITY RECORDS FOR SGCNS. THE UNHP STAFF CONTINUALLY ADD NEW SPECIES LOCALITY RECORDS TO OUR CENTRAL DATABASE AS DATA ARE RECEIVED FROM THE UDWR BIOLOGISTS AND UWAP PARTNERS. MAINTAINING SGCN LOCALITY INFORMATION IS CRITICAL TO DETERMINING THE SUCCESS OF THE UWAP IN MAINTAINING HEALTHY POPULATIONS OF SGCNS IN UTAH.

SEE ATTACHED.THIS PROPOSAL SEEKS TO ASSIST ADF&G'S THREATENED, ENDANGERED, AND DIVERSITY PROGRAM BY CENTRALIZINGAND SERVING CONSERVATION DATA FOR ALASKA'S SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED. DATA INCLUDECONSERVATION ASSESSMENTS, CONSERVATION RANKS, TAXONOMIC CHECKLISTS, AND OTHER PRODUCTS TO SUPPORT THEREVISION OF ALASKA'S STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN.

THIS PROJECT WILL RESTORE OR ENHANCE EXISTING DEGRADED GRASSLANDS RESULTING FROM WOODY SPECIES ENCROACHMENT ONINTACT GRASSLANDS LOCATED IN THE SOUTHERN PORTION OF SOUTH DAKOTA'S MISSOURI RIVER BASIN. WITH THE RECENT RETURNOF HIGH AGRICULTURAL COMMODITY PRICES, CONVERSION OF NATIVE GRASSLANDS TO ROW CROP PRODUCTION CONTINUES ATALARMING RATES, IT IS IMPERATIVE THAT REMAINING GRASSLAND COMPLEXES ARE MAINTAINED AND MANAGED TO ENHANCE FLORALAND FAUNAL DIVERSITY, RANGELAND FORAGE PRODUCTION AND ECONOMIC VIABILITY OF GRASS-BASED AGRICULTURAL ENTERPRISES RESPONSIBLE FOR STEWARDING THESE IMPORTANT GRASSLANDS.

NEBRASKA GAME AND PARKS COMMISSION (NGPC) BEGAN BASELINE SURVEYS FOR REGAL FRITILLARIES (ARGYNNIS IDALIA) IN2016. THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE THE SUCCESS OF THAT EFFORT BY SUPPORTING CONTINUED SURVEYS THAT USE ESTABLISHEDPROTOCOLS TO UNDERSTAND TRENDS OF THE REGAL FRITILLARY, MONARCH, AND ASSESS THEIR HABITATS. ADDITIONALLY, NGPCWILL PARTNER WITH THE XERCES SOCIETY TO CONTINUE THE NEBRASKA BUMBLE BEE ATLAS (NEBBA), A COORDINATED VOLUNTEERMONITORING PROGRAM THAT WORKS TO TRACK AND CONSERVE NEBRASKA'S BUMBLE BEE SPECIES. THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE OURUNDERSTANDING OF THE STATUS AND HABITAT NEEDS OF THESE ESSENTIAL POLLINATORS, DEVELOP A GREATER AWARENESS OF THESPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN), AND PROVIDE EVIDENCE-BASED CONSERVATION RECOMMENDATIONS. THISINFORMATION WILL BE USED TO INFORM PRESENT AND FUTURE STATE AND FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES LISTING DECISIONS, TOFACILITATE SGCN ADAPTATION TO CLIMATE CHANGE, AND TO PROVIDE A DATASET THAT CAN CONTRIBUTE TO BUMBLE BEE RECOVERYAND HELP AVOID EXTIRPATIONS AND EXTINCTIONS OF THESE IMPORTANT POLLINATORS. LASTLY, BY ENGAGING THE PUBLIC, THISPROGRAM WILL HELP TO BUILD A NETWORK OF VOLUNTEERS THAT CAN HELP MONITOR RARE BUTTERFLIES AND BUMBLE BEES BEYONDTHE SCOPE OF THIS PROJECT AND HELP TO SERVE AS AN EARLY WARNING SYSTEM FOR CHANGES IN THEIR POPULATIONS.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT BUILDS ON MORE THAN TWENTY YEARS OF WORK CONDUCTED BY THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW), USDA FOREST SERVICE (USFS), U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) AND RESEARCHERS. CDFW'S CONTRIBUTION TO SIERRA NEVADA YELLOW-LEGGED FROG (RANA SIERRAE) CONSERVATION HAS BEEN CONDUCTED BY THE HIGH MOUNTAIN LAKES (HML) PROJECT. THROUGHOUT ITS TWENTY-YEAR HISTORY, THE HML PROJECT HAS ACCOMPLISHED THE FOLLOWING:-SURVEYED APPROXIMATELY 13,000 DISTINCT WATER BODIES IN THE SIERRA NEVADA, WITH A FOCUS ON DETECTING POTENTIAL R. SIERRAE AND SOUTHERN MOUNTAIN YELLOW-LEGGED FROG (R. MUSCOSA) OCCUPANCY;-CREATED AND MANAGED A LONG-TERM MONITORING DATABASE, WHICH IS USED TO ANALYZE R. SIERRAE POPULATION TRENDS AND INFORM MANAGEMENT DOCUMENTS;-DEVELOPED FOURTEEN AQUATIC BIODIVERSITY MANAGEMENT PLANS (ABMPS) THAT ADDRESS SEVERAL THOUSAND WATER BODIES AND FOCUS ON R. SIERRAE RECOVERY;-IMPLEMENTED OR ASSISTED WITH TWENTY-FIVE SUCCESSFUL NON-NATIVE FISH REMOVAL PROJECTS TO HELP RESTORE R. SIERRAE IN DOZENS OF LAKES;-REVIEWED, REDUCED, AND HALTED HATCHERY TROUT PLANTING ACTIVITIES TO ACCOMMODATE R. SIERRAE RECOVERY, RESULTING IN A 70% DECLINE IN HIGH MOUNTAIN TROUT STOCKING;-SPEARHEADED THE CALIFORNIA ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT LISTING PROCESS FOR R. SIERRAE AND SIERRA NEVADA POPULATIONS OF R. MUSCOSA;-CONDUCTED BROAD SCALE AMPHIBIAN CHYTRID FUNGUS (BATRACHOCHYTRIUM DENDROBATIDIS; BD) TESTS TO HELP DETERMINE THE DISTRIBUTION OF BD ACROSS SIERRA NEVADA FROG POPULATIONS; AND-FACILITATED RESEARCH ON NUMEROUS TOPICS RELATED TO SIERRA NEVADA YELLOW-LEGGED FROG CONSERVATION.ADDITIONAL FUNDS ARE NECESSARY TO IMPLEMENT KEY ACTIVITIES IDENTIFIED BY THE USFWS AND CDFW AS CRITICAL TO THE RECOVERY OF THE SPECIES, INCLUDING MAINTAINING LONG-TERM MONITORING TO IDENTIFY POPULATION TRENDS AND CONTINUE MONITORING AT COMPLETED FISH REMOVAL SITES. CDFW'S HML PROJECT CONDUCTS THIS WORK IN COLLABORATION WITH FEDERAL PARTNERS AND LEADING SPECIES EXPERTS. FUNDING FOR PAST WORK WAS PROVIDED BY A COMBINATION OF CALIFORNIA STATE FUNDS AND FEDERAL GRANT SOURCES, INCLUDING STATE WILDLIFE GRANTS (SWG), TRADITIONAL SECTION 6, AND SPORTS FISH RESTORATION ACT (SFRA).

PROCESSING AND ANALYSIS OF EXISTING WILDLIFE SURVEY DATA TO INFORM CONSERVATION IS OFTEN SLOW AND INEFFICIENT, RESULTING IN LENGTHY LAG TIMES BETWEEN QUESTIONS FROM MANAGERS AND ANSWERS FROM SCIENTISTS. THIS GRANT WILL IMPROVE EFFICIENCY OF DATA ANALYSIS. THROUGH A CONTRACT, RESEARCHERS AT UC BERKELEY WILL CUSTOMIZE THE NIMBLE APPLICATION OF R STATISTICAL SOFTWARE TO SPEED UP SOLVE TIMES OF MULTI-SPECIES OCCUPANCY MODELS USING EXISTING LANDSCAPE-SCALE, WILDLIFE SURVEY DATA FROM CAMERAS (TERRESTRIAL MAMMALS) AND SOUND RECORDERS (BIRDS AND BATS). ADDITIONALLY, STAFF AT THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (CDFW) WILL PACKAGE THE SOFTWARE CODE IN A CONVENIENT DASHBOARD APPLICATION THAT RUNS BATCHES OF MODELS; VISUALIZES TRENDS AND ASSOCIATIONS WITH WILDFIRE, CLIMATE, AND OTHER STRESSORS; AND SHOWS SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MAPS.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS GRANT IS TO IMPLEMENT FLORIDA'S STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN WITH SELECT RESEARCH AND MONITORING PROJECTS AIMED AT BENEFITING SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED. THIS STATE WILDLIFE GRANT INCLUDES FIVE PROJECTS FOR THE PERIOD COVERED.1. HABITAT SUITABILITY INDEX OF BLUENOSE SHINER (PTERONOTROPIS WELAKA) FOR ST. JOHNS RIVER TRIBUTARIES AND PANHANDLE RIVERS2. DIAMONDBACK TERRAPIN BYCATCH IN BLUE CRAB TRAPS3. SOUTHEASTERN AMERICAN KESTREL MOVEMENTS, HOME RANGE, AND HABITAT USE4. POPULATION STATUS AND THREATS TO THE SUWANNEE ALLIGATOR SNAPPING TURTLE (MACROCHELYS SUWANNIENSIS) IN THE SUWANNEE RIVER 5. CALAMINTHA BEE PROJECT CONTINUATION: ADVANCING POPULATION MONITORING AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT FOR THREE RARE FLORIDA SCRUB BEES.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS GRANT IS TO IMPLEMENT FLORIDA'S STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN WITH SELECT MARINE AND ESTUARINE PROJECTS AIMED AT BENEFITING SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED. THIS STATE WILDLIFE GRANT INCLUDES FOUR PROJECTS FOR THE PERIOD COVERED.1. RESTORATION OF BENTHIC REEF BUILDERS IN ISLAMORADA2. MINIMIZING FISH PREDATION ON MASSIVE CORALS OUTPLANTED FOR RESTORATION3. CORAL AND DIADEMA RESTORATION FOR THE FLORIDA KEYS4. USE OF PERVIOUS OYSTER SHELL HABITATS IN REDUCING SHORELINE EROSION AND RESTORING COASTAL HABITATPARTNERS INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH FLORIDA, TIMUCUAN ECOLOGICAL AND HERITAGE PRESERVE,FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION, FLORIDA STATE UNIVERSITY, I.CARE, KEY MARINE LABORATORY, ISLAMORADA NURSERY, NOAA CORAL LAB, REEF RENEWAL, SUSTAINABLE OCEANS AND REEFS.

THIS PROJECT WOULD PROVIDE PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES, AND OTHER NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT GROUPS WITH A COST-EFFECTIVE SOLUTION TO ENHANCE AQUATIC HABITATS AND IMPROVE STREAM FRAGMENTATION. IDENTIFYING AND PRIORITIZING BARRIERS WILL ALLOW MANAGERS TO TARGET SPECIFIC LOCATIONS WHERE INVESTING EFFORT AND FUNDING WILL PROVIDE THE GREATEST BENEFIT TO STREAM CONNECTIVITY FOR SPECIES OF CONCERN AND GAME FISHES. IN ADDITION, RIGOROUS TESTING OF DROP CULVERT FISH PASSAGES WILL DETERMINE IF ADDITIONAL IMPROVEMENTS CAN BE MADE TO INCREASE FISH PASSAGE EFFICIENCY WITH LOW-COST OPTIONS.

HEADWATER STREAMS ARE HIGHLY SUSCEPTIBLE TO GEOMORPHIC ALTERATIONS DUE TO THEIR SMALL SIZE. EFFECTS OFANTHROPOGENIC STREAM-CHANNEL ALTERATIONS (CHANNELIZATION AND CULVERTS) ON POPULATION DEMOGRAPHIC RATES OF NATIVEFISH HAVE BEEN DOCUMENTED IN NEBRASKA, AS WELL AS MANY SURROUNDING STATES. MITIGATION OF THESE STREAM ALTERATIONSIS BECOMING IMPORTANT ESPECIALLY IN AREAS CONTAINING AT-RISK SPECIES SUCH AS THE NIOBRARA RIVER BASIN IN NORTHCENTRALNEBRASKA. GRADUATE RESEARCH WILL BE PERFORMED FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA-LINCOLN COOPERATIVE FISHAND WILDLIFE RESEARCH UNIT PARTNERED WITH THE NEBRASKA GAME AND PARKS COMMISSION. ESTIMATION OF CHANNELIZATIONEFFECTS ON DEMOGRAPHIC RATES (SURVIVAL, MOVEMENT, ABUNDANCE, RECAPTURE PROBABILITY) AS WELL AS CULVERT EFFECTS ONGENETIC STRUCTURE FOR NORTHERN PEARL DACE (MARGARISCUS NACHTRIEBI) IN HEADWATER STREAMS IN THE NEBRASKA SANDHILLSECOREGION. THE NORTHERN PEARL DACE IS IDENTIFIED AS A SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN) IN THENEBRASKA NATURAL LEGACY PROJECT, NEBRASKA'S STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN.

PER CONGRESSIONAL MANDATE, THE LOUISIANA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND FISHERIES (LDWF) IS REQUIRED TO DEVELOP AND UPDATE ITS STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP) IN ORDER TO PARTICIPATE IN THE STATE WILDLIFE GRANT (SWG) PROGRAM. THE SWAP IS A ROADMAP FOR NONGAME CONSERVATION IN LOUISIANA AND MUST BE REVIEWED AND REVISED EVERY TEN YEARS TO ENSURE THAT IT REMAINS AN EFFECTIVE TOOL FOR CONSERVATION PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION. THE NEXT MAJOR REVISION OF THIS DOCUMENT IS DUE IN 2025. THIS COMPREHENSIVE REVISION REQUIRES THAT ALL EIGHT OF THE ORIGINAL REQUIRED ELEMENTS ARE MET AND THAT DOCUMENTATION OF THE REVISION PROCESS BE SUBMITTED TO THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE. THIS GRANT WILL ADDRESS THE NEED FOR A DEDICATED FUNDING SOURCE TO SUPPORT STAFF INVOLVEMENT IN THE REVISION PROCESS AND WILL QUALIFY AS A PLANNING GRANT.

THE WEST VIRGINIA DIVISION OF NATURAL RESOURCES (WVDNR) WILDLIFE RESOURCES SECTION (WRS) IS THE STATE AGENCY CHARGED WITH RESTORING, CONSERVING, AND MANAGING FISH AND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS FOR THE USE AND ENJOYMENT OF ITS CITIZENS. AS PART OF THIS FUNCTION, WVDNR IS RESPONSIBLE FOR CREATING A STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP) EVERY TEN YEARS. AIMED AT CONSERVING WILDLIFE AND HABITATS, THIS PLAN IDENTIFIES SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (SGCN), THEIR HABITATS, THREATS, AND NEEDED MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES TO KEEP THEM OFF THE LIST OF FEDERALLY THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES. SGCN MANAGEMENT DEPENDS ON THEIR CONNECTION TO HABITATS ACROSS THE LANDSCAPE AND A REQUIRED COMPONENT TO UPDATING THE SWAP IS ALSO UPDATING THE TERRESTRIAL HABITAT.THE PREVIOUS HABITAT MAPPING EFFORT, THE WEST VIRGINIA TERRESTRIAL HABITAT MAP (WVDNR 2015), WAS CREATED IN 2015 FROM THE NORTHEAST TERRESTRIAL HABITAT MAP (FERREE AND ANDERSON 2013) AND ULTIMATELY BASED ON THE 2001 NATIONAL LAND COVER DATA AT A 30- METER RESOLUTION. ADDITIONAL WEST VIRGINIA SPECIFIC LAND COVER MAPPING EFFORTS AT HIGHER RESOLUTIONS HAVE TAKEN PLACE SINCE THIS TIME BUT NONE HAVE FULLY REMAPPED HABITAT, WHICH IS THE AIM OF THIS PROJECT. THE OPPORTUNITY EXISTS TO PARTNER WITH WEST VIRGINIA UNIVERSITY NATURAL RESOURCE ANALYSIS CENTER (WVU NRAC) TO TAKE ADVANTAGE OF THE FREE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE STATEWIDE 2020 HIGH RESOLUTION NATIONAL AGRICULTURE IMAGERY PROGRAM (NAIP) IMAGERY FOR WEST VIRGINIA TO REMAP LAND COVER.THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO PARTNER WITH WVU NRAC TO CLASSIFY THE HIGH SPATIAL (60CM) AND TEMPORAL (2YR) NAIP IMAGERY SPECTRALLY. THE WVDNR WILL USE THE RESULTING 5-METER RESOLUTION, 9-CLASS LAND COVER TO PLAN, MODEL, AND REMAP HABITATS FOR USE IN THE 2025 STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP) COMPREHENSIVE REVISION AND TO ALLOW FOR ANALYSIS AND MORE TIMELY MANAGEMENT OF WILDLIFE SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS ACROSS WEST VIRGINIA. THIS WILL ALLOW FOR A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF HABITATS ACROSS WEST VIRGINIA AND HOW THEY RELATE TO SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED OUTLINED IN THE STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN.

PRAIRIE RIVERS OF NORTHERN OKLAHOMA CONTAIN A DIVERSE GROUP OF FRESHWATER MUSSELS, BUT FACTORS AFFECTING THEIR ABUNDANCE AND HABITAT USE ARE NOT WELL KNOWN. RECENT STUDIES HAVE DOCUMENTED INCREASES IN SOME RARE SPECIES, BUT IT IS NOT KNOWN IF THOSE INCREASES HAVE PERSISTED CURRENTLY. THIS PROJECT WILL SURVEY FOR FRESHWATER MUSSELS IN THE VERDIGRIS RIVER ABOVE OOLOGAH LAKE AND THE CANEY RIVER IN OKLAHOMA USING SNORKELING AND SCUBA DIVING TO DOCUMENT CURRENT ABUNDANCES. SITES FOR SAMPLING WILL CONSIST OF RANDOMLY SELECTED QUADRATS (A SQUARE MEASURING 0.25 M X 0.25 M) WITHIN LARGER REACHES OF EACH RIVER. QUADRATS WILL BE SEARCHED THOROUGHLY FOR MUSSELS AND INCLUDE MEASUREMENTS OF HABITAT AT A SMALL SPATIAL SCALE. THE ENTIRE REACH WILL THEN BE SURVEYED WITH SIDE-SCAN SONAR, WHICH CAN BE USED TO IDENTIFY HABITAT TYPES AT A LARGER SPATIAL SCALE, SO THAT RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN MUSSEL ABUNDANCE AND SPECIES TYPE CAN BE DETERMINED. WITH THIS SAMPLING DESIGN, WE WILL MAKE STATISTICAL MODELS THAT CAN BE USED IN THE FUTURE TO PREDICT AREAS NOT SAMPLED THAT MAY ALSO HAVE HIGH DIVERSITY OR ABUNDANCE OF FRESHWATER MUSSELS. THE FINAL PRODUCTS FOR THE PROJECT WILL CONSIST OF A DATABASE OF FRESHWATER MUSSEL SPECIES AT EACH SAMPLING SITE, THEIR ABUNDANCES (DENSITY; NUMBER PER SQUARE METER), AND ASSOCIATED HABITAT TYPES (SUCH AS WATER DEPTH, WATER FLOW RATE, AND SUBSTRATE TYPE). A FINAL REPORT WILL BE WRITTEN ALONG WITH ONE OR MORE MANUSCRIPTS TO BE SUBMITTED TO PEER-REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC JOURNALS. THESE FINDINGS CAN HELP INFORM THE STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES REGARDING THE PRESENCE AND CURRENT STATUS OF FRESHWATER MUSSELS IN THE VERDIGRIS RIVER AND CANEY RIVER, ESPECIALLY THOSE THAT ARE CONSIDERED THREATENED, ENDANGERED, OR SPECIES OF CONSERVATION NEED.

GENOMIC DATA IS USEFUL IN INFERRING BASIC DYNAMICS OF NATURAL POPULATIONS (E.G., COATES ET AL. 2018), INCLUDING FRESHWATER MUSSELS (GARRISON ET AL. 2021; SMITH ET AL. 2021B). HOWEVER, THERE REMAINS LIMITED INFORMATION REGARDING THE CONTRIBUTION OF HOST MOVEMENT PATTERNS ON GENETIC STRUCTURING IN MUSSELS. BY USING COMPARATIVE GENOMIC METHODS, WE SET OUT TO EXAMINE PATTERNS OF GENETIC VARIATION IN CYCLONAIAS NECKI (GUADALUPE ORB) AND FUSCONAIA MITCHELLI (FALSE SPIKE) AND THEIR CONFIRMED HOSTS ICTALURUS PUNCTATUS (CHANNEL CATFISH) AND CYPRINELLA VENUSTA (BLACKTAIL SHINER) (DUDDING ET AL. 2020) TO BETTER UNDERSTAND POPULATION DYNAMICS OF IMPERILED FRESHWATER MUSSELS AND THEIR HOSTS IN THE GUADALUPE RIVER.
T-07-R-29 ANALYZING INDIANA ACOUSTIC DATA TO INFORM BAT CONSERVATION

THIS GRANT PROJECT IS FOCUSED ON ESTABLISHING A SELF-SUSTAINING POPULATION OF THE EASTERN INDIGO SNAKE, THROUGH REINTRODUCTIONS, ON CONECUH NATIONAL FOREST, ALABAMA. APPROXIMATELY 200 SNAKES HAVE PREVIOUSLY BEEN RELEASED ONTO CONECUH NATIONAL FOREST; BASED ON EARLY MODELING EFFORTS IT IS PREDICTED THAT AN ADDITIONAL 100 SNAKES ARE REQUIRED TO ENSURE ENOUGH INDIVIDUALS ARE PRESENT SUCH THAT REPRODUCTIVE RATES EXCEED MORTALITY RATES. MONITORING WILL ALLOW FOR ASSESSMENT OF SURVIVAL AND MONITOR FOR SNAKE REPRODUCTION. THE GRANTEE HAS IDENTIFIED AUBURN UNIVERSITY AS A SUBRECIPIENT.

THIS PROJECT DESCRIBES ACTIVITIES TO ASSIST THE OHIO DIVISION OF WILDLIFE (DOW) IN REVISING THE STATE WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (SWAP) FOR 2025. THIS INCLUDES WORK TO MEET REQUIRED ELEMENTS OF THE SWAP: IDENTIFYING ADDITIONAL ACTIONS FOR ADDRESSING SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED (ELEMENT 4), MONITORING (ELEMENT 5), COORDINATING THE REVISION WITH PARTNERS (ELEMENT 7) AND SEEKING PUBLIC PARTICIPATION (ELEMENT 8). THESE ACTIVITIES WILL: (1) PROVIDE DOW WITH SYSTEMATICALLY COLLECTED SOCIAL SCIENCE DATA TO INITIATE AND FOCUS THE SWAP REVISION PROCESS; (2) HELP EXPAND AND ENHANCE PARTNER AND PUBLIC PARTICIPATION; (3) FACILITATE DEVELOPMENT OF A DATA-DRIVEN ENGAGEMENT STRATEGY TO INFORM BOTH THE SWAP REVISION AND ITS IMPLEMENTATION; AND (4) PROVIDE ASSISTANCE WITH DESIGN AND MANAGEMENT OF STAKEHOLDER AND PUBLIC OUTREACH EVENTS.
NJ T-1-9 SGCN CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO RESEARCH, MONITOR, AND SURVEY SPECIES LISTED AS SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED IN TENNESSEE. TENNESSEE HAS OVER 600 SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED. THE PROJECT WILL HELP INCREASE MONITORING, SURVEYS AND DATA COLLECTION EFFORTS IN ORDER TO BETTER NEED DETERMINE THE DISTRIBUTION, SURVIVAL, HABITAT NEEDS, THREATS, AND TO CONDUCT RESEARCH, SURVEYS, AND MONITORING ON SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED. FOCAL SPECIES FOR THIS GRANT INCLUDE SPOTTED SKUNK, EASTERN HELLBENDER, STREAMSIDE SALAMANDERS, AND PYGMY RATTLESNAKE. SUBRECIEPENTS AT THE TIME OF THE AWARD INCLUDE NASHVILLE ZOO.RESTORING SOME SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION MAY REQUIRE HEAD-STARTING OR PROPAGATION OF SPECIES DUE TO THEIR LIMITED DISTRIBUTION, LIMITED GENETIC DIVERSITY, SMALL POPULATION SIZE OR ISSUES THAT RESULT HIGH JUVENILE MORALITY. THE HEAD-STARTING PROJECT WILL HELP IN DEVELOPING A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF USING HEAD-STARTED HELLBENDERS TO RESTORE OR AUGMENT EXISTING HELLBENDER POPULATIONS. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE INITIAL STEPS NEEDED TO INCREASE SURVIVAL OF HEAD-STARTED HELLBENDERS UPON RELEASE IN TO THE WILD. PARTNERSHIPS FOR THIS GRANTINCLUDE NASHVILLE ZOO TO HOUSE THE HEADSTARTING PROGRAM.

BLANDINGS TURTLES ARE OF CONSERVATION CONCERN THROUGHOUT THEIR RANGE IN THE UNITED STATES AND CANADA. BLANDINGS TURTLES HAVE STATE CONSERVATION STATUS IN 14 OF THE 15 STATES IN WHICH THEY OCCUR, ARE CONSIDERED ENDANGERED BY THE IUCN, ARE A CITES II-LISTED SPECIES, AND HAVE BEEN PETITIONED FOR FEDERAL LISTING UNDER THE ESA. RECENTLY, MANY STATES HAVE INITIATED BLANDINGS TURTLE MONITORING AND CONSERVATION PROGRAMS TO DETERMINE STATUSES THROUGHOUT THE SPECIES RANGE. TO CONTRIBUTE TO THIS LARGE-SCALE EFFORT, WE WILL ASSESS THE DISTRIBUTION OF BLANDINGS TURTLES USING A COMBINATION OF MULTI-TECHNIQUE FIELD SURVEY, GENETIC ANALYSES, AND SPATIALLY EXPLICIT MODELS TO INFORM AND PRIORITIZE FUTURE MANAGEMENT EFFORTS. FIELD SURVEYS WILL ALSO PROVIDE DATA FOR STANDARDIZED POPULATION ASSESSMENTS TO DETERMINE STATUS AND MONITOR TRENDS IN BLANDINGS TURTLE POPULATIONS, INFORM ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES, AND IDENTIFY CRITICAL HABITAT. OVERALL, IT IS OUR GOAL TO DETERMINE THE STATUS OF BLANDINGS TURTLES IN MICHIGAN AND OHIO AND IDENTIFY HIGH-PRIORITY SITES TO IMPLEMENT ADAPTIVE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS AS NECESSARY.

IN MICHIGAN'S WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (WAP), SEVERAL FOCAL SPECIES WERE IDENTIFIED FOR CONSERVATION WITHIN GRASSLANDS AND SAVANNAS, INCLUDING DICKCISSEL (MI-WAP LARGE GRASSLANDS: 5) (SPIZA AMERICANA), GRASSHOPPER SPARROW (AMMODRAMUS SAVANNARUM, MI-WAP LARGE GRASSLANDS: 5), HENSLOW'S SPARROW (AMMODRAMUS HENSLOWII, MI-WAP LARGE GRASSLANDS: 4), AND EASTERN MASSASAUGA RATTLESNAKE (EMR; SISTRURUS CANTENATUS CATENATUS, MI-WAP PRAIRIES AND SAVANNAS: 6), FROSTED ELFIN (INCISALIA IRUS, MI-WAP PRAIRIES AND SAVANNAS: 5), KARNER BLUE BUTTERFLY (KBB; LYCAEIDES MELISSA SAMUELIS, MI-WAP PRAIRIES AND SAVANNAS: 4), AND MONARCH BUTTERFLY (DANAUS PLEXIPPUS, MI-WAP LARGE GRASSLANDS: 6), AND WILL BENEFIT FROM THE ACTIVITIES PROPOSED UNDER THIS GRANT.

THE STATE WILDLIFE GRANTS PROGRAM PROVIDES STATES, THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, COMMONWEALTHS, AND TERRITORIES (STATES) FEDERAL GRANT FUNDS FOR THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF PROGRAMS FOR THE BENEFIT OF WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS, INCLUDING SPECIES THAT ARE NOT HUNTED OR FISHED. ELIGIBLE ACTIVITIES INCLUDE BOTH PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION. PLANNING ACTIVITIES MUST CONTRIBUTE DIRECTLY TO THE DEVELOPMENT OR MODIFICATION OF THE STATE⿿S CURRENT WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (PLAN) APPROVED BY THE DIRECTOR OF THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE). IMPLEMENTATION ACTIVITIES ARE ACTIVITIES THAT A STATE INTENDS TO CARRY OUT TO EXECUTE THEIR PLAN. PRIORITY FOR USE OF THESE FUNDS SHOULD BE PLACED ON THOSE SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED AND TAKE INTO CONSIDERATION THE RELATIVE LEVEL OF FUNDING AVAILABLE FOR THE CONSERVATION OF THOSE SPECIES. INELIGIBLE ACTIVITIES INCLUDE WILDLIFE EDUCATION AND LAW ENFORCEMENT ACTIVITIES, UNLESS THE LAW ENFORCEMENT OR EDUCATION COMPONENT IS A MINOR OR INCIDENTAL ACTIVITY WHICH IS CONSIDERED CRITICAL TO THE SUCCESS OF A PROJECT. ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ABOUT THE STATE WILDLIFE GRANTS PROGRAM IS ON THE WEB AT ¬HTTP://WSFRPROGRAMS.FWS.GOV/SUBPAGES/GRANTPROGRAMS/SWG/SWG.HTM. IF YOU DO NOT HAVE ACCESS TO THE INTERNET AND WOULD LIKE TO RECEIVE INFORMATION BY MAIL, CONTACT THE SERVICE POINT OF CONTACT IDENTIFIED IN THE AGENCY CONTACTS SECTION BELOW. THE STATE WILDLIFE GRANTS PROGRAM PROVIDES STATES, THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, COMMONWEALTHS, AND TERRITORIES (STATES) FEDERAL GRANT FUNDS FOR THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF PROGRAMS FOR THE BENEFIT OF WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS, INCLUDING SPECIES THAT ARE NOT HUNTED OR FISHED. ELIGIBLE ACTIVITIES INCLUDE BOTH PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION. PLANNING ACTIVITIES MUST CONTRIBUTE DIRECTLY TO THE DEVELOPMENT OR MODIFICATION OF THE STATE⿿S CURRENT WILDLIFE ACTION PLAN (PLAN) APPROVED BY THE DIRECTOR OF THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE). IMPLEMENTATION ACTIVITIES ARE ACTIVITIES THAT A STATE INTENDS TO CARRY OUT TO EXECUTE THEIR PLAN. PRIORITY FOR USE OF THESE FUNDS SHOULD BE PLACED ON THOSE SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED AND TAKE INTO CONSIDERATION THE RELATIVE LEVEL OF FUNDING AVAILABLE FOR THE CONSERVATION OF THOSE SPECIES. INELIGIBLE ACTIVITIES INCLUDE WILDLIFE EDUCATION AND LAW ENFORCEMENT ACTIVITIES, UNLESS THE LAW ENFORCEMENT OR EDUCATION COMPONENT IS A MINOR OR INCIDENTAL ACTIVITY WHICH IS CONSIDERED CRITICAL TO THE SUCCESS OF A PROJECT. ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ABOUT THE STATE WILDLIFE GRANTS PROGRAM IS ON THE WEB AT ¬HTTP://WSFRPROGRAMS.FWS.GOV/SUBPAGES/GRANTPROGRAMS/SWG/SWG.HTM. IF YOU DO NOT HAVE ACCESS TO THE INTERNET AND WOULD LIKE TO RECEIVE INFORMATION BY MAIL, CONTACT THE SERVICE POINT OF CONTACT IDENTIFIED IN THE AGENCY CONTACTS SECTION BELOW.
